column2: A discovery in South Africa shows just how mixed up humans are.
In discussing his grief with Stephen Colbert, Joe Biden revealed what could be the core of a very compelling presidential campaign.
The F.T.C. tries to shut down illegal pyramid schemes yet won’t explain how they differ from legal multilevel marketing companies.
It’s not enough to grant asylum. Berlin must lead Europe in solving the crises that led them to flee Syria in the first place.
The officer’s unprovoked aggression reflects a larger problem.
Affluent African-Americans are denied the opportunity to buy into high-value areas.
The bungled prosecutions of two Chinese-American professionals suggest the United States is being rash in its effort to fight economic espionage.
A reader recommends blind review to avoid bias and favoritism in the editorial selection process.
Readers cite workers’ commitment to their jobs and unclear expectations from employers as reasons.
Readers react to a doctor’s account of taking matters into his own hands when he felt that a hospital was not properly treating his daughter.
Australians have mixed views on news of Malcolm Turnbull toppling Tony Abbott as prime minister to become the country’s fifth leader in eight years.
Corrections appearing in print on Tuesday, September 15, 2015.
Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 15, 2015.

ASHER--David L. The board, staff, students, and alumni of the Israel Center for Excellence through Education and the Israel Arts and Science Academy deeply mourn the sudden and untimely passing of David Asher, son of our Founders Robert H. Asher and Mary Jane Asher of Chicago, IL. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire family. 1/3

MUELLER--Michael. Died August 27th, 2015 in Carson City, Nevada. Michael was one of those exceptional human beings seldomly met in life. It is impossible to fully describe a man such as he in any amount of paragragh or verse. Michael Robert Mueller was born October 6, 1946 in Decatur, IL. He endeavored to earn both bachelor's and master's degrees in mechanical engineering and finance from Cornell University, where he was a member of the Phi Gamma Delta fraternity. Mr. Mueller sat on the board of directors of Mueller Co., developed large portions of Columbia, MD, and was involved with other successful projects throughout the world. He was last engaged in publishing and charitable pursuits. Michael was an accomplished golfer who was good enough to go pro - but happier not to. His body and mind were perpetually engaged in various simultaneous projects and experiments. All who knew him can take solace in knowing he now has the final solutions to all of them. Michael offered unwavering support and endless encouragement to his entire family. And all those fortunate to have crossed paths with him remember. He was preceded by his father, mother, and brother and is survived by three grandchildren, two children, and a brother. 1/3
BONNELL--Stewart. After 2 years, lovingly remembered, greatly missed. Phyllis and Jerry 1/3
BERNSTEIN--Mary. 14 years since I last saw you. Best wife, best mother, best friend. With love & longing, B. 1/3

GILROY--Frank D. The Dramatists Guild mourns the passing of former Guild President and Pulitzer Prize- winning dramatist Frank D. Gilroy, who died September 12th at the age of 89. Frank's career began during the Golden Age of television before gracing the Broadway stage with his gritty and compassionate play, "The Subject Was Roses", for which he won the Tony, Pulitzer Prize and Drama Critics Circle Awards. Also a successful novelist and screenwriter, he received the Writer's Guild Lifetime Achievement Award in 2011. Frank's commitment to public service was vast, encompassing his stint in the Army during World War II, and his tenure advocating for his fellow writers as a Dramatists Guild member since 1962, and as the Guild's President from 1968 to 1971. He was a modest man, with a sly sense of humor, who never lost his enduring sense of wonder at the world and the people in it...the very quality that brought such vivid life to his writing. Our deepest sympathies to his loved ones at this difficult time. We share their loss. 1/3

WINICK--Ina. Loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and sister, Dr Ina Esther Hodes Winick, a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, died on September 13, 2015 after a year-long illness. Born in 1936 in St. Joseph, Missouri, she grew up in Kansas City and was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Colorado, where she met her New Jersey-born husband, to whom she was married for 57 years. Ina Winick was the wife of Eugene Winick of Hastings-on-Hudson, mother of Janet Winick Rubinstein of Mareil- Marly, France, Leigh Ann Winick of Hastings-on-Hudson, and Elizabeth Winick Rubinstein of Scarsdale, grandmother to David, Daniel, and Dalia Rubinstein, Gabriel and Eli Pinkus, and Ava Rubinstein. She was the sister of Phil Hodes and Dr. Herb Hodes, both of Leawood Kansas. Dr Winick earned both her Masters Degree and her Doctor of Philosophy Educational Psychology degree from the City University of New York. She worked for several local school systems. She was a past director of the Community Nursery School in Dobbs Ferry, and the school psychologist in the Henrick Hudson school district in Westchester, NY. Retiring from education in 2001, she then worked with her husband at his literary agency in New York City, McIntosh & Otis, Inc. A resident of Hastings-on-Hudson since 1968, Ina Winick had a zest for life and a keen interest in people of all ages and backgrounds. She was beloved for her kind, gentle, generous, and caring nature, and her passion for her community, family, and Temple Beth Shalom in Hastings. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that any gifts or donations be made to AIPAC or Gilda's Club Westchester. Services will be held at 10am on Wednesday, September 16 at Edwards-Dowdle Funeral Home in Dobbs Ferry, NY. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence S. We mourn the loss of our friend, philanthropist and supporter. Larry's enthusiasm, good humor and wise counsel continued for decades. We extend our sympathy to Larry's sister Carol P. Green and his children David and Laura. Peter J. Solomon Founder & Chairman Peter J. Solomon Company 1/3

BLESHMAN--Rita Packer, on Monday, September 14th, died peacefully in her home in Great Neck, NY at age 94. Raised in Manhattan, she graduated from Hunter High School '37, Smith College '41, and Columbia School of Social Work '43. She was predeceased by her husband, Norman. Survived by her children Martha and Joseph, grandchildren Rachel and James, and daughter-in-law Lucia Vassallo. Memorial service will be held at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows NY 11365, Wednesday, September 16 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, consider donation to The New York Times' Neediest Cases Fund. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence. The Wellfleet and Truro communities of Massachusetts, along with our family at Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater (WHAT), is saddened by the loss of our beloved friend and supporter Larry Phillips. Larry was well known in the community and loved by all. He had a true philanthropic spirit that was born at the center of his giving heart. There were many organizations that Larry supported and his support of growing Wellfleet Harbor Actors Theater had an immense impact on the cultural economic growth of the community. We shall all miss him terribly. Our love and support are with his family and, in particular our very special friend and trustee, Larry's sister Carol Green. 1/3

DUBUSS--Robert Francis, 80, of Rumson, passed away at home on Sunday, September 13, 2015. Robert was born in Brooklyn, NY to Francis and Catherine (O'Hehir) Dubuss. He earned his BS in Business from Pace University, Class of 1964. He honorably served our country from 1953 to 1956 in the US Marine Corps as part of an international peace-keeping effort in Korea and Japan. Robert was a longtime communicant of Holy Cross RC Church in Rumson. Robert worked for The Dreyfus Corporation, an investment manager, for nearly 38 years, playing a key role in the creation of the tax exempt mutual fund industry. Through his work with Congress and the IRS, Robert helped bring about 1976 legislation that allowed mutual fund shareholders access to tax-exempt income, leading to the extraordinary growth of tax exempt mutual funds. He played a major role in establishing Dreyfus' New York Tax Exempt Bond Fund and California Tax Exempt Bond Fund. A humble, caring and generous man, Robert touched many lives through his commitment to his family and to charity, including his support of veterans and Native Americans. A beneficiary of the G.I. Bill, Robert understood the transformative power of education and put more than a dozen children and grandchildren through college. He will be remembered for his sense of humor and his passion for sports, particularly the New York Jets, the New York Mets and horse racing. Robert was predeceased by his parents. He is survived by his loving wife of 24 years, Minerva Gonzalez Dubuss; children: Robert F. Jr and wife Beth of Floral Park, NY, Noah F. of Red Bank, Seamus of Manhattan, Norma Walling of Middletown, Catherine Bondick and husband Dan of High Point, NC, Cynthia Joyce and husband Joe of Little Silver, Mary Kate Kim and husband Minki of Astoria, NY and Fiona Stauffer and husband Don of Rochester, NY; stepchildren: Joseph Gonzalez and wife Nancy of Howell and JoAnn Roman and husband Anthony of Jackson; 13 grandchildren, five step- grandchildren, nine great- grandchildren and two step- great-grandchildren. Visitation will be held on Wednesday, September 16th from 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Avenue, Red Bank. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Thursday, September 17th at 10:30am at The Church of the Precious Blood, 72 Riverdale Ave., Monmouth Beach, NJ 07750. Burial will follow at St. Rose of Lima Cemetery in Freehold. Please visit Robert's memorial website available: johnedayfuneralhome. com. 1/3
LOW--Richard. 2/20/27-9/15/14 "And death shall have no dominion." Barbara 1/3

UGELOW--June passed away suddenly September 12, 2015 at the age of 91. Beloved wife of the late Leonard. Survived by her children Susan Konigsberg (Fred), Judith Blak, Linda Ugelow (husband, Endre Jobbagy), grandchildren Eric Konigsberg (Shari), Brian Konigsberg (Sara), Clint and Thor Blak, Lexi Ugelow, five great-grandchildren, sister Betty Zale (Marvin), sisters-in-law Elaine London and Pauline Feldman. She had a wonderful spirit and dynamic personality. She loved everything- music, dance, theater, travel, people and above all, laughter. She was an avid golfer, tennis player, modern dancer and bridge player. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. Rest in peace Mom. Your loving Family 1/3

LIGOTTI--Albert F. Beloved husband, father, teacher, and friend, passed away Saturday, September 12, 2015, at the age of 88 years. His life-long love of music is his legacy to those who knew and loved him, and he generously shared that love with his world. Mr. Ligotti was born in Bronx, NY where he lived until 1968 when he moved to Athens, GA with his wife and daughters to begin a teaching career at the University of Georgia's Music Department. An Associate Professor Emeritus of Music, he served on the music faculty for 27 years teaching trumpet and conducting. He was the founder and director of the UGA Wind Ensemble, played in the UGA Faculty Brass Quintet, and served as music director of the Opera/MusicTheatre in association with the UGA Department of Drama and Theatre. Prior to his appointment at UGA, Mr. Ligotti performed as a professional trumpet player for eleven years with the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Leonard Bernstein. He also performed with the Metropolitan Opera Company, the Boston Pops with Arthur Fiedler, as trumpet soloist with the Knickerbocker Chamber Players, the New York City Opera and Ballet companies, the Goldman Band, the Bell Telephone Television Orchestra, the Radio City Music Hall Orchestra, in Broadway show ensembles, and in brass quintets. Mr. Ligotti studied conducting under Michael Fiviesky with coaching from Pierre Monteaux. He held a bachelor's degree from Queen's College and a master's degree from Columbia University. He was active as an adjudicator, clinician, and guest conductor throughout the southeast and arranged and transcribed music, with many works published and professionally recorded. His accomplishments include election to full membership in the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers (ASCAP). He was the recipient of the 1999-2000 Bank of America Man of Achievement Award and received the Distinguished Alumni Music Award from Queen's College. As a young man just graduated from Queen's College, he chose to serve his country by enlisting in the United States Coast Guard and was a member of their distinguished Coast Guard Band. The Band developed an international reputation as one of the finest professional concert bands in the world, offering music of great variety and appeal, and he was proud and privileged to be a part of that organization. In the late 1970s, Mr. Ligotti was approached about forming a community orchestra in the Athens, GA area. With the help of the then Office of Cultural Affairs and Jill Read, its director, the plans went ahead, and in the Fall of 1978 the first Board of Directors was selected and the Symphony's charter received from the State of Georgia. In the month of January 1979, the Symphony began rehearsing in the band room of Clarke Central High School and subsequently presented its first concert on April 29, 1979, in Mell Auditorium. Thereafter, under his leadership, grateful musicians who had been given the opportunity to play before family, friends and the community through the Athens Symphony performed consistently before enthusiastic audiences of 2,000 in the Classic Center. Due to health considerations, in 2012 Mr. Ligotti handed over his baton to Susan Dinwiddie, and the Symphony Orchestra, that marvelous gift to the Athens community begun so long ago, continues to this day. Patrons of the Athens Symphony continue to be delighted with the elegant bronze sculpture of Maestro Albert Ligotti produced by Gregory Johnson, Artist. This sculpture can be seen in the lobby of the Classic Center. the Symphony's home since 1996. Mr. Ligotti is survived by his loving wife of 50 years Arlene F. Ligotti, daughter Fran Rothman Prince of Athens, GA, and his brother Raymond Ligotti of Long Island, NY. He was preceded in death by his daughter Jeannie Rothman and his parents Victor and Tilly Ligotti of Athens, GA. Lord & Stephens Funeral Home, Athens, GA, is in charge of services. Friends who wish may make a memorial contribution honoring Maestro Albert F. Ligotti to the Athens Symphony, P.O. Box 5244, Athens, GA 30604. No service is planned at this time. 1/3

KIRBY--Sr. Joan. Longtime board member and founding executive director of homeless services nonprofit Homes for the Homeless, Sr. Joan Kirby passed away September 9. She was a compassionate voice for New York City's poor and a tireless advocate for quality education. Sr. Kirby's lifelong commitment to education and service was a driving force in creating partnerships between government, faith- based organizations, and nonprofits. She served as Executive Director for Homes for the Homeless from the organization's founding in 1986, working in conjunction with the City of New York and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and was an innovative pioneer in addressing the needs of homeless families. Sr. Kirby advanced a new approach to move families from congregate shelters to more humane facilities that provided not only safe shelter, but life opportunities as well, serving as a model for operations that tie in vital services and offer not only a safe place for families to stay, but a place where they could thrive. 1/3

MOORE--Dick. Actors' Equity Association deeply mourns the passing of Dick Moore, a great friend, member and colleague. His contributions were many: Councillor, Public Relations Director, and Publisher of Equity News. 1/3

McKEE--John. The City University of New York deeply mourns the passing of John McKee, CUNY's Deputy Director of Public Safety, who died September 12 at his home after a long illness. Not long after taking that post in 2000, he courageously led the University's 9/11 Response Team at Ground Zero. As Deputy Director, he was instrumental in formulating the University's emergency response plans as well as coordinating the CUNY SAFE Team, which responds to emergencies throughout the city. He left his mark on many CUNY colleges, but most notably Bronx Community College and New York City College of Technology, where he served as Acting Director of Public Safety, before ending his career as the full-time Director of Public Safety at The City College of New York (CCNY). He graduated from John Jay College of Criminal Justice with a B.A. and joined CUNY's Public Safety Department as a sergeant in 1992, assigned to CCNY. He was a respected leader of the women and men of the CUNY Department of Public Safety. We extend our deepest sympathies and condolences to his family. James B. Milliken, Chancellor 1/3

ASNIS--Deborah S.,MD, 59, passed away at 11:30am, September 12, 2015 in the presence of her loved ones. Dr. Asnis was Director of Infectious Disease at Flushing Hospital Medical Center and discovered the first US outbreak of West Nile Virus in 1999. Thanks to her quick action, public officials took aggressive precautions against the spread of the virus. On December 8, 2007, she was inducted into the New York City Hall of Fame for Health and Science. Dr. Asnis was also an HIV specialist and prolific clinical researcher, publishing over 35 articles in her career. She was beloved by her residents, nursing staff, and patients. At home, Debbie was devoted to her family. She loved traveling the world with her husband, going to the theater with her children, and being with her mother. She played tennis and piano, delighted in art and culture. Her smile always lit the room. She was committed to education, self-improvement, and the happiness of her loved ones. Dr. Asnis' intelligence was matched with beauty, quick wit, and exquisite fashion sense. She was as kind and concerned for the health of others as she was strong and driven in her own life. She leaves behind a loving husband, Dr. Hal Kazdin, sons Joshua and Matthew, brother Dr. Greg Asnis, and mother Ruth. The world is a poorer place without her. Funeral services will be held at 10am Wednesday at Boulevard- Riverside Chapels and interment at Beth Moses Cemetery. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence S. We mourn the loss of our friend, philanthropist and supporter. Larry's enthusiasm, good humor and wise counsel continued for decades. We extend our sympathy to Larry's sister Carol P. Green and his children David and Laura. Peter J. Solomon Founder & Chairman Peter J. Solomon Company 1/3

BRAM--William. Bill lived with integrity, passion and dedication. He adored his wife Jane Eisner Bram; his children Judy, Steven and Elizabeth; their spouses and his six terrific and dynamic grandchildren. Bill, we will miss that smile of yours, your provocative but always cordial political discussions, your friendship, your wise counsel, your adventurous spirit, and the good times we had together. Carole and Dick Eisner 1/3

GARSON--Roberta Ann, (January 28, 1954 - September 11, 2015). Beloved daughter of Gloria and the late Eugene Garson. Robbie met life with a formidable fighting spirit to overcome many physical hardships. We shall miss her wonderful infectious laugh, her good humor and her warm radiant smile. She is survived by her mother Gloria and sister Heidi. 1/3

KIRBY--Sr. Joan. Longtime board member and founding executive director of homeless services nonprofit Homes for the Homeless, Sr. Joan Kirby passed away September 9. She was a compassionate voice for New York City's poor and a tireless advocate for quality education. Sr. Kirby's lifelong commitment to education and service was a driving force in creating partnerships between government, faith- based organizations, and nonprofits. She served as Executive Director for Homes for the Homeless from the organization's founding in 1986, working in conjunction with the City of New York and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and was an innovative pioneer in addressing the needs of homeless families. Sr. Kirby advanced a new approach to move families from congregate shelters to more humane facilities that provided not only safe shelter, but life opportunities as well, serving as a model for operations that tie in vital services and offer not only a safe place for families to stay, but a place where they could thrive. 1/3

BRADLEY--Jane C.,of Manchester, MA, 87, died peacefully on Monday morning surrounded by her family. She is survived by her husband John, her children: Juliet Bradley of Truckee, CA, Ralph and his husband John Mahi of Washington, D.C., Francis and his wife Adrienne of Manchester, MA, Jane ("Didi") Blau and her husband Richard of Manchester, MA, and by her eight grandchildren Sarah Jane Bradley Miller, Katrina, Brett and Erika Cornell, Camilla and Cecily Bradley, and Emily and Amanda Blau. Her immediate and extended families adored her. She attended Thayer Academy in Braintree, MA, and Radcliffe College. Much of her life was spent in service. She was, at various times, President of the Radcliffe Alumni Association, a member of the Board of Overseers of Harvard University, member and/or officer of the boards of trustees of the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Boston Museum of Science, Beverly Hospital, Cabot Family Charitable Trust, and the Institute of Contemporary Art. She had also served on the boards of trustees at Cabot Corporation and Fiduciary Trust Company. The family plans a private burial service. A memorial service to celebrate Jane Bradley's life will be announced at a later date. Donations may be made in her memory to the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Boston Museum of Science, or the Radcliffe Institute of Harvard University. 1/3

STIX--Roger, of Atlanta, formerly of Boston and Scarsdale, died peacefully Sunday, September 13th. He was the beloved husband of Jane Share, MD; father of Michael, son of Carol and the late Edgar Stix and dear brother of Allen, Wayne and Gail Stix. A graduate of Tulane University, he was a successful businessman, a devoted family member and dear friend. A memorial service will be held later in Atlanta. 1/3

GRAD--Fay, 91, of Co-op City The Bronx, died September 14 following complications from a series of strokes. Fay was predeceased by Zoltan, her husband of 58 years who was a longtime editor of the Hungarian weekly Magyar Szo, and her elder son, Robert, a computer systems programmer. She is survived by her son Peter, an editor at The Record (New Jersey). Fay was an executive secretary for John Barnes at the flagship Barnes and Noble store on 18th Street and Fifth Avenue and an administrative assistant to Drs. John Robbins and Alex Novikoff at Jacobi Hospital and Albert Einstein College of Medicine for more than 20 years. She was a passionate advocate for peace, for racial justice and for workers' rights. She was an extraordinarily loving and devoted wife and the world's greatest mom. Details on funeral at JJFFH.com 1/3

WALSER--Theodore R.,of Water Mill, New York died on September 13. He was 80 years old and died of cancer. He spent his childhood in New Canaan, Connecticut, attended the Lawrenceville School and Yale University, Class of 1957. He began his career as a banker at Chemical Bank and went on to become Senior Vice President of Corporate Banking for Lloyd's Bank. In his retirement he served as Executive Interviewer for Greenwich Associates. Ted was well loved in the banking community and remembered as a consummate professional and a kind and generous man, popular with everyone. In his personal life his greatest pleasures were enjoying the beach, traveling, and spending time with his family. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Sandra; a sister Jeanne Burdell of Oregon; four children: Julia Allan of Cummington, Massachusetts; Elizabeth Gassimi of Mexico; James Walser of Seattle, Washington; Kenneth Walser of Tallahassee, Florida; and grandchildren Riley, Jackson, Kaly, Madeleine, Amanda and Caroline. He was predeceased by a brother, Mackenzie Walser, and a sister, Mary Brady. Memorial service Thursday 11am at the First Presbyterian Church, Southampton, NY. Donations in his name may be made to Doctors Without Borders, 333 7th Avenue, New York, NY 10001. 1/3

BIRNBAUM--Bernard A. The trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center mourn the passing of our friend and colleague, Bernard A. Birnbaum, MD, senior vice president and vice dean, chief of hospital operations. Over the course of a distinguished career, Dr. Birnbaum made seminal contributions to the field of radiology. Equally important, he served as one of the principal architects of NYU Langone Medical Center's rapid ascent to its position today as one of our nation's premier academic medical centers. Under his leadership and focus on improving quality and safety, our institution received many accolades, including our #

JACOBOWITZ--Dr. Walter E.,82, of Morristown, NJ. Beloved husband of Suzanne; father of Glenn (Marilyn), Dana (Michael), Karen (Jeff); brother of Elaine Rubenstein; loving grandfather of Bryan, Lauren, Brett, Adam and Sophia, died peacefully on September 3rd. Dr. Jacobowitz practiced OB/GYN for forty years at Morristown Memorial Hospital during which time he served as Chair of the Department of OB/GYN and President of the Medical Staff. His family loved him dearly as did his patients. His quiet presence and dignity will live on through his children and grandchildren. May his memory be a blessing to all. Donations to be made in his memory to the Center for Jewish Life, Hillel at Princeton University, 70 Washington Road, Princeton, NJ 08540. Attention: Robin Rudofker, Director of Development. 1/3

BRICELAND--W. Alan, S.J.,on September 14, 2015. Beloved brother of Betty Dunne and Eileen Bleem of Naples, FL. Most recently Chaplain at Elmhurst Hospital. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY, on Thursday, 3-5pm and 7-8:30pm. Funeral Mass at the Fordham University Church, Bronx, NY, Friday, 12:15pm. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Northeast Province of the Society of Jesus, 39 E. 83rd St., New York, NY 10028. For info, contact Farenga Bros., Inc., Directors 718-654-0500. 1/3

ADLER--Myron, passed away at home on September 15th. Mike (Myron) attended Stuyvesant High School and graduated from NYU after serving in the 3rd Armored Division under General Patton. Mike was awarded the Bronze Star, among other medals. In 1949, he married his wife, Elaine Finkel, and that same year, they both founded Myron Manufacturing, Corp., a global direct-marketing firm. Mike is survived by four children and 11 grandchildren: William (Leslie) Russell, Olivia, Michaela and Lucas; Richard (Haekyung) Edison and Hannah Lee; Donald James (Dana) Harrison, Carolyn and Eliana; Marie Adler Kravecas (Saul) Alex and David. In 2003, Mike founded the Adler Aphasia Center, creating awareness of aphasia and offering support. Mike served on the Board of Hackensack Hospital and the UJA. Recently, he expanded the School of Nursing at Ramapo College. In addition to his family, Mike enjoyed traveling, tennis and most of all, piloting his own single engine plane. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made in Mike's memory to the Adler Aphasia Center, 60 W. Hunter Avenue, Maywood, NJ 07607. 1/3
STRAUSS--David. We will never forget you. Nancy and Bob 1/3
LIFF--Samuel ("Biff") Memorial gathering on Thursday September 24 at 1130am at The Lambs Club, 132 West 44th Street, NYC. RSVP must: biffmemorial@gmail.com 1

GOLUB--Arnold, of New York, NY on Tuesday, September 15, 2015. Born and raised in Boston, he was a long time resident of New York City and an accomplished psychologist, specializing in speech restoration and devoted to the care and treatment of disabled United States veterans. Cherished son of the late Charles and Lena (Zimmerman) Golub and dear brother of Benjamin Golub of Boca Raton, FL and the late Herbert Golub, Leon Golub and Rosalie Golub. An enthusiastic participant in extended family events, he is also survived by his many devoted nieces, nephews and their families. Funeral services will be private. Remembrances may be made to a charity of your choice. 1/3

PHILLIPS--Lawrence S. The Trustees, Faculty, and Staff of the Mount Sinai Health System mourn the passing of our longtime benefactor Lawrence (Larry) S. Phillips, a great-grandson of Mount Sinai Beth Israel's founder Moses Phillips. Larry was instrumental in the creation of the Phillips Ambulatory Care Center and the Hyman-Newman Institute for Neurology and Neurosurgery, and was a generous supporter of the Phillips Beth Israel School of Nursing. We are grateful for his deep commitment, insight, and leadership and for steadfastly sustaining the Phillips family's history of philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his children, David and Laura, and to his entire family. Peter W. May, Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Steven Hochberg, Senior Vice Chairman of the Boards of Trustees; Kenneth L. Davis, MD, President and CEO; Dennis S. Charney, MD, Anne and Joel Ehrenkranz Dean, Icahn School of Medicine at Mount Sinai and President for Academic Affairs, Mount Sinai Health System; Susan Somerville, RN, President, Mount Sinai Beth Israel 1/3

STONE--Jacqueline P. In loving memory. August 16, 1921-April 28, 2015. Loving wife to Louis Stone. Loving mother to Oliver Stone. Loving grandmother to Sean, Michael and Tara. A ceremony will be held Friday the 18th of September 2015 at St. James' Church, 865 Madison Avenue, New York, NY 10021. 1/3

LUXEMBURG--Linda, loving wife of Marc for 54 years. Loving mother of Carolyn. Loving mother of Rachel. She loved her family, her brothers, sisters-in-law, nieces, nephews, and cousins, the special relationship with her step family, and her son- in-law, and her many friends, old and new, from her youth, or acquired thru her synagogue memberships, her chavurah, and her activities, social and athletic. She loved her house in Connecticut, taking care of the grounds and growing flowers. She loved her dogs. She loved opera, ballet, and the New York Rangers. She loved art and museums and archeological sites, especially Roman ruins. She loved travelling to Europe, Africa, South America, and South East Asia, but especially to Italy, so she learned to speak Italian. She was the trip planner. She was athletic and loved tennis and running. She ran in many races. She loved hiking. She loved sailing. She was the mainsail trimmer and the Admiral. She loved sailing and snorkeling in the Caribbean. She loved wine -- white or rose. She loved eating out, and she loved preparing meals for friends and family. She loved the family rituals of Judaism, and loved giving Seders. She organized the ritual and prepared the meal. She edited the family Haggadah. She especially loved doing these things because she did them together with Marc. She loved and was loved. She died way too soon. She will be sorely missed. Funeral services will be at Plaza Chapel, Amsterdam Ave. and 91st St., Thursday, September 17, 9:30. 1/3

WOLF--Eleanor, passed away at 92 on September 11 after a lengthy debilitating illness that she braved with will and strength. An identical twin and one and a half pounds at birth, she fought for her life in her first days in a way that mirrored her battle in her last. Her grace for life was matched only by her warmth and spirit. She wasn't just beautiful, she was glamorous, as well as protective, embracing and affectionate, a strong personality with a kind soul. With husband Marvin, a 66-year love affair that lasted until his death, she raised a family of three, had cherished friends and traveled the world for pleasure and business. Her impeccable sense of style made her an invaluable asset to the family business. An avid bridge and tennis player, she also was a great enthusiast of theater, film, opera and day at the museum. She is survived by her daughter Barbara Emden, son-in-law James Emden, and son Robert, and predeceased by her daughter Marcia. For those she loved and left behind, her loss will be profoundly felt. 1/3

BIBERMAN--David Marcus, died peacefully surrounded by his family in New York on September 13, 2015 just shy of his 93rd birthday. Dave was a lifelong resident of Philadelphia, where for him it was truly and always sunny. Dave was an electrical engineer, WWII Army Veteran, and believer in social justice and irreverent Yiddish humor. Devoted husband of 72 years to his beloved Annette; father to Nancy (Roger Evans) and Dana (Paul Gregory); adoring grandpa to Matthew B. Colbert, Abby J. Biberman (Dave Jaklevic), Jacob B. Evans, Lilias B. Evans. Great grandpa to Samuel Marcus Jaklevic. Dave instilled humanitarian values into his family and rejoiced in their accomplishments. At the end of WWII Dave was deployed to White Sands, New Mexico where, because of his scientific expertise and fluent German, he participated in the interrogation of Nazi POW Werner Von Braun. Dave was a man of intellect, compassion and culture, volunteering after retirement as a Cancer Society driver and at the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Anthropology and Archeology. He was an avid reader, theater, opera, symphony and jazz concertgoer and dancer extraordinaire. For the last 18 years of his life Dave was afflicted with Alzheimer's Disease which slowly robbed him of his intellect, memory and all physical and mental function. There is both relief at the end of his suffering and sadness that such a giant is no longer in our lives. In his memory contributions may be made to: endoflifechoicesny.org. 1/3

MARSHALL--Irene R. My beautiful engaging wife Irene passed on Sunday, September 13, 2015. She was a beautiful, dynamic, knowledgeable spirit who will be missed by her husband Alan, her brother Martin Sandler and wife Patricia, her stepson Andrew and wife Mandy, her stepson Bob and wife Michele, her stepdaughter Beth and husband Rob. Services on September 17, 2015 at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel and interment at Eternal Life Cemetery, Delray Beach, FL. 1/3

MICHALOS--Peter J.,died on September 5 in Miami Beach of brain cancer. Beloved son of the late Professor James Michalos and much loved and mourned by Paulo, mother Claire, sister Kiki, cousins, and many friends. Alumnus of Hackley School, Yale, NYU. Gifted writer, creatively following his life's path. Private cremation. Memorial service in the fall in NYC. 1/3

STRAUSS--David B.,Jr. 1929-2015. David B. Strauss, Jr. of Aventura, Florida, passed away last night with his family by his side. From starring as the Union College QB to taking over his family business at age 25, to creating DarySue Fashions, a women's apparel powerhouse in the 1980's, highlighted by the creation of the Jacklyn Smith line at Kmart. David was extremely charitable to dozens of organizations. He loved golf, tennis, skiing, movies, travel, and time spent with his many friends, but nothing was more important than his loving family. He is survived by the true love of his life, Susan, their three children --Dary, Robert and Jon, their spouses -- Mark, Katia and Jamie and their 10 grandchildren: Matt, Danielle, Zach, Brian, Alex, Sam, Blake, Jack, Natalie, and Ethan. Funeral will be held September 16th at 12:00, at Beth David in Hollywood. 1/3

GREENE--Elizabeth Ann nee Kaplan, died September 14, 2015 of pancreatic cancer at the age of 78. Liz was an avid tennis player, world traveler and had a take charge spirit that she used for her many volunteer endeavors and her successful career in advertising. She rejoiced in her many friends and she found true love and joy with her family. She was quick to laugh and warm of heart. She is survived by her beloved husband of 57 years, Joseph, and their three children David, Michael and Susan, their three children in law Jennifer, Elizabeth and Kenneth and seven grandchildren Matthew, Benjamin, Ethan, Samantha, Evan, Andrew and Abigail. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth El in Chappaqua, NY 10514 at 10am, on Thursday, September 17th. Burial services will be held immediately following at Cedar Park Cemetery in Paramus, NJ. Shiva will be held at 43 Devoe Road, Chappaqua, NY on Thursday, from 5 to 8pm and Friday from 1 to 6pm. We will continue to celebrate Liz's life on Saturday between 1pm and 6pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Liz's name to the Lustgarten Foundation. www.lustgarten.org 1/3

McEVILY--Thomas F.,Jr. of New York, NY died on September 15, 2015 at the age of 90. Born in New York City to Thomas F. and Ellen R. (McDonnell) McEvily, he is survived by his devoted wife of 33 years, Mary Ellen Foster McEvily, by his children, Thomas F. III (Mary), Richard P. (Michele), Ellie Murphy (Michael), Patrick (Ann), Mary McMillan (Keith) and Michael (Ellen), by his grandchildren, Christopher (Maureen), Peter (Sarah), Kathleen and Alison McEvily, Kyle (Jessica), Conor and Caitlin McEvily and Erin (Andrew) McArdle, Thomas Murphy, Katie, Patrick and Claire McEvily, Lizzie, Neil and Will McMillan and Megan, Thomas and Cara McEvily and by his great grandchildren, Daniel, Sean, Ryan, Alexandra, Kevin and Trevor. He was predeceased by his first wife, Catherine Shea McEvily, and by his daughter, Claire Keating McEvily. Tom graduated from Fordham Prep ('43), the United States Merchant Marine Academy ('45) and the University of Notre Dame ('50) and he was a proud and loyal alumnus of each school. He also served in the United States Navy during WW II. He was the President for many years of Keevily Spero Whitelaw, Inc. a successful insurance brokerage now located in Harrison, NY - which was founded by his father, greatly expanded by him and now managed by several of his children and grandchildren. However, what his family would like him to be most remembered for was that he was a man of great Catholic faith and that, especially in his retirement, he strongly lived that faith on a daily basis by serving his fellow man as a lay member of the Archdiocese of New York's Inter-Parish Finance Committee, as the President and long-time member of the Board of Directors of Abbott House, as a Eucharistic Minister for cancer patients at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center and, until most recently, as the leader of the Saturday Morning Homeless Breakfast Program for over 20 years at Our Lady of Good Counsel Church. Tom was a Knight of Malta and also served on the Board of Trustees of Fordham Prep and The Ursuline School. His lifelong pursuit of learning was found in his love of reading and in speaking French. He was an avid tennis player and sailor and vocal fan of Notre Dame Football and the New York Yankees. Truly a life well-lived. The wake hours will be on Friday, September 18, 2015 from 3-5pm and 7-9pm at the Chas. Peter Nagel Funeral Home, 352 East 87th Street, New York, NY 10128. A Mass of Christian Burial will be held at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Avenue at 84th Street in New York City at 9:30am on Saturday, September 19, 2015. Interment to follow at Gate of Heaven Cemetery in Hawthorne, NY. Rather than flowers, the family requests that contributions be made to either Our Lady of Good Counsel Church, 230 East 90th Street, New York, NY 10128 (Memo: Saturday Morning Breakfast Program), or to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center Chaplaincy, MSK Development Office, Attn: Carol A. Blumenfeld, 633 3rd Avenue, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017. 1/3

HILL--Dorothy Helen, passed away peacefully in her home on Sunday, September 13. Born in Sheridan, Wyoming on July 6, 1917, Dorothy lived a long and fulfilled life, graced by a frontier spirit of fierce independence and a passion for helping others. She leaves behind family and friends, whose lives have been strengthened by her love, her mentoring and her enthusiasm for life. Dorothy's passions were wide-ranging... creating art, giving herself to community service, devoting herself to her four grandchildren, breaking the age barrier in Tai Chi classes and collecting as many pennies as she could at her weekly poker game at Kendal on Hudson. What family and friends will remember most about Dorothy was her genuine faith, and her belief that spirit transcends temporal life. Her library is populated with all persuasions of books dealing with spirituality, from Joan Chittister to Henri Nouwen. As an artist, who studied at the Art Students' League of New York, she was prolific and comfortable working in many mediums: drawing, painting, sculpture and collage. Her artworks include clay busts, bronze figurines, seascapes, and landscapes, demonstrating a willingness to take artistic risks in both abstraction and realism. Along with Helen Price, she founded the Art Committee and Art Room at Kendal and organized the Rue des Artistes shows, having a new show every two months. As a volunteer, in the 1940s and 1950s, Dorothy was a strong advocate for education, and in later decades she devoted much of her life to community service as a long standing Board member of the Community Service Society, among other organizations. As a beloved grandmother to Margot, Alexis, Astrid and Jamie, and a great-grand- mother to Eliza Joy, she relished the many opportunities to read to them, to play with them and to celebrate their chosen paths. As a firm believer that "you become better with age," she took up yoga in her 60s and Tai Chi in her 70s. Never one to back away from a challenge, she decided ten years ago to forge a new life at Kendal on Hudson, where her clarity of thought kept pace with her physical prowess, up until the very end, as she celebrated her 98th birthday two months ago. Throughout her life, Dorothy found beauty and inspiration for her art and her spirit from the Wyoming mountains, the Cape Cod seas, and the Hudson River views at Kendal. As a devoted wife to James T. Hill, Jr., who predeceased her in 1978, Dorothy followed him east upon his graduation from Harvard Law School and never looked back. As her grandchildren would often say, "You can take her out of Wyoming, but you can never take the Wyoming out of her!" She leaves behind her loving children and daughter-in-law, Susan, Tom and Janine, her four devoted grandchildren, Margot, Alexis, Astrid and Jamie, and the newest joy in her life, her great-granddaughter, Lizzie, as well as countless friends whom she loved. Her lasting legacy to family and friends was her gift for making our time with her so much fun. Contributions in lieu of flowers may be sent to St. Paul's Episcopal Church, 60 East Ave., Norwalk, CT 06851 and/or The Nature Conservancy, 322 8th Ave #

TRACHTENBERG--Michael Albert Einstein College of Medicine records with profound sorrow the passing of our dear friend Michael Trachtenberg, beloved husband of Inge of blessed memory, and father of David (Deborah) and of Shoshanah of blessed memory. Together with other members of the Trachtenberg-Frackman family, Michael was a longtime generous supporter of biomedical research and education programs at Einstein, and established the Dr. Shoshanah Trachtenberg Frackman Faculty Scholar in Biomedical Ethics. We extend our heartfelt condolences to David and the entire family. Albert Einstein College of Medicine Allen M. Spiegel, MD, The Marilyn and Stanley M. Katz Dean 1
STRAUSS--David. We will never forget you. Nancy and Bob 1/3

LEVANS--Daniel. All of us at Ballet Tech - fellow teachers, pianists, staff and students past and present - mourn the passing of Daniel Levans, Dan, or Mr. Levans as he came to be known. He imbued generations of students with his passion for the rigor, technique, epaulement, elegance and continuity of classical ballet. Yes, part of him goes on in those he trained to carry on. Farewell with love, Dan. Rest. 1/3

WALSER--Theodore R.,of Water Mill, New York died on September 13. He was 80 years old and died of cancer. He spent his childhood in New Canaan, Connecticut, attended the Lawrenceville School and Yale University, Class of 1957. He began his career as a banker at Chemical Bank and went on to become Senior Vice President of Corporate Banking for Lloyd's Bank. In his retirement he served as Executive Interviewer for Greenwich Associates. Ted was well loved in the banking community and remembered as a consummate professional and a kind and generous man, popular with everyone. In his personal life his greatest pleasures were enjoying the beach, traveling, and spending time with his family. He is survived by his wife of 25 years, Sandra; a sister Jeanne Burdell of Oregon; four children: Julia Allan of Cummington, Massachusetts; Elizabeth Gassimi of Mexico; James Walser of Seattle, Washington; Kenneth Walser of Tallahassee, Florida; and grandchildren Riley, Jackson, Katy, Madeleine, Amanda and Caroline. He was predeceased by a brother, Mackenzie Walser, and a sister, Mary Brady. Memorial service Thursday 11am at the First Presbyterian Church, Southampton, NY. Donations in his name may be made to Doctors Without Borders, 333 7th Avenue, New York, NY 10001. 1/3

ADLER--Myron. With great admiration and affection, the Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation (APGF) remember Myron (Mike) Adler, beloved husband of devoted trustee, Elaine Adler. Intelligent and wise, kind and caring, accomplished and remarkably humble, Mike was a champion in his industry and among his fellow human beings. His name and that of his company, Myron Manufacturing Corp., became synonymous with product excellence, business acumen and the highest ethical standards. Locally and abroad, innumerable diverse charitable endeavors have benefitted from Mike and Elaine's generosity, including their establishment of the Adler Center for Nursing Excellence at Ramapo College and the APGF-AACN Nursing White Coat Ceremony. At the heart of Mike's philanthropy has been a visionary determination to establish unique opportunities for individuals with aphasia to regain confidence, acquire life skills and enjoy social happiness. The Adlers created The Adler Aphasia Center in Maywood, NJ as a model which is currently being replicated nationally and internationally. We are grateful for the Adler family's leadership on behalf of Humanistic Healthcare, and for the many good deeds that are Mike Adler's legacy. With heartfelt condolences to Elaine, the children, the grandchildren and the entire family. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D., Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D., President/CEO 1/3

SABLE--Elissa. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Elissa Sable, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Elissa's beloved children, Judy and David; her grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3

KIRBY--Sr. Joan. Longtime board member and founding executive director of homeless services nonprofit Homes for the Homeless, Sr. Joan Kirby passed away September 9. She was a compassionate voice for New York City's poor and a tireless advocate for quality education. Sr. Kirby's lifelong commitment to education and service was a driving force in creating partnerships between government, faith- based organizations, and nonprofits. She served as Executive Director for Homes for the Homeless from the organization's founding in 1986, working in conjunction with the City of New York and the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and was an innovative pioneer in addressing the needs of homeless families. Sr. Kirby advanced a new approach to move families from congregate shelters to more humane facilities that provided not only safe shelter, but life opportunities as well, serving as a model for operations that tie in vital services and offer not only a safe place for families to stay, but a place where they could thrive. 1/3

TULMAN--Adele, on September 15, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Samuel. Devoted mother of Alan and Eric and mother-in-law of Lorraine. Cherished grandmother of Sarah, Andrew, Ryo and Kenji and great- grandmother of Jake and Kyle. Services: Friday, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

McNALLY--Thomas E. on September 15, 2015. Retired Psychiatric Social Worker at Sewanhaka School District. Beloved husband of Antoinette "nee Camilleri." Devoted father of Michael, Mark, Colin, and Jennifer Buyer. Proud grandfather of Thomas, Jessica, Molly, Christian, Roy, Amanda, Luke, Paul, and Andrew. Loving brother of Ann Dagher, Veronica McNally, Bernadette Puccala, and the late Kathleen "Pat" Davidson. Reposing at the Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th St. Whitestone, NY. Visiting: Thursday, 2-5pm and 7-10pm. Mass of Christian Burial: Friday, St. Luke's R.C. Church 10:15am. Committal Saint Raymond's Cemetery. 1/3

ORLOFF--Dr. David, died peacefully Sunday of brain cancer. He graduated from St. Albans School 1975, Harvard 1979 and NYU Medical School 1984. He completed his medical training at Yale University and fellowship at the National Institutes of Health. His laboratory work in immunology at the National Institutes of Health was published in Nature. As Director of the Division of Metabolism and Endocrinology Products at the FDA, he oversaw the approval of a new class of statin drugs. After achieving the rank of Captain in the Public Health Service in 2005, he joined Medpace Inc., where he was regarded as an industry opinion leader in the study of metabolic diseases and drug development. David is survived by his mother Dr. Martha Vaughan, sons Nicholas and Jeremy, former wife Dr. Catherine Orentreich, and his siblings, Jonathan, Gregory and Lee. A memorial service will be held at 2:30pm on October 3rd at the Cosmos Club in Washington DC. 1/3

GROSS--Martin M.,aged 98, passed peacefully September 14th. Predeceased by his loved wives Florence (died 1995), Irene (died 2002) and Rosalyn (died 2014). Proud WWII Veteran who received The Purple Heart, Bronze Star, and French Croix de Guerre. Beloved father of Janet (Bill) Schnall, Barbara (Richard) Weinberg, and Andrew (Linda Koenig) Gross. Service Friday, September 18, 1pm at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

NEWBURGER--Robert L. September 15th 2015. Stockbroker, Sportsman and Philanthropist. Husband of Ann Webster Lord. Father of John Newburger, Susan Kauchmer (Michael), Kay Wisniewski (Michael) and Grandfather of Katherine Wisniewski. In Lieu of Flowers contributions to William George Agency, 380 Freeville Rd., Freeville, NY 13068 would be appreciated. 1/3

CAMPBELL--Castle Berry, 86, died peacefully at Calvary Hospital on August 7, 2015. Close friend. Beloved uncle. We miss him. Blessed with an easy smile and outgoing personality, Castle never met a stranger, nor forgot those who became friends. He was born in Big Spring, Texas, the son of James Campbell and the former Lula Mae Castle. A graduate of Big Spring High School, he attended Abilene Christian College (now Abilene Christian University) in Abilene, Texas; then moved to Dallas where he worked as a film booker for RKO Pictures. By the late 50s, Castle was working in New York City as an airline ticketing agent. That began a long and varied travel career which culminated at Loew's Hotels, where he worked in travel agency sales. During the Loew's years, he traveled almost constantly, domestically and abroad. Budapest, Cairo, Lisbon, Bangkok, Hamburg, and Taipei were some of the cities he visited and explored. Castle never tired of traveling and used his vacations to do even more. France was always a favorite and the source of many anecdotes, including the time he fell asleep on a sunny afternoon in a cow pasture surrounded by the magnificent Cirque de Gavarnie in the French Pyrenees. Another special travel moment was a motor launch cruise in New Zealand's spectacular Milford Sound. In recognition of his travel experience and industry credentials, Castle was elected a member of Skal, the international travel fraternity. Castle liked the theater, movies, mystery novels, Masterpiece Theater series, and was a fanatical fan of "Keeping Up Appearances". Then there was ballroom dancing. Just ask Skal or ASTA members who was the last guy to leave the dance floor at their dinner dances? After retiring from Loew's, Castle served as a volunteer docent at Carnegie Hall for 20+ years and continued to travel. Castle was preceded in death by a brother, Woodrow Campbell, a sister, Dorothea Evans, nephews Warren Evans and Jim Pat Campbell, and a much beloved first cousin, Janice Dunagan. He is survived by Malcolm Crawford, his long time friend who patiently cared for him during the final months, a niece, Judy Schoen of Terrell, Texas, two nephews, Roger Evans of Oslo, Norway and Joe Keith Campbell of Tulsa, Oklahoma plus several cousins and a host of great nieces and nephews. Castle adopted New York as his home, but never forgot his Texas roots. He loved his family and friends, never forgot them and kept up with what they were doing until his demise. Interment services will be held at Mount Olive Cemetery in Big Spring, Texas at 11am on Saturday, September 26, 2015. A reception and lunch will follow at the Hotel Settles. Please share your remembrances of Castle on line at www.npwelch.com (Nalley-Pickle & Welch Funeral Home) in Big Spring. Memorial contributions may be made to the Pulmonary Fibrosis Foundation, Carnegie Hall, the New York Public Library. 1/3

GARSON--Roberta Ann, (January 28, 1954 - September 11, 2015). Beloved daughter of Gloria and the late Eugene Garson. Robbie met life with a formidable fighting spirit to overcome many physical hardships. We shall miss her wonderful infectious laugh, her good humor and her warm radiant smile. She is survived by her mother Gloria and sister Heidi. 1/3

ADLER--Myron. The officers and members of the Board of Directors of the Jewish Home Family boards, our residents and our staff note with profound sorrow the passing of our long-devoted supporter, very dear friend, and husband of our board member Elaine Adler. Alongside his devoted wife, Mike established a world-renowned business and later in life, transformed the personal challenge of Aphasia into a deep commitment and advocacy for those suffering the disorder. Mike was a man loved by all who exhibited a profound commitment to countless organizations and causes in the local, national and international communities. Together with Elaine, Mike was a community builder and supporter of numerous humanitarian, educational and social institutions. Their strong belief of providing for elders in our community has resulted in decades of support for our Jewish Home Family. He will be missed by many. We extend our deepest sympathy to his beloved wife Elaine, his children William and Leslie, Richard and Haekyung, Donald James and Dana, Marie and Saul, his eleven grandchildren and the entire family. May his memory be for a blessing. Eli Ungar, Chairperson of the Board Carol Silver Elliott, President and CEO 1/3

RIOS--Sara Elena, passed away peacefully at her home in Toledo, Ohio on Thursday, September 10, 2015, surrounded by her loving family. She was born October 31, 1952 in Toledo, Ohio to Sara (Vasquez) and Martin Rios. Sara's career history included: Vice President of the Farm Labor Organizing Committee; Senior Attorney and Interim Executive Director of the Center for Constitutional Rights; Executive Director of the National Employment Law Project; Director of Litigation at the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund; and Director of the Human Rights, Peace and Social Justice unit at the Ford Foundation. Sara retired unexpectedly from her position as President of the Ruth Mott Foundation in Flint, MI in November 2013 due to ALS against which she waged a valiant battle. Sara dedicated her life to peace and social justice causes, and equality for all. Her philanthropic work took her across the U.S. and around the world. She is survived by her parents, seven siblings, six nephews and nieces, and many dear friends. In lieu of flowers, please consider making a donation in Sara's memory to the following organizations: Farm Labor Organizing Committee, www.floc.com; and or, ALS Association, www.alsa.org/research/. Online condolences may be offered at: reebfuneralhome.com 1/3

WONHAM--Ann Brunie, of Vero Beach, Florida, and formerly Stamford, Connecticut, died peacefully in the Adirondacks on September 14, of complications from Parkinson's Disease. An avid bridge player and teacher, tennis and paddle tennis player, and a low handicap golfer, she brought, fun, laughter, and a love of competition and of friends, whom she adored, to every game and match she played. Ann grew up in New York City, graduated from the Brearley School in 1950, and was a member of the class of 1954 of Smith College. She was a former president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association, and a member of the board of the Fresh Air Fund of New York for a number of years. She is survived by her devoted husband of 62 years, Frederick S. Wonham, her daughter Stapley Emberling (David) of Weston, Connecticut, her son Henry B. Wonham. (Connie) of Eugene, OR, and her younger son Lincoln Wonham of Lake Forest, IL, as well as her sister Susan Hughes of Vero Beach (Ed) and formerly Greenwich, Connecticut, and her half-brother Charles (Rex) Hubbard (Libby) of Huntington, L.I. She also leaves seven dearly loved grandchildren: Anna Emory Wonham, Henry Grant and Walker Lincoln Wonham, Ryan and Rachel Emberling, and Jack and Cal Wonham. With Annie at every step since 1998, her beloved Tiger lives on. 1/3

WETTERAU--Gary P. Mutual of America, its Board of Directors, together with all of its Officers and Employees, mourn the passing of our respected colleague and friend, Gary P. Wetterau. For 20 years, Gary worked diligently and made significant contributions to Mutual of America Capital Management LLC as Executive Vice President Fixed Income, where he distinguished himself as an expert in the structured products area of the fixed income community. Gary served as a captain in the United States Air Force and was an active supporter of the Boy Scouts of America. We will deeply miss his quiet, gentlemanly presence and extend our most sincere sympathy to his wife, Linda, their two children and family. Thomas J. Moran, Chairman and CEO John R. Greed President Mutual of America Life Insurance Company Amir Lear Chairman and CEO Mutual of America Capital Management LLC 1

REINIG--William Charles, 91, died on August 25, 2015, in Annapolis, MD. A graduate of Polytechnic Institute of Brooklyn, Reinig was the leader of the radiation protection program for the first peacetime nuclear reactor at Brookhaven National Laboratory. He subsequently led the research team that performed the preoperational survey of the Savannah River Site near Aiken, SC, the first large-scale assay of naturally occurring radioactivity. He later served as Superintendent of Health Physics and Deputy General Manager at SRS. He was a fellow and President of the Health Physics Society, Chairman of the American Board of Health Physics, and served on the NCRP. He enjoyed gardening, watching movies and reading The New York Times. He maintained an out-of-town subscription to the Times for 64 years. After retirement, he wrote a remarkably detailed memoir about growing up in Queens describing the smallest details of daily life including the daily meals, how Mayor La Guardia read the Sunday comic pages of the New York papers over the radio in the 1930s during a newspaper distribution strike, the presence of a speech teacher at PS 108 who attempted to correct the Brooklyn accents of many of the students, including Bill, and watching Memorial Day parades down Rockaway Blvd led by Civil War Veterans followed by Spanish-American War Vets wearing Teddy Roosevelt hats and World War I Vets marching behind. He greatly enjoyed movies for the simple pleasure of watching, a habit begun in the movie theaters of Queens during the Depression. Bill was a survivor of the 1950 LIRR crash in Rockville Center. In 1949, he married Marion Borgstrom whom he met at Brookhaven. She died in 2007. He is survived by Dr. James Reinig (Ellen) of Annapolis, Dr. Christine Reinig of Santa Fe, NM, and grandchildren Margaret and Ann Reinig and Dennis and Alice Flournoy. 1/3
BONCHICK--Robert E. Oct. 4, 1936-Sept. 18, 2005 "I carry your heart. I carry it in my heart." Always loved. Forever remembered. Annise 1/3

NOBLE--William L. August 22, 1932 - September 15, 2015. Resident of New York City and Wainscott, NY. Graduate of The Lawrenceville School and Columbia University. Served honorably in The Marine Corps during the Korean War. Life-long member of The Blue Hill Troupe and Squadron A Association. He is survived by his wife, Jennifer; children, Nick, Maggie, Kate and Polly; stepchildren, Roxanne and Jared; and grandsons, Jonathan, Owen and Graham. Bill was a friend to all and will be remembered fondly as the Mayor of East 68th Street. Service will be held at The Brick Presbyterian Church at 91st Street and Park Avenue, Monday, September 21 at 11:00am. 1/3

STIX--Roger, of Atlanta, formerly of Boston and Scarsdale, died peacefully Sunday, September 13th. He was the beloved husband of Jane Share, MD; father of Michael, son of Carol and the late Edgar Stix and dear brother of Allen, Wayne and Gail Stix. A graduate of Tulane University, he was a successful businessman, a devoted family member and dear friend. A memorial service will be held later in Atlanta. 1/3
WILK-HARRIS--Ellen. Happy Anniversary. Our wonderful journey ended last year, but you live on in my heart. Love, Rogie 1/3

GREENE--Ethan Frederick, D.M.A.,University of Texas (2013), and graduate of Columbia High School, South Orange, NJ, Amherst College (2004), and Rice University (2010), passed away September 13, 2015 at age 32. A brilliant and prolific composer in diverse musical genres, he is survived by loving wife, Alma Lagarda, 18-month old son Mateo, parents, Peter and Rebecca, and brother Abraham. Ethan was an Assistant Professor of Digital Arts at Stetson University in DeLand, FL. Services will take place September 18, 2015, 10:00am at Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Road, Vauxhall (Union), NJ 07088. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in memory of Ethan Frederick Greene to Anthropos Arts at: https://anthroposarts.org/efg/ 1/3

ADLER--Myron. With great admiration and affection, the Board of Trustees and staff of The Arnold P. Gold Foundation (APGF) remember Myron (Mike) Adler, beloved husband of devoted trustee, Elaine Adler. Intelligent and wise, kind and caring, accomplished and remarkably humble, Mike was a champion in his industry and among his fellow human beings. His name and that of his company, Myron Manufacturing Corp., became synonymous with product excellence, business acumen and the highest ethical standards. Locally and abroad, innumerable diverse charitable endeavors have benefitted from Mike and Elaine's generosity, including their establishment of the Adler Center for Nursing Excellence at Ramapo College and the APGF-AACN Nursing White Coat Ceremony. At the heart of Mike's philanthropy has been a visionary determination to establish unique opportunities for individuals with aphasia to regain confidence, acquire life skills and enjoy social happiness. The Adlers created The Adler Aphasia Center in Maywood, NJ as a model which is currently being replicated nationally and internationally. We are grateful for the Adler family's leadership on behalf of Humanistic Healthcare, and for the many good deeds that are Mike Adler's legacy. With heartfelt condolences to Elaine, the children, the grandchildren and the entire family. Jordan J. Cohen, M.D., Chairman Richard I. Levin, M.D., President/CEO 1/3

GROSS--Martin M.,aged 98, passed peacefully September 14th. Predeceased by his loved wives Florence (died 1995), Irene (died 2002) and Rosalyn (died 2014). Proud WWII Veteran who received The Purple Heart, Bronze Star, and French Croix de Guerre. Beloved father of Janet (Bill) Schnall, Barbara (Richard) Weinberg, and Andrew (Linda Koenig) Gross. Grandfather of Lisa, Laura, Amy, Matthew (Arielle Gordon), and Benjamin. Great- grandfather to Sophia. Services on Friday, 12:45pm at "The Riverside" on Amsterdam Ave. and West 76th St. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome, passed away peacefully on Thursday morning September 17th surrounded by his family. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Maxine and son Michael (Kathy). He is survived by his son Tad, daughter Brianne (Sanford), brother Victor and grandchildren Matthew (Jodi), Joshua (Katy), Jaclyn, Toby and Jonathan, and great grandchildren Noah, Ariel, and Paisley. The funeral will be held Sunday, September 20th at 12pm at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY. He will be missed by those who knew him best for his larger than life personality. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to New Hope Community, Inc. 1/3

BRENER--Jacob L.,M.D. Passed away on September 8th. Beloved husband of Goldie. Cherished father of Michelle (Yitzchak) Teitelbaum, Judy (Marty) Grumet and Stanley Brener. Adored grandfather of Yonina, Jonathan (Basya) and Naava Teitelbaum; Avi (Leah), Alexandra, and Duvi Grumet. Proud great-grandfather of Noa Hadar Grumet. Devoted brother of Rabbi Pynchas Brener and the late Rabbi Mark Brener. Dr. Brener was a physician whose dedication to his patients was unparalleled. A Professor of Medicine at New York Medical College for over fifty years, he was a well-respected teacher and clinician. Dr. Brener was steadfast in his commitment to his family, his faith and his profession. Donations in his memory may be made to American Friends of Magen David Adom or Chai Lifeline. 1/3

SOMMER--Nat, beloved husband for 65 years of Janice, died Wednesday morning after a brief illness. Nat was just shy of his 93rd birthday. He was the devoted father of Jeffrey (Wendy), Andrew (Susan) and Susan (Stephen) and proud grandfather of Paul, William, Jack, Erik, Samuel, Anne and Sarah. Nat owned Abbott-Sommer, the construction company that put the roofs on the World Trade Center. Born in Scranton, PA, he was a Veteran of WWII, attended the University of Scranton, UCLA and Columbia Teachers College, and was active in the Jewish community in Kew Gardens Hills, Roslyn Heights and Lake Success. 1/3

BROZINSKY--Hilda, 97. Devoted daughter of Hymie and Anna Needell. Beloved wife of the late Nathan and loving mother to Michael (Susan) and Steven (Roseann). Adoring grandmother of Shari, Craig, Amanda and Noah. Big sister to the late Burton, Melvin and to Martin. Wonderful aunt to countless nieces and nephews. Mouthwatering mandel bread and strudel were her specialties. Green- thumbed gardener. Truly the "hostess with the mostess." For information: jewish- funeral-home.com 1/3

SCHWIMMER--Robert I.,66, beloved husband of Cynthia (nee Dodick); devoted father of Jonathan Lee, Caitlyn Rose, and Scott Michael Schwimmer; loving brother of Lawrence (Leslie) Schwimmer and David Schwimmer; cherished uncle, cousin, and friend of many. An accomplished corporate attorney, Bob's honesty and integrity were without compare. He was exceptionally generous with a huge heart. Funeral service Monday, 10:30am, at Weinstein & Piser Funeral Home, 111 Skokie Blvd, Wilmette, IL. Interment Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Wounded Warrior Project, woundedwarriorproject.org Journeycare Hospice, www.journeycare.org or Death with Dignity, www.deathwithdignity.org For info: 847-256-5700. 1/3
LITT--Solomon. April 12, 1904 - Sept. 18, 1995. Remembered always. Susan, Mark and Families 1/3

CHASE--Ira S. Devoted husband, father, grandfather, and father-in- law died September 10th at the age of 88. A leader in the New Jersey automobile industry in the 70's and 80's, he started his first dealership in Woodbridge in 1960. He devoted his life to his family, business and the many charities he supported. He leaves behind his wife Sally, two daughters, four grandchildren and two sons-in-laws. Donations may be made to Hadassah in memory of Ira Chase at hadassah.org 1/3

HOLLINGSWORTH--John T.,of Sarasota, FL died on September 16, 2015. John was a World War II combat veteran of the United States Coast Guard. He retired from the Real Estate Division of the IBM Corporation with 49 years of service as a Real Estate negotiator. Survivors include his wife, Maureen Daly Hollingsworth, his son; John Francis Hollingsworth; his grandson, Kevin Ahrens and his great-grandson, Jared Ahrens. In addition to his wife, Theresa who passed away in April 1972 John was also predeceased by his parents and his daughter, Theresa Ahrens. Interment will be at Madonna Cemetery in Ft. Lee, New Jersey. 1/3
SADOWSKY--Patricia, 73. Beloved daughter of Marjory and Charles. Burial, Sunday, September 20 at 11:30am, Mt. Carmel, Glendale, NY. www.PhynesFamily.info 1/3
MUGGEO--Sam. Graphics Arts Designer died on September 12, 2015. He lived in New York and had been in advertising for over 35 years. Sam was loved very much and will be solely missed. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome. The St. John's University School of Law family celebrates the life and mourns the passing on Thursday of Jerome Belson '48L, '80HON, an extraordinary man and a generous benefactor. The School of Law building bears his name, along with the name of his wife of 56 years, Maxine Belson '98HON, as does the school's Belson Moot Court Room and the University's Belson Stadium. Belson's selfless service to the University's board of trustees and to St. John's Law was rooted in his business acumen, his compassion for people, and his dedication to community. He achieved tremendous success as chairman of Jerome Belson Enterprises and distinguished himself in a range of real estate industry leadership roles. Along with his wife--and motivated by their son, Tad-- Belson was a pioneer in promoting the independence of people with intellectual disabilities and guided several organizations that championed this cause. Above all, he was a loving husband, a proud father of three, and a devoted grandfather and great- grandfather. As his legacy endures at St. John's and beyond our gates, he will be missed. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Belson family. Michael A. Simons, Dean and John V. Brennan Professor of Law and Ethics Alfred C. Cerullo III, President, Law School Alumni Association 1/3

KAPELL--William. Dear Willy, you would have been 93 today. On October 29, 1953, the world lost its greatest American pianist. I lost a brother who was also my protector and best friend. I miss and think of you every day. Your loving brother, Bobby 1/3

GOLDFELD--Robert (Bob), died on September 17, 2015 in New York City at the age of 75. Bob attended Midwood High School, Columbia College and Harvard Law School. He devoted his life to making the world a better place through his work in city and state government, The Vera Institute for Justice, The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and New York University, where he spent 20 years as Vice President for Administration. He was loved and respected by his friends and colleagues for his kindness, intelligence, integrity and humor. He enjoyed traveling with his wife but was happiest being with her at his home in Goshen, Connecticut. He is survived by his loving wife Carole, daughter Johanna and son-in-law Bradley Rank. He deeply loved his family, who adored him and will keep him in their hearts forever. A funeral will be held on Sunday, September 20 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society or WMNR radio in Monroe, Connecticut. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome, passed away peacefully on Thursday morning September 17th surrounded by his family. He was predeceased by his beloved wife Maxine and son Michael (Kathy). He is survived by his son Tad, daughter Brianne (Sanford), brother Victor and grandchildren Matthew (Jodi), Joshua (Katy), Jaclyn, Toby and Jonathan, and great grandchildren Noah, Ariel, and Paisley. The funeral will be held Sunday, September 20th at 12pm at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY. He will be missed by those who knew him best for his larger than life personality. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to New Hope Community, Inc. 1/3
BELSON--Jerome. An extraordinary man; an extraordinary partner; an extraordinary friend - Never to be duplicated again. Love, Phyllis & Alan Wolpert 1/3

GROSZ--Erno. The Officers, Trustees, and members of Forest Hills Jewish Center mourn the death of our beloved Cantor Emeritus Erno Grosz, who served our community with great distinction for thirty-six years. His glorious voice filled our lives with prayer and music, and his warmth endeared him to generations of members. To his beloved Anna and the entire family, we share in your grief, and offer heartfelt condolences. Rabbi Gerald C. Skolnik Jack Gostl, President Deborah Gregor, Executive Director 1/3

BUDD--Harlan M.,passed away last week in his home in San Francisco. He was 44 yrs old. Harlan was a handsome, skilled computer engineer with a family and many friends who loved him. He graduated from Midwood High School in Brooklyn and received his engineering degree from the University of Rochester. He is survived by his mother Anna Budd, his father Martin Budd, his step- mother Aviva Budd, his sister Robin Budd and her husband Jeff Waid, his brother Randall Budd and Randall's wife Laurie Budd, his step siblings Rachel Becker and her husband Richard Becker, Jonah Neuman and his wife Claire Neuman, Jody Hausman and Jeffrie Hausman and his wife Mindy Hausman. Harlan will be sorely missed by many. Services will be held on Monday, September 21 at 11:30am at Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel," 81st and Madison Ave. Contributions can be made to your favorite charity in honor of Harlan Budd. 1/3
WILSON--Lela J. Sept. 19, 1916 - March 24, 2014. 1/3

HILL--Dorothy Helen. The Board and staff of Lincoln Center Theater were saddened to learn of the death of Dorothy Hill, mother of our Board Chairman J. Tomilson Hill. She was an extraordinary woman, and Tom's dedication to the arts is a vital part of her legacy. We send our warmest condolences to Tom and Janine, to Tom's sister Susan, and to Dorothy's grandchildren and great-granddaughter. Andre Bishop, Producing Artistic Director Eric M. Mindich, President 1/3

ADLER--Martelle B.,died at her home in Scarsdale, NY on September 18, age 98. Devoted wife of the late Theodore W. Adler and loving mother of Louise and the late Thomas. Born and raised in Mississippi, she attended "Ole Miss" and then worked at the Dayton Air Field where she met "Captain Teddy." Volunteered for over 45 years at the White Plains Hospital Patient Library and Scarsdale Woman's Club Operation Bookshelf. Services private. Relatives and friends are invited to the home Sunday, September 20, from 12-2pm and on Monday, September 21 from 5-7pm. Contributions may be made to White Plains Hospital. 1/3

DUBIN--Melvin. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) express deep regret at the loss of Melvin Dubin, of Great Neck, NY, a valued leader and past president of the New York Metropolitan Region, Life Trustee of the National Board of Regents, and Honorary Life Member of the Technion Board of Governors. He established the Ellie and Mel Dubin Laboratory for Advanced Optoelectronic Material Growth with his beloved late wife, Eleanor. Mr. Dubin was a Technion Guardian, signifying the highest level of support for the university, and received an honorary fellowship in 1991. We express our deep sympathy to his son, Adam, and the entire Dubin family. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Jeffrey Richard, Executive Vice President Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President Emeritus 1/3

WONHAM--Ann Brunie, of Vero Beach, Florida, and formerly Stamford, Connecticut, died peacefully in the Adirondacks on September 14, of complications from Parkinson's Disease. An avid bridge player and teacher, tennis and paddle tennis player, and a low handicap golfer, she brought, fun, laughter, and a love of competition and of friends, whom she adored, to every game and match she played. Ann grew up in New York City, graduated from the Brearley School in 1950, and was a member of the class of 1954 of Smith College. She was a former president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association, and a member of the board of the Fresh Air Fund of New York for a number of years. She is survived by her devoted husband of 62 years, Frederick S. Wonham, her daughter Stapley Emberling (David) of Weston, Connecticut, her son Henry B. Wonham. (Connie) of Eugene, OR, and her younger son Lincoln Wonham of Lake Forest, IL, as well as her sister Susan Hughes of Vero Beach (Ed) and formerly Greenwich, Connecticut, and her half-brother Charles (Rex) Hubbard (Libby) of Huntington, L.I. She also leaves seven dearly loved grandchildren: Anna Emory Wonham, Henry Grant and Walker Lincoln Wonham, Ryan and Rachel Emberling, and Jack and Cal Wonham. With Annie at every step since 1998, her beloved Tiger lives on. 1/3

SPARACO--Anthony, 77, of New York NY died peacefully at his home September 16, 2015. He was predeceased by his husband Andrew Ciolino and his parents Dorothy (Esposito) and Benedetto Sparaco of Jersey City, NJ. He is survived by his sister Grace and brother-in-law John Durkin of Wood-Ridge, NJ; his sister Marie Mason of Scotch Plains, NJ; and his many cousins, nieces and nephews, and dear friends. He was self-employed as an architectural interior designer, and he took great joy in beautifying homes for people from New York City to Southampton. He was formerly employed in creative marketing at Atari, Mennen and Shulton. He was a veteran of the US Army. Services will be private. Condolences and Mass intentions may be directed to the family via Kohler Funeral Home, 280 Hackensack Street, Wood-Ridge NJ 07075 Phone 201-438-7777. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome. The Board and membership of Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York mourn the loss of our chairman emeritus, a leader in the housing industry and valued friend. He was larger than life, and will be remembered for his charitable good deeds. Our sympathies to his brother, children and grandchildren. 1/3

BRENER--Jacob L.,M.D. Passed away on September 8th. Beloved husband of Goldie. Cherished father of Michelle (Yitzchak) Teitelbaum, Judy (Marty) Grumet and Stanley Brener. Adored grandfather of Yonina, Jonathan (Basya) and Naava Teitelbaum; Avi (Leah), Alexandra, and Duvi Grumet. Proud great-grandfather of Noa Hadar Grumet. Devoted brother of Rabbi Pynchas Brener and the late Rabbi Mark Brener. Dr. Brener was a physician whose dedication to his patients was unparalleled. A Professor of Medicine at New York Medical College for over fifty years, he was a well-respected teacher and clinician. Dr. Brener was steadfast in his commitment to his family, his faith and his profession. Donations in his memory may be made to American Friends of Magen David Adom or Chai Lifeline. 1/3
