Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 20, 2015.

BOBST-- Mamdouha S. The NYU Libraries note with sorrow the passing of our champion, Mamdouha Bobst, whose vision and generosity, together with her husband's, enabled NYU to build the Elmer Holmes Bobst Library on Washington Square. Mrs. Bobst was passionate about giving NYU a beautiful, elegant space to inspire creativity and learning, and she remained dedicated to the library all her life, generously supporting programs and renovations. As our esteemed Honorary Curator, she helped us to build collections and to present them to the public in the Mamdouha S. Bobst Gallery. We will be ever grateful. Our thoughts are with her family. 1/3

KAPELL--William. Dear Willy, you would have been 93 today. On October 29, 1953, the world lost its greatest American pianist. I lost a brother who was also my protector and best friend. I miss and think of you every day. Your loving brother, Bobby 1/3

SCHWIMMER--Robert I.,66, beloved husband of Cynthia (nee Dodick); devoted father of Jonathan Lee, Caitlyn Rose, and Scott Michael Schwimmer; loving brother of Lawrence (Leslie) Schwimmer and David Schwimmer; cherished uncle, cousin, and friend of many. An accomplished corporate attorney, Bob's honesty and integrity were without compare. He was exceptionally generous with a huge heart. Funeral service Monday, 10:30am, at Weinstein & Piser Funeral Home, 111 Skokie Blvd, Wilmette, IL. Interment Memorial Park. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Wounded Warrior Project, woundedwarriorproject.org Journeycare Hospice, www.journeycare.org or Death with Dignity, www.deathwithdignity.org For info: 847-256-5700. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome. Builder, lawyer, philanthropist, visionary, sportsman, devoted friend, loving family man and larger than life personality. All of these labels describe Jerry Belson, who passed away peacefully on Thursday, September 17 surrounded by his family. He lived many lifetimes in his 90 years, working his entire life to improve the lives of others through the thousands of apartments he helped build and maintain, to the many charities he supported, to the numerous industry groups and companies he led and advised, to the endless advice and support he provided to family and friends. His wide and varied circle of friends and colleagues were testament to a life spent working in and for the community. He helped build affordable housing across the city and Jerome Belson Associates was a leading manager of apartments. He served on boards as varied as Waterhouse Securities, a leading discount broker, to the Doe Fund, a non-profit group dedicated to helping formerly homeless men and women become self-sufficient, to St. John's University. A long-time congregant at Temple Beth Emeth in Brooklyn, he was also chairman of the United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, a trustee of the National Jewish Fund, Handicapped Boy Scouts and the Disabled and Alone/Life Services for the Handicapped, Inc. Motivated by their son, Tad, Jerry and Maxine, his late wife of 55 years, helped create New Hope Community in Loch Sheldrake, NY, to promote the independence of people with intellectual disabilities. He worked tirelessly for St. John's University as a trustee for more than 20 years, forever thankful for the law degree and the honorary doctorate he earned there. Tad provided the idea for Belson Stadium, a soccer stadium on the St. John's campus. Jerome and Maxine Belson Hall, which houses the School of Law and the Belson Moot Courtroom, speak to Jerry's enduring commitment to law and his alma mater. He played an outsized role as a family patriarch. Predeceased by Maxine and son Michael (Kathy), he is survived by his son Tad, daughter Brianne (Sanford), brother Victor and grandchildren Matthew (Jodi), Joshua (Katy), Jaclyn, Toby, and Jonathan, and three great grandchildren Noah, Ariel, and Paisley, and many cousins, nieces and nephews. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Jerry graduated from Lafayette High School and enrolled in Brooklyn College. After a stint in the U.S. Army during and after World War II, he graduated from St. John's Law School in 1948. Working as an assistant corporation counsel for the city, he helped prosecute racketeers. From an early age, Jerry had a gift for getting things done. In his 20s, he worked with the Knights Before Christmas to help underprivileged children, built clubhouses for the Boys' Club, helped war veterans and was director of an old age home. After entering private practice, at the behest of his father, Joseph, who became the president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of America, he worked in real estate. His first development, in Brooklyn in 1952, was affordable housing for soldiers returning home. He went on to create 25,000 more apartments in the city, all non- profit co-ops. From 1955 to 2005, Jerry managed 50,000 apartments through Jerome Belson Associates. His relationships with members of federal, state and city agencies led to his involvement in Mitchell-Lama housing and noteworthy projects such as Roosevelt Island in Queens, Concourse Village in the Bronx and Jamie Towers, named after his son, Jamie Tad. Because of his friendship with President John F. Kennedy, Jerry went on five mission trips with the American Institute for Free Labor Development to Mexico, Nicaragua, Brazil and Columbia to create non-profit housing there. He worked for decades with the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, Inc., eventually becoming and winning the Fred C. Trump Award for lifetime achievement. He was the first person from New York City to be inducted into the New York State Builders Association Hall of Fame. He started We Media, a magazine devoted to people with disabilities, built a bakery that employed the disabled in Maine, and traveled to Rome with the St. John's 1996 NCAA champion soccer team to meet His Holiness, Pope John Paul II. When honored by Rome as affiliates of the Vincentian community, Jerry and Maxine said they wanted their legacy to be simple: "That we cared." The funeral will be held Sunday September 20th at 12pm at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to New Hope Community, Inc., a home for people with developmental and intellectual disabilities. 1/3

WEISS--Richard, 86, passed peacefully September 17th. A resident of Heritage Hills, NY and formerly of Merrick, NY recently celebrated his 60th anniversary with his beloved wife Lenore. He is survived by his wife Lenore; children Leon, Steven and Peter; daughters-in-law Angela and Diane; grandchildren Joshua, Noah and Emma, sister and brother-in-law Eunice and Ernie Benchell and many nieces, nephews, grandnieces and grandnephews. He instilled in his loved ones a passion for family and education. He cherished the opera and duplicate bridge reaching Silver Master. Services on Sunday, 10am, Clark Associates Funeral Home, 4 Woods Bridge Rd., Katonah, NY. 1/3

BONCHICK--Robert E. Oct. 4, 1936-Sept. 18, 2005 "I carry your heart. I carry it in my heart." Always loved. Forever remembered. Annise 1/3

SIMON--Kerry Glen, of Las Vegas, NV, passed away peacefully on September 11, 2015, with his brothers by his side; after a long battle with multiple systems atrophy (MSA), a rare form of Parkinson's Disease. Born in Philadelphia, Kerry was raised in Seattle prior to the family settling outside of Chicago. Kerry's culinary passion and curiosity was sparked as he experimented preparing recipes from a Julia Child cookbook after working shifts, flipping pizzas at Little Caesar's alongside friend and co-worker Bill Murray. Working hard, Kerry received a scholarship to attend the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, NY. Upon graduation, Kerry worked under such culinary luminaries as Jean-Jacque Rachou, Andre Soltner and Jean-Georges Vongerichten. But it was at Donald and Ivana Trump's New York Plaza Hotel, in the Edwardian Room kitchen, that the Chef first achieved his own fame thanks to the countless celebrities he served at his private table inside his kitchen. It was a phenomenon; Rock 'n' Roll royalty loved Kerry's food. Kerry is survived by his brothers Glen, Doug, Scott and nieces, Meg Santoro and Sophie Sue Simon. A memorial celebrating the life of Kerry Simon, Chef, friend and one of the kindest human beings in the world is planned for October 18th, 2015 in Las Vegas. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to the Kerry Simon Fight MSA fund at Cleveland Clinic Lou Ruvo Center for Brain Health. www.keepmemoryalive.org/ways--to--contribute/ opportunities--to--give/donate 1/3

BING--Alexander III "Sandy," 84, passed away at home after a brief but difficult fight with lung cancer on September 12, 2015. Sandy was born and lived in New York City. He attended Dalton and Lincoln Schools, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Middlebury College and received a Masters degree in American History from Columbia University. As a member of the United States Army, he served in France and Germany after WWII. Sandy was a partner and Director of Research at L.F. Rothschild, and later worked at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in fixed income research. During his career, he was ranked by Institutional Investor as a top research analyst. In 1972, he married Cynthia Eaton Bing, education and environmental philanthropist, and together they raised four children. Sandy supported numerous non-profit organizations and served as president of two co-op boards. He was treasurer and board member of the Friends of the Upper Delaware River and was instrumental in an effort led by River Network that saved a stretch of the Madison River (Montana) from real estate development. He spent his summers in Montana where he broke his own horse at 16, worked as a wrangler at 20, and shoed his horses into his 60s. Mostly, he loved to go on long, rugged horseback rides with his family. His passion and excellence as a fly fisherman was rivaled only by his ability to build handcrafted, Queen Anne style, fine furniture. Throughout his life he was an avid basketball and baseball player, often found on the hardscrabble fields of Central Park. Sandy's parents, Matilda S. and Alexander S. Bing; wife, Cynthia E. Bing; daughter, Abigail R. Bing; and former wife, Elisabeth G. Bing predeceased him. He is survived by son, Alexander M. Bing; daughters, Cynthia K. Bing and Virginia G. Bing; son-in-law, Michael Padial; and granddaughter, Eloise B. Padial. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave. at 3pm, October 16, 2015 with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Friends of the Upper Delaware River (FUDR.org) and/or EarlySteps.org. 1/3

CAVALIERO--Isaac. Incredible husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother, and friend. He lived the definition of the American dream, arriving in the United States in 1962 with his wife Jeanine and their two daughters, with a son born soon after. His kindness, charisma and strength of will made a profound impact on everyone he met and built relationships that lasted across continents and decades. He clung fast to his Jewish faith and heritage with unwavering faith in God, and his love for his family laid the foundation for many generations. He is survived by a large, close-knit family grateful for all he has done and for the legacy he leaves behind: children Joyce Horowitz, Tanya and Russ Mandor, Johnny and Mindy Cavaliero, grandchildren Ian and Fara Horowitz, Craig and Jen Horowitz, Jamie and Adam Glassman, Samantha Mandor, Ari, Amanda and Jesse Cavaliero, and great- grandchildren Casey, Shane, Hannah, and Alexa Horowitz. We will always love you. 1/3

He was both generous and kind to the special kids and families battling cancer at the Ronald McDonald House. Our sincere sympathy and deepest condolences go out to the entire Belson family. SADOWSKY--Patricia, 73. Beloved daughter of Marjory and Charles. Burial, Sunday, September 20 at 11:30am, Mt. Carmel, Glendale, NY. www.PhynesFamily.info 1/3

STUEBE--William, died peacefully at his home in Savannah, GA on September 14, 2015, surrounded by his family. He had been diagnosed with metastatic melanoma in June. Bill was born in Manhasset, NY on May 8, 1941, to Alma and William Stuebe. He was graduated from Lehigh University in 1963 and spent more than 30 years in New York in commercial real estate. His passion, however, was for residential real estate and historic preservation. In 1998, he and his wife Isabel moved to Savannah, where he helped to initiate the redevelopment of Broughton Street. He became actively involved in the Historic Savannah Foundation, working to ensure that new projects honored the scale and spirit of historic Savannah. Bill is survived by his wife of 49 years, Isabel C. Stuebe; his daughter Alison Stuebe and her husband Geoffrey Green of Chapel Hill, NC; his son, David Stuebe, and his wife, Shira Hirshberg of Providence, Rhode Island; and his four grandchildren, Noah Green, Samuel Green, Max Green, and Ayla Stuebe. Services will be held at St. John's Episcopal Church in Savannah on September 21 at 11am, followed by a reception at the Green-Meldrim House. A private family burial will be held at Bonaventure Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, the family has requested contributions be made to the William H. Stuebe fund at Historic Savannah Foundation, 321 E York St, Savannah, GA 31401. http://j.mp/WHS-HSF 1/3

NOBLE--William L. August 22, 1932 - September 15, 2015. Resident of New York City and Wainscott, NY. Graduate of The Lawrenceville School and Columbia University. THOMAN--Dr. Richard S. (1919-2015) was born near Lamar, Colorado, married Evelyn Zumwalt on November 28th, 1942; and passed away last Wednesday at the age of 96. Reared on a primitive dust bowl farm in Lamar, Dick won gold medals in statewide scholarship contests in high school. He built a nest in the trees where he was able to both study for these exams and also attend to the cattle on the farm. He received his BA and MA from University of Boulder, CO; and his PHD (Geography) from University of Chicago. With his wife Evelyn, his lifelong colleague/editor as well as mate, he authored and edited 20 books, numerous articles and reviews. In 1967, he became the province of Ontario's first Director of Regional Planning and Development. He taught Geography at University of Colorado, University of Maine in Gorham, University of Missouri, University of Chicago, University of Nebraska Omaha, Northwestern, Queens (Canada), and Cal State, Hayward. He started a new Dept of Geography at Omaha, and conducted a distance learning TV program there-- in which he was "better than [popular competing TV program] The Hawk!" according to one young viewer who once recognized him to his delight. Dick is survived by his son G. Richard Thoman, six grandchildren Camille, Alexis, Kylie, Max, Amy and Eric; three great-grandchildren Breier, Georgia and Mac, nieces Kim, Lila, Marta, Lynda; nephews Roger, Eric, John, Perry, Howard; and numerous other relatives with whom he was constantly involved. Timothy W Tillman, who joined the Thoman household, lived in Raymond, MA until is death in 2005. He has two sons Nathan and Austin. Wry, brilliant, generous, irascible, eloquent, a man of social conscience, a go-getter, a man with a strong sense of family-- practical, poetic and funny. He wished to be remembered like this "he lived profitably, not monetarily, but intellectually". 1/3

CHENEY--Richard E.,"Dick" A prominent figure in the mergers and acquisitions of major companies in the 1960s-1980s, died September 2 at home in New York City after a long illness. He was 94. Dick was born in Pana, IL and graduated from Knox College in Galesburg, IL. He was a Naval Lieutenant JG in World War II serving in the mine- sweeper fleet in the Pacific. He later attended the University of Chicago. Moving to New York, he worked for a group of mutual funds, then Mobil Oil, and ultimately Hill & Knowlton, a public relations firm where he helped many companies ward off takeovers and rose to become Chairman. During his business career, Dick went to school at night to study psychoanalysis. He obtained his license as a psychoanalyst in both New York and Vermont, charging patients only what they could afford. Survivors include his wife, Virginia, their children, Benjamin and Annie, his children from his first marriage, Christopher and Elyn MacInnis, his sons- in-law, Peter MacInnis and Benjamin Bailes, and four grandchildren, Mika and Charlotte MacInnis and Louise and Helen Bailes. A memorial service will be held in New York City on October 14. Donations may be made to Knox College or to a charity of your choice. 1/3

WINICK--Ina. Loving and devoted wife, mother, grandmother, and sister, Dr Ina Esther Hodes Winick, a longtime resident of Hastings-on-Hudson, NY, died on September 13, 2015 after a year-long illness. Born in 1936 in St. Joseph, Missouri, she grew up in Kansas City and was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of the University of Colorado, where she met her New Jersey-born husband, to whom she was married for 57 years. Ina Winick was the wife of Eugene Winick of Hastings-on-Hudson, mother of Janet Winick Rubinstein of Mareil- Marly, France, Leigh Ann Winick of Hastings-on-Hudson, and Elizabeth Winick Rubinstein of Scarsdale, grandmother to David, Daniel, and Dalia Rubinstein, Gabriel and Eli Pinkus, and Ava Rubinstein. She was the sister of Phil Hodes and Dr. Herb Hodes, both of Leawood Kansas. Dr Winick earned both her Masters Degree and her Doctor of Philosophy Educational Psychology degree from the City University of New York. She worked for several local school systems. She was a past director of the Community Nursery School in Dobbs Ferry, and the school psychologist in the Henrick Hudson school district in Westchester, NY. Retiring from education in 2001, she then worked with her husband at his literary agency in New York City, McIntosh & Otis, Inc. A resident of Hastings-on-Hudson since 1968, Ina Winick had a zest for life and a keen interest in people of all ages and backgrounds. She was beloved for her kind, gentle, generous, and caring nature, and her passion for her community, family, and Temple Beth Shalom in Hastings. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that any gifts or donations be made to AIPAC or Gilda's Club Westchester. 1/3

GINSBURGH-- Gail Winslow. Age 85, of Naples, FL, Bethesda, MD, and Rehoboth Beach, DE, died peacefully on September 12, 2015 at Beebe Healthcare, Lewes, DE. She was born on December 2, 1929 in Baltimore, MD, daughter of the late Allen and Carolyn (Myers) Whitehead. After attending Radcliffe College, she married Alan F. Winslow, a Central Intelligence Agency officer. Her second marriage in 1959 was to Robert N. Ginsburgh, an Air Force officer who went on to serve as an aide to President John F. Kennedy and President Lyndon Johnson and retired as a major general. In 1956, she joined Ferris & Company, a Washington, DC based brokerage and investment bank as a secretary and "Gal Friday." She was a pioneer in a male-dominated industry. After passing the Securities and Exchange Commission exam, she became a successful stockbroker. According to a 1958 newspaper headline, "in a man's world, Gail Winslow is a financial whiz." In recognition of her growing stature on Wall Street, the New York Stock Exchange invited her to visit the all-male trading floor. Until then, the exchange had issued only two other invitations to women - the widow of former President Calvin Coolidge and the actress Tallulah Bankhead. She rose swiftly through Ferris & Company and was admitted as a general partner in 1965. In 1977 Gail was appointed Vice Chairman. In the 1990s, the firm's successor, Ferris Baker Watts, Inc. registered a seat on the New York Stock Exchange in her name in honor of her service. After the Royal Bank of Canada acquired the firm in 2008, she was appointed Senior Vice President - Financial Advisor, a position she held at the time of her death. She served on the boards of many charitable and educational institutions, including Trinity College in Hartford, CT; the Choral Arts Society of Washington; WETA, Washington's public television station; Washington Area Tennis Patrons Foundation and the YWCA. Mrs. Ginsburgh was also a member of the Maryland State Advisory Committee to the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. In 2008, Heritage University in Toppenish, WA established the Gail Winslow Ginsburgh Scholarship. She was a passionate world traveler, sports fan, and an avid bridge player who in 2013 became a Life Master. She is survived by six children: Alan Winslow III of San Francisco; R. Brand Ginsburgh of Annapolis, MD; William Winslow of Reston, VA; C. Lee Ginsburgh of Williamsburg, VA; Carolyn Grant-Suttie of Potomac, MD; and Anne Rosenau of Washington. She is also survived by six grandchildren: Hickory Ginsburgh of Redondo Beach, CA; Katherine Grant- Suttie of Seattle; Catherine Winslow of Boston; Ian Grant-Suttie of Denver; Grant Gins- burgh and Trevor Ginsburgh, both of Williamsburg; and William Rosenau of Washington; and by two great-grandchildren, Millie and Chloe Ginsburgh of Redondo Beach, CA. A Celebration of Life will be held on Friday, September 25, 2015 at 4pm at St. Columba's Episcopal Church in Washington, DC. Services by Parsell Funeral Homes & Crematorium, Atkins-Lodge Chapel, Lewes, DE. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to the Wounded Warrior Project, P.O. Box 758517, Topeka, Kansas 66675 or www. woundedwarriorproject.org Please visit Gail's Life Memorial webpage and sign her online guestbook at www. parsellfuneralhomes.com. 1/3

BOBST--Mamdouha. Mamdouha El-Sayed Bobst, 90, passed away peacefully in her New York City apartment, surrounded by family and friends. Former UN delegate, public health advocate, distinguished philanthropist. Born in Tripoli, Lebanon in 1925, she graduated from The American University of Beirut in 1947 and earned a Masters in Public Health education from UC Berkeley a few years later. Brilliant, charismatic and fearless, she began her career in Libya, where she worked as a health advisor to the government, and helped develop their national public health program. Soon after, she was appointed as a Lebanese delegate to the United Nations, and was one of only a few females to assume such a post. In 1961, she married Elmer Bobst, a successful businessman and pharmaceutical executive who shared her interests in public health. He was a leader in the war on cancer, and a driving force behind former President Nixon's signing of the National Cancer Act in 1971. Together, Elmer and Mamdouha created The Bobst Foundation. Their first major joint contribution was The NYU Elmer Holmes Bobst Library, in 1973. After Elmer died in 1978, Mrs. Bobst took over as president of the foundation and continued its mission of and devotion to philanthropy, making numerous significant and transformative donations to the fields of medicine and health, education, social justice and animal welfare. While impossible to list all the generous activities of the Bobst Foundation, key beneficiaries include: New York University; NYU Langone Medical Center; Princeton University (The Mamdouha S. Bobst Center for Peace and Justice); The American University of Beirut (The Elmer and Mamdouha El-Sayed Bobst Chemistry Center); The American University of Beirut Medical Center (The Mamdouha El-Sayed Bobst Breast Unit); Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center (The Bobst International Center and The Bobst Pavilion); and The Animal Medical Center (The Elmer and Mamdouha Bobst Hospital). The Bobst Foundation has also donated generously throughout the years to the American Cancer Society and the ASPCA. Mrs. Bobst set up numerous scholarship funds for several universities across the world, as well as fellowship programs throughout various medical colleges. Whether it concerned social justice issues or cancer research, The Bobst Foundation fostered alliances between global institutions to encourage active dialogue and exchange of ideas. Mrs. Bobst was a woman of great humility and faith, who adopted and lived American values while never forgetting her homeland, Lebanon. She will be dearly missed by her friends and family for her wisdom, work ethic, generosity, and relentless dedication to changing the world. She will be forever remembered for the thousands of people she helped to educate, and the thousands of lives that she helped to save. May she and her beloved husband Elmer, now united, rest in peace. Mrs. Bobst is survived by one brother, three sisters, many nieces and nephews, and extended family living all around the world. 1/3

CYNAMON--Victor. It is with profound sadness that we observe the passing of Victor Cynamon our dearest friend for nearly sixty years. May Victor's memory bring strength and comfort to his beloved wife Celia; children Diana, Paul, Harry, and Marilyn; grandchildren Amy, Tara, Jeremy and Shane; and great-grandchildren. We lived as business partners and neighbors since 1957. In Huntington, Roslyn and Aventura our homes were always nearly side by side. 'The Wagner's and Cynamons' were often said as one name with either Victor or Ruby referred to as 'The Partner'. Twice weekly card games, Catskill vacations and every family simcha or loss were observed together as we grew up as family. Victor led by example as a Jew and Holocaust Survivor lessons from which we learned. His vision for and work to create The Holocaust Museum at Aventura Turnberry Jewish Center will be a fitting tribute to him and his work for generations to come. By his efforts Victor fulfilled his Father's wish that he survive to bear witness to the unimaginable. We have lost a great friend. Our prayers are with The Cynamon's. Harry and Myra Leon and Leesa The Wagner, Blum, and Lewin Families. 1/3

OZER--Harvey, M.D. Dr. Ozer died at home after a long illness, on Rosh Hashanah, year 5776, at age 77. His wife will not sit Shiva, due to the high holiday. Also survived by the whole extended Ozer family, Zitomorsky family; and by the Gaston-Reilly and Thompson family members. BOBST--Mamdouha El-Sayed. The Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center community mourns the loss of Mamdouha El-Sayed Bobst, a farsighted friend and emerita member of the MSK Board of Overseers who inspired us with her deep commitment to the health and well-being of others. Together with her husband, the late Elmer Bobst, she played a leading role in the fight against cancer, and through her generosity and that of the Elmer and Mamdouha Bobst Foundation she has supported efforts to set a new global standard for understanding and treating the disease. Over the past decade she and the Bobst Foundation have funded innovative collaborations between MSK and the American University of Beirut, and, in 2009, MSK was honored to establish the Elmer and Mamdouha El-Sayed Bobst International Center to provide services to patients from abroad who come to MSK for treatment. The work that Dodo Bobst has made possible at MSK will have an enduring impact, and we extend our sincere condolences to her family. Douglas A. Warner III Chairman, Boards of Overseers and Managers; Craig B. Thompson, M.D. President and CEO 1/3

BOBST--Mamdouha. The NYU community mourns the death of our good friend, Mamdouha S. Bobst, a Life Trustee of NYU and the NYU Langone Medical Center. Educated at some of the world's finest universities, she was a social scientist and public health specialist who worked with the World Health Organization. A member of the Lebanese delegation to the United Nations, she was a recipient of the Medal of the Order of Cedars of Lebanon and the World Rehabilitation Fund Award. She and her husband helped establish NYU's Elmer Holmes Bobst Library, a pivotal moment in the University's modern history because it finally provided NYU with a main library equal to its aspirations as a research university, and it has been the heart of the campus ever since. Throughout her association with NYU, she was the Library's wise counselor and dedicated supporter, in later years making possible its modernization and the expansion of its collection. Her love of the written word led her to establish the Elmer Holmes Bobst Award in Arts and Letters and the Mamdouha S. Bobst Book Endowment Fund. A recipient of NYU's Presidential Medal and our Albert Gallatin Medal, a supporter not only of our Library but also our School of Law, our School of Medicine, and NYU Langone Medical Center, Dodo will long be remembered for her devotion to NYU, her intelligence, and her charm. The legacy she leaves helped shape the university we know today. Her loved ones are in our thoughts and our hearts on this sorrowful day. Martin Lipton, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President 1/3

CASHIN--Gail. 1955-2015. Gail died peacefully September 16, 2015, at the age of 59, with family by her side after a three year battle with cancer. Gail is survived by her brother John (Deni) and sister Gillian MacPherson (Bruce). She was Super Aunt Gail to Kaili, Greg, Lindsay and Sarah. She is predeceased by parents Jim and Joan Cashin. Gail led a fascinating and unorthodox life full of travels, managing to visit 85+ countries in her life, including a three year trans-African adventure. She was an accountant by training (CMA). For 20+ years Gail combined her love of travel with her career, working for international aid organizations such as the United Nations (UN) and the International Rescue Committee (IRC). She enjoyed living in and exploring the countries where she lived and worked, such as Afghanistan, Bosnia, Indonesia and Thailand. Gail had a unique ability to touch people in a special way and leave a lasting impression. She is described as a mentor, teacher and shining star by her extended family at the International Rescue Committee. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Canadian Breast Cancer Foundation are appreciated. A celebration of her life will be held September 26 in Aurora, ON. 1/3

FLOCKEN--P. Jay. Paul Jay Flocken, 86, died peacefully at home in Stratford, Connecticut August 16, surrounded with family, after a three year battle with cancer. Jay was born and raised in Lebanon, Pennsylvania, where he married his high school sweetheart, Polly Berkheiser. He died one month shy of their 68th anniversary. Jay graduated in 1951 from Lebanon Valley College, Annville, Pennsylvania. He worked for McGraw- Hill in Washington, DC from 1951-1960 as a reporter for Business Week, where he covered legal and court affairs and regulatory agencies, while putting himself through George Washington University Law School, from which he received an LLB in 1956. He served as a trial attorney at the U.S. Department of Justice, Antitrust Division from 1960-1963, where he litigated several major bank merger cases. Jay joined the New York office of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft in 1963, where he was a partner from 1965-1983. In addition to litigation and antitrust, Jay's practice included over 35 bank mergers and acquisitions, U.S. and international regulated industries and intellectual property. Following his retirement from Cadwalader, Jay worked for Ingersoll-Rand supervising trade regulation and general litigation for the company. He served several terms on the Session of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church, where he and Polly were active for decades. Jay was known for his keen intellect, sense of humor, warmth and generosity. He was predeceased by his son, Jed, Harrisburg, PA. He is survived by his wife, Polly; his daughter and son-in-law, Ann and George Wilbanks, Westport, CT and his greatest delights - his grandchildren, Elizabeth Grace and George Alexander Wilbanks, Los Angeles and Santa Cruz, CA, respectively. Memorials would be welcome in memory of Jay to Lebanon Valley College, in support of scholarships: Advancement Office, 101 No. College Ave., Annvile, PA 17003. 1/3

GOLDFELD--Robert (Bob), died on September 17, 2015 in New York City at the age of 75. Bob attended Midwood High School, Columbia College and Harvard Law School. He devoted his life to making the world a better place through his work in city and state government, The Vera Institute for Justice, The Federation of Jewish Philanthropies and New York University, where he spent 20 years as Vice President for Administration. He was loved and respected by his friends and colleagues for his kindness, intelligence, integrity and humor. He enjoyed traveling with his wife but was happiest being with her at his home in Goshen, Connecticut. He is survived by his loving wife Carole, daughter Johanna and son-in-law Bradley Rank. He deeply loved his family, who adored him and will keep him in their hearts forever. A funeral will be held on Sunday, September 20 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the Leukemia & Lymphoma Society or WMNR radio in Monroe, Connecticut. 1/3

GROSS--Leonard B. Passed away peacefully at home in Fort Lee, New Jersey, on September 14, 2015, aged 80. WINICK--Dr. Charles. The City College of New York mourns the passing of its alumni Charles Winick, Class of 1941. Dr. Winick was professor emeritus of the sociology department in the Colin Powell School for Civic and Global Leadership. He also taught at the CUNY Graduate Center. His writings touched on some of the most provocative issues of his time, including shifting gender roles, drug addiction, and a variety of world cultures as well as the communities near his New York office. He was among one of the first sociologists to study the process of detoxification, emphasizing the experience of going "cold turkey." Dr. Winick helped define the academic work of social sciences at City College and in the department of sociology. On behalf of City College, we extend our sincerest condolences to the Winick family. Lisa S. Coico, President 1/3

BELSON--Jerome, Beloved brother of Victor and loving uncle of Jeff and Susan, Ken and Harumi, Elizabeth, Jared and Emma. You will be remembered by many, including the two Sandys. We miss you and will always remember you in our hearts. 1/3

MUGGEO--Sam. Graphics Arts Designer died on September 12, 2015. He lived in New York and had been in advertising for over 35 years. Sam was loved very much and will be solely missed. 1/3

CARDOZO--Danforth, Jr.,a long time resident of Weston, Connecticut, died September 13, 2015. Born in New York City, May 4, 1924, son of Danforth and Constance (Mordecai) Cardozo, he was graduated from Friends Seminary, 1941 and received his Sc.B from Brown University, class of 1945. He served as an Engineering, Watch and Division Officer, P.F. and P.A. Divisions, in the U.S. Navy during the Second World War aboard the battleship USS Indiana in the Pacific, participating in six campaigns. He was an industrial designer and worked with Norman Bel Geddes, Egmont Arens, Lippincott & Margulies, Walter Dorwin Teague (where he was an associate), and Saphier, Lerner, Schindler. He was Director of Corporate Industrial Design at Pitney Bowes, Inc., and a life member of the Industrial Designers Society of America. He was a long time member of the Cedar Point Yacht Club in Westport, Connecticut, where he sailed Snipe class boats in the late 30s and Lightnings in the 80s. He was a member of the Stamford Rotary and a Paul Harris Fellow. He was predeceased by his sister, Nancy Cardozo Cowles. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Ann (Lynch), his sons John and Danforth, III, their spouses, and four granddaughters. 1/3

STAMEY--Thomas A.,MD. Professor Emeritus of Urology at Stanford University School of Medicine and a noted leader in the study and treatment of prostate cancer, died Friday, September 4, 2015, at his home in Portola Valley, CA. He was 87. At Stanford, Stamey developed the PSA blood test for prostate cancer and helped transform urology and surgery from purely clinical fields to research fields. In 1989 he became the first urologist ever elected to the Institute of Medicine. He was also named an honorary fellow of the Royal College of Surgeons of Edinburgh. "He was truly one of the giants in academic urology, with his biggest impact in prostate cancer. His research formed the basis of much of what we know about prostate cancer today. He trained over 100 residents and fellows, many of whom went on to be leaders in urology in their own right. His permanent influence in the field is assured", stated Eila Skinner, MD, professor and chair of Urology at Stanford. Born in North Carolina in 1928, he worked with his parents in their general store as a young boy, going on to attend Virgina Military Institute for two years then graduating from Vanderbilt University. Medical training was at Johns Hopkins University where he earned his MD, did his internship and urology residency. He served on the faculty there from 1958 to 196l, (after serving two years as Urological Consultant for the United States Air Force in the United Kingdom). In 196l he was recruited to Stanford University School of Medicine to serve as Chairman of Urology, a position he held for 33 years. One of his great achievements there was to make one year of research in the laboratory a requirement of the resident's training, which was almost unique compared to many other parts of the country. "People talk about translational medicine now, but we were doing it back then. That research focus was the reason", stated Linda Shortliffe, MD, a resident from 1977 to 1981. Stamey authored or co- authored more than 225 scientific papers, four books, 30 textbook chapters and seven monographs. Among many other awards, he received the Hugh Hampton Young award and the Ramon Guiteras Award from the American Urological Association and the Valentine Award from the New York Academy of Medicine. He was a resident scholar at the Rockefeller Foundation Study and Conference Center in Bellagio, Italy, and had a sabbatical year at Oxford University, England. Many former residents, when hearing of Dr. Stamey's death commented on their memories of their training, and of still hearing his soft, but authoritative, North Carolina accented voice (not very common in the West) even today while working in the operating room, or sometimes in their sleep. Dr. Stamey was devoted to his family and is survived by his wife Kathryn, and children Frederick, Charline (Douty), Alex, Theron (Cooper) and Allison. 1/3

BACON--Varick, died September 11 with his loving wife of 52 years, Mary Jane, at his bedside. A daughter, Alexandra Bacon, a niece Brent Brookfield Loyer and nephew Montgomery Brookfield also survive him. After graduating Harvard in 1955, he worked in New York and San Francisco in the financial world as Research Director and Portfolio Manager. Upon retiring in 2001, he returned to his first love composing music for theater and cabaret. His work has been performed in New York and other cities. Varick will be greatly missed by his many friends. 1/3

REGNIER--Jerome. 88, died September 13. Beloved husband of Nita Regnier, brother of Lalie Oudin, and father of daughters Emmy, Julie, Henny, Felicie and Melanie. Born September 5, 1927 in Listrac, France, he taught geology at Bryn Mawr, Wellesley, and Vassar Colleges. Endowed with an infectious curiosity, he created innumerable artistic works including family cabins, catamarans, a Japanese house, large tapestries, and natural gardens. Through his many talents and interests he has left Nita, his girls, and ten grandchildren a wealth of riches. Donations in Jerome's memory may be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America, www.plannedparenthood.org or The Nature Conservancy, www.nature.org. 1/3

BOBST--Mamdouha. The trustees, faculty, and staff of NYU Langone Medical Center are deeply saddened by the death of Mamdouha "Dodo" Bobst, a Life Trustee of NYU Langone Medical Center. Mamdouha Bobst and the Elmer and Mamdouha Bobst Foundation have supported the Emergency Department and established the Mamdouha S. Bobst Professorship in Internal Medicine. Mrs. Bobst was a social scientist and public health specialist. She spent three years in Libya on behalf of the World Health Organization as a public health consultant. There, she founded a school of nursing and developed a public health program. In 1960, she was appointed a member of the Lebanese delegation to the United Nations. She has also been honored with the Medal of the Order of Cedars of Lebanon. Our sincerest condolences go out to the family and friends of Mamdouha Bobst. Kenneth G. Langone, Chair, Board of Trustees, and Robert I. Grossman, MD, Dean and CEO 1/3

MAGINNIS--Silvia Porzio. Silvia died suddenly at home in New York City on September 15, she was 70. Born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Silvia came to the US in 1964 to study. She graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson and Georgetown Universities. Silvia joined the United Nations in 1968 and served as a simultaneous interpreter until her retirement in 2005. She is survived by her husband, Thomas P. Maginnis, her brother, Mario Porzio, her daughter and son-in-law, Veronica L. Maginnis and Richard Erwine, her two grandchildren, James and Pia, her son and daughter-in-law, Thomas C. Maginnis and Ellen Carey, and beloved nieces, nephews and family. A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, September 21 from 4-7pm. A mass of Christian burial will be held at St. Thomas More at 65 East 89th Street on Tuesday, September 22 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund in Silvia's memory. 1/3

ASNIS--Deborah S.,MD. Deborah S. Asnis, MD, 59, passed away at 11:30am, September 12, 2015 in the presence of her loved ones. Dr. Asnis was Director of Infectious Disease at Flushing Hospital Medical Center and discovered the first US outbreak of West Nile Virus in 1999. Thanks to her quick action, public officials took aggressive precautions against the spread of the virus. On December 8, 2007, she was inducted into the New York City Hall of Fame for Health and Science. Dr. Asnis was also an HIV specialist and prolific clinical researcher, publishing over 35 articles in her career. She was beloved by her residents, nursing staff, and patients. At home, Debbie was devoted to her family. She loved traveling the world with her husband, going to the theater with her children, and being with her mother. She played tennis and piano, delighted in art and culture. Her smile always lit the room. She was committed to education, self-improvement, and the happiness of her loved ones. Debbie's intelligence was matched with beauty, quick wit, and exquisite fashion sense. She was as kind and concerned for the health of others as she was strong and driven in her own life. She leaves behind a loving husband, Dr. Hal Kazdin, sons Joshua and Matthew, brother Dr. Greg Asnis, and mother Ruth. The world is a poorer place without her. Donations may be made in Debbie's memory to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation (www.bcrfcure.org). 1/3

WONHAM--Ann Brunie, of Vero Beach, Florida, and formerly Stamford, Connecticut, died peacefully in the Adirondacks on September 14, of complications from Parkinson's Disease. An avid bridge player and teacher, tennis and paddle tennis player, and a low handicap golfer, she brought, fun, laughter, and a love of competition and of friends, whom she adored, to every game and match she played. Ann grew up in New York City, graduated from the Brearley School in 1950, and was a member of the class of 1954 of Smith College. She was a former president of the Women's Westchester and Fairfield County Golf Association, and a member of the board of the Fresh Air Fund of New York for a number of years. She is survived by her devoted husband of 62 years, Frederick S. Wonham, her daughter Stapley Emberling (David) of Weston, Connecticut, her son Henry B. Wonham. (Connie) of Eugene, OR, and her younger son Lincoln Wonham of Lake Forest, IL, as well as her sister Susan Hughes of Vero Beach (Ed) and formerly Greenwich, Connecticut, and her half-brother Charles (Rex) Hubbard (Libby) of Huntington, L.I. She also leaves seven dearly loved grandchildren: Anna Emory Wonham, Henry Grant and Walker Lincoln Wonham, Ryan and Rachel Emberling, and Jack and Cal Wonham. With Annie at every step since 1998, her beloved Tiger lives on. 1/3

ULLMAN--Katherine Kiernan, 90, passed away peacefully at home in Orange, NJ on September 19, 2015 surrounded by family. The Funeral Mass is at Our Lady of Sorrows Church, 217 Prospect St., South Orange, NJ on Wednesday, September 23, 2015 at 10:30am. Burial at Gate of Heaven Cemetery, East Hanover, NJ. Visitation at Preston Funeral Home, 153 South Orange Ave., South Orange, NJ on Tuesday 3-5 and 7-9pm. Kate Ullman was from Maplewood, NJ. Graduated Manhattanville College, and received a graduate degree from the Art School of Pratt Institute. In 1948, she was awarded a scholarship to the first class at the Institute Pius XII Graduate School of Fine Arts for American Women in Florence, Italy. Married to David Ullman in 1954, she lived in Orange for 60 years, raising eight children and travelling with her husband in the US and overseas. She is survived by her husband David, her eight children: David Jr., Liz Grun (Paul), Katy, Diana, Daphne, Douglas (Karen), Geoffrey (Emily) and Richard (Lorie), nine grandchildren, her brother, Brother Robert Kiernan, OSB and sister, Anne Kiernan Fasulo. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Benedictine Monks of Weston Priory, 58 Priory Hill Rd, Weston, VT 05161. 1/3

ADLER--Elsie. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our longtime devoted member, Elsie Adler. With her loved ones, we share the grief of loss and bereavement. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger as a legacy to her life and be a comfort to those who mourn her passing. 1/3

PAUL--William, M.D. The Board of Directors and staff of the Lupus Research Institute (LRI) deeply mourn the death of Dr. William "Bill" Paul, our beloved friend and esteemed scientific leader in the journey toward better treatment, prevention and a cure for the devastating autoimmune disease, lupus. Chief of the Laboratory of Immunology and former director of the Office of AIDS Research at the National Institutes of Health, Dr. Paul generously shared his broad scientific vision and his depth of understanding of immunology as chairman of the LRI Scientific Advisory Board since our organization's inception in 2000. Over the past 15 years, Dr. Bill Paul's leadership and knowledge of the challenges required to achieve advances in a complex disease gave the lupus community--patients, families and scientists--the confidence and courage to be bold, the inspiration to take a different path, to not shy away from big ideas, and to pursue the very best in scientific innovation. And with Bill behind us, the discoveries flowed. Dr. Bill Paul's worldwide impact on biomedical research and on lupus is enormous. Our profound sadness at losing him and our deep gratitude for his time among us strengthens our determination to fulfill his vision for the science of the future. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to Bill's wife Marilyn, his children and all his family. 1/3

MORIARTY--Janet. "El Ultimo Adios." Glastonbury, CT, Associate Professor Emerita at the University of Connecticut, daughter of Gladys Lagan and Thomas Moriarty and stepdaughter of Alice Moriarty, passed on September 17, 2015. She survived 82 birthdays! Janet taught at Lauralton Hall, East Hartford Schools and West Georgia College, and enjoyed a long career at UConn/West Hartford and Storrs, retiring (jubilacion!) in 1997. "She never met a verb she didn't like." She earned a BA, MA, and PhD at UConn and studied at University of San Francisco in Valencia and University of Madrid. She leaves siblings Timothy, Thomas, Ted, and Judith. Her favorite place: Dunquin, Dingle, County Kerry, Ireland, home of grandfather, Timothy. Her reading favorite: Don Quixote. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome. Builder, lawyer, philanthropist, visionary, sportsman, devoted friend, loving family man and larger than life personality. All of these labels describe Jerry Belson, who passed away peacefully on Thursday, September 17 surrounded by his family. He lived many lifetimes in his 90 years, working his entire life to improve the lives of others through the thousands of apartments he helped build and maintain, to the many charities he supported, to the numerous industry groups and companies he led and advised, to the endless advice and support he provided to family and friends. His wide and varied circle of friends and colleagues were testament to a life spent working in and for the community. He helped build affordable housing across the city and Jerome Belson Associates was a leading manager of apartments. He served on boards as varied as Waterhouse Securities, a leading discount broker, to the Doe Fund, a non-profit group dedicated to helping formerly homeless men and women become self-sufficient, to St. John's University. A long-time congregant at Temple Beth Emeth in Brooklyn, he was also chairman of the United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, a trustee of the National Jewish Fund, Handicapped Boy Scouts and the Disabled and Alone/Life Services for the Handicapped, Inc. Motivated by their son, Tad, Jerry and Maxine, his late wife of 55 years, helped create New Hope Community in Loch Sheldrake, NY, to promote the independence of people with intellectual disabilities. He worked tirelessly for St. John's University as a trustee for more than 20 years, forever thankful for the law degree and the honorary doctorate he earned there. Tad provided the idea for Belson Stadium, a soccer stadium on the St. John's campus. Jerome and Maxine Belson Hall, which houses the School of Law and the Belson Moot Courtroom, speak to Jerry's enduring commitment to law and his alma mater. He played an outsized role as a family patriarch. Predeceased by Maxine and son Michael (Kathy), he is survived by his son Tad, daughter Brianne (Sanford), brother Victor and grandchildren Matthew (Jodi), Joshua (Katy), Jaclyn, Toby, and Jonathan, and three great grandchildren Noah, Ariel, and Paisley, and many cousins, nieces and nephews. Born and raised in Brooklyn, Jerry graduated from Lafayette High School and enrolled in Brooklyn College. After a stint in the U.S. Army during and after World War II, he graduated from St. John's Law School in 1948. Working as an assistant corporation counsel for the city, he helped prosecute racketeers. From an early age, Jerry had a gift for getting things done. In his 20s, he worked with the Knights Before Christmas to help underprivileged children, built clubhouses for the Boys' Club, helped war veterans and was director of an old age home. After entering private practice, at the behest of his father, Joseph, who became the president of the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen of America, he worked in real estate. His first development, in Brooklyn in 1952, was affordable housing for soldiers returning home. He went on to create 25,000 more apartments in the city, all non- profit co-ops. From 1955 to 2005, Jerry managed 50,000 apartments through Jerome Belson Associates. His relationships with members of federal, state and city agencies led to his involvement in Mitchell-Lama housing and noteworthy projects such as Roosevelt Island in Queens, Concourse Village in the Bronx and Jamie Towers, named after his son, Jamie Tad. Because of his friendship with President John F. Kennedy, Jerry went on five mission trips with the American Institute for Free Labor Development to Mexico, Nicaragua, Brazil and Columbia to create non-profit housing there. He worked for decades with the Associated Builders and Owners of Greater New York, Inc., eventually becoming and winning the Fred C. Trump Award for lifetime achievement. He was the first person from New York City to be inducted into the New York State Builders Association Hall of Fame. He started We Media, a magazine devoted to people with disabilities, built a bakery that employed the disabled in Maine, and traveled to Rome with the St. John's 1996 NCAA champion soccer team to meet His Holiness, Pope John Paul II. When honored by Rome as affiliates of the Vincentian community, Jerry and Maxine said they wanted their legacy to be simple: "That we cared." The funeral will be held Sunday September 20th at 12pm at Community Synagogue of Rye, 200 Forest Ave, Rye, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to New Hope Community, Inc., a home for people with developmental and intellectual disabilities. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome, Beloved brother of Victor and loving uncle of Jeff and Susan, Ken and Harumi, Elizabeth, Jared and Emma. You will be remembered by many, including the two Sandys. We miss you and will always remember you in our hearts. 1/3

CAVALIERO--Isaac. Incredible husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, brother, and friend. He lived the definition of the American dream, arriving in the United States in 1962 with his wife Jeanine and their two daughters, with a son born soon after. His kindness, charisma and strength of will made a profound impact on everyone he met and built relationships that lasted across continents and decades. He clung fast to his Jewish faith and heritage with unwavering faith in God, and his love for his family laid the foundation for many generations. He is survived by a large, close-knit family grateful for all he has done and for the legacy he leaves behind: children Joyce Horowitz, Tanya and Russ Mandor, Johnny and Mindy Cavaliero, grandchildren Ian and Fara Horowitz, Craig and Jen Horowitz, Jamie and Adam Glassman, Samantha Mandor, Ari, Amanda and Jesse Cavaliero, and great- grandchildren Casey, Shane, Hannah, and Alexa Horowitz. We will always love you. 1/3

BADER--Mildred, on September 19, 2015, age 89 of The Upper West Side. Beloved wife to the late Leo. Loving mother, aunt and grandmother. Longtime volunteer at The New York Public Library. Funeral services, Tuesday, 10:30am at the Wellwood Cemetery, Pinelawn, New York. 1/3

ADLER--Elsie. 1929-2015. Elsie passed away peacefully at her home in New York City early Sunday morning, September 20, at the age of 86, after a courageous two year battle with cancer, surrounded by her loving family, including her children, grandchildren, and her devoted partner of more than 25 years, Stuart Herman. She is survived by her son, James Adler, and by her three daughters, Barbara Adler, Susan Chapman, Elizabeth Wertheimer, and by grandchildren, Sara Jane, Max, Harry, Cameron, Gideon, Ruby, Nicholas, and Helena. She is also survived by her sister, Louise Sommers, stepbrother, Ronald Levite, devoted nieces and nephews, and by Stuart's daughters Lisa and Helen, and grandchildren, Meredith, David, and Ivy. Elsie was born in Straubing, Germany, from where she escaped at the age of seven. She was radiantly intelligent, gentle, warm, and generous, with a mischievous sense of humor and a beautiful smile. She offered her love and support to all of her family and friends, to whom she was devoted. She gave generously to numerous charities and to Temple Emanu-El, where she sought to honor her grandparents, who perished in the Holocaust. Elsie cherished time spent with Stuart at their home in Naples, Florida. Elsie was very much loved as a mother, a grandmother, sister, partner to Stuart, and aunt. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a favorite charity. Services will be on Monday, September 21, at 10:30am. At Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. 1/3
BELSON--Jerome. Condolences to our dearest friends Brianne and Sandy and the entire family. May you be comforted among the mourner in Zion. Penny and David 1/3

MAGINNIS--Silvia Porzio. Silvia died suddenly at home in New York City on September 15, she was 70. Born in Buenos Aires, Argentina, Silvia came to the US in 1964 to study. She graduated from Fairleigh Dickinson and Georgetown Universities. Silvia joined the United Nations in 1968 and served as a simultaneous interpreter until her retirement in 2005. She is survived by her husband, Thomas P. Maginnis, her brother, Mario Porzio, her daughter and son-in-law, Veronica L. Maginnis and Richard Erwine, her two grandchildren, James and Pia, her son and daughter-in-law, Thomas C. Maginnis and Ellen Carey, and beloved nieces, nephews and family. A wake will be held at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home at 1076 Madison Avenue on Monday, September 21 from 4-7pm. A mass of Christian burial will be held at St. Thomas More at 65 East 89th Street on Tuesday, September 22 at 10am. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund in Silvia's memory. 1/3

SUTHERLAND--William P.,died in August after a valiant display of the will to live. Cherished husband of Karen Luerssen. Beloved by sister Kathryn Sutherland, family and friends. Generous, loving, brilliant, funny, honest, stubborn, inquisitive, and a lifelong scholar. Gifted leader and CEO of Chapman Direct ad agency. A man who truly cared about people. Memorial service Saturday, 11am September 26 at Church of the Transfiguration. 1/3

CANDEMERES--Irene, on Sunday, September 20, 2015 died peacefully at the age of 96. Devoted wife of the late John Candemeres for 58 years and loving mother of Penelope Zangas and mother-in-law of Leonard Zangas. Cherished grandmother of Yelena Zangas, great-grandmother of Catherine Krahn, Ethan Krahn and of the youngest great-grandson, Adrian Thomas. Funeral service, 9am, Wednesday, September 23rd at the Archangel Michael Church, 100 Fairway Dr., Port Washington, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Archangel Michael Church. 1/3
ROOT--Dr. Leon. Dear ones, our thoughts and love are with you now. Carmel, Missy, Philippa & Jonathan 1/3

LIMPE--Anthony T.,of Greenwich, CT passed away peacefully on September 14th. Beloved husband of Emily and father of Stephen. Adored grandfather of Emily and Alexandra. Tony was an engineer and successful businessman, serving as the long-time Chairman of Petro-Chem Development. His integrity and generosity were without compare, and he will be dearly missed. Service to be held at Indian Harbor Yacht Club, 710 Steamboat Road, Greenwich, CT on Thursday, September 24th at 11:00am. Donations may be made in his memory to the Greenwich Library. 1/3

RINARD--Irven H. Professor emeritus of chemical engineering at City College, he passed unexpectedly on September 17. He was a dedicated trombonist and playwright and deeply committed to environmental causes and his many pets. A wonderful uncle, and valued brother, he was predeceased by his beloved wife Jacque. May they be together again. 1/3

ROOT--Leon, M.D. (June 15, 1929 - September 21, 2015) Dr. Leon Root, devoted husband, father, grandfather, orthopedic surgeon and role model to many, peacefully passed away on Monday, September 21 surrounded by loved ones. Dr. Root established Hospital for Special Surgery's pediatric service in 1972 and spent 25 years as Chief of Pediatric Orthopedics. He also was appointed President of the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine in 1988. He authored several books including No More Aching Back. In addition to his private practice, Dr. Root derived great pleasure and satisfaction from teaching residents and treating inner-city children with monthly visits to elementary schools throughout Manhattan and the Bronx through the hospital's Pediatric Orthopedic Outreach Program, or POP, which he founded in 1987. He was also the director of the HSS Department of Rehabilitation which lead to the Leon Root, M.D. Motion Analysis Laboratory, one of the most advanced in the country. He was the recipient of the Healthcare Chaplaincy's Wholeness of Life Award, and the Hospital for Special Surgery's first Lifetime Achievement Award. For his forty-plus years of service the medical wing of the United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County is named after him and he was recognized for his dedication to teaching and mentoring with the first Mentorship Award of the American Academy of Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine. The youngest of five children of Sadie and Max Root, Dr. Root was an all-American football player at Rutgers University class of 1951 and was inducted in the Rutgers Football Hall of Fame in 1992. He served in the Navy as lieutenant commander. He attended New York Medical College, did his residency at St. Joseph's Hospital, and his fellowship at Hospital for Special Surgery where he proudly served as an attending surgeon for his entire career. Leon and his beloved wife, Paula, were the first couple to receive the 2010 United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Community Service Award for the tangible improvements they have made in the lives of thousands of New Yorkers. In addition to countless friends and generations of surgeons, Leon was devoted to his family and is survived by his wife of 54 years Paula, son Matthew, daughter Lili and her husband Peter Bianchi, and four adoring grandchildren, Beau and Leigh Root, Quincy and Aaron Bianchi. Services will be on Thursday, September 24, 2015 at 10:30am Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Pediatric Orthopedic Outreach program at the Hospital for Special Surgery. 1/3

ADAMS--Charles Francis, 83, of Manhattan, died September 18. Born in Fairbury, Nebraska, he attended the University of Alabama and graduated from Spring Hill College, Mobile. Korean War veteran, he enjoyed a dual career as television commercials producer and kitchen designer. Former Governor of the New York Athletic Club, he was a member there for almost 50 years. He loved skiing in Vermont with friends from Norse Lodge, and playing French Horn with the New Horizons Band at the Third Street Music School. He leaves behind his loving wife of 48 years, Pamela, brother Robert and his wife Lauretta, nephews Robert, Matthew, and Peter, sister-in-law Judith Osgood and countless friends who will miss him very much. 1/3
SCHWARTZ--Stephen. Gone 5 years, remembered every day. Michael 1/3
ROOT--Leon. An angel who masqueraded as a human. Leon gave so much to so many and will be missed by all. My condolences to Paula, Matt, Lili (Peter) and the entire family. Love, Lara 1/3

ROOT--Leon--Congregation Emanu-EI of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Dr. Leon Root. It is our hope and prayer that beautiful memories will linger and endure forever in the hearts of those who loved him. 1

SONNEBORN--Babette Hofheimer. July 10, 1920 - September 19, 2015 - can't really be gone. She's too much a part of every breath we take. She was and is the best example of a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and friend. She lives on in the hearts of her three sons, David, Jonathan and Henry and their wives; her 11 grandchildren, Jennifer, Zachary, Sam, Jon Leo, Jacob, Miranda, Jessica, Jeff, Hannah, Dan and Brian; and 11 great- grandchildren. Services will be held September 25 at Kol Ami White Plains at 11:30am. 1/3

van VOORHEES--Nancy, 91, Memorable Intellectual and Socialite, widow of Clifford Irving van Voorhees Jr., passed away in West Palm Beach, FL on September 13, 2015, surrounded by members of her family. A resident of McKeen Towers, West Palm Beach, FL, she was born in Manhattan, the eldest daughter of Dr. Arthur L. Washburn and his wife, the former Sona de Got. As Nancy Wickes Washburn, she graduated from New York's Convent of the Sacred Heart, and made her debut in 1942. After the war, Clifford finished his law degree and the couple moved to Farmington, CT, Old Black Point, CT, and later lived in Gstaad, Switzerland, Darien, CT, Woodstock, VT, Manhattan, NY, Southampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, FL. Besides devoting her life to raising five children, Nancy was passionate and widely read in matters of faith, religion, philosophy, and sociology. She was known and adored for her masterful entertaining for the family and the couple's many friends. Surrounded by a family of tennis players, she became a "circuit mom." Through her father, she was a descendant of William Washbourne, a patentee of Hempstead, L.I. in 1647. Her mother belonged to the de Got family of France, which included Bertrand de Got, a collateral descendant, who was Clement V (1305-1314), the first pope of France under King Philip IV. Her mother's mother was a member of the Philbin family of New York, which included Judge Stephen A. Philbin of the Appellate Division First Department, as well as his son, Judge Eugene A. Philbin, who was instrumental in creating Central Park, in New York City. Mrs. van Voorhees was predeceased by her husband in 2002 and by her youngest child, Peter Cortlandt van Voorhees (1995). She is survived by her children, Clifford I. van Voorhees III of Darien, CT, Roger Washburn van Voorhees of Fairfield, CT, Victoria Grey and Sona Reese, both of Palm Beach, as well as eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. She was pre-deceased by her sisters, Elisabeth Deihle and Joan Coyle, and her brother, A. Lawrence Washburn Jr. She is also survived by two sisters, Cornelia Granger and Camilla Donnelly. Committal (burial) will take place at the Southampton Cemetery, Southampton, L.I. on September 26, 2015 at 11:00am. 1/3

STUTCH--Nathan. The New York Philharmonic mourns the passing, on September 17, of Nathan Stutch, a kind and beloved member of the Orchestra, 1946-88, including his service as Associate Principal Cello. Mr. Stutch's Philharmonic solo appearances included the 1960 and 1963 Stadium Concerts, and his performances live on through his Decca recording with the New York Philharmonic Cello Quartet. We extend deepest condolences to his wife, Ann; daughter, Pamela; son-in-law, Patrick Dunton; and grandson, Alexander Dunton. 1/3

ROOT--Leon M.,MD The Board of Trustees, the Medical Staff and the entire HSS community extend our heartfelt condolences to the family of Leon M. Root, MD. Dr. Root has been a cornerstone of HSS since joining the staff in 1967. He considered himself an orthopedic family doctor who cared for patients from childhood through their adulthood, but we recognized him as one of the nation's foremost specialists in pediatric orthopedics. His contributions to patient care, medical education and research were extraordinary. During his 27-year tenure as Chief of Pediatric Orthopedics at HSS, he established New York City's first clinic for children with Osteogenesis Imperfecta, founded New York State's first Pediatric Orthopedic Outreach Program, and expanded the Hospital's Cerebral Palsy Clinic. Dr Root's many other accomplishments and contributions include serving as President of the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine, and authoring books that received wide acclaim. Born and raised in New Jersey, Dr. Root attended Rutgers University on a War Memorial Scholarship. Interested in medicine since boyhood, he went on to attend New York Medical College on a partial scholarship and later interned as a general practitioner at New Jersey's Beth Israel Hospital. From there, he went into the U.S. Navy where his interest in orthopedics developed. Upon his honorable discharge from the Navy, he did his residency at St. Joseph's Hospital in Paterson, NJ, followed by a one-year fellowship at Hospital for Special Surgery and the start of an exemplary career. We honor Dr Root's extraordinary legacy of selfless care and character as an obligation to the communities and Hospital we serve. On behalf of the HSS Family, we extend our greatest sympathies and appreciation to Dr Root's wife Paula, their children Matthew and Lillian, and their four grandchildren. Kendrick R. Wilson III, Chair, Board of Trustees; Louis A. Shapiro, President and CEO; Todd J. Albert, MD, Surgeon- in-Chief and Medical Director, Hospital for Special Surgery 1/3

REGNIER--Jerome. 88, died September 13. Beloved husband of Nita Regnier, brother of Lalie Oudin, and father of daughters Emmy, Julie, Henny, Felicie and Melanie. Born September 5, 1927 in Listrac, France, he taught geology at Bryn Mawr, Wellesley, and Vassar Colleges. Endowed with an infectious curiosity, he created innumerable artistic works including family cabins, catamarans, a Japanese house, large tapestries, and natural gardens. Through his many talents and interests he has left Nita, his girls, and ten grandchildren a wealth of riches. Donations in Jerome's memory may be made to Planned Parenthood Federation of America, www.plannedparenthood.org or The Nature Conservancy, www.nature.org. 1/3

BOBST--Mamdouha El- Sayed. The Board of Trustees of the American University of Beirut and members of the AUB community note with great sadness the passing of our dear friend and former trustee, Mamdouha Bobst. Mamdouha Bobst graduated from the University in 1947, and has been a member of the AUB International Advisory Council since 1993. For 60 years, she lobbied to raise public health awareness and worked to make proper healthcare available through countless initiatives in the Middle East and North America. She was dedicated to education and was a generous supporter of student scholarships and the AUB Medical Center, where she established the Mamdouha El- Sayed Bobst Breast Center, a state-of-the-art center that provides affordable care for needy women. She shared her love of Lebanon and Tripoli with everyone around her. She once said, "My years at AUB are the foundation for most of the achievements I have attained today," and we are proud to have known her. Mamdouha Bobst was an extraordinary woman whose career infinitely improved, and will continue to improve, the lives of many others. Philip S. Khoury, PhD, Chairman of the Board of Trustees Fadlo R. Khuri, MD, President American University of Beirut, Beirut, Lebanon 1/3

SHOHAM--Sidney, Rabbi. The Yeshiva University and RIETS family and Canadian Friends of Yeshiva University mourn the passing of our esteemed colleague and friend, Rabbi Sidney Shoham, z"l who received an honorary degree in November 1990 and in whose honor The Rabbi Sidney Shoham Chair in Rabbinic and Community Leadership was established. He was rabbi emeritus of Beth Zion Congregation in Montreal, where he served for more than 60 years. Heartfelt condolences are extended to his beloved wife, Jewel Shoham, and his loving children: Mindy Mamelak, Donna Tripp and Linda Lieberman and family. May they be comforted among those who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University and RIETS Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Marion. The staff of the Department of Psychiatry and Behavioral Sciences at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center mourns the loss of our beloved and valued colleague. Marion played an integral role in our research administration. She left us too soon. Our condolences to her family and friends. 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Nancy. 1960-2015. You were the best friend I ever had and my partner in crime. If only you knew the impact you had on so many people (I can hear you laughing about that right now). There is no one tougher than you - you fought the fight like no other. My heart is broken but at last you are at peace. I will always love you. Your spirit will live on forever. Vicki 1/3

PHELAN--James J.,of Potomac, Maryland, died September 19, 2015 after a courageous battle with Multiple Myeloma. Born in Rockville Centre, NY, he was the beloved husband of Kathleen McGrath Phelan for 26 years and devoted father of two sons, John Morgan (Jack) Phelan and Peter O'Brien Phelan. He is the son of Madeleine (Mimi) Phelan Welsh and the late Robert T. Phelan. He is survived by his sister Jody Phelan Cooney and his brothers, Gerard T. Phelan and Robert M. Phelan. Jimmy was a loyal graduate of the Cranwell Preparatory School, Lenox, MA, and a proud graduate of Georgetown University, where he was a member of the varsity lacrosse team. He was on the President's Council of Catholic Charities, and a committed supporter of the Washington Jesuit Academy in Washington, DC. He had a 40-year Wall Street career, most recently with The Washingtonian Group at UBS Financial Services in Washington, DC. Visitation will take place at Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church, 9200 Kentsdale Drive, Potomac, MD, Friday, September 25 from 3:30 to 6:00pm. Mass of Christian burial will be held on Saturday, September 26, at 1:00pm at Our Lady of Mercy Catholic Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to The Shepherd Foundation, P.O. Box 50 Kensington, MD 20895 or The Washington Jesuit Academy, 900 Varnum St. NE, Washington, D.C. 20017. 1/3

HOFFENBERG--Haskel "Hack", died on September 15th, 2015, peacefully in his sleep at the age of 93. After attending Allegheny College, Hack served in the army in WWII where he was recruited into the Office of Strategic Services (OSS). He was part of a small group of German, French and Belgian resistance officers in Europe securing villages and towns of German troops after Allied victories. His WWII experiences created a lifelong pursuit of questioning traditional structures and searching for deeper meaning. After the war, he graduated from the University of Chicago School of Law and practiced law before moving to Brazil where he lived for 20 years; later he returned to New York City. During his years traveling throughout all of South America, Hack amassed an impressive collection of art from various countries. He had a keen eye for 19th Century photography and became a major collector, dealer and contributor with one of the largest collections of 19th Century photography of Latin America. Hack influenced many people from around the globe with his intelligence, eclectic interests and his ability to encourage others to take risks in their own lives. Hack was a mentor to so many who were privileged to come under his aegis. He is survived by his wife Nancy Abel, his children Jennings (Claudia), Bettina (Jeff), Sasha (David,) and his grandchildren Carolina, Lucas and Noah. Special thanks to his nephew Adam Abel, his faithful companion, George and beloved canine girls Cleopatra and Babe Ruth. Funeral services were held in private. 1/3

BROAD--Steven, 57. On behalf of Israel Discount Bank of New York we mourn the loss of our esteemed colleague, Steven Broad. Putting passion before profit, throughout his career, Steven arranged numerous financial transactions for scores of nonprofits, healthcare organizations, educational institutions, charities and cultural organizations. Steven joined the Bank in 2011 to focus on this sector, where he continued helping hospital networks expand into lower income areas and championing the developmentally disabled. His dedication and warm friendship will be truly missed. Our heartfelt condolences go out to his partner of 23 years, Michael Rosenson, his father Daniel Broad, his sister Jacqueline Stein, (Dr. Kenneth Stein) and his nieces Ariel and Gillian. Services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Thursday, September 24, 2015. Riversidememo rialchapel.com (212)-362-6600. Ehud Arnon, President and CEO and Lissa Baum, Chief Lending Officer, IDB Bank, and the entire IDB family. 1/3

ROOT--Leon, M.D. (June 15, 1929 - September 21, 2015) Dr. Leon Root, devoted husband, father, grandfather, orthopedic surgeon and role model to many, peacefully passed away on Monday, September 21 surrounded by loved ones. Dr. Root established Hospital for Special Surgery's pediatric service in 1972 and spent 25 years as Chief of Pediatric Orthopedics. He also was appointed President of the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine in 1988. He authored several books including No More Aching Back. In addition to his private practice, Dr. Root derived great pleasure and satisfaction from teaching residents and treating inner-city children with monthly visits to elementary schools throughout Manhattan and the Bronx through the hospital's Pediatric Orthopedic Outreach Program, or POP, which he founded in 1987. He was also the director of the HSS Department of Rehabilitation which lead to the Leon Root, M.D. Motion Analysis Laboratory, one of the most advanced in the country. He was the recipient of the Healthcare Chaplaincy's Wholeness of Life Award, and the Hospital for Special Surgery's first Lifetime Achievement Award. For his forty-plus years of service the medical wing of the United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County is named after him and he was recognized for his dedication to teaching and mentoring with the first Mentorship Award of the American Academy of Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine. The youngest of five children of Sadie and Max Root, Dr. Root was an all-American football player at Rutgers University class of 1951 and was inducted in the Rutgers Football Hall of Fame in 1992. He served in the Navy as lieutenant commander. He attended New York Medical College, did his residency at St. Joseph's Hospital, and his fellowship at Hospital for Special Surgery where he proudly served as an attending surgeon for his entire career. Leon and his beloved wife, Paula, were the first couple to receive the 2010 United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Community Service Award for the tangible improvements they have made in the lives of thousands of New Yorkers. In addition to countless friends and generations of surgeons, Leon was devoted to his family and is survived by his wife of 54 years Paula, son Matthew, daughter Lili and her husband Peter Bianchi, and four adoring grandchildren, Beau and Leigh Root, Quincy and Aaron Bianchi. Services will be on Thursday, September 24, 2015 at 10:30am Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Pediatric Orthopedic Outreach program at the Hospital for Special Surgery. 1/3

CURTIN--Ann Dixon, formerly of Montclair, NJ, died at her home in Vero Beach, FL on Saturday, September 19 just two weeks shy of her 94th birthday. Born in Elizabeth, NJ, Ann resided in Montclair, NJ for more than 65 years. She graduated from The Kimberly School in 1939 and Manhattanville College in 1943. Ann was also a member of the first training class of New York City's Red Cross Volunteer Nurses' Aid Corps during World War II. She was married to her beloved husband John P. Curtin for 39 years until his death in 1986. Ann was an active volunteer with the Junior League of Montclair, Mountainside Hospital, and the Red Cross. She was a member of The Oak Harbor Club and Holy Cross Catholic Church in Vero Beach. Ann was also a long- time member of the Montclair Golf Club, the Bay Head Yacht Club, and The Moorings Club. She is survived by her four devoted children: Ellen Curtin of San Diego, John P. Curtin, Jr. of Toronto, Kate Curtin Lindsey of Washington, DC and Kyle Curtin of New York City as well as her five grandchildren: Hayden Curtin, Thomas F Curtin III, Whitney Curtin, John Lindsey and Andrew Lindsey. Ann's keen mind, unparalleled wit, and well-known feisty spirit, combined with her commitment to family and friends will never be forgotten by those lucky enough to have known her. Memorial donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association and Hospice Foundation of Indian River County, 1110 35th Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960 in memory of Ann Dixon Curtin. Services will be held at Holy Cross Catholic Church on Monday, October 5 at 11am. Services are under the direction of Strunk Funeral Home, Vero Beach. An online guestbook is available at www. strunkfuneralhome.com. 1/3
