BOBST--Mamdouha. The Board of Trustees and the Staff of The Animal Medical Center (AMC) mourn the loss of fellow Honorary Trustee and friend, Mamdouha Bobst. An AMC Trustee since 1983, Dodo was a dedicated public health advocate, a distinguished philanthropist and a staunch proponent of healthcare for animals as evidenced in her transformational commitment to The Elmer and Mamdouha Bobst Hospital at AMC - a grant that in her own words was described as "special because it is helping creatures who cannot say, 'I am sick.'" Mrs. Bobst and The Elmer and Mamdouha Bobst Foundation were honorees at the 1995 Top Dog Benefit Gala, she was personally recognized by the Board of Trustees with a Heart of Gold Award that same year and continued to give generously throughout her lifetime. Mrs. Bobst had an abiding love for all animals, especially her Yorkshire Terriers, Gigi and Jou Jou. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family and all those who were touched by her intelligence and compassion. 1/3

ADAME--Omar R. A 42 year resident of Greenwich, CT, passed away on September 20, 2015 following a lengthy struggle with Parkinson's Disease. He was 84. Born in the Bronx on May 21, 1931 to Don and Ruth (nee Iscra) Adame. Omar was a graduate of Mount Saint Michael Academy in the Bronx and Centre College in Kentucky, where he studied Chemistry and Biology and was a member of Sigma Chi Fraternity. A proud Air Force veteran, he began serving in 1952, joining the Strategic Air Command, flying KC-97s on mid- air refueling missions. In 1954, he joined the New York Air National Guard, often flying, as a volunteer, to Vietnam. He retired in 1982 as a Brigadier General. In civilian life, Omar's career in the cosmetics industry spanned 30 years, during which time he served as a senior executive with Orlane/Jean D'Albret and Adrien Arpel, and most recently, CEO of Theodore Wrapp Associates. Passionate about his family, flying, photography and travel. Omar was renowned for his personal generosity. He is survived by his beloved wife of 42 years, Margaret Hayes, daughter Alexandra and daughter Liz Adame from a previous marriage. He is also survived by his devoted brother Ramon and grandchildren Quincy, Casey and Febee. To honor his life friends may call on Thursday, from 2 to 4 and 7 to 9 at Coxe & Graziano Funeral Home 134 Hamilton Ave. Greenwich, CT. A Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Friday, 11:00am at St. Catherine of Sienna followed by interment at Putnam Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research. www.mich aeljfox.org. For more information or to place an online condolence; www.coxeand graziano.com 1/3

ROOT--Leon. Dearest Leon: You did make a difference. The world is a better place because you were there, and you will always be remembered. Dinny and Lester 1/3
EVERS--Sally J. Sept. 11, 1942 - Sept. 24, 2010. Missed every day, loved always. Helen, Susan, Barbara, Bill 1/3

DIAZ-CRUZ--Mario Carlos, III, beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle and attorney died September 21 following a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of forty four years, Margaret Rowan Diaz-Cruz, his daughter, Elizabeth Diaz-Cruz Sarosi and her husband, David and his grandsons George Bela and Paul Carlos Sarosi, all of New York. He was predeceased by his mother, Matilde Pages Sanchez; stepfather, Jorge W. Sanchez; father, Mario Diaz-Cruz, Jr.; and stepmother Carmen Fuertes Diaz-Cruz. Born in Havana, Cuba on July 20, 1946, he and his family immigrated to the United States in. 1961. He graduated from Christopher Columbus High School in 1963, University of Miami in 1967, and Harvard Law School in 1970. Over his lifetime Mario travelled the globe. He was an enthusiastic tennis player and always found pure joy in the company of his friends and family; he was known as the life of the party. Mario began his legal career at White and Case as an associate in 1970 specializing in antitrust litigation. He then joined Gadsby and Hannah as a partner. In 1988 he moved to Townley and Updike where he served as partner and management committee member through 1995. Since 1995, he has been an active partner at Dorsey and Whitney, serving as chairman of both the Latin America and the Latin America Financing and Privatization practice groups. He represented corporate and individual clients operating throughout the Iberian Penisula and Latin America, supporting their business objectives in the United States. His experience spanned a full range of services relating to mergers and acquisitions, capital market transactions, franchising and distribution, trade and investments, corporate and commercial transactions and international trade. He was a member of the New York State Bar Association, the American Bar Association, the Hispanic National Bar Association and the International Bar Association. Mario was a member of the Spain-US Chamber of Commerce and was elected president in 2000. He served as chairman of the board from 2003 to 2007 and from 2008 to 2009. He was honored with the "Cruz del Merito Civil" bestowed by King Juan Carlos II of Spain. Mario served on the board of Girls Quest, formally The Girls Vacation Fund. Until his death he served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. Mass of Christian burial will be held Tuesday September 29 at 2:30, Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St., NYC preceded by 1:30 visitation in the Church chapel. In lieu of flowers, kindly consider a donation to Catholic Charities, 1011 First Ave. 11th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10022 (www. catholiccharitiesny.org) or The Association to Benefit Children 419 East 86th St. New York, N.Y. 10028. 1/3

LICHTENSTEIN--Irene Quartin, in her 90th year. Loving mother of Ellen Cogut (Casey), Deborah Moskowitz (Ivan), Richard Lichtenstein (Melanie), and the late Amy Graham (Doug). Cherished grandmother of Pamela and Rachel, Charlie (Lissy) and Jon (Amanda), Jessica and Daniel, Matthew (Sarah) and Dilyn (Andrew). Great- grandmother and adored as "Gigi" by Zoe, Julian and Jordan. Treasured and loyal friend of many in Great Neck, San Diego, Lenox and New York City. Irene was passionate about art, bridge, movies, tennis, theater, travel and all liberal causes. She loved life and lived it that way. Services will be held Thursday, September 24th at noon at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in her honor to a charity of your choosing. 1/3
ROOT--Leon. Over 50 years of memories. It is hard to imagine our life without Leon. Lynn and Peter 1/3

SONNEBORN--Babette Hofheimer. July 10, 1920 - September 19, 2015 - can't really be gone. She's too much a part of every breath we take. She was and is the best example of a wonderful wife, mother, grandmother and friend. She lives on in the hearts of her three sons, David, Jonathan and Henry and their wives; her 11 grandchildren, Jennifer, Zachary, Sam, Jon Leo, Jacob, Miranda, Jessica, Jeff, Hannah, Dan and Brian; and 11 great- grandchildren. Services will be held September 25 at Kol Ami White Plains at 11:30am. 1/3

McGRAW--Deborah Ann (Hunkele). Surrounded by family, Deborah Ann (Hunkele) McGraw died at home on September 18, 2015, after a courageous 12 year battle with cancer. She was 74. Loving spouse, mother, grandmother, sister, cousin and friend, Debbie lived life fully. She lived hers in a compelling spirit of strength, integrity, kindness and grace, reflected in a dazzling smile, which immediately drew people to her. She was born in Newark, NJ and graduated with honors from Passaic Valley High School in Little Falls, NJ. She attended Montclair State University and Katharine Gibbs Business College. Three children from a first marriage to Edward "Ned" Connolly, MD, survive her: Sean Connolly (Hannah), Kristin (Connolly) Barnes, and Eli Connolly, as well as two step-children: Sean McGraw and Maureen McGraw. She is also survived by her husband of 36 years, David, and devoted Old English Sheepdog, Lexie; as well as three beloved grandchildren, Shamus Berry, Brenna Connolly and Asher Connolly. After her children were well into high school, she began a retail business career, which included positions at Papyrus in Berkeley, Batus Corporation in North Carolina, and Peet's Coffee & Tea in Berkeley, where she rose through various management positions to Vice President of Retail Store Operations & Merchandising. In retirement she spent time on the board of the Berkeley City Club, where she restored the hotel portion to its original Julia Morgan elegance. Deborah and David traveled widely in North America and Europe. Debbie especially loved Italy, the people and culture, returning many times. A Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church at 2808 Lakeshore Avenue in Oakland, CA on Friday, October 23rd at 11am. 1/3

LANDAU--Harold, 96 years young, of Valley Stream, NY and Boca Raton, FL passed away on Saturday, September 19, 2015. He was laid to rest on Tuesday, September 22, 2015 joining his beautiful wife of 43 years Bernice Landau. He is survived by five children and their significant others, thirteen grandchildren, and one great- grandson. He is also survived by his loving sister Ileana Dwoskin. He was a brilliant and hard working man with a great sense of humor who taught his family the values of life. We all loved him dearly and will miss him greatly. We love you dad. 1/3

ROOT--Leon. We will miss his sheltering hands, his big heart, and the warmth of his smile. And his hugs, his jokes, his voice and his laugh. The world is a poorer place without him. Rebecca and Peter 1/3

HOFFENBERG--Haskel "Hack", died on September 15th, 2015, peacefully in his sleep at the age of 93. After attending Allegheny College, Hack served in the army in WWII where he was recruited into the Office of Strategic Services (OSS). He was part of a small group of German, French and Belgian resistance officers in Europe securing villages and towns of German troops after Allied victories. His WWII experiences created a lifelong pursuit of questioning traditional structures and searching for deeper meaning. After the war, he graduated from the University of Chicago School of Law and practiced law before moving to Brazil where he lived for 20 years; later he returned to New York City. During his years traveling throughout all of South America, Hack amassed an impressive collection of art from various countries. He had a keen eye for 19th Century photography and became a major collector, dealer and contributor with one of the largest collections of 19th Century photography of Latin America. Hack influenced many people from around the globe with his intelligence, eclectic interests and his ability to encourage others to take risks in their own lives. Hack was a mentor to so many who were privileged to come under his aegis. He is survived by his wife Nancy Abel, his children Jennings (Claudia), Bettina (Jeff), Sasha (David,) and his grandchildren Carolina, Lucas and Noah. Special thanks to his nephew Adam Abel, his faithful companion, George and beloved canine girls Cleopatra and Babe Ruth. Funeral services were held in private. 1/3

ROOT--Leon, M.D. (June 15, 1929 - September 21, 2015) Dr. Leon Root, devoted husband, father, grandfather, orthopedic surgeon and role model to many, peacefully passed away on Monday, September 21 surrounded by loved ones. Dr. Root established Hospital for Special Surgery's pediatric service in 1972 and spent 25 years as Chief of Pediatric Orthopedics. He also was appointed President of the American Academy for Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine in 1988. He authored several books including No More Aching Back. In addition to his private practice, Dr. Root derived great pleasure and satisfaction from teaching residents and treating inner-city children with monthly visits to elementary schools throughout Manhattan and the Bronx through the hospital's Pediatric Orthopedic Outreach Program, or POP, which he founded in 1987. He was also the director of the HSS Department of Rehabilitation which lead to the Leon Root, M.D. Motion Analysis Laboratory, one of the most advanced in the country. He was the recipient of the Healthcare Chaplaincy's Wholeness of Life Award, and the Hospital for Special Surgery's first Lifetime Achievement Award. For his forty-plus years of service the medical wing of the United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County is named after him and he was recognized for his dedication to teaching and mentoring with the first Mentorship Award of the American Academy of Cerebral Palsy and Developmental Medicine. The youngest of five children of Sadie and Max Root, Dr. Root was an all-American football player at Rutgers University class of 1951 and was inducted in the Rutgers Football Hall of Fame in 1992. He served in the Navy as lieutenant commander. He attended New York Medical College, did his residency at St. Joseph's Hospital, and his fellowship at Hospital for Special Surgery where he proudly served as an attending surgeon for his entire career. Leon and his beloved wife, Paula, were the first couple to receive the 2010 United Hospital Fund's Distinguished Community Service Award for the tangible improvements they have made in the lives of thousands of New Yorkers. In addition to countless friends and generations of surgeons, Leon was devoted to his family and is survived by his wife of 54 years Paula, son Matthew, daughter Lili and her husband Peter Bianchi, and four adoring grandchildren, Beau and Leigh Root, Quincy and Aaron Bianchi. Services will be on Thursday, September 24, 2015 at 10:30am Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue at 65th Street. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Pediatric Orthopedic Outreach program at the Hospital for Special Surgery. 1/3

BROAD--Steven, 57, on September 21, 2015. Senior Vice President of Israel Discount Bank. Beloved partner of Michael Rosenson, devoted son of Daniel Broad, cherished brother of Jacqueline and Kenneth Stein, dear uncle of Ariel and Gillian. Funeral service on Thursday, September 24, 11:15am, at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3
ROOT--Leon. So much love has left the world, but so much love remains. Skippy & Manny 1/3

ROOT--Dr. Leon. Dr. Root was the most caring, thoughtful, and wonderful friend; a doctor who devoted his life to help other people, especially children. My deepest sympathy to my friend Paula, their children and grandchildren. With love, Elaine Sargent 1/3

DUDAR--Walter. Veteran Connecticut newspaperman, innovator at directing state and business coverage as an editor, always a writer first in his heart and time, a loner of sorts but seriously witty, leaves wife Diane Zavras Dudar, a writer. March 27, 1926--August 21, 2015. 1/3

BELSON--Jerome. New Hope Community extends its deepest condolences to the Belson family on the passing of Mr. Jerome ("Jerry") Belson. Jerry was a highly respected supporter of New Hope Community and an advocate for people with intellectual and other developmental disabilities. His commitment to New Hope's mission will always be remembered. 1/3

GRUSKIN--Felice, age 87, passed away on August 14, 2015. She was born and spent most of her life in NYC. She received a business degree from City College and worked as a bookkeeper. She lost her husband Abraham, in 1971, never remarried. She is survived by her brother, two sons and a grandson. She spent most of her life in Washington Heights (upper Manhattan), where she was active in the Democratic Party and twice elected as District Leader. She also started a grassroots organization, Transit Riders In Pursuit, which published a quarterly newsletter and advocated for increased mass-transit and lowering/eliminating the fare. Later on she also became active in the Henry George School and Schalkenbach Foundation, advocating for a Land Value Tax and two-rate taxation (of land). In 1995, she moved to Rego Park, Queens, where she continued to be active in the Republican Party. She is very well traveled, having visited Europe, Russia, Mexico, Hong Kong, China, Central and South America as well as Israel and the Middle East. 1/3

ADAME--Omar. The Lauder Family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the passing of Omar Adame, the beloved husband of Margaret Hayes, the President of Fashion Group International. Mr. Adame passed away on September 20, 2015 in Greenwich Connecticut. He was a proud veteran of the United States Air Force Strategic Air Command and later joined the New York Air National Guard, from which he retired as a Brigadier General. In civilian life, he had a 30 year career in the cosmetics industry as a senior executive with Orlane/Jean D'Albret and Adrien Arpel. Mr. Adame is survived by his wife Margaret and daughter Alexandra, and Liz Adame, his daughter from a previous marriage. He is also survived by his devoted brother, Ramon. Our thoughts are with Margaret and their family and friends. 1/3

ARENSTEIN--Effrem, 94. Adoring husband of Martha (Ring), beloved father of Lois (Harvey) and Sandy, devoted grandfather of Bradley (Brittni) and Evan, thrilled great- grandfather of Xander. Effie was a man of uncommon integrity, generosity and vision (Lido Toys), an exceptional raconteur and enthusiastic traveler. 1/3

SPELLMAN--Joseph. The Lauder family and The Estee Lauder Companies are deeply saddened by the passing of our beloved colleague, Joseph Spellman. He passed away on September 22, in New York City. Joe worked at the Estee Lauder brand during the 1970's, where he rose to Vice President of Marketing and then established his own marketing and creative design firm. He worked at Elizabeth Arden starting in 1988 and was considered the prime creative force in the revitalization of the brand. Joe was instrumental in the launch of the blockbuster fragrance, Elizabeth Taylor's White Diamonds, which is still a perennial best-seller during the holidays and was amongst the first in the celebrity fragrance genre. For the past decade, Joe served as a senior consultant for The Estee Lauder Companies, contributing to the success of multiple brands including Tom Ford Beauty and Bobbi Brown. "He was one of the architects of the modern beauty industry," said John Demsey, Group President, The Estee Lauder Companies, who worked closely with Joe. "Whether working alongside Estee Lauder or Leonard Lauder or Charles Revson or Elizabeth Arden- he was there on the ground floor. He was a brilliant marketer." Joseph Spellman is survived by his wife, Victoria and daughter, Chloe and son Luke. 1/3

PAUL--William E.,MD The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of William E. Paul, MD, chief of the Laboratory of Immunology, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, and former director of the National Institutes of Health Office of AIDS Research. An internationally acclaimed researcher, Dr. Paul was a 1960 graduate of SUNY Downstate's College of Medicine, and a recipient of a SUNY honorary Doctor of Science degree and a Distinguished Alumni Award. Dr. Paul's contributions to medicine, science, and public health will be long remembered. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, colleagues, and friends. Carlos N. Pato, MD Dean, College of Medicine John F. Williams, MD, EdD, MPH President 1/3

BIKOFF--Jacqueline Shereen (April 10th 1960 - September 23rd, 2015) Beloved mother to Sasha and Maxwell Bikoff has passed on as our GOD opened the gates of the heavens for her concluding the most holiest of Jewish holidays, Yom Kippur. Although we are left with heavy hearts her spirit will live deep within us forever. Through her passions of classical piano, ballet, running through central park, and playing tennis we are all blessed to have known a woman who was larger than life. She greatly impacted everyone who met her. Above all, the most cherished gift GOD gave her in this life were her twins whom she fought till the end to live for. We find comfort in the fact that she is up in the heavens with her parents, William and Suzy Bikoff shining like the bright star that she is and watching over us our every move. Baruch Dayan Ha Emet. Services will be at The Frank E. Campbell on Friday, September 25, 2015 at 10am. Entombment to follow at Beth David Cemetery Elmont, NY. 1

MASSEY--Calvin, of Concord, NH and Deer Isle, ME, died peacefully September 23, 2015. Daniel Webster Distinguished Professor of Law, UNH Law School, 2012-2015. Professor of Law at University of California, Hastings, San Francisco, 1987-2012. Author of many articles and books on constitutional law and property. Born Walla Walla, WA in 1949, he received a B.A. from Whitman College in 1969, an M.B.A. from Harvard in 1971, and a J.D. from Columbia in 1974. A creative cook, avid hiker and sailor, and possessed of a quick mind and vast store of knowledge, faith and courage. He was a beloved husband and father and will be deeply missed. Survived by wife Martha, daughter Ellen, son-in-law Seth Leonard, sister Mary Alice Tonn. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Dana Farber Cancer Institute, Attn: Dr. Robert J. Soiffer, MD 450 Brookline Ave., Boston, MA 02215-5450 1/3

DIAZ-CRUZ--Mario Carlos, III, beloved husband, father, grandfather, uncle and attorney died September 21 following a brief illness. He is survived by his wife of forty four years, Margaret Rowan Diaz-Cruz, his daughter, Elizabeth Diaz-Cruz Sarosi and her husband, David and his grandsons George Bela and Paul Carlos Sarosi, all of New York. He was predeceased by his mother, Matilde Pages Sanchez; stepfather, Jorge W. Sanchez; father, Mario Diaz-Cruz, Jr.; and stepmother Carmen Fuertes Diaz-Cruz. Born in Havana, Cuba on July 20, 1946, he and his family immigrated to the United States in. 1961. He graduated from Christopher Columbus High School in 1963, University of Miami in 1967, and Harvard Law School in 1970. Over his lifetime Mario travelled the globe. He was an enthusiastic tennis player and always found pure joy in the company of his friends and family; he was known as the life of the party. Mario began his legal career at White and Case as an associate in 1970 specializing in antitrust litigation. He then joined Gadsby and Hannah as a partner. In 1988 he moved to Townley and Updike where he served as partner and management committee member through 1995. Since 1995, he has been an active partner at Dorsey and Whitney, serving as chairman of both the Latin America and the Latin America Financing and Privatization practice groups. He represented corporate and individual clients operating throughout the Iberian Penisula and Latin America, supporting their business objectives in the United States. His experience spanned a full range of services relating to mergers and acquisitions, capital market transactions, franchising and distribution, trade and investments, corporate and commercial transactions and international trade. He was a member of the New York State Bar Association, the American Bar Association, the Hispanic National Bar Association and the International Bar Association. Mario was a member of the Spain-US Chamber of Commerce and was elected president in 2000. He served as chairman of the board from 2003 to 2007 and from 2008 to 2009. He was honored with the "Cruz del Merito Civil" bestowed by King Juan Carlos II of Spain. Mario served on the board of Girls Quest, formally The Girls Vacation Fund. Until his death he served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York. Mass of Christian burial will be held Tuesday September 29 at 2:30, Church of St. Thomas More, 65 E. 89th St., NYC preceded by 1:30 visitation in the Church chapel. In lieu of flowers, kindly consider a donation to Catholic Charities, 1011 First Ave. 11th Floor, New York, N.Y. 10022 (www. catholiccharitiesny.org) or The Association to Benefit Children 419 East 86th St. New York, N.Y. 10028. 1/3

FLOURNOY--Thomas N. February 10, 1922 - August 15, 2015, passed peacefully in the San Diego, CA home of Peter and Sally Flournoy, He is survived by many Flournoy and Greathouse nieces and nephews. 1/3

WILDER--Susan Katrina Peters. Died on September 22, 2015 at her Manhattan home of breast cancer. She was 71. A native New Yorker and daughter of German born parents, she maintained a residence in Manhattan her entire life. She graduated in 1962 from Holy Cross Academy in New York; and, after receiving a liberal arts degree from Barnard in 1966, Sue received a master's degree from NYU in Russian History. Starting as an Investment research assistant at Bankers Trust in 1966, Sue became an institutional investment manager and vice president at Citibank, moving on to investment management positions at Alliance Capital and then with Oppenheimer. While she remained a committed, lifelong New Yorker, her second love was her private weekends at her farm in Upstate New York, becoming an accomplished tennis player, windsurfer, skier, and horseperson. She loved animals and supported many charities that focused on animal rescue and rehabilitation efforts, volunteering with the Wildlife Conservation Society and as an assistant to a researcher-author at the Museum of Natural History. She is survived by her husband, Robert and by her cat, Dickens. Donations in her memory may be made to: The Raptor Center at the University of Minnesota or the Wildlife Conservation Society. 1/3

BING--Alexander III "Sandy," 84, passed away at home after a brief but difficult fight with lung cancer on September 12, 2015. Sandy was born and lived in New York City. He attended Dalton and Lincoln Schools, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Middlebury College and received a Masters degree in American History from Columbia University. As a member of the United States Army, he served in France and Germany after WWII. Sandy was a partner and Director of Research at L.F. Rothschild, and later worked at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in fixed income research. During his career, he was ranked by Institutional Investor as a top research analyst. In 1972, he married Cynthia Eaton Bing, education and environmental philanthropist, and together they raised four children. Sandy supported numerous non-profit organizations and served as president of two co-op boards. He was treasurer and board member of the Friends of the Upper Delaware River and was instrumental in an effort led by River Network that saved a stretch of the Madison River (Montana) from real estate development. He spent his summers in Montana where he broke his own horse at 16, worked as a wrangler at 20, and shoed his horses into his 60s. Mostly, he loved to go on long, rugged horseback rides with his family. His passion and excellence as a fly fisherman was rivaled only by his ability to build handcrafted, Queen Anne style, fine furniture. Throughout his life he was an avid basketball and baseball player, often found on the hardscrabble fields of Central Park. Sandy's parents, Matilda S. and Alexander S. Bing; wife, Cynthia E. Bing; daughter, Abigail R. Bing; and former wife, Elisabeth G. Bing predeceased him. He is survived by son, Alexander M. Bing; daughters, Cynthia K. Bing and Virginia G. Bing; son-in-law, Michael Padial; and granddaughter, Eloise B. Padial. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave. at 3pm, October 16, 2015 with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Friends of the Upper Delaware River (FUDR.org) and/or EarlySteps.org. 1/3

ZAFRIN--Florence. Beloved mother of Ina Gold (Steven), adored grandmother of Douglas and Brett, and devoted aunt of Ilene Silberman and Cynthia Elbling. We will forever miss her. A graveside funeral will be held at Mount Lebanon in Queens, NY. Ina and Steven 1/3

PENNIMAN--Anne Winchester, of Essex, CT died peacefully in the embrace of her family on September 17, 2015. She was the beloved wife of Caleb J. Penniman. Boo, as she was always known to friends and family, was born in Wilmington, Delaware on April 14, 1929, the daughter of Anne Canby Winchester and George Winchester. She attended Foxcroft School in Middleburg, VA. After marrying in 1952, Boo and Caleb lived in Lake Forest, Illinois, New York City and Chappaqua, New York before settling in Essex in 1977. Boo had a deep love of history and culture, a prodigious intellect, and a boundless curiosity for learning and exploring, which she shared eagerly with others in her community. Throughout her life she quietly touched an untold number of lives with her love and compassion, gifts she gave willingly, asking nothing in return. Boo is survived by her husband Caleb and their three children: Mary and her husband Garrett Moran of Greenwich; George and his wife Anne of Essex; Caleb Jr. of Essex; and grandchildren Elizabeth, George and Caleb Moran and Jeannette and Amelia Penniman. She is also survived by her sister Judith Spruance of Wilmington, Delaware. A memorial service will be held on October 24, 2015 at 11:00 AM at St. John's Episcopal Church in Essex. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made in Boo's memory to the Essex Library Association, 33 West Avenue, Essex, CT, 06426, or to the Scholarship Foundation at Essex Meadows, 30 Bokum Road, Essex, CT, 06426. To share a memory of Boo or send a condolence to her family, please visit www.rwwfh.com. 1/3

HOFFENBERG--Haskel "Hack", died on September 15th, 2015, peacefully in his sleep at the age of 93. After attending Allegheny College, Hack served in the army in WWII where he was recruited into the Office of Strategic Services (OSS). He was part of a small group of German, French and Belgian resistance officers in Europe securing villages and towns of German troops after Allied victories. His WWII experiences created a lifelong pursuit of questioning traditional structures and searching for deeper meaning. After the war, he graduated from the University of Chicago School of Law and practiced law before moving to Brazil where he lived for 20 years; later he returned to New York City. During his years traveling throughout all of South America, Hack amassed an impressive collection of art from various countries. He had a keen eye for 19th Century photography and became a major collector, dealer and contributor with one of the largest collections of 19th Century photography of Latin America. Hack influenced many people from around the globe with his intelligence, eclectic interests and his ability to encourage others to take risks in their own lives. Hack was a mentor to so many who were privileged to come under his aegis. He is survived by his wife Nancy Abel, his children Jennings (Claudia), Bettina (Jeff), Sasha (David,) and his grandchildren Carolina, Lucas and Noah. Special thanks to his nephew Adam Abel, his faithful companion, George and beloved canine girls Cleopatra and Babe Ruth. Funeral services were held in private. 1/3

POSNIACK--Max. Loved by all. Funeral Services to be held on September 27, 2015 at 10am at Madison Jewish Center, 2989 Nostrand Avenue(between Quentin Rd. and Avenue P) Brooklyn, NY. 1/3

TREIBER--Millicent Hope, died peacefully (or as Hope would prefer, "gathered") on September 14, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. She is survived by her brother, Henry C. Haer and her sister-in-law, Sally Haer; her children - John H. (Carol-Ann), H. Craig (Lora), Bruce D. (Virginia), Peter S. (Irene), Scott R. (Jo-Ellen), Pamela H. Treiber Baldwin; 18 grandchildren, and many nieces, nephews, and loving friends. Hope was predeceased by her husband Howard, her sister Joan, her niece Robin Gross, and her parents Henry C. and Mae Lillian (Murphy) Haer. Hope was born in Morristown, NJ, and raised in Sayville, NY, where she played soccer and was a Sayville High School cheerleader. She was proud of her participation in the war effort as a plane spotter in the tower of the old Sayville High School. She went on to graduate from St. John's Episcopal Hospital Nursing School as a RN. Hope married Howard F. Treiber on November 25, 1949 and moved to Old Brookville in 1955 where they raised their six children. Hope loved her home most when it was filled with her children and their friends and in later years with her grandchildren. She enjoyed being very active all her life with golf, tennis, jogging, and until only several years ago, working out at the YMCA at Glen Cove. Hope's love of nature and living things was a passion all her life, whether feeding birds, watching baby birds in her birdhouses, butterflies, insects, bird nests, and her ever-blooming garden and house plants. Hope was an accomplished crossword aficionado and a dedicated Jeopardy fan. She was a fiercely independent lady, with an indomitable spirit and will, and she always put other's needs and sensitivities ahead of hers throughout her life. Hope's unconditional love and support became the strength of her family. She was a remarkable mother and grandmother and will be missed so very much. Hope did not believe in death but rather in life, and in accordance with her wishes, there will be no wake but a memorial service on Saturday, October 24, at 2pm, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Highland Avenue, Glen Cove. In lieu of flowers, donations in Hope's memory may be made to: SCO Family of Services, One Alexander Place, Glen Cove, NY 11542, or YMCA at Glen Cove, Dosoris Lane, Glen Cove, NY 11542. 1/3
MASSEY--Calvin. Scholar, law professor, beloved husband and father. Memorial service Saturday, October 3 at 2pm, St Andrew's Episcopal Church, Hopkinton, NH. 1/3

BOXILL--Professor Roger, (27 March 1928 to 15 September 2015) As a boy, Roger attended the Little Red School House in Greenwich Village, and New York's Professional Children's School and High School of Music and Art. After training at the Royal Academy in London, he was an actor on Stage and Television. Of his many roles his favorite was Prince Hal in Shakespeare's I Henry IV. Later he took a PhD at Columbia University and joined the English Department at the City College of CUNY. Not surprisingly, his preferred course as an instructor was Shakespeare, which he taught many times. During this time he also was a respected director of theater productions in the New York area. As a critic of drama he published two books, one on Bernard Shaw's views on health and the medical profession and the other on the plays of Tennessee Williams. His interest in the exotic led him to travel up the Nile to see the pyramids and to explore other parts of the Middle East. Somewhat closer to home, he spent a year as Adjunct Professor of English at the University of Paris. In 1993 he retired from academic life. He had long been an ardent tennis player, and continued honing his game in retirement, but his primary study was the singing of choral and solo music. He was an avid student of voice and music theory, sang in many venerable New York choruses, became a devoted member of the "Friday Night" singing group and released a recording of his favorite songs and arias several years ago. Roger had no immediate family, but his many friends will miss him deeply. Please inquire at oaklandopensing@gmail.com to send remembrances and for information about a celebration of his life in early November. 1/3

In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution in her honor to a charity of your choosing. 1/3

BATES--Dorli Faesy, of Noank, CT, died very peacefully at home on August 6, 2015 at the age of 83, with the cherished comfort of her beloved husband of 63 years, Tom, and her family. Dorli Faesy was born on October 5, 1931 in New York, NY, to A. Robert Faesy, Sr. and Margaret Dorothy Greene Faesy. She grew up in New York and Ridgefield, CT, and attended the Spence School and Barnard College in NYC. In 1952, Dorli married Thomas Edgerly Bates. They moved to Wilton, soon thereafter, where she delighted in building a home and starting a family. The family moved to Windsor, CT (1974). After her children finished school, she took a job at Traveler's Insurance. After retirement, Dorli and Tom moved to Noank, CT (1995). Dorli is survived by her husband, her children, Julianna Faesy Bates (Shrewsbury, MA), and Christopher Edgerly Bates (Ellington, CT), her grandchildren, Ian Edgerly Bates and Catherine Elizabeth Bates (Hebron, CT), her brother A. Robert Faesy Jr (Wilton, CT and Dorset, VT) and her sister, Virginia Faesy, (Manchester Center, VT) and numerous nieces and nephews. A memorial service will be scheduled at a later date. 1/3

BLAICHMAN--Cesia, 90, passed away peacefully September 24, 2015 surrounded by family. Cherished and loving wife of Frank for 70 years. Devoted mother to Bella and Charles (Aviva); grandmother to Etan, Talia (Tym), Maya, Micah, Sabrina and Noah. Great-grandmother to Ceila. Sister of Jack Pomeranc. Raised in Wlodawa, Poland she fought bravely against Nazi Germany as a Jewish Partisan, active in the forests and small villages around Lublin. Cesia nursed the wounded, cooked for her fellow partisans and participated in operations to both protect her fellow Jews and punish their murderers. She survived with her three partisan fighting brothers - Jack, Yurik z"l and Abie z"l. Their parents, Bella Ita z"l, Lazar z"l, as well as three sisters -Chaya z'l, Matele z"l, Chana z"l, perished along with innumerable relatives. After the War she married Frank, her dearest comrade-in-arms, and emigrated with him to New York where they began a vibrant life and raised a beautiful family. Her elegant, delicious Shabbat and Holiday meals were legendary; her love and devotion to her family and friends absolute; her grief for her lost loved ones un-ending. As a true daughter of Israel, her commitment to Yiddishkeit and Holocaust Remembrance was sacrosanct. Cesia served as a committee member for the American IDF, Yad Va Shem, Hadassah, and several other notable organizations. Most of all, she was the warmest, most caring and loving woman, and will live forever in our hearts. Donations may be made to yadvashemusa.org or jewishpartisans.org. Services to be held Sunday, September 27 at noon "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

ROCHE--Brenda Boel. March 21, 1942--September 13, 2015. Brenda Boel Roche died peacefully in her Upper East Side home on Sunday, September 13, 2015 at the age of 73. Born in Shafter, California, she earned her Bachelor of Science degree in Physical Therapy from the University of California, Davis in 1964 before moving to New York City. An accomplished artist, Mrs. Roche was both an illustrator and a sculptor. She was a lover of fine and contemporary art and took a variety of classes at the National Academy Museum and School. Having lived in New York City for over five decades, Mrs. Roche was a true New Yorker and had a voracious appetite for the city's cultural offerings, rarely missing a play, art opening, or museum exhibition. She will be remembered for both her extraordinary talent as well as her wry sense of humor. She was married to the late John G. Roche for 42 years until his death in April of 2014. She is survived by her brother, Bonner Boel, her son, Jonathan Roche, her daughter, Sarah Roche Gilman, son in law, Felix Gilman, and grandchildren, William and Zoe Gilman, as well as countless devoted friends. A service is being planned for later this fall. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Center for Arts Education, which benefits New York City youth. 1/3

CRATE--Marian K. (Keil), 76, beloved wife of William R. Crate, passed away peacefully on Tuesday, September 1st, at her home. Born in the Bronx, New York, she is the daughter of the late William E. and Marie Deibold Keil. Marian struggled in her later years with a debilitating neurological disease. Always elegant, she never left home without wearing lipstick, and will be remembered as an active and vivacious woman. Marian was born and raised in the Bronx and a true New Yorker, down to her accent. She attended New York public schools as a child, and graduated from Freeport High School on Long Island. Marian was a woman of adventure, embracing excitement without fear - a trait she passed on to her sons and her grandchildren. In her early twenties, Marian was known to drive around New York City in a car that had no brakes, stopping only when she yanked the emergency brake. This later manifested itself in an early driving lesson with her son Bradley when they were traveling on the George Washington Bridge. Marian decided suddenly that she and her son were going the wrong way. So she pulled a U-turn right at the end of the bridge. It was a lot of fun for Bradley, but the police did not think so. In her youth, Marian was a model and a stewardess until she met a Naval Aviator named William Robert Crate, whom she married in 1961. Together they raised two sons, Darrell and Bradley, along with numerous pets. Marian was a devoted wife and mother, and an active volunteer in her sons' schools, serving as a classroom mother for each of her sons in every year. She held a deep sense of conviction in her sons' abilities and offered complete support for their endeavors, whatever they were. She was always proud of their efforts, regardless of result, and strove to give them the unflappable courage that comes from a strong and loving support system. Marian now has a chance to be in heaven with her parents, both of whom she lost at a very early age, her brother Charles, who passed away earlier this year, and her daughter-in-law Natalie, who passed away in 2014. In addition to her devoted husband William, with whom she shared 54 years of marriage, Marian is survived her two loving sons, Darrell W. Crate, of Beverly Farms, MA, and Bradley T. Crate of Beverly Farms, MA, and five grandchildren: William R. Crate II; Emma W. Crate; Audrey T. Crate; Elizabeth L. Crate; and Helena R. Crate. She is predeceased by her brother Charles E. Crate and her daughter-in-law Natalie W. Crate. Visiting hours will be held from 2:00pm--3:30pm at the Campbell Funeral Home, 525 Cabot Street, Beverly, MA on Tuesday, September 29th with remembrances taking place at 3:30pm. Relatives and friends are respectfully invited to attend. The burial will be held at the Pleasant Grove Cemetery in Manchester-by-the-Sea, MA immediately following the remembrances. Memorial donations may be made in Marian's Memory to Stop3.org, a foundation dedicated to brain cancer research at 138 Conant Street, 2nd Floor, Beverly, MA 01915. Information, directions condolences at: www.campbellfuneral.com. 1/3

RHYNER--Frank. Here you are at last in The New York Times. Not quite the Sunday Styles but you should have been. Love always and forever, Deirdre. 1/3

LUFKIN--Marie (Maisie), RSCJ, died September 20 in Albany, NY. Born in New York City August 22, 1932, she was the daughter of Elgood M. and Marie M. Lufkin. Predeceased by her parents and her brothers Thomas Murray McDonnell and John Lufkin, she is survived by her sister- in-law Jane Fisher McDonnell, numerous nieces and nephews, and her sisters in the Society of the Sacred Heart. Sr. Lufkin first met the Society of the Sacred Heart as a student at Manhattanville College. She served in schools in Greenwich, CT, and Buffalo, NY before becoming curriculum coordinator, teacher and guidance counselor at Convent of the Sacred Heart, E. 91st St., New York. She served on the provincial leadership team for the former RSCJ New York Province, 1974-82. From 1993-2014, she served the economically poor at Little Sisters Family Health Services in East Harlem, NY, teaching English as a Second Language and as administrative assistant to the director. Funeral Mass 1pm Monday, September 28 at Convent of the Sacred Heart, 1 E. 91st St., New York. Burial at Society of the Sacred Heart Cemetery at Kenwood 11am, October 3. 1/3

URCIUOLI--Margaret Jane "Maggie." Maggie Urciuoli, 73, succumbed on September 19, 2015, after a long battle with multiple myeloma. She is survived by her husband of 49 years, J. Arthur ("Archie") Urciuoli, their children, Caryn Sloan Jacoby and her husband R.J. Jacoby, of Greenwich, CT, and Christian J.A. Urciuoli, and his wife Rebecca Jones Urciuoli, of New York City, and grandchildren Jackson, Sloan and Maggie Jacoby, and Jane and Nina Urciuoli. Born on March 8, 1942, the daughter of Matthew A. Forelli and the former Ethel Jane Sloan, Maggie was raised in Old Greenwich, CT, and was a Choate Rosemary Hall, Garland Junior College, and Boston University Fine Arts graduate. She was "Moopsie" as a child, "Maggie" most of her life, and "Nanni" to her beloved grandchildren. She was an artist, artisan and avid golfer. As a young woman, she was a well-known painter in oils. With partner Bobbie Schoonmaker, she founded and ran Small Ideas, a producer of fine antique furniture reproductions in miniature, for almost 20 years. As a hobby, she produced exquisite handmade Nantucket baskets. She served on the Board of Trustees of Choate Rosemary Hall and the board of the Casey Key Library. She was an active supporter of the Casey Key Association and of Girls Inc. of Sarasota County, and was a member of the Oaks, Ritz-Carlton, and Silvermine (Connecticut) golf clubs. Maggie and Archie moved to Casey Key, FL, in 1999, and spent their summers in Rowayton, CT. They previously lived in New York City, Paris, and Greenwich, CT. Memorial services will be held at 11:00am at the Ewing Chapel in Venice, FL on November 10, and at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, CT on November 23. Donations may be made in Maggie's memory to Girls Inc. of Sarasota County. 1/3

HERTZIG--Rita Post. Beautiful Rita Post Hertzig died peacefully at home after a short illness. She was the wife of philanthropist Saul Hertzig for 35 wonderful years. They led an exciting, interesting life traveling the world. She was a successful stock broker and a philanthropist in her own right. She is survived by her brother Dr. Stanley Post and her sister-in-law Gladys, as well as her niece and nephew Victoria Risko and Jack Risko and Dr. Anthony Post and Dr. Marjorie Greenfield and great grand nephews and niece, all of who loved and admired her. 1/3

ROCHE--Brenda Boel. March 21, 1942--September 13, 2015. Brenda Boel Roche died peacefully in her Upper East Side home on Sunday, September 13, 2015 at the age of 73. Born in Shafter, California, she earned her Bachelor of Science degree in Physical Therapy from the University of California, Davis in 1964 before moving to New York City. An accomplished artist, Mrs. Roche was both an illustrator and a sculptor. She was a lover of fine and contemporary art and took a variety of classes at the National Academy Museum and School. Having lived in New York City for over five decades, Mrs. Roche was a true New Yorker and had a voracious appetite for the city's cultural offerings, rarely missing a play, art opening, or museum exhibition. She will be remembered for both her extraordinary talent as well as her wry sense of humor. She was married to the late John G. Roche for 42 years until his death in April of 2014. She is survived by her brother, Bonner Boel, her son, Jonathan Roche, her daughter, Sarah Roche Gilman, son in law, Felix Gilman, and grandchildren, William and Zoe Gilman, as well as countless devoted friends. A service is being planned for later this fall. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations to the Center for Arts Education, which benefits New York City youth. 1/3

ARNEBERG--Tor Birger, sportsman, died September 23rd following a long and courageous battle with Ataxia. A man of great personal integrity, he was an excellent athlete, Olympic silver medalist, and captain of the 1950 Dartmouth ski team. He received his MBA from Harvard Business School. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Jean, three daughters, Elisabeth Phillips of Belleair, FL, Marianne Arneberg of Orlando, FL, Karin Hathaway of Norwich, VT, six grandchildren and three great- grandchildren. Donations may be made to the American Scandinavian Foundation, 58 Park Ave., NY, NY 10016. 1/3

TAKAGI--Paul Takao, died of natural causes on September 13, 2015 at his home in Oakland, CA. He was 92 years old. He was preceded in death by his wife of 36 years, Mary Anna H. Takagi, his sister, Hannah Tomiko Holmes, and his son-in-law, Toby D'Oench. After internment at Manazar during WWII, he attended UC Berkeley, worked as a probation officer for the California Department of Corrections, returned to school to earn a Ph.D. in Sociology from Stanford University, and became a faculty member in the School of Criminology at UC Berkeley. A strong and steadfast advocate for social justice, he was critical of police use of deadly force and an early advocate for community policing. He is well-known as a key figure in the Third World Strike (1969) at UC Berkeley, the first faculty sponsor of a course on the history of Asian Americans at UC Berkeley, and an early advocate for reparations for Japanese Americans imprisoned during WWII. While his accomplishments are many, those closest to him will remember him as a fabulous cook with a generous heart and acerbic wit, a man with an abiding love of the rugged outdoors. He loved his annual fall trips to camp and fish on the Klamath River. He will be missed by his daughters Tani Hideyo Takagi and Dana Yasu Takagi, grandchildren Robin Takao D'Oench and Miye Emma D'Oench, Brenda Ponthier, and many close family friends, colleagues, and students. No memorial services are planned. 1/3

FISCHLER--William J.,86, of Manhattan and Ancram died peacefully on September 25. Beloved father of Jeffery (Lillian) and Paul, dear sister of Anlee Marcus (Myron), adored grandfather of Gabe and Danny, husband of the late Sandra Zook, uncle and great-uncle, and devoted companion of Susan Gersten. His zest for life, travel, family, and friends, and his humor and generosity will be sorely missed by all who love him. 1/3

BLAICHMAN--Cesia, 90, passed away peacefully September 24, 2015 surrounded by family. Cherished and loving wife of Frank for 70 years. Devoted mother to Bella and Charles (Aviva); grandmother to Etan, Talia (Tym), Maya, Micah, Sabrina and Noah. Great-grandmother to Ceila. Sister of Jack Pomeranc. Raised in Wlodawa, Poland she fought bravely against Nazi Germany as a Jewish Partisan, active in the forests and small villages around Lublin. Cesia nursed the wounded, cooked for her fellow partisans and participated in operations to both protect her fellow Jews and punish their murderers. She survived with her three partisan fighting brothers - Jack, Yurik z"l and Abie z"l. Their parents, Bella Ita z"l, Lazar z"l, as well as three sisters -Chaya z'l, Matele z"l, Chana z"l, perished along with innumerable relatives. After the War she married Frank, her dearest comrade-in-arms, and emigrated with him to New York where they began a vibrant life and raised a beautiful family. Her elegant, delicious Shabbat and Holiday meals were legendary; her love and devotion to her family and friends absolute; her grief for her lost loved ones un-ending. As a true daughter of Israel, her commitment to Yiddishkeit and Holocaust Remembrance was sacrosanct. Cesia served as a committee member for the American IDF, Yad Va Shem, Hadassah, and several other notable organizations. Most of all, she was the warmest, most caring and loving woman, and will live forever in our hearts. Donations may be made to yadvashemusa.org or jewishpartisans.org. Services to be held Sunday, September 27 at noon "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

ADLER--Myron "Mike". The Board of Directors, staff, members with aphasia, their caregivers and volunteers of the Adler Aphasia Center fondly remember Myron "Mike" Adler, beloved husband of Elaine Adler and co-founder in 2003 of the Adler Aphasia Center. Mike was a game changer in the world of aphasia. A real hero to people with aphasia and their caregivers, he devoted much of his life following his own stroke in 1993 to improving the quality of life for those living with aphasia. Mike helped to guide the Adler Aphasia Center in developing its profile as a model of excellence in the worldwide aphasia community. He was a longtime board member of the National Aphasia Association and a driving force behind the creation of AphasiaAccess. Mike also served his community on numerous boards and was the recipient of national and state awards. His vision and passionate support to the aphasia community will always be a part of Mike Adler's legacy. Our heartfelt condolences to Elaine, and the entire Adler family. The family has requested that donations in Mike's memory be made to AdlerAphasiaCenter.org. Charles P. Berkowitz, President, Board of Directors and Karen Tucker, Executive Director, Adler Aphasia Center 1/3

ROOT--Dr. Leon. The Visiting Nurse Service of New York wishes to express our deep condolences to the family of Dr. Leon Root, including his wife, Paula, his children, Matthew and Lili, his brother, Benjamin, and his four grandchildren. The founder and longtime chief of the pediatric orthopedic program at the Hospital for Special Surgery, Dr. Root was one of the nation's outstanding surgeons and healers, as well as a tireless advocate for children and their families throughout the New York metropolitan area and beyond. As one of many institutions that have recognized him for his immense contributions over the years, VNSNY was privileged to present Dr. Root with the 2008 Lillian D. Wald Award, our own organization's highest honor. In addition to his own work, Dr. Root was a staunch supporter of his wife, Paula, and her many efforts on behalf of VNSNY, for which we are especially grateful. Paula, now an Emeritus Director of VNSNY, served as a member of the VNSNY Board of Directors for three decades, a role that included chairing VNSNY's Family Care Services Board, where she introduced many innovative initiatives to improve the health of New York's children. As a physician, visionary community health leader, devoted husband, father and grandfather, and a friend to all who knew him, Dr. Root has left an indelible legacy. The Board of Directors and Leadership of Visiting Nurse Service of New York 1/3

GRUSKIN--Felice, age 87, passed away on August 14, 2015. She was born and spent most of her life in NYC. She received a business degree from City College and worked as a bookkeeper. She lost her husband Abraham, in 1971, never remarried. She is survived by her brother, two sons and a grandson. She spent most of her life in Washington Heights (upper Manhattan), where she was active in the Democratic Party and twice elected as District Leader. She also started a grassroots organization, Transit Riders In Pursuit, which published a quarterly newsletter and advocated for increased mass-transit and lowering/eliminating the fare. Later on she also became active in the Henry George School and Schalkenbach Foundation, advocating for a Land Value Tax and two-rate taxation (of land). In 1995, she moved to Rego Park, Queens, where she continued to be active in the Republican Party. She is very well traveled, having visited Europe, Russia, Mexico, Hong Kong, China, Central and South America as well as Israel and the Middle East. 1/3

HAROVAS--Dr. Antoine C, The Harovas family is deeply saddened by the unexpected passing of Dr. Antoine C Harovas, beloved husband of Euterpe Harovas, devoted father of Anna and Michael Xylas, Lea and John Bendo, and Stephanie and Bryan Ferro, cherished grandfather of Alexander, Evan, Alexa, Nicholas, Andrew, and Sophia, and dedicated brother of Arthur and Betty Harovas. Born in Hartford, Connecticut, Dr. Harovas, at 82 years old, passed away peacefully with his family and friends by his side in New York City on September 24, 2015. He worked tirelessly as a dedicated cardiologist, where most of his professional life including his training was spent at Roosevelt Hospital. He was equally devoted to the Greek Orthodox Church and its ministries. He was a man of uncommon integrity, generosity, and compassion who instilled strong values in all of his family members. The viewing will be at The Cathedral of the Holy Trinity at 319 East 74th Street, New York, NY on September 28th from 6:00 to 9:00pm. Funeral services will be at The Cathedral of the Holy Trinity on September 29th at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in memory of Antoine C Harovas to the Saint Nicholas National Shrine at the World Trade Center, c/o the Greek Orthodox Archdiocese of America, 8 East 79th Street, New York, NY 10075. 1/3

LARSON--Jack. The Directors of the Virgil Thomson Foundation, Ltd. mourn the passing of Jack Larson, longtime friend of Virgil Thomson and librettist for Thomson's third opera, "Lord Byron." Jack was a distinguished poet, playwright, actor, and translator of musical works including "L'Histoire du Soldat" by Stravinsky. His friendship and collaboration with composers and musicians are treasured memories for all of us. Charles Fussell, President 1/3

GOLD--Gloria, a gentle and creative woman, died on August 18, 2015. Born Gloria Judith Lipsky in Rochester, N.Y., on June 17, 1924, she attended Indiana University and, while raising her family, graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1970. She was the devoted wife of Martin Gold, who died in 2012. She lived in White Plains, Manhattan, and Chevy Chase, Md. She loved books, opera, crossword puzzles, and a good joke. A prolific artist, she was a member of the Art Students League from 1978 until her death. Her paintings and collages adorn the walls of her children, grandchildren, nephews, and nieces. She dearly loved her sisters Harriet and Esther; children Laurence, Matthew, and Emily, and their spouses Susanne, Lois, and Barney; grandchildren Marisa, David, Diana, Dana, Alice, Owen, Kira, and Clara; and her extraordinary extended family. 1/3

CURTIN--Ann Dixon, formerly of Montclair, NJ, died at her home in Vero Beach, FL on Saturday, September 19 just two weeks shy of her 94th birthday. Born in Elizabeth, NJ, Ann resided in Montclair, NJ for more than 65 years. She graduated from The Kimberly School in 1939 and Manhattanville College in 1943. Ann was also a member of the first training class of New York City's Red Cross Volunteer Nurses' Aid Corps during World War II. She was married to her beloved husband John P. Curtin for 39 years until his death in 1986. Ann was an active volunteer with the Junior League of Montclair, Mountainside Hospital, and the Red Cross. She was a member of The Oak Harbor Club and Holy Cross Catholic Church in Vero Beach. Ann was also a long- time member of the Montclair Golf Club, the Bay Head Yacht Club, and The Moorings Club. She is survived by her four devoted children: Ellen Curtin of San Diego, John P. Curtin, Jr. of Toronto, Kate Curtin Lindsey of Washington, DC and Kyle Curtin of New York City as well as her five grandchildren: Hayden Curtin, Thomas F Curtin III, Whitney Curtin, John Lindsey and Andrew Lindsey. Ann's keen mind, unparalleled wit, and well-known feisty spirit, combined with her commitment to family and friends will never be forgotten by those lucky enough to have known her. Memorial donations may be made to the Visiting Nurse Association and Hospice Foundation of Indian River County, 1110 35th Lane, Vero Beach, FL 32960 in memory of Ann Dixon Curtin. Services will be held at Holy Cross Catholic Church on Monday, October 5 at 11am. 1/3

VAN ALEN--Elizabeth (Betty) Brinton Kent, of Palm Beach, Florida, who spent a long life of devotion to family, friends and country, died of natural causes on September 6 at age 104. She was the daughter of inventor and radio manufacturing pioneer A. Atwater Kent and Mabel Lucas Kent. In 1931, she married architect William L. Van Alen, many years chairman of Children's Hospital of Philadelphia, and enjoyed a loving marriage over more than 71 years until his death in 2003. During World War II, she was the president of the Stage Door Canteen in Philadelphia, serving members of the armed forces. In the 1960s, she founded and operated the successful Pear Tree Shop in Bryn Mawr, PA, which was highly regarded as an excellent source of home furnishings. She was a board member of the Freedom's Foundation at Valley Forge, the Temple of Understanding in Washington, D.C., the Philadelphia Recreation Association, the National Recreation Association and the International Recreation Association. Mrs. Van Alen was the magnetic center of her family. She was warm and supportive and was admired for her ever-present loving nature which characterized her personality even during the difficulties of old age. She is survived by her son James L. Van Alen and his wife Bonnie, her daughter, Cassandra Ludington and her husband Nick, nine grandchildren and 16 great-grandchildren. Her oldest son, William L. Van Alen Jr. died in 2010. She will be sorely missed and long and lovingly be remembered by her extended family and friends. A memorial service will be held at St. David's Church, 753 Valley Forge Road, Wayne, PA, 19087 at 2:30pm, October 16, 2015. In place of flowers, please make a donation to Children's Hospital of Philadelphia or Willistown Conservation Trust. www.maugergivnish.com 1/3

BURNS--George Edward, 86, died September 23, 2015, of complications from Alzheimer's Disease. Born in Scranton, grew up in Washington, DC, graduated from Georgetown, finally settling in NYC in the 60's. He had a varied career with AAA, Pan Am, TWA, and Citibank. He was active in Civil Air Patrol, Overseas Press Club, and the Iron Gate Chapter of the Air Force Association. He is survived by his wife Barbara. There will be a wake from 6-9pm at Riverside Memorial Chapel on Monday evening the 28th, with a Vigil Service of sung evening vespers and remembrances at 7:30pm. A funeral mass will be held at Holy Name of Jesus Church (96th and Amsterdam) at 10:30am on Tuesday, September 29th. Burial will take place at Mt. Olivet Cemetery in Washington, DC, on Thursday morning at 11:30. A full obituary is on the Riverside Memorial Chapel website. 1/3

ROBINSON--Joyce Ellen. November 13, 1932 -September 23, 2015. Joyce E. Robinson was Executive Director and President of the Marie Walsh Sharpe Art Foundation. Under her direction and leadership, the foundation created programs to provide assistance to artists through workshops, teaching seminars, artist resources and studio space. Joyce was a tireless supporter of the arts. Her legacy lives on through the work of the many thousands of artists lives she has impacted. We are honored to continue her legacy through the Sharpe- Walentas Studio Program and send our deepest sympathies to her immediate family. David and Jane Walentas Lisa Kim Sharpe-Walentas Studio Program 1/3

McGRAW--Deborah Ann (Hunkele). Surrounded by family, Deborah Ann (Hunkele) McGraw died at home on September 18, 2015, after a courageous 12 year battle with cancer. She was 74. Loving spouse, mother, grandmother, sister, cousin and friend, Debbie lived life fully. She lived hers in a compelling spirit of strength, integrity, kindness and grace, reflected in a dazzling smile, which immediately drew people to her. She was born in Newark, NJ and graduated with honors from Passaic Valley High School in Little Falls, NJ. She attended Montclair State University and Katharine Gibbs Business College. Three children from a first marriage to Edward "Ned" Connolly, MD, survive her: Sean Connolly (Hannah), Kristin (Connolly) Barnes, and Eli Connolly, as well as two step-children: Sean McGraw and Maureen McGraw. She is also survived by her husband of 36 years, David, and devoted Old English Sheepdog, Lexie; as well as three beloved grandchildren, Shamus Berry, Brenna Connolly and Asher Connolly. After her children were well into high school, she began a retail business career, which included positions at Papyrus in Berkeley, Batus Corporation in North Carolina, and Peet's Coffee & Tea in Berkeley, where she rose through various management positions to Vice President of Retail Store Operations & Merchandising. In retirement she spent time on the board of the Berkeley City Club, where she restored the hotel portion to its original Julia Morgan elegance. Deborah and David traveled widely in North America and Europe. Debbie especially loved Italy, the people and culture, returning many times. A Funeral Mass will be held at Our Lady of Lourdes Catholic Church at 2808 Lakeshore Avenue in Oakland, CA on Friday, October 23rd at 11am. 1/3
GINSBURGH--Gail Winslow. We have lost our dearest friend and irreplaceable companion. May she rest in peace. With Love, Lynn, Bob and Talley 1/3

SOBOL--Tom. A memorial service for educator Tom Sobol will be held on Saturday, October 24, 2015 in the Cowin Auditorium at Teachers College, Columbia University, Broadway and 120 St. Assembly 10:15-11am Program 11am. BOXILL--Professor Roger, (27 March 1928 to 15 September 2015) As a boy, Roger attended the Little Red School House in Greenwich Village, and New York's Professional Children's School and High School of Music and Art. After training at the Royal Academy in London, he was an actor on Stage and Television. Of his many roles his favorite was Prince Hal in Shakespeare's I Henry IV. Later he took a PhD at Columbia University and joined the English Department at the City College of CUNY. Not surprisingly, his preferred course as an instructor was Shakespeare, which he taught many times. During this time he also was a respected director of theater productions in the New York area. As a critic of drama he published two books, one on Bernard Shaw's views on health and the medical profession and the other on the plays of Tennessee Williams. His interest in the exotic led him to travel up the Nile to see the pyramids and to explore other parts of the Middle East. Somewhat closer to home, he spent a year as Adjunct Professor of English at the University of Paris. In 1993 he retired from academic life. He had long been an ardent tennis player, and continued honing his game in retirement, but his primary study was the singing of choral and solo music. He was an avid student of voice and music theory, sang in many venerable New York choruses, became a devoted member of the "Friday Night" singing group and released a recording of his favorite songs and arias several years ago. Roger had no immediate family, but his many friends will miss him deeply. Please inquire at oaklandopensing@gmail.com to send remembrances and for information about a celebration of his life in early November. 1/3

GRANGER--Patricia Anne. Patricia Anne Granger Peet, passed away at her home in Key West, Florida on Thursday, September 10, 2015 after courageously battling a long illness. Patricia is survived by her husband and soulmate Stephen Peet, her four daughters; Lisa Marie Willett of Fairfield, CT, Cari Anne Hanzl of Charleston, SC, Bridget Peet Conger of Rockville, MD and Deirdre Peet Baule of Chevy Chase, MD and eight wonderful grandchildren. Patricia was an active person throughout her life, playing competitive golf and tennis. Patricia was a gourmet cook, an avid reader and movie goer, constantly challenging herself and exploring new sources of learning. Ending her business career as the CEO of UTAC America Inc., Patricia was the first woman to be inducted into the 24 Karat Club of the City of New York. Outside of the corporate world, Patricia was also very passionate about art and upon retirement, she became an accomplished pastel, portrait artist. Patricia was a high energy person who loved to be involved in her community. A native New Yorker who moved to Key West in 2003 and in her typical fashion, she promptly became an official Key West Ambassador. Patricia loved spending time with her family and traveling. She loved life and loved to laugh. We love you and miss you very much. Here are your red balloons! Contributions in Patricia's memory may be made to CurePSP at: www.psp.org. 1/3

HALL--Emma Swan, June 30, 1914 to September 23, 2015. Miss Hall was a 1937 graduate of Bennington College and received a Master of Arts from Columbia University. A writer and editor in the Department of Ancient Art at The Brooklyn Museum from 1963 to 1983 and at NYU's Institute of Fine Arts from 1983 to 1993. She was the author and editor of many books. Member of the International Association of Egyptologists, Life Member of The American Research Center of Egypt, The Brooklyn Museum, The Courtauld Institute, London. Widow of the late Monroe B. Hall. Survived by two nephews, Joseph Junkin and David Junkin, and a first cousin, Dr. Richard Lawrence, Jr. She lived a rich life and was involved in ideas and activities she loved. 1/3

HALBRIDGE--Donald. Passed away on September 20, 2015. Loving son of the late Benjamin and Esther Halbridge. Devoted brother of Ellen Berman, Barbara Halbridge and Edward Halbridge. Caring uncle and granduncle. He was loved and will be missed. 1/3

KULPERGER--Robert J.,74, peacefully at home on September 22, 2015. Founder and Chairman of the Board of National Chemistry. Beloved husband of Arlene McKay. WILDER--Susan Katrina Peters. Died on September 22, 2015 at her Manhattan home of breast cancer. She was 71. A native New Yorker and daughter of German born parents, she maintained a residence in Manhattan her entire life. She graduated in 1962 from Holy Cross Academy in New York; and, after receiving a liberal arts degree from Barnard in 1966, Sue received a master's degree from NYU in Russian History. Starting as an Investment research assistant at Bankers Trust in 1966, Sue became an institutional investment manager and vice president at Citibank, moving on to investment management positions at Alliance Capital and then with Oppenheimer. While she remained a committed, lifelong New Yorker, her second love was her private weekends at her farm in Upstate New York, becoming an accomplished tennis player, windsurfer, skier, and horseperson. She loved animals and supported many charities that focused on animal rescue and rehabilitation efforts, volunteering with the Wildlife Conservation Society and as an assistant to a researcher-author at the Museum of Natural History. She is survived by her husband, Robert and by her cat, Dickens. Donations in her memory may be made to: The Raptor Center at the University of Minnesota or the Wildlife Conservation Society. 1/3

ROOT--Leon. Leon was talented and compassionate. At the Hospital for Special Surgery he cared for and treated every single member of the Levitt family and we miss him dearly. Marylin and Arthur Levitt 1/3

TREIBER--Millicent Hope, died peacefully (or as Hope would prefer, "gathered") on September 14, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. She is survived by her brother, Henry C. Haer and her sister-in-law, Sally Haer; her children - John H. (Carol-Ann), H. Craig (Lora), Bruce D. (Virginia), Peter S. (Irene), Scott R. (Jo-Ellen), Pamela H. Treiber Baldwin; 18 grandchildren, and many nieces, nephews, and loving friends. Hope was predeceased by her husband Howard, her sister Joan, her niece Robin Gross, and her parents Henry C. and Mae Lillian (Murphy) Haer. Hope was born in Morristown, NJ, and raised in Sayville, NY, where she played soccer and was a Sayville High School cheerleader. She was proud of her participation in the war effort as a plane spotter in the tower of the old Sayville High School. She went on to graduate from St. John's Episcopal Hospital Nursing School as a RN. Hope married Howard F. Treiber on November 25, 1949 and moved to Old Brookville in 1955 where they raised their six children. Hope loved her home most when it was filled with her children and their friends and in later years with her grandchildren. She enjoyed being very active all her life with golf, tennis, jogging, and until only several years ago, working out at the YMCA at Glen Cove. Hope's love of nature and living things was a passion all her life, whether feeding birds, watching baby birds in her birdhouses, butterflies, insects, bird nests, and her ever-blooming garden and house plants. Hope was an accomplished crossword aficionado and a dedicated Jeopardy fan. She was a fiercely independent lady, with an indomitable spirit and will, and she always put other's needs and sensitivities ahead of hers throughout her life. Hope's unconditional love and support became the strength of her family. She was a remarkable mother and grandmother and will be missed so very much. Hope did not believe in death but rather in life, and in accordance with her wishes, there will be no wake but a memorial service on Saturday, October 24, at 2pm, at St. Paul's Episcopal Church on Highland Avenue, Glen Cove. In lieu of flowers, donations in Hope's memory may be made to: SCO Family of Services, One Alexander Place, Glen Cove, NY 11542, or YMCA at Glen Cove, Dosoris Lane, Glen Cove, NY 11542. 1/3

ROTH--Jacob Harrison. Left our world Sunday morning September 20th at the age of 5. To his big sister Emma, he was Jakey. To his mother and father, Mark and Amanda, he was the best son imaginable. He had an infectious smile. He was smart beyond his years. So smart, we can't say that enough. He loved math, his friends, his religious studies and most of all his ENTIRE family. His spirit will never ever leave us. He will never be forgotten and we know he is now with his great grandparents Ira and Elaine. We ALL will always love you more than words can tell. Jacob's memory will also live on with through the Jacob H. Roth Opportunity for Excellence Scholarship Fund at the Jewish Academy in Commack, NY. 1/3

Denise is best remembered for her eight years on the Garry Moore Show, her hit record "If I give my heart to you" and, most of all, for a lifetime of kindness and generosity to all who crossed her path. She is survived by her two sons, Ron and Denis Martin. 1/3

Irene was passionate about art, bridge, movies, tennis, theater, travel and all liberal causes. She loved life and lived it that way. BLACHMAN--Lucy Lipshitz. On Thursday, September 24th, Lucy Blachman, passed away peacefully, with those who loved her at her side. Lucy was born in 1927 in the Bronx, as the only child of Bernard and Sara Lipshitz. She is survived by her son, Eric; son and daughter-in-law, Jeremy and Lauren, and their children, Abby and Ben; son and daughter-in-law, Neil (Asher) and Hannah, and their four children, Natan, Renana, Shaul and Meir. She was preceded in death by her husband, of 45 years, Arthur Blachman. Lucy graduated from the Juilliard School of Music. She taught piano for over 50 years, at Juilliard, The School for Strings in Manhattan, and privately in her home in Briarcliff Manor, NY. She also performed in many venues in the northeast, including Carnegie Hall and Alice Tully Hall. Lucy will be remembered for her great intellect, kind and gentle demeanor, talent in music and passionate love of her family. Donations in her memory may be made to The Juilliard School, https://giving.juilliard. edu/, The Emery Weiner School, www.emeryweiner. org, or The Shlenker School, www.shlenker.org. 1/3

CURTIS--Dr. Gabriel George, (79) of Crestwood passed away peacefully on Tuesday, September 22, 2015. Since his retirement, Gabe and his wife Elaine resided in Chester County, PA. Born in 1936 in Manhattan, Gabe was the son of the late Gabriel and Anna (Turcut) Cuculescu. Gabe graduated from Fordham University in 1958 and New York Medical College in 1962. He was a commissioned Naval Officer serving as a doctor onboard the USS Enterprise (CVN-65) and was honorably discharged as Lieutenant Commander. Prior to retiring, Gabe practiced anesthesia for 38 years at New York Hospital - Weill Cornell Medical Center where he was a highly regarded member of the medical facility and a distinguished Professor. Gabe is survived by his wife Elaine, sister Diana McGonnell, daughters Kim Venditto and Kris Irey, son Robert Curtis, and stepchildren Daria Miller, Matthew, Paul and Andrew Greenjack. Also surviving are 15 grandchildren and step grandchildren. Visitation will be held at St. Herman's of Alaska Orthodox Church, 855 Middletown Road, Gradyville, PA (610-459-5310) on September 28 from 3pm-7pm. A Service of Christian Burial will be held September 29 at 11am in the church, followed by Interment at Union Hill Cemetery in Kennett Square, PA. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to St. Herman's of Alaska Orthodox Church or the Wounded Warriors Project. Services are being handled by Kaniefski, Kendus, D'Anjolell Memorial Home in Trainer, PA (610-494-6220). 1/3
