25BLACKMAN--Mark Kenneth III, died peacefully at his home in Brooklyn on September 20, 2015. Mark, born October 25, 1941 in Cedar Rapids, IA, was a consummate storyteller and his own life story is a good one, complex and interesting. From All American Boy in Fargo, ND, to graduating from Princeton University cum laude, to international banking in Bangkok, Thailand and Sao Paulo, Brazil, to silver importer in Chicago and finally as professor at LaGuardia Community College, Mark embraced the world with curiosity and humor, communicating fluently in five languages. AA was an integral part of his life in New York. He is survived by his son, Matthew, siblings John (Paddy) and Anne Collins and numerous nieces and nephews to whom he was affectionately known as "Unc." Mark, always a challenge, was nonetheless loved by his family and will be greatly missed. A private family service will be held at a later date. Raccuglia and Son handled the local services. Memorials can be made to LaGuardia Community College. 1/3
TIEFER--Rosalind Crost. Ninth Yahrzeit. So much grief and gratitude. Leonore 1/3

HALL--Emma Swan, June 30, 1914 to September 23, 2015. Miss Hall was a 1937 graduate of Bennington College and received a Master of Arts from Columbia University. A writer and editor in the Department of Ancient Art at The Brooklyn Museum from 1963 to 1983 and at NYU's Institute of Fine Arts from 1983 to 1993. She was the author and editor of many books. Member of the International Association of Egyptologists, Life Member of The American Research Center of Egypt, The Brooklyn Museum, The Courtauld Institute, London. Widow of the late Monroe B. Hall. Survived by two nephews, Joseph Junkin and David Junkin, and a first cousin, Dr. Richard Lawrence, Jr. She lived a rich life and was involved in ideas and activities she loved. 1/3

MAISEL--Jerome E.,M.D. With great sadness the family of Dr. Jerome E. Maisel announces his death on September 25, 2015, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. He was the beloved husband of 31 years of Ruth Israelite Seiger Maisel, the devoted father of John, William and Luisa Maisel, caring step-father of Kenneth I. Seiger, and loving grandfather of Lindsay, Roxanna, Theo, and Olivia. He was pre-deceased by his late wife Melva Weinberger Maisel in 1981. Dr. Maisel served in the Army Air Force as a weatherman in WWII. "Jerry" was known for his devotion to humanitarian causes, his spirit, and zest for life. He was a compassionate pediatrician who practiced in Hewlett, NY for 50 years, and was loved and admired by his patients and their families for his caring, gentleness and expertise. Service Tuesday, September 29, 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76 St and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

LINETT--Eugene Salem, died at home on September 25 at the age of 83. Beloved husband of Caryl. Devoted father of Dana Linett-Silber (Uzi) and Andrea Linett-Waring (Michael). Much loved grandfather of Jack, Libby and Asher. Graduate of Horace Mann High School, Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Williams College and graduate of Yale Law School. He will be missed by many friends and relatives. 1/3

de BROSSARD--Boyd, died peacefully at his home on Thursday, September 24th, 2015 at the age of 94. He is survived by his beloved wife, Dina. He will be missed dearly by his family and friends all over the world. He was a true gentleman at all times and had a great sense of humor, he was a loving spouse and friend, and lived his life fully until the end. 1/3

FISHMAN--Gloria. High Ridge Country Club acknowledges with sorrow the passing of our esteemed member, Gloria Fishman. We extend our deepest sympathy to her beloved family. Robert D. Lang, President Harvey Karofsky, Secretary 1/3

BREITKOPF--Burton "Buddy," 86, died peacefully on September 26, 2015. Born and bred in Brooklyn, graduated from the City College of New York and New York University Law School with a Juris Doctor degree, he served honorably in the United States Army during the Korean War in the Army Intelligence Unit as a Corporal. Late in his law career he became a Magistrate which he enjoyed immensely. Beloved father of Neil, David and Joel, beloved stepfather of Lilac and Ronen, adored grandfather of Natalie and Olivia, adored step-grandfather of Noah, Jonah, Luke and Dean, and Uncle Buddy to countless competitive tennis players of all ages. He ran national and sectional tennis tournaments for decades at the Shelter Rock Tennis Club in Manhasset and was actively involved with the Eastern Tennis Association. Buddy loved being a lawyer for over fifty years and counted many of his clients as his family and closest friends. His love of family, travel, fishing, tennis and fine food gave him great stories which he shared with many. His humor, wisdom, generosity and warm smile will be missed by all who knew him. Memorial service will be at 11:30am on Tuesday, September 29th at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, NY. 1/3

OPPENHEIMER--Muriel Faith Wolfson, born January 26, 1920 in the Bronx, passed away peacefully in her sleep in New York on September 26, 2015. She was a life-long activist for social justice, and one of the founders of Women Strike For Peace. She was pre-deceased by Peter Oppenheimer, her husband of 56 years, and leaves behind her loving children Michael, David and Amy, their wives Donna, Marcy and Jennifer, her grandchildren Alex, Joel, Harry, Talia, Julius, Peter and Adin, and her great-grandchildren Isaac and Vincent. 1/3

SPERLING--Norman "Mel", 85, left us on September 24, 2015 after a series of prolonged illnesses. He was surrounded in his final hours by his adoring wife, Marylin Kurlan Sperling, his devoted children, Harvey Sperling and Elissa Lazev, and son-in-law Rick Lazev. He is mourned by his many beloved nieces, nephews, cousins, and his cherished grandchildren, Jordan, Ryan, and Ava Lazev. His parents, Ceil and Paul Sperling, and sister, Francine Mendelsohn, predeceased him. He will live forever in the hearts and minds of his beloved ones. Donations in his memory my be sent to the Jewish National Fund, the Jewish Genealogical Society of Long Island, or a charity of choice. 1/3

ARNEBERG--Tor Birger, sportsman, died September 23rd following a long and courageous battle with Ataxia. A man of great personal integrity, he was an excellent athlete, Olympic silver medalist, and captain of the 1950 Dartmouth ski team. He received his MBA from Harvard Business School. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Jean, three daughters, Elisabeth Phillips of Belleair, FL, Marianne Arneberg of Orlando, FL, Karin Hathaway of Norwich, VT, six grandchildren and three great- grandchildren. Donations may be made to the American Scandinavian Foundation, 58 Park Ave., NY, NY 10016. 1/3

RESNICK--Al Deane, 86, peacefully passed away Saturday, September 19, 2015 at the Hebrew Home in Riverdale, NY. She is survived by her daughters Linda and Doretha and predeceased by her husband Sam and her son Alwyn. Rest In Peace, DeeDee. 1/3

FEHRENBACHER-- Fr. Henry. 1920-2015. Died September 18 in St. Cloud, MN. A pastor in Minnesota, writer for U.S. Catholic, Salt and seven books, English teacher at Morehead State and Baruch, minister to alienated Catholics in NYC, actor (True Confessions, Prizzi's Honor), traveler to 192 countries, a lover of life and God's people, may he rest in peace. 1/3

PORT--Diana, passed away on September 25 at the age of 86. Beloved wife of 65 years of Sol. Loving mother of Joel (Tamar) and Kevin (Sharon). Doting grandmother of Jason, Zachary, Carly and Mathew. She spent a lifetime teaching primary school aged children. Service Friday, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76 Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

WEISFELD--Meyer "Mike." We offer our condolences to Barry, Susan, Danielle and David on the loss of Mike who loved his family and lived life with his huge smile. Karen, Ray, Michael, Spencer and Chelsea 1/3

FISHMAN--Gloria, 89, of Palm Beach, FL passed away peacefully September 26 due to complications from heart surgery. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, she married Harry, the love of her life for 61 years, lived in Hewlett Harbor and later Palm Beach. Wonderful wife, devoted mother, proud grandmother and caring friend, Gloria adored her family and vibrant life. Always impeccably dressed and passionate about everything she did, she enjoyed good food, books, art, old movies, her weekly card games and, for so many years, her renowned annual Rosh Hashanah parties. An ardent supporter of Israel, the homeless and other charitable causes, her generous, independent spirit and warmth will be greatly missed. Predeceased by her loving husband, Harry, Gloria is survived by her daughter Laurie, son Michael (Pam), three adoring grandchildren, Samuel, Joshua and Anna and her sister, Elaine Schwartz. Donations in Gloria's memory may be made to Rachel Coalition, 256 Columbia Turnpike, Suite 105, Florham Park, NJ 07932. Graveside service Tuesday, 11am at Mt. Ararat Cemetery in Lindenhurst, NY. 1/3

BABAD--Herman, 90, died on September 25, 2015. A great lover of life and all it had to offer. Award-winning theater director and dramaturg for community and professional theater. Performer in Yiddish Theatre and community theatre. Life partner of Karen Gerson, of beloved memory, for over 25 years. He is survived by his daughter, Erica; son, Gary; their spouses, Tim Palmer and Mindi Wapner-Babad; his three grandchildren, Adina, Janna, and Zoe; and his ex-wife and lifelong friend, Barbara Babad. 1/3

RAINWATER--Richard Edward, philanthropist, legendary and renowned investor, father, husband, mentor, loyal friend and native Texan, passed away September 27, 2015 at his home in Fort Worth. He was 71. Since 2009, Richard fought valiantly against a debilitating and rare neurological disease, Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP). Along with his family's foundation, he spent the latter part of his life funding and actively engaging the international medical community to launch a bold research effort to combat PSP and discover a cure. His significant investment into brain research and neurodegenerative diseases has been called transformational; the goal is to find a treatment for brain-related diseases. Richard is survived by his wife Darla Moore and three children from a prior marriage, Courtney Rainwater, Todd Rainwater and Matthew Rainwater as well as Richard's brother, Walter Rainwater, sister-in-law, Lori and niece, Kelley. He also leaves behind hundreds of friends, business colleagues and people Richard mentored and launched into entrepreneurship as well as the numerous causes he funded and the countless individuals who were deeply touched by his generosity. "A person's legacy is truly who they leave behind," said Darla Moore, "and Richard populated this country with extraordinary talent that he recognized when they were very young. Not many people are generous with their time when mentoring young people. Richard was the exception." Richard has not made any public appearances since 2010. His son, Matthew said his father was the personification of heroism as he battled the illness. "There is an extraordinary untold story about his heroism and bravery as the symptoms worsened. He was determined to embrace every available moment with his loved ones, and he resolved to establish a robust platform for long term research into tauopathies such as PSP and Alzheimer's Disease," said Matthew. "It's another example of him actually 'willing' something into reality." Richard's life was undoubtedly extended because of the extraordinary care he received over the last five and a half years. The family is deeply appreciative of Stephen Boyd, Jerry Harper, Robert Patterson, Eric Thompson, Barry Less, Norman Finley, Rick Castle, Scott Rhode and Bonnie Dears. Their loving, professional and attentive care added much quality to Richard's life. Former President George W. Bush partnered with Richard and Rusty Rose in 1989 to purchase the Texas Rangers MLB club. Mr. Bush issued a statement about his friend. "I was so saddened to learn that my friend Richard Rainwater died this weekend. Richard had a brilliant mind and a generous heart. He was a lot of fun, inspiring to be around, and generous and courageous to the very end. Laura and I send our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Darla, and to the children he was so proud of: Matthew, Courtney, and Todd. We also send our condolences to his loyal brother, Walter, and to Richard's family, friends, and staff who loved and cared for him." Those sentiments were echoed across the country from Deepdale Country Club where the flags flew at half-mast to the offices of some of the most powerful people in business to a family that Richard seeded money in order to teach a colleague's children how to give money to worthy charities. Richard's friend Ken Hersh called the loss of his friend immeasurable. "I truly believe he was the godfather of the North American private investment business," Hersh told the News. He created an atmosphere and environment where accomplished, ambitious, entrepreneurial and creative people could work." With all of his business success, family and friends were paramount to Richard, and they describe him as playful. In fact, once he was quoted as saying, "I don't feel like it's in anybody's interest to take themselves and life so seriously that they can't have fun." Richard's "fun" came on the golf course, and he was once a partner in the famed Pebble Beach Golf Club. He also invented a new form of friendly competitive golf for rounds with friends; the game was labeled as "Two Ball." A self-described fitness fanatic, Richard, prior to the onset of his illness, was an avid marathon runner. He also loved motorsports and sponsored cars, most notably a 1957 "muscle car," in competitions. Born June 15, 1944 to Walter J. Rainwater Sr. a wholesale grocer, and Regina Dieb Rainwater, a J.C. Penney sales clerk, Richard treasured his Texas roots. He grew up in his native Fort Worth, graduating from R.L. Paschal High School, and he remained a steadfast Panthers fan. He received his undergraduate degree from the University of Texas and had an MBA from Stanford University. At age 26, Sid Bass, a former classmate, hired Rainwater as an investment manager for the Bass family fortune. He directed the Bass fortune of $50 million into $5 billion between 1970 and 1986. In fact, he assisted Michael Eisner when he was Disney CEO to increase his fortune into billions of dollars. In 1986, Richard started his own firm, Rainwater Inc and successfully acquired stakes in companies such as Columbia/HCA Healthcare, Ensco International, Pioneer Natural Resources, Mid Ocean Limited and Crescent Real Estate Equities. His success as an investor is legendary, prompting The New York Times to describe him this week as a "quiet mover of wealth and power" in the country. Services to celebrate a man whose life can be defined by its optimism, generosity, belief in his loved ones as well as his colleagues and friends will be held Friday, October 2, 2015 at Broadway Baptist Church, 305 W. Broadway Avenue, Fort Worth, Texas at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be offered to the Rainwater Neurological Research Fund, www.cfntx.org/rainwater. In addition, the family plans to announce details for a memorial service to be held in New York City on October 27, 2015. 1/3

WEISFELD--Meyer "Mike". It is with deep sorrow that his family announces his passing. Dear husband of Rose, loving father of Steven and Barry, thoughtful father-in-law of Violette and Susan, joyful grandpa of Danielle, Evan, David and Avery. Mike, a pioneer in wholesale optical, was well known and respected as he was on the tennis court until age 92. Funeral services will be private. 1/3

PATTNER--Evelyn, July 23, 1915 to September 26, 2015. It is with great sadness that we announce the passing of Evelyn Pattner. The loving grandmother of Jocelyn and Jonathan Wagner, Justin and Brittany Pattner and great-grandmother of Harper Alexandra Wagner. She will live on in our hearts and minds - love infinitely. SOROKIN--Peter P.,of South Salem, NY. Loving husband of Anita, father to Elena and Paul, brother of Sergei. A physicist at IBM Research for 43 years and a laser pioneer. Calling hours, Wednesday, September 30th from 5 to 7pm at the Kane Funeral Home, 25 Catoonah Street, Ridgefield, CT. 1/3

LAGUDIS--Nicholas, 94, at home on September 25, 2015. Devoted husband of the late Esme (62 years), father to his adoring daughters, Stephanie Neckles, Maria Lechich and Stella Lagudis, and sons-in-law, Tony Lechich and the late Spero Neckles, proud grandfather to Christina, Alexander, Nicholas and Stephanie. Nick, born in Chios, Greece, graduated Brooklyn Technical High School and was in the first graduating class of Kings Point U.S. Merchant Marine Academy ('43). He was deployed as second officer to Pacific, Atlantic and Mediterranean theaters of WWII. For many years he held a coveted Master's License that entitled him to command vessels of all tonnage on all oceans. The memory of his integrety, encyclopedic mind and loving heart will be cherished by all who knew him. 1/3

RAINWATER--Richard. Richard Edward Rainwater, philanthropist, legendary and renowned investor, father, husband, mentor, loyal friend and native Texan, passed away September 27, 2015 at his home in Fort Worth. He was 71. Since 2009, Richard fought valiantly against a debilitating and rare neurological disease, Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP). Along with his family's foundation, he spent the latter part of his life funding and actively engaging the international medical community to launch a bold research effort to combat PSP and discover a cure. His significant investment into brain research and neurodegenerative diseases has been called transformational; the goal is to find a treatment for brain-related diseases. Richard is survived by his wife Darla Moore and three children from a prior marriage, Courtney Rainwater, Todd Rainwater and his wife Lowisa; and Matthew Rainwater and his wife Jessica; as well as Richard's brother, Walter Rainwater, sister-in-law, Lori and nieces, Kelley and Kathryn. He also leaves behind hundreds of friends, business colleagues and people Richard mentored and launched into entrepreneurship as well as the numerous causes he funded and the countless individuals who were deeply touched by his generosity. "A person's legacy is truly who they leave behind," said Darla Moore, "and Richard populated this country with extraordinary talent that he recognized when they were very young. Not many people are generous with their time when mentoring young people. Richard was the exception." Richard has not made any public appearances since 2010. His son, Matthew said his father was the personification of heroism as he battled the illness. "There is an extraordinary untold story about his heroism and bravery as the symptoms worsened. He was determined to embrace every available moment with his loved ones, and he resolved to establish a robust platform for long term research into tauopathies such as PSP and Alzheimer's Disease," said Matthew. "It's another example of him actually 'willing' something into reality." Richard's life was undoubtedly extended because of the extraordinary care he received over the last five and a half years. The family is deeply appreciative of Stephen Boyd, Jerry Harper, Robert Patterson, Eric Thompson, Barry Lee, Norman Finley, Rick Castle, Scott Rhode and Bennie Dears. Their loving, professional and attentive care added much quality to Richard's life. Former President George W. Bush partnered with Richard and Rusty Rose in 1989 to purchase the Texas Rangers MLB club. Mr. Bush issued a statement about his friend. "I was so saddened to learn that my friend Richard Rainwater died this weekend. Richard had a brilliant mind and a generous heart. He was a lot of fun, inspiring to be around, and generous and courageous to the very end. Laura and I send our deepest sympathies to his beloved wife, Darla, and to the children he was so proud of: Matthew, Courtney, and Todd. We also send our condolences to his loyal brother, Walter, and to Richard's family, friends, and staff who loved and cared for him." Those sentiments were echoed across the country from Deepdale Country Club where the flags flew at half-mast to the offices of some of the most powerful people in business to a family that Richard seeded money in order to teach a colleague's children how to give money to worthy charities. Richard's friend Ken Hersh called the loss of his friend immeasurable. "I truly believe he was the godfather of the North American private investment business," Hersh said. He created an atmosphere and environment where accomplished, ambitious, entrepreneurial and creative people could work." With all of his business success, family and friends were paramount to Richard, and they describe him as playful. In fact, once he was quoted as saying, "I don't feel like it's in anybody's interest to take themselves and life so seriously that they can't have fun." Richard's "fun" came on the golf course, and he was once a partner in the famed Pebble Beach Golf Club. He also invented a new form of friendly competitive golf for rounds with friends; the game was labeled as "Two Ball." A self-described fitness fanatic, Richard, prior to the onset of his illness, was an avid marathon runner. He also loved motorsports and sponsored cars, most notably a 1957 "muscle car," in competitions. Born June 15, 1944 to Walter J. Rainwater Sr. a wholesale grocer, and Regina Dieb Rainwater, a J.C. Penney sales clerk, Richard treasured his Texas roots. He grew up in his native Fort Worth, graduating from R.L. Paschal High School, and he remained a steadfast Panthers fan. He received his undergraduate degree from the University of Texas and had an MBA from Stanford University. At age 26, Sid Bass, a former classmate, hired Rainwater as an investment manager for the Bass family fortune. He directed the Bass fortune of $50 million into $5 billion between 1970 and 1986. In fact, he assisted Michael Eisner when he was Disney CEO to increase his fortune into billions of dollars. In 1986, Richard started his own firm, Rainwater Inc and successfully acquired stakes in companies such as Columbia/HCA Healthcare, Ensco International, Pioneer Natural Resources, Mid Ocean Limited and Crescent Real Estate Equities. His success as an investor is legendary, prompting The New York Times to describe him this week as a "quiet mover of wealth and power" in the country. Services to celebrate a man whose life can be defined by its optimism, generosity, belief in his loved ones as well as his colleagues and friends will be held Friday, October 2, 2015 at Broadway Baptist Church, 305 W. Broadway Avenue, Fort Worth, Texas at 11:00am. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be offered to the Rainwater Neurological Research Fund, www.cfntx.org/rainwater. In addition, the family plans to announce details for a memorial service to be held in New York City on October 27, 2015 at Lincoln Center. 1/3

CAMPY--Sheila. Born May 14, 1934 in Queens, NY, daughter of Thomas and Marjorie Keane. And, lastly daughter Susan Young-Smith. For whose heart will forever ache in her mother's absence. CURVIN--Robert. The Trustees of the Charles H. Revson Foundation note with great sadness the passing of our esteemed Trustee Emeritus, Bob Curvin. Bob's keen intellect, unbounded generosity of spirit, and wise judgment were expressed through his numerous contributions to making the world a better place. He will be sorely missed. Reynold Levy, Chairman Julie Sandorf, President 1/3

BARRY--John H.,of Morris Township, NJ died September 29, 2015. He was born in Easton, Pennsylvania in 1916. Mr. Barry, a Certified Public Accountant, was a long time resident of Madison and a member of St. Vincent Martyr Church. He retired from the Mobil Oil Corporation in 1981 where he was the General Auditor. He graduated from Lehigh University in 1938. During World War II, Mr. Barry was a First Lieutenant in the 759 Light Tank Battalion, serving in five campaigns in the European Theater of Operations. He was awarded the Bronze Star. He leaves his wife, Barbara; daughter, Nancy (Larry) Bruce, Madison, NJ; son William (Mary Joe), Carlsbad, CA; son John (Karen), Burlington, VT; and grandchildren Katharine Bruce, Matthew, Kelsey, Margaret Barry and Kevin and Christopher Barry. 1/3
FIFE--Joseph. You were family and a dear friend. I will miss you. Carol 1/3

HILDEBRAND--Gene D. Oklahoma native, quintessential New Yorker, died of cancer at his residence in Pennington, NJ. Devoted husband of many decades of Janice Stogniew Hildebrand. Renaissance man, talent for languages, lover of opera, poetry, Ballet Theatre. Nonprofit executive with an affinity for investment management. A gentleman and gentle man admired by all who truly knew him for his intellect, wit and unprepossessing manner. 1/3
AARON--Gregg. 9/19/1967-10/1/2001 Remembered with love, always in my heart. Mom 1/3

BERNFELD--Marcia Coltun, September 10, 1919 - Sep-tember 24, 2015. Devoted and loving mother, mother-in-law, grandmother, great- grandmother and friend, was born in Brooklyn to immigrants from Eastern Europe. Professionally, she was a Master Teacher to troubled adolescents. Under her healing leadership students thrived. Personally, she was brave, independent, spirited, resourceful, and resilient with clarity about what G-d wanted from her, particularly as a Jewish woman. Jewish values, like education, were important to her. She earned a BA and two MA degrees in Education. In the last decade of her 96 years she found a religious and spiritual home at B'nai Jeshurun Synagogue. She is survived by her children Col. Lawrence Schneider (US Army, Ret.), Rabbi Bonita Taylor and daughter-in-law Nadine Beth Schneider; grandchildren, Edward and Charla Schneider; and LTC Aimee (US Army) and Col. John DeJarnette (US Army, Ret.), and seven great-grandchildren. Donations may be made to NAJC, 901 Route 10, Whippany, NJ, 07981-1156 or WhyHunger, 505 8th Avenue, NYC, NY 10018. 1/3

GREEN--Rita W.,96, of Buffalo, NY, on September 26, 2015. Born in Brooklyn, NY, formerly of Queens Village, NY and Poughquag, NY. From 1970-1974 was the co-district leader of the former 24th Assembly district (Jamaica Estates, Hollis and Queens Village) Independence Democratic Club with former speaker of the Assembly Saul Weprin. Survived by Andrew Green, MD of Buffalo, NY and Leslie Green, DMD of Malvern, PA, five grandchildren, two great-grandchildren. 1/3

BLAICHMAN--Cesia. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of Cesia Blaichman, wife of Board member Frank Blaichman, sister of Board member Jack Pomeranc. Our heartfelt condolences to her husband, her children Bella and Charles (Aviva), her grandchildren, great-grand- children, her brother and to the extended family. May her memory be for a blessing and may the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Leonard Wilf, Chairman Ron Meier, Executive Director 1/3

GLANTZ--Rose. The Board of Trustees of The Fire Island Synagogue notes with sorrow the passing of Rose Glantz, mother of Board member Ellen Portnoy and mother-in-law of Board member Hy Portnoy. Our deepest condolences to the Reiss-Portnoy families. Shaul Magid, Rabbi Basya Schechter, Cantor 1/3

WILLIG--Alan B.,Of Little Falls, NJ died on Saturday, September 26, 2015. He was 76 years of age. Born in Philadelphia, PA, he was the son of the late Benjamin Willig and Bessie Cohen. He was a graduate of Central High School (Class 206). He received Bachelor and Master of Arts degrees from Villanova University. Alan enjoyed a more than forty year career as a theatrical agent. He worked for Hesseltine Baker, Alan Willig Associates, The Tantleff Office, HWA, and Don Buchwald & Associates agencies. His client list included Philip Bosco, Elaine Stritch, Joe Morton, Christopher Reeve, Kevin Gray, Mark Jacoby, Joan Collins, and a host of talented Broadway stars. For a large number of years, he was assistant producer at Philadelphia's Playhouse in the Park. He also was an instructor of English at Baruch College in New York and at the University of Puerto Rico. Alan also worked in the SchooI District of Philadelphia and with the Philadelphia Drama Guild. In recent years, he was in great demand to teach classes in auditioning and career management at many New York theater training schools. His theatrical career began as an actor and he had the good fortune to be a member of the American Shakespeare Festival Company of Stratford, CT in 1961. Alan was an avid supporter of the arts, a long-time subscriber and patron of the Metropolitan Opera, NJPAC, New Jersey Shakespeare Festival, Irish Repertory, and numerous other drama organizations. He had an unabated love affair with everything British, especially the London theater and traveled there numerous times. Alan is survived by his lifetime companion, Dennis Cafiero, of Little Falls; his sister, Sandra Friter and his brother-in-law, Barry Friter of Doylestown, PA; his nephew, Eric Rubin, and his wife, Jennifer; and his niece, Stefanie Rubin along with numerous loving friends, clients, colleagues and students. He was predeceased by his brother Harvey and his stepmother, Dorothy Willig. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 4, at 12 noon at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), in New York City. Friends and family will be gathering at 11am . 1/3

del CORRAL--Victoria. With great sadness, the family of Victoria del Corral inform that she died peacefully Monday, September 28, 2015, in NYC. A Memorial Mass will be held on Saturday, October 3rd, at 10:30am, at St. Thomas More Church, 65 East 89th St. New York, NY. Between Park Ave. and Madison Ave. 1/3

FIFE--Joseph D. The family of Joseph D. Fife, 85, from Hewlett, NY and Boca Raton, FL. died peacefully on Wednesday, September 30, 2015. He is survived by his wife of 62 years, Sondra, his children Mark, Karen, Stuart and their respective spouses, Lori and Mitchell, grandchildren Jennifer, Courtney, Elizabeth, Brandon and Blake, and great-grandchildren Sydney and Aiden. He was a wonderful father, loving Grampy and adoring husband who lived a full and happy life. He will be remembered and missed by all who knew him. 1/3

BASCH--Norma, nee Woloshin, of New York, NY and Truro, MA, born July 4, 1934, died September 29, 2015, on Cape Cod. A professor of American History at Rutgers the State University Of New Jersey from 1979 to 2004, Norma was the author of two groundbreaking works of feminist legal history, Framing Divorce: From the Revolutionary Generation to the Victorians and In the Eyes of the Law: Women, Marriage, and Property in Nineteenth-Century New York. She leaves behind her husband of 59 years, Sheldon, her children Rachel and Fred, her daughter-in-law Susan, and her three grandchildren, Nathaniel, Hannah and Emma. A graveside service will be held for the family. A memorial service is planned for Sunday, October 25, at the Village Temple in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Caroline's Gift, Newtown Youth & Family Services, 15 Berkshire Rd., Sandy Hook, CT 06482. 1/3

BROWN--Thomas Steele. (March 12, 1932 - October 2, 1990), neuropsychologist and father, took his own life 25 years ago today, after a life long battle with manic- depression, or as it is called today, bi-polar disorder. My father was betrayed, and utterly undone by some fault of his brain chemistry or arrhythmia of its circuitry. He spent the best years of his life and career researching the structures of the human brain, a twist both bitter and ironic. His depression today would probably be termed treatment resistant depression. But he was also unable to benefit from all of the advances in pharmacology and treatment which have occurred in the past quarter century. My father wrote a text book entitled Physiological Psychology, published in 1980. Reading the section on depression and manic depression, is especially poignant for me. He succinctly described what was then known about the disorder, its symptoms, and treatment. On those pages he was describing himself. Did he know he had it? If so, tragically, he did not seek treatment. Depression took a heavy toll on my father, and on all aspects of his life, during the ups and downs of his illness his family, his work and research also fell victim. He made bad, audaciously poor decisions - which lead to even further immiseration. Depression is a disease of loneliness. My father never talked about it. But he should have. It would have helped him to know that someone was paying attention. I tried to - but when I was a child, adolescent, and young man I had no real understanding of the nature of depression. The last decade of his life was terribly hard, his suffering must have been intense. He wanted so desperately to live -but eventually he reached a point of despair where he just could not hold on any longer. My father was a wonderful, lovely, and, very kind man. He had that particular degree of empathy those who have known suffering can have. His kindness is what I remember best. I never had the chance to forgive him for all that went wrong, but more importantly: I never thanked him for all that went right and for all the good he did. I never told him all that he meant to me, how much I truly loved him, or - goodbye. Dr. Thomas S. Brown was my father. I loved him. And I will miss him forevermore. 1/3

URCIUOLI--Margaret Jane "Maggie." Maggie Urciuoli, 73, succumbed on September 19, 2015, after a long battle with multiple myeloma. She is survived by her husband of 49 years, J. Arthur ("Archie") Urciuoli, their children, Caryn Sloan Jacoby and her husband R.J. Jacoby, of Greenwich, CT, and Christian J.A. Urciuoli, and his wife Rebecca Jones Urciuoli, of New York City, and grandchildren Jackson, Sloan and Maggie Jacoby, and Jane and Nina Urciuoli. Born on March 8, 1942, the daughter of Matthew A. Forelli and the former Ethel Jane Sloan, Maggie was raised in Old Greenwich, CT, and was a Choate Rosemary Hall, Garland Junior College, and Boston University Fine Arts graduate. She was "Moopsie" as a child, "Maggie" most of her life, and "Nanni" to her beloved grandchildren. She was an artist, artisan and avid golfer. As a young woman, she was a well-known painter in oils. With partner Bobbie Schoonmaker, she founded and ran Small Ideas, a producer of fine antique furniture reproductions in miniature, for almost 20 years. As a hobby, she produced exquisite handmade Nantucket baskets. She served on the Board of Trustees of Choate Rosemary Hall and the board of the Casey Key Library. She was an active supporter of the Casey Key Association and of Girls Inc. of Sarasota County, and was a member of the Oaks, Ritz-Carlton, and Silvermine (Connecticut) golf clubs. Maggie and Archie moved to Casey Key, FL, in 1999, and spent their summers in Rowayton, CT. They previously lived in New York City, Paris, and Greenwich, CT. Memorial services will be held at 11:00am at the Ewing Chapel in Venice, FL on November 10, and at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, CT on November 23. Donations may be made in Maggie's memory to Girls Inc. of Sarasota County. 1/3

CLEARY--Robert "Rob" E. Jr.,71, born September 28, 1943, died at home on August 26, 2015, after a 17-year battle with Parkinson's. His family owned Welsh Farms dairy in New Jersey. Graduated Dartmouth, 1966; Harvard School of Design, 1974. USMC, bombardier/navigator, flying 208 combat missions in Vietnam, 1969-1970. Loved fly-fishing, marathon running and squash. Wrote "Welcome Intruder", a book about his Vietnam experiences. Married his love, Judy Hartley. Survived by Judy, sister Susan and brother John. 1/3

MacARTHUR--Dugald, passed away early Tuesday morning, September 29, 2015, as a result of Alzheimer's disease. Mr. MacArthur, beloved by many in the Philadelphia theater community, was last seen "on the boards" when he received the 2009 Barrymore Lifetime Achievement Award, Philadelphia's version of the Tony Awards. This was a highpoint in a long and illustrious career in the theater. Mr. MacArthur was born in Birmingham, AL in 1929. The son of a prominent businessman, he was groomed to do the same. Educated at Kent School in Connecticut, he received his B.A. from Dartmouth College and finally his M.B.A. from Harvard University. He had no real experience in the theater until a friend took him to see a production at Baylor University in Waco, TX directed by the famous innovator, Paul Baker. He knew immediately that theater was what he wanted to do. After receiving his M.A. from Baylor, Mr. MacArthur was hired as the Director of the Arkansas Arts Center - funded generously by Winthrop Rockefeller. He established a professional theater degree program that produced actors of national recognition. His production of a play about the state prison system was suppressed before it opened, and evolved into the movie Brubaker with Robert Redford and Jane Alexander. Mr. MacArthur was then appointed as chairman of the Theater Department at San Francisco State University during the time of student riots against the Vietnam War. During that explosive time, he directed Marat Sade. A year later, he was approached by Herbert Blau, then co-director of the Julliard School, and Robert Corrigan, founder of the NYU TISCH School of the Arts, to join them in the creation of a new college training program funded by the Disney family. Mr. MacArthur recruited students and formulated the curriculum of what is now The California Institute of the Arts. Three years later, Mr. MacArthur was chosen to lead the Master of Fine Arts program in Theater for Temple University. During his twenty-five years at Temple, he recruited and trained many actors who continue to work and thrive in the profession. He also directed many plays, notably: "Noises Off," "The Time of your Life," "Our Country's Good," "Three Sisters" and "The Cherry Orchard." His production of "Moby Dick Rehearsed" won the Best Ensemble at the American College Theatre Festival in Washington, D.C. Regionally, he directed at People's Light & Theatre Company, Villanova Shakespeare Company, The Pennsylvania Festival for New Plays, Philadelphia Theatre Company, and Act II Playhouse. He also directed at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis, the Hopkins Center at Dartmouth College, The Loeb Drama Center at Harvard University, and StageWest in Springfield, MA. After retiring from Temple University, Mr. MacArthur was a director, consultant and board member for the Lantern Theater. He directed several plays for Lantern including "The Bacchae," "Speed the Plow," "Copenhagen" and "Novecento." He was nominated for a Barrymore award in 1998 for "The Steward of Christendom," and also won a Barrymore in 1996 for his direction of "The Lower Depths" for The Venture Theater. Mr. MacArthur is survived by his wife, Christine, daughters Gwyneth, Meredith, and Alexandra, his son, Lorne, grandchildren, Kira Hanlan, Brigid and Rhys MacArthur- Thompson, and three great- grandchildren: Maeve, Fiona, and Colleen Dougherty. Memorial Service will be held at 3pm on Monday, October 5, 2015, The Philadelphia Episcopal Cathedral, 19 S. 38th Street, Philadelphia, PA. A reception will follow the service. In lieu of flowers, donations in Dugald's memory may be made in support of the Alzheimer's Disease and Dementia Center at Jefferson University Hospital. Please make checks payable to Jefferson and mail to: Office of Institutional Advancement, 125 S. 9th St., Suite 700, Philadelphia, PA 19107 or donate online by visiting Advancement.Jefferson.edu/ memorialgiving Helweg & Rowland Funeral Home, Abington, PA www.helwegrowlandfh.com 1/3

WHITMORE--Robert H. Died peacefully at his weekend house in Southampton, NY on September 29, age 77. Bob was born in West Virginia, raised in Lynchburg VA, and for nearly 45 years lived in and loved the UWS. A graduate of Lynchburg College, with a Masters from UVA and a doctorate from Columbia, Bob was a superlative college teacher, an inspiring leader, a proud veteran of the US Navy, and a loving husband to Alan Koral in a relationship of over 38 years. Among Bob's notable achievements was his early leadership of the New York Ramblers soccer team, the first gay soccer club in the country, which now boasts over 150 members and which nurtured gay teams nationwide, helping to form IGLFA, the international federation of gay/lesbian soccer clubs with thousands of proud participants. Besides his husband, Bob leaves his dear sister, Sherry Whitmore, of Punta Gorda, FL, his beloved nephew Steve Johnson of Lynchburg (loving sons Tyler and Brandon), fond nephew Robert Brooks (Annette) of Madison Heights, VA, and their family, loving in-laws Robert and Marianne Smythe of Chevy Chase, MD, their daughters Katherine Newman (Robert) and Sarah Lane (Mark) and their dear children, and a host of adoring friends. His wit, humor, style and kindness will be intensely missed. There will be a Memorial Gathering at Brockett Funeral Home in Southampton at 3:30pm on Saturday, October 31 (Halloween costumes encouraged) followed by a reception at the house on Herrick Road. Another Memorial Gathering and reception will be held at La Vela restaurant, Amsterdam Avenue 77/78, at 5:00 pm on Monday November 9. In lieu of flowers please consider a tax deductible gift in Bob's honor at: www.newyorkramblers.org, or by check at either reception. 1/3

SCHAEFER--Aileen Rose Mannix, passed away peacefully on October 1, 2015, surrounded by her loving husband of 58 years and her ten devoted children. Aileen was born on April 4, 1934 in Brooklyn, NY, to the late Henry and Mary Margaret Mannix. Aileen attended the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT and graduated in 1956 from Newton College of the Sacred Heart. In September of 1957, she married Richard Henry Schaefer and so began a life filled with love, laughter, faith and family. Over the years, Aileen gave of her time to the community so generously. She served on the St. Mary's School Board. She was a St. Mary's Parish trustee for 20 years and also served on the St. Mary's Parish Finance Committee for almost as long. Aileen volunteered for over 35 years at Birthright, a program to advise and support unwed mothers. Aileen spent countless hours visiting retired nuns at Maria Regina. Along with her husband she volunteered at the Mission Baptist Church Soup Kitchen. But her greatest joy was being a wife and mother. Together, Aileen and Richard were named to the St. John the Baptist DHS Hall of Fame. They were honored by St. Mary's Parish for their years of dedicated service. Aileen was awarded the Medal of St. Agnes by the Diocese of Rockville Centre for her service to the parish community. In addition to her husband, Aileen is survived by her ten children, Mary Catherine Gutmann, Aileen Rose Aviles, Ann Flint Wood, Richard Henry Schaefer, Jr., Elise Schaefer, Mary Margaret Schaefer, Alison Warner, Sheila Marie Schilling, Constance Schaefer, Delia Teresa Fulweiler and her 14 grandchildren. Mrs. Schaefer is also survived by her siblings, Sheila Mannix, Charles Mannix and Delia Burke and predeceased by her brothers Henry, John and Joseph and her sisters Frances Ziminsky and Mary Margaret Hughes. Reposing at The Fredrick J. Chapey & Sons West Islip Funeral Home, 1225 Montauk Highway (1/4 mile west of The Robert Moses Cswy.). Celebration of the Liturgy of Christian Burial will be held at St. Mary's R.C. Church at 20 Harrison Ave, East Islip, NY on Monday, October 5, 2015 at 10:15am. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to St. Mary's Church 20 Harrison Avenue, East Islip, NY 11730 or Birthright 533 Main Street, Islip, NY 11751. Visiting on Saturday, October 3, 2015 from 6pm until 8pm and Sunday, October 4, 2015 from 2pm until 4pm and 6pm until 8pm. 1/3

CARUCCI--Anne Betty, 91, of Branford, CT, wife of the late Enrico Carucci, died peacefully at home on September 30, 2015. She is survived by her children, Ellen Carucci (Will Tracy) of New York, NY and Short Beach, CT and Rick (Julee) Carucci of Prospect, KY; and her granddaughters, Amanda and Rachel Carucci. Funeral services handled by W. S. Clancy in Branford, CT. 1/3

GUTTMAN--Lucille, 92. Carnegie Mellon and Columbia Graduate. School Psychologist. WWII Cryptographer G2 Army Intelligence. Lived a wonderful life with her husband Harry (1996). Spoke and wrote her mind on issues important to her. Created an extended family ranging from the Westchester Jewish community to those who came to help her. We love you more-- Dan, Robert, Reuben, Joy, Aliza & Jesse Guttman. 1/3

FINAN--Farrell J.,on October 1, 2015. (Ret. Lt. FDNY). Beloved husband of the late Dorothy G. (nee Smith). Devoted father of Elizabeth V. Finan and the late Robert Finan. Dear brother of Donald Finan and Theresa Martin. Reposing at Edward D. Lynch Funeral Home, 43-07 Queens Blvd., Sunnyside, NY Sunday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass: St. Mary's RC Church (Woodside) Monday l0am. Interment: Gate of Heaven Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to FDNY Foundation. New York Firefighters Burn Center Foundation or Calvary Hospital would be deeply appreciated. 1/3

ROSENTHAL--Ruth, age 90, passed peacefully on October 1st surrounded by her devoted family. She is survived by her caring son Richard, her loving daughter-in-law Stacy Fischer-Rosenthal, and her adoring grandson Max. Services will be held at "The Riverside" on 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. on Sunday, October 4, 2015 at 12pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Ruth's name to ramapoforchildren.org 1/3
BYRNE--Patrick. In loving memory of your birthday and all of our treasured memories of you. BMCC and KJEBI 1/3

ZUCKERMAN--Harriet Braunstein, passed away peacefully on October 1, 2015. She was the daughter of the late Louis and Lillian (nee Kaplan) Lurie. Family was the most important part of her life. She was predeceased by her adoring husbands Mac Braunstein and Irwin Zuckerman. She is survived by daughters Merle (Alan) Schwartz, Ronni (Paul) Schneider and Jill (Jeff) Marcus, brother Donald (Shelly) Lurie, sister Joyce (Jerry) Schwartz, sister-in-law Barbara Lurie and daughter-in-law Susan Zuckerman. She was predeceased by brother Harvey Lurie and son-in-law Cary Zuckerman. Harriet was the loving grandmother of 10 and great-grandmother of 14. She will be in our hearts forever. 1/3

CAMPY--Sheila. Born May 14, 1934 in Queens, NY, daughter of Thomas and Marjorie Keane. Please let it be known that from her daughter Susan's tender embrace, Sheila has peacefully gone into the loving arms of God and carried through the gates of Heaven on September 25, 2015. Her deep loves included her three grandchildren Simon, Michael, Amanda Young. Great-grandson Elliot Young. Beloved sisters Deborah Bell and Joan Formanek. Only Love, Frank Campanello. And, lastly daughter Susan Young-Smith. For whose heart will forever ache in her mother's absence. The family plans a memorial service in the Spring of 2016, please call (912)373-4193 for details. 1/3

GLICKMAN--Alice Buchman. We mourn the loss of our dear friend of 50 years, together with her and her husband Lewis, we shared so many life events. From Ditmas Park in Brooklyn to Park Avenue in Manhattan we nurtured our friendship, we discussed our children and grandchildren, world events and financial matters. She enriched our lives with her friendship. To her husband Lewis, to her daughters Amy (Andy), Emily (Howard) and her grandchildren, Caroline, Anna, Hallie, and Julia we send our heartfelt condolences. Barbara & Bernard Scharfstein 1/3

WEISBERGER--Pamela Ann, 64, left us on September 25th after a short illness. After a career in film and television, Pamela found her lifelong passion as a professional genealogist, becoming an internationally acclaimed researcher and lecturer who inspired--and grew--the genealogical community worldwide. Her loving family, husband Kenneth Kaufman, children Michael, Nicholas, and Lily, brother Douglas, and her extended family of cousins, many of whom she discovered through her remarkable work, are devastated by her sudden death. Contributions in her memory can be made to the Pamela Weisberger Memorial Fund, c/o JGSLA, POB 55443, Sherman Oaks, CA 91413, which will establish a lecture series in her name. 1/3

SINGER--Jack Bernard, 88, passed away peacefully at his home in East Hampton on October 2nd, after a long battle with Parkinson's Disease. He is survived by his loving wife of 50 years, Jackie and adoring daughter, Rachel. He will always be loved. Jack was a talented and passionate photographer and avid sports fan, whose quick wit and sense of style will be truly missed. In lieu of flowers please consider a tax deductible gift in Jack's memory to either The Parkinson's Disease Foundation at: www.michaeljfox.org or The Phillips Beth Israel Ambulatory Center at: www.supportbethisrael.org. 1/3

ZIMMER--Michael J. 72, of Evanston, IL, Professor of Law at Loyola University Chicago, died September 23, 2015. A widely recognized scholar in labor and employment, employment discrimination and constitutional law, Professor Zimmer received a JD from Marquette, where he was Editor in Chief of the Marquette Law Review, and an LL.M from Columbia, where he was a James Kent Fellow. He clerked for the Honorable Thomas Fairchild of the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit. Before Loyola, he was a professor and Associate Dean at Seton Hall Law School. Survived by his wife, Margaret L. Moses, also a law professor at Loyola; son, Michael Zimmer, a writer and filmmaker, and daughter, Lanier Zimmer, a Henry Luce Scholar in Myanmar. Memorial Service October 11, 2015 at 11:00am at Michigan Shores Club, Wilmette IL. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Bonnie J. Addario Lung Cancer Foundation or to Planned Parenthood. For Information: (847) 675-1990 or visit: www.donnellanfuneral.com. 1/3

WEINBERG--Arnold N.,M.D., 85, of Rockport, MA, died at home on September 28, 2015, after a full life and a year of declining health. He leave his wife, Inge, and three daughters: Suzanne, Davida, and Carolyn. Burial will be private and a celebration of his life will be held later in the fall. Services are by Greely Funeral Home, 212 Washington Street, Gloucester, MA. 1/3

BASCH--Norma, nee Woloshin, of New York, NY and Truro, MA, born July 4, 1934, died September 29, 2015, on Cape Cod. A professor of American History at Rutgers the State University Of New Jersey from 1979 to 2004, Norma was the author of two groundbreaking works of feminist legal history, Framing Divorce: From the Revolutionary Generation to the Victorians and In the Eyes of the Law: Women, Marriage, and Property in Nineteenth-Century New York. She leaves behind her husband of 59 years, Sheldon, her children Rachel and Fred, her daughter-in-law Susan, and her three grandchildren, Nathaniel, Hannah and Emma. A graveside service will be held for the family. A memorial service is planned for Sunday 2pm, October 25, at the Village Temple in NYC. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Caroline's Gift, Newtown Youth & Family Services, 15 Berkshire Rd., Sandy Hook, CT 06482. 1/3

CLARK--Sterling. Born on May 27, 1940, passed away on September 25, 2015 in Los Angeles battling cancer. Sterling was in over 25 theater, film and Television productions. His heart was a "Broadway Baby" and he supported and loved the arts. He will be missed. 1/3

BARRY--John H.,of Morris Township, NJ died September 29, 2015. He was born in Easton, Pennsylvania in 1916. Mr. Barry, a Certified Public Accountant, was a long time resident of Madison and a member of St. Vincent Martyr Church. He retired from the Mobil Oil Corporation in 1981 where he was the General Auditor. He graduated from Lehigh University in 1938. During World War II, Mr. Barry was a First Lieutenant in the 759 Light Tank Battalion, serving in five campaigns in the European Theater of Operations. He was awarded the Bronze Star. He leaves his wife, Barbara; daughter, Nancy (Larry) Bruce, Madison, NJ; son William (Mary Joe), Carlsbad, CA; son John (Karen), Burlington, VT; and grandchildren Katharine Bruce, Matthew, Kelsey, Margaret Barry and Kevin and Christopher Barry. 1/3

SALVATO--Lawrence A. After nearly 18 years of a serious debilitating illness. Lawrence A. Salvato has passed away on October 1, 2015. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 27 years, Susan Reall Salvato. Funeral services entrusted to Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel". 1/3

LAGUDIS--Nicholas, 94, at home on September 25, 2015. Devoted husband of the late Esme (62 years), father to his adoring daughters, Stephanie Neckles, Maria Lechich and Stella Lagudis, and sons-in-law, Tony Lechich and the late Spero Neckles, proud grandfather to Christina, Alexander, Nicholas and Stephanie. Nick, born in Chios, Greece, graduated Brooklyn Technical High School and was in the first graduating class of Kings Point U.S. Merchant Marine Academy ('43). He was deployed as second officer to Pacific, Atlantic and Mediterranean theaters of WWII. For many years he held a coveted Master's License that entitled him to command vessels of all tonnage on all oceans. The memory of his integrety, encyclopedic mind and loving heart will be cherished by all who knew him. 1/3

RANEY--George Neal, 92, died at home on September 13, 2015 of natural causes. Born in Portland, OR on October 14, 1922, he spoke most fondly of his middle childhood years in Elmhurst, IL. In 1952 he married Barbara Robinson. They shared a love for their good friends, art, music, and travel for 60 years. He was predeceased by his wife, Barbara, his sister Patricia Lubar, and is his brother David Raney. He is survived by his sister, Helen Gowan, his daughters Rebecca Raney and Patricia Raney, as well as two grandchildren, two nieces, nine nephews, and many dear friends. Raney served from 1944-1946 as a navy radio engineer, and drove in a truck convoy on the Burma road from India to China in 1946. With a BA from Queens College 1943, Raney received a PhD in mathematics from Columbia University in 1954. He taught math and engineering at MIT, Columbia, Penn State, and finally settled at the University of Connecticut in 1963, becoming emeritus 1984. His contributions were in the field of lattice theory, automata, and infinite series of functions and vectors. The Raney theorem became useful in computer science decades later. Raney also enjoyed studying botany and geology, hiking, and most of all, people. He will be remembered by those who knew him as a great friend, father and teacher, who was humble, generous, and just. 1/3
WHITMORE--Robert. We will miss our joyful, colorful and playful friend who loved Alan, art, travel, soccer, swans and certain cats. Dennis and Pearl 1/3

WHITMORE--Robert H. Died peacefully at his weekend house in Southampton, NY on September 29, age 77. Bob was born in West Virginia, raised in Lynchburg VA, and for nearly 45 years lived in and loved the UWS. A graduate of Lynchburg College, with a Masters from UVA and a doctorate from Columbia, Bob was a superlative college teacher, an inspiring leader, a proud veteran of the US Navy, and a loving husband to Alan Koral in a relationship of over 38 years. Among Bob's notable achievements was his early leadership of the New York Ramblers soccer team, the first gay soccer club in the country, which now boasts over 150 members and which nurtured gay teams nationwide, helping to form IGLFA, the international federation of gay/lesbian soccer clubs with thousands of proud participants. Besides his husband, Bob leaves his dear sister, Sherry Whitmore, of Punta Gorda, FL, his beloved nephew Steve Johnson of Lynchburg (loving sons Tyler and Brandon), fond nephew Robert Brooks (Annette) of Madison Heights, VA, and their family, loving in-laws Robert and Marianne Smythe of Chevy Chase, MD, their daughters Katherine Newman (Robert) and Sarah Lane (Mark) and their dear children, and a host of adoring friends. His wit, humor, style and kindness will be intensely missed. There will be a Memorial Gathering at Brockett Funeral Home in Southampton at 3:30pm on Saturday, October 31 (Halloween costumes encouraged) followed by a reception at the house on Herrick Road. Another Memorial Gathering and reception will be held at La Vela restaurant, Amsterdam Avenue 77/78, at 5:00 pm on Monday November 9. In lieu of flowers please consider a tax deductible gift in Bob's honor at: www.newyorkramblers.org, or by check at either reception. 1/3

Alice was predeceased by her parents Harry and Dorothy Buchman. 1/3

HARNETT--Bertram. Mentor and beloved friend for 45 years. Original founder of The Children's Medical Fund which was the catalyst for the creation of the Children's Hospital at the Long Island Jewish Medical Center. He fought for what he believed was right and made our community a better place. He will be remembered and missed. Ellie and Martin Lifton 1/3

DAVENPORT--William Kirk. William "Bill" Kirk Davenport (1928-2015) died peacefully at his home in Bloomfield Hills, Michigan on September 29, 2015. He was 86. The cause was lung cancer. Bill was born in Jackson, Michigan on December 22, 1928. He graduated from Cranbrook School in 1946, Harvard College in 1950 and the University of Michigan Law School in 1953. After law school, he worked as an associate lawyer at Cravath, Swaine & Moore, a law firm in New York City, until 1962. His time at Cravath was interrupted for three and a half years when he served at the Pentagon in the Army Judge Advocate General's Corps as a 1st Lieutenant. In 1962, he moved from New York back to Michigan to work as a lawyer for Ford Motor Company. He retired from Ford as Assistant General Counsel in 1990. Bill was fortunate to have married Gertrude Baldwin Perkins "Kitty", one of the fabulous identical Perkins Twins of Wilkes-Barre, PA. He was married to Kitty for 47 years until her death in 2006. He also outlived his younger sister, Jean Davenport Crawford, who died in 2002. Bill had a wonderful life. Those who knew him will remember his intelligence, charm, sense of humor and strong moral character, all of which are captured in his daughter Nina Davenport's HBO documentary "First Comes Love" (premiering on Netflix in November). Bill loved his time at Cranbrook, Harvard, and Michigan Law School. He spent his summers at his cottage in the Chicago Club of Charlevoix, Michigan where he had a close community of friends. After retirement, he and Kitty also rented a house every spring in Provence. Bill's favorite sports were cooking, 19th century English literature, vegetable gardening and the New York Times. After his wife Kitty died, he became an avid bridge player. He will be missed by his many bridge partners. Above all, he was a loving and devoted husband and father. Bill is survived by his three children, Kirk, Tim and Nina Davenport, and seven grandchildren: Lydia, Addison, Alexander, Eliza, Jackson, Lucas and Jasper. A memorial service in Bloomfield Hills is being planned for the weekend of November 14, 2015. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that you consider a gift to The Davenport Family Scholarship Fund at the University of Michigan Law School, 701 S. State St., Ann Arbor, MI, 48109-3091. View obituary and share memories at: AJDesmond.com 1/3

HILDEBRAND--Gene D. Oklahoma native, quintessential New Yorker, died of cancer at his residence in Pennington, NJ. Devoted husband of many decades of Janice Stogniew Hildebrand. Renaissance man, talent for languages, lover of opera, poetry, Ballet Theatre. Nonprofit executive with an affinity for investment management. A gentleman and gentle man admired by all who truly knew him for his intellect, wit and unprepossessing manner. 1/3

LONDON--Elaine H. Marcus, of White Plains, NY passed away on October 1, 2015 surrounded by her loving family. She was 86. Elaine was born in New York, NY on April 13, 1929 to Samuel and Sarah Marcus. She was a journalist, artist and educator. Beloved wife of Edwin London, loving mother of Elizabeth London (husband David Piaker), Patty London-Wager and Nancy London, she is also survived by her six cherished grandchildren, Sarabeth Tukey, Samantha Wager, Danielle and Jordan Bryan, and Zachary and Joseph Piaker. A Funeral Service will be held 1pm Sunday at Bet Am Shalom Synagogue in White Plains, followed by interment at Sharon Gardens Cemetery in Valhalla. For more information; www.zionchapel.com. Donations may be made to Friends of White Plains Public Schools, P.O. Box 133, White Plains, NY 10602; or, Friends of Tanglewood, Symphony Hall, 301 Mass. Avenue, Boston, MA 02115. 1/3

MALONEY--Nancy, 72, of Manhattan and East Quoque died on Tuesday, September 22, 2015 at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center in New York City. She was predeceased by her parents, Mary Martin and Matthew Maloney and her sister, Mary. Nancy earned her MBA at NYU and after taking early retirement from the New York Telephone Company, she pursued her interest in real estate as both an investor and an agent. She reignited her talent for oil painting, studied at the Art Students League and the Salmagundi Club. She exhibited in the 2013 National Arts Club Roundtable Exhibition, and in 2014 at the prestigious Samagundi and was the New York featured artist in the Spring 2015 arts and culture magazIne "Exploring Tosca". Nancy is survived by niece Kathleen Corrado, great-nieces and great-nephew (Mary Jewel, Kelsey, Douglas), cousins Della and Kevin Shannon, and many friends. 1/3

WILLIG--Alan B.,Of Little Falls, NJ died on Saturday, September 26, 2015. He was 76 years of age. Born in Philadelphia, PA, he was the son of the late Benjamin Willig and Bessie Cohen. He was a graduate of Central High School (Class 206). He received Bachelor and Master of Arts degrees from Villanova University. Alan enjoyed a more than forty year career as a theatrical agent. He worked for Hesseltine Baker, Alan Willig Associates, The Tantleff Office, HWA, and Don Buchwald & Associates agencies. His client list included Philip Bosco, Elaine Stritch, Joe Morton, Christopher Reeve, Kevin Gray, Mark Jacoby, Joan Collins, and a host of talented Broadway stars. For a large number of years, he was assistant producer at Philadelphia's Playhouse in the Park. He also was an instructor of English at Baruch College in New York and at the University of Puerto Rico. Alan also worked in the SchooI District of Philadelphia and with the Philadelphia Drama Guild. In recent years, he was in great demand to teach classes in auditioning and career management at many New York theater training schools. His theatrical career began as an actor and he had the good fortune to be a member of the American Shakespeare Festival Company of Stratford, CT in 1961. Alan was an avid supporter of the arts, a long-time subscriber and patron of the Metropolitan Opera, NJPAC, New Jersey Shakespeare Festival, Irish Repertory, and numerous other drama organizations. He had an unabated love affair with everything British, especially the London theater and traveled there numerous times. Alan is survived by his lifetime companion, Dennis Cafiero, of Little Falls; his sister, Sandra Friter and his brother-in-law, Barry Friter of Doylestown, PA; his nephew, Eric Rubin, and his wife, Jennifer; and his niece, Stefanie Rubin along with numerous loving friends, clients, colleagues and students. He was predeceased by his brother Harvey and his stepmother, Dorothy Willig. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 4, at 12 noon at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street), in New York City. Friends and family will be gathering at 11am . 1/3

SCRIPPS--Luise Elcaness. November 22, 1927-September 11, 2015. Luise died in her Manhattan home, surrounded by her family after a long battle with Alzheimer's Disease. Born Luise Ellen Elcaness to Estelle and Lewis Elcaness in Brooklyn, New York. Luise was the great- granddaughter of Samuel Gompers, the founder of the American Federation of Labor. Luise was a graduate of the High School of Music and Art in New York and Syracuse University. She met her husband, Samuel Scripps while teaching art at the Bishop's School in La Jolla, CA. They married in August of 1956. In 1962, Luise met the famed South-Indian classical dancer and teacher, Tanjore Balasaraswati. She was immediately accepted as a student and studied Bharatanatyam under the master until her death in 1984. Inspired early on by Balasaraswati's art, and the American enthusiasm for the art of Indian culture, Luise and her husband, Sam, co-founded The American Society for Eastern Arts the following year (1963) in Berkeley, California with the mission of bringing Asian performing arts to the American public. It soon became a school sponsoring performers and teachers from Asia who brought their cultural heritage to generations of American scholars and students. It continues today as the Center for World Music in San Diego, California. In 1975, Luise established the Balasaraswati School of Music and Dance. Its mission was to continue and preserve the teaching style of her mentor. The school continues today in the U.S. and India, directed by Balasaraswati's grandson, Aniruddha Knight. In 1991, with the help of Walter Beinecke, she established the Balasaraswati/Joy Ann Dewey Beinecke Endowed Chair for Distinguished Teaching at the American Dance Festival, an institution where Luise first studied dance and later served as teacher. She is survived by her children Sebastian and Wendy and her grandchildren, Welland, Samuel, Katherine, Julia, Rachel Vaughn and her great-granddaughter Isobel. Luise is predeceased by her husband Samuel H. Scripps. 1/3

IX--Alexander Frank, Jr. It is with great sadness that the family of Alexander Frank Ix Jr., 87, of Spring Lake, NJ announces his passing on September 28, 2015. A graduate of Englewood School for Boys and Princeton University Class of 1949. He served in the Navy during the Korean War. He spent his entire career at Frank Ix & Sons becoming its President in 1970. He married the love of his life Annrose Collins in 1952 and they had six children: Alexander III, Constance, Melissa, Sarah (predeceased), Charles and Mark. He was the cherished Pop-Pop to 10 grandchildren. He was an avid sportsman playing tennis, skiing and croquet. He was President of the Green Gables Croquet Club and was inducted into the Croquet Hall of Fame in 2010. He will be lovingly remembered for his boundless generosity, sharp wit and matinee idol good looks. Alex was a man of infinite class a true gentleman. 1/3

FINDLAY--David B.,Jr. Dave was born in Kansas City, Missouri in 1933 to David Beals Findlay, a third generation art dealer, and Harriet Jones Findlay. His family moved to New York City, then to Darien in 1936, when his father established the David Findlay Galleries in New York City. In 1943 the Findlays purchased Extown Farm in New Canaan. In 1948 he entered Deerfield Academy as a sophomore, class of '51. He was on the varsity lacrosse, soccer and hockey teams. He has attended all Deerfield reunions, created an annual Deerfield Dinner in New York City, and enjoyed talking frequently to his classmates as Class Secretary. Dave double majored at Cornell, receiving a BS in Mechanical Engineering and an MBA in 1955 and was a member of Chi Psi. He worked for IBM in computer sales, then for McKinsey and Co. in New York City. Following a brief stint at the Beech-Nut Corporation, he joined Lehman Brothers until 1976, when, after 20 years in finance, he joined his brother and sister as a partner in his father's gallery when it expanded onto Madison Avenue. The business specialized in American and European paintings and sculpture. In 1982 Dave started his own gallery, the David Findlay Jr Gallery, with a focus on American art. He was proud to have his daughter the fifth generation, Lee Findlay Potter, join him in its management. In 1973 Dave married the former Mimi Adams from Darien. Dave loved to ski and went cat-skiing at Selkirk Wilderness Skiing in British Columbia forty times, frequently taking a child or grandchild with him. His other passion was golf: he became a golf member of the Country Club of New Canaan in 1968 and served as its President 2004-06. Subsequently he joined the Sankaty Head Golf Club in Nantucket and the John's Island Club in Vero Beach, Florida. He was a great communicator, eschewing emails for telephone calls to children and grandchildren on a regularbasis. He was a trustee of the New Canaan Library Board from 1968 to 1974, and its President 1971-1973. Together with his wife Mimi, to whom he was married 42 years, he enjoyed a life-long interest in arts, architecture, history and antiques, frequently traveling on international tours with an academic or arts focus. He loved the out of doors, and recently he traveled with his daughter Lee and her family to Nairobi and with daughter Kim down the Colorado River. David is survived by his wife Mimi, his brother Peter Findlay of New York City and Salisbury, Connecticut, daughters Kim Findlay of Charlotte, Vermont and Lee Findlay Potter of New York City; step-daughters Sindi Adams Sheers of McLean, Virginia and Brook Adams Visser of Framingham, Massachusetts, and sons Hal Findlay of Delray Beach, Florida and Michael Findlay of New Haven, Vermont, nineteen grandchildren and one great-granddaughter. A Memorial Service in Celebration of Dave Findlay's wonderful life will be held on Saturday, October 24, 2015 at 11:00am at the First Presbyterian Church of New Canaan. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made in his name to the David B. Findlay Jr. Scholarship Fund at Deerfield Academy, or to the Herbert F. Johnson Museum at Cornell University. 1/3

BLACKMAN--Mark Kenneth III, died peacefully at his home in Brooklyn on September 20, 2015. Mark, born October 25, 1941 in Cedar Rapids, IA, was a consummate storyteller and his own life story is a good one, complex and interesting. From All American Boy in Fargo, ND, to graduating from Princeton University cum laude, to international banking in Bangkok, Thailand and Sao Paulo, Brazil, to silver importer in Chicago and finally as professor at LaGuardia Community College, Mark embraced the world with curiosity and humor, communicating fluently in five languages. AA was an integral part of his life in New York. He is survived by his son, Matthew, siblings John (Paddy) and Anne Collins and numerous nieces and nephews to whom he was affectionately known as "Unc." Mark, always a challenge, was nonetheless loved by his family and will be greatly missed. A private family service will be held at a later date. Raccuglia and Son handled the local services. Memorials can be made to LaGuardia Community College. 1/3

MURRAY--The Reverend Charles Kephart, Jr.,91, of Fredericksburg, VA, entered paradise on September 26, 2015 at 3:16am. A retired Presbyterian minister, he served congregations in New Jersey and Pennsylvania for 35 years. He joins his wife Nancy Burnside Murray and his eldest son, Charles K. Murray III. Survivors include: his sister Zetta (Kris) Boucherle, son John B. Murray, an architect in NYC, and grandchildren, Natalie, Gabriel, Luke and Jesse Murray, and Christa Klippen. His was an amazing life, overflowing with the mission to share the Good News. It is fitting indeed that he passed from this world at 3:16. His favorite Bible verse: John 3:16. "For God so loved the world that he gave his only Son, so that everyone who believes in him will not perish but have eternal life." Online guest book: covenantfuneralservice.com. 1/3

GILL--William Nelson. Dr. William Nelson Gill, PhD, died at home on September 16 in Troy, NY. He was 87 years old. Born in Brooklyn on Sept. 13, 1928, son of William Nelson Gill and Frances Margaret Murphy, he graduated from Brooklyn Tech High and received BS, MS, and Ph.D. degrees from Syracuse University. He was a consummate researcher and educator, serving on the Chemical Engineering faculties of Syracuse University, Clarkson University (Department Chairman), SUNY Buffalo (Dean of Engineering) and Rensselaer (Department Head, Russell Sage Professor). He enjoyed a dry martini and had an inspiring passion for exercise and healthy living, as evidenced by his 75 push-up per day routine maintained beyond his 86th birthday. Bill was a PBS supporter, had a keen interest in current events, and cared deeply for the welfare of others. He is survived by his wife Chandlee Stevens Gill, and was the beloved father of Alison, Christine, Douglas, and Max Gill, grandfather to Dylan Gill, and friend to his former wife, Marie Gill. He had three step-children, Brooke Lenkei, Kevin Stevens and Lynne Stevens and three step-grandchildren, Rachel and Alex Lenkei and Dustin Lewis. Dr. Gill was advisor to over 50 PhD candidates, and authored over 250 peer reviewed papers with over 5500 citations. His many important contributions to the field of chemical engineering resulted in the receipt of numerous awards and honors, and he was cited for his "outstanding contributions to fundamental chemical engineering theory and practice" by the American Society of Engineering Education. He received two Fulbright Senior Research Scholarships, spent two years as the Glenn Murphy Distinguished Professor at Iowa State University, and served as Editor of the journal Chemical Engineering Communications for 35 years. He was deeply loved and will be greatly missed. He will always be in our hearts. 1/3
TURNER--Renee H. Television producer, 4/15/24 - 9/17/15 http://tributes.com/ReneeTurner 1/3

COMISKEY--James, was born in New York August 5, 1934 and died in his home in Los Angeles on September 26, 2015. A Rhodes Scholar, he retired as Vice President from McGraw Hill Publishing Company in religious and educational publications; he was a devoted father to his son Timothy and daughter-in-law Natascia. In his dedication to history, religion, philosophy, and arts--particulary ballet--he was a bookworm who never dodged a responsibility to family, friends, or coworkers. He will live in the minds and hearts of many as a warm, kind, and generous friend.
