HEWES--Jane, passed away peacefully on October 2nd at her home in New York. She was a loving wife, mother, sister and friend as well as a pioneer in the educati- onal consulting field. Pre-deceased by Henry Hewes, her husband of 61 years, Jane is survived by her sons, Henry, Tucker and Havelock and six grandchildren, Henry, William, John, Duncan, Daniel and Allise. Her brother, Robert Fowle, lives in Somerset, Bermuda. She founded Jane Hewes Educational Consulting in 1978 and was a founding member of the Independent Educational Consultants Association. We miss her greatly. 1/3

GLASER--Gloria T. Beloved wife of Alvin for 67 years. Adored mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York City, October 6th at 10:30am. 1/3

VAN BOMEL DuREN--MaryRose. October 3, 1948 - October 2, 2015. Born to Edward and Rosemary (Kelly); loving wife, daughter, sister and aunt; retired Merrill Lynch. Schuyler Hill Funeral Home, 3535 E. Tremont Ave. Bronx, NY; 2-5 and 7-9pm, October 7; Mass of Christian Burial, St. Frances deChantal, October 8, 10:00am. 1/3

SALVATO--Lawrence A. After nearly 18 years of a serious debilitating illness. Lawrence A. Salvato has passed away on October 1, 2015. He leaves behind his beloved wife of 27 years, Susan Reall Salvato. Funeral services entrusted to Frank E. Campbell "The Funeral Chapel". 1/3

MURRAY--The Reverend Charles Kephart, Jr.,91, of Fredericksburg, VA, entered paradise on September 26, 2015 at 3:16am. A retired Presbyterian minister, he served congregations in New Jersey and Pennsylvania for 35 years. He joins his wife Nancy Burnside Murray and his eldest son, Charles K. Murray III. Survivors include: his sister Zetta (Kris) Boucherle, son John B. Murray, an architect in NYC, and grandchildren, Natalie, Gabriel, Luke and Jesse Murray, and Christa Klippen. His was an amazing life, overflowing with the mission to share the Good News. It is fitting indeed that he passed from this world at 3:16. His favorite Bible verse: John 3:16. "For God so loved the world that he gave his only Son, so that everyone who believes in him will not perish but have eternal life." Online guest book: covenantfuneralservice.com. 1/3

HARNETT--Bertram, age 92, passed away peacefully at his home in Boca Raton, Florida on October 1. He is survived by his dear wife of 71 years, Ruth, and children, Andrea, a retired Magistrate Judge in Washington, DC; David, a psychiatrist in Medford, Mass.; James, a retired lawyer in Madison, Wisconsin; six grandchildren and one great granddaughter. He was predeceased by his brother, Joel, of New York and Arizona. Raised in Brooklyn, New York, he graduated from Brooklyn College and Columbia Law School. He taught and practiced law in New York and Florida for over 60 years. He wrote two legal treatises and other legal works of more general interest. He served as Nassau County Attorney from 1962 to 1963 and as a Judge on the New York State Supreme Court from 1968 to 1977. He was the prime moving force in the establishment of the Cohen Children's Medical Center of New York in New Hyde Park, NY. He was a man of great intellect and accomplishment and led a long, full life. He was known for a keen sense of justice, an engaging sense of humor, and endless curiosity. He travelled the world and read voraciously. He charmed people of all ages until his final days. Most of all, he loved and was devoted to his family. He will be missed terribly. A funeral service will be held at Temple Beth-El in Boca Raton, Florida at 2:00pm on October 7. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to North Shore LIJ Cohen Children's Medical Center in New Hyde Park, NY or to the Strobis Glaucoma Foundation in Boca Raton. 1/3

WHITEHEAD--John C. We acknowledge with reverence and respect the United States Navy funeral, with full military honors, for Commander John C. Whitehead, USN (Ret.) at Arlington National Cemetery on October 5, 2015, 10:30am. John was a remarkable man whose full and productive life is admired by all. His friends at the Helping Africa Foundation 1/3

LYNCH--Josephine D. (nee Dexter) died at home Monday, July 27, 2015 in Gladwyne, PA. Beloved wife of the late David B. Lynch, who died in 2001, and sister of the late Polly Newbold, who died in 2010, Joedy was the devoted mother of David, Tina Fiertz (Stuart) and Linda (Kevin Johnson), and devoted grandmother of Henry, Callie, Mimi, Louisa, Theo, Lucy and Annie. She attended The Shipley School and graduated in 1948 from St. Timothy's School in Stevenson, MD. In the 1950's Joedy was an accessories editor for Harper's Bazaar magazine in New York City. A memorial service will be held on Friday, October 9, 2015 at 4pm at St. Christopher's Church, 226 Righter's Mill Road, Gladwyne, PA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her name to The Bryn Mawr Hospital Foundation, Bryn Mawr, PA. Online condolences: donohuefuneralhome.com 1/3
VENTLINE--Pfc Lukas, of Detroit, 23, Vietnam, February 18, 1968, a half-century gone, a pawn, with 58,000 other U.S. loyals in TET futile battle. Eternal Rest. 1/3
FAERBER--Doris Goldblum. December 16, 1919--October 3, 2015. Extraordinary Mother, Grandmother, Mathematician and Teacher. Our Mother lived and loved life to the fullest. 1/3

SMITH--Doris H.,96, of Tamarac, FL, passed away on October 3, 2015. Devoted wife of Philip (deceased). Beloved mother of Jeffrey (Barrie) and Michael (Rita). Grandmother of eight grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Loving sister of Gladys and the late Seymour and Howard. A wonderful lady - you will be sorely missed. Graveside service. 1/3

SIEGEL--Rabbi Paul R.,who was the Senior Rabbi for Temple Beth Abraham in Tarrytown, NY for 43 years, died peacefully Sunday at Village Care in New York City. He was 91 years old. Rabbi Siegel was born in Baltimore, MD, on March 6, 1924, his parents recently having emigrated from Safed, Israel. In 1948 Rabbi Siegel was ordained by his teacher, friend and mentor, Rabbi Steven Wise at the Hebrew Union College, Jewish Institute of Religion in New York. That same year, he married Lorraine Peltz in a ceremony officiated by Rabbi Wise. In addition to receiving a Bachelor's Degree in Political Science from Brooklyn College, Rabbi Siegel received a Masters Degree in Educational Psychology from Columbia University. Rabbi Siegel served as a chaplain in the Air Force during the Korean War, attaining the rank of Captain, and then began his long and distinguished career as the Rabbi for Temple Beth Abraham. During his tenure there, he led both conservative and reform services, in two different chapels within the same building, to honor tradition as well as innovation. Rabbi Siegel was in the vanguard of the Reform Jewish movement, having been instrumental in establishing interfaith services in Tarrytown and ensuring the equality of men and women in the synagogue. In 1976 Rabbi Siegel was awarded an Honorary Doctor of Divinity from Hebrew Union College. Rabbi Siegel was known for his kindness, generosity of spirit, keen intelligence and ability to skillfully yarn a story or joke to capture the meaning or absurdity of any conceivable situation. Rabbi Siegel is survived by his loving wife of 67 years, Dr. Lorraine Siegel, and his three children, Frederic Siegel of Briarcliff Manor, NY, Deborah Zoller of Allentown, PA, and Arthur Siegel of Albany, NY (his loving son, Joshua Siegel, having predeceased him). Also surviving are his grandchildren Evan, Jeremy, Matty, Mallory, Sarah Zoller Levinson and Rachel Zoller Lipsman. 1/3

GLASER--Gloria T. Beloved wife of Alvin for 67 years. Adored mother, grandmother and great-grandmother. Services will be held at Frank E. Campbell Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave., New York City, October 6th at 10:30am. 1/3

SIDNAM--Gloria, longtime New York City and Bedford resident, died on October 5th at home in Manhattan. Born in New York on 23 January 1937, Gloria was married to Joseph Ercolano in 1956, to Burt Wells in 1969, and to Alan Sidnam, the love of her life, in 1975. Art was the centerpiece of Gloria's life. She spent more than thirty years on the creative side of the advertising business in its heyday, working at Warwick & Legler, Grey Advertising, and finally Ogilvy & Mather, where she was Associate Creative Director when she retired. Starting in 1989 Gloria devoted a great part of her boundless energy to becoming an art history scholar and docent at the Metropolitan Museum in New York City. Throughout her years at the Met, she studied constantly, continually expanding her knowledge base. She reveled in the details and loved inspiring her students. She was completely fluent on all aspects of the Met collection -- Greek, Roman, European, and American art, even Arms & Armor. Her free time was devoted to cultivating beauty in everything she touched, oil painting, visiting museums and art collections, but, perhaps most of all, to her many friends. She was surrounded by people whom she loved and who loved her dearly. In addition to those friends, Gloria is survived by her son Gregory Ercolano, her stepdaughter Caroline Sidnam, and her extended family. The time and place of a memorial gathering have not yet been determined. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Northern Westchester Hospital and the Metropolitan Museum. 1/3

HANFT--Edwin, 90, of Manhattan, New York, died on October 4, 2015. Even to his last days, Ed displayed the wit, wisdom, and unflagging humor with which he lived his life. He was born on October 31, 1924, to Max and Anna Hanft, and grew up in the tenements of New York's Lower East Side. At 17, he met the love of his life, Gladys Potash, at Kutsher's, a Catskills resort, where he was working as athletic director and where she was staying with her family nearby. The two began dating and, when Ed enlisted in the U.S. military to serve in World War II that fall, he wrote to Gladys nearly every single day during his time in the service. He served in the weather service of the military--one of many testaments to his utter brilliance and persuasive powers, because his knowledge of meteorology was largely self-taught in the libraries of New York City. After the war, he returned to City College and married Gladys. His love of words was cultivated there, where he was one of the founders of the Observation Post, City College's activist undergraduate newspaper, and majored in English. He went on to a successful career in advertising as a creative director and copywriter, with much of his career spent as principal and creative director of Chalk, Nissen, Hanft, Inc. One of his projects consisted of a pro bono campaign for the NAACP, portraying the harsh effects of continuing school segregation even after the Supreme Court's decision in Brown v. Board of Education. He garnered many awards for his advertising copy. Among Ed's numerous hobbies was harness racing, and he bred and raced harness horses, as owner of the Polysyllabic Grange (aptly named by him, with his characteristic irony). His sharp wit also continued into his retirement, on display in the humorous and biting letters to the editor he wrote to the many publications which he continued to read religiously, for as long as his eyesight allowed him. Ed was deeply loved by his soul mate and wife of more than 68 years, Gladys Hanft; his sons, Noah and Joshua Hanft; his daughters-in-law Dora Barlaz Hanft and Claudia Chernov; and his six grandchildren, Ali, Elizabeth, Genevieve, Paul, Gideon, and Eliezer Hanft. He died as he had lived, surrounded by his adoring family. 1/3

HARNETT--Bertram, age 92, passed away peacefully at his home in Boca Raton, Florida on October 1. He is survived by his dear wife of 71 years, Ruth, and children, Andrea, a retired Magistrate Judge in Washington, DC; David, a psychiatrist in Medford, Mass.; James, a retired lawyer in Madison, Wisconsin; six grandchildren and one great granddaughter. He was predeceased by his brother, Joel, of New York and Arizona. Raised in Brooklyn, New York, he graduated from Brooklyn College and Columbia Law School. He taught and practiced law in New York and Florida for over 60 years. He wrote two legal treatises and other legal works of more general interest. He served as Nassau County Attorney from 1962 to 1963 and as a Judge on the New York State Supreme Court from 1968 to 1977. He was the prime moving force in the establishment of the Cohen Children's Medical Center of New York in New Hyde Park, NY. He was a man of great intellect and accomplishment and led a long, full life. He was known for a keen sense of justice, an engaging sense of humor, and endless curiosity. He travelled the world and read voraciously. He charmed people of all ages until his final days. Most of all, he loved and was devoted to his family. He will be missed terribly. A funeral service will be held at Temple Beth-El in Boca Raton, Florida at 2:00pm on October 7. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to North Shore LIJ Cohen Children's Medical Center in New Hyde Park, NY or to the Strobis Glaucoma Foundation in Boca Raton. 1/3

BARRETT--Lucille, died October 4, 2015, at age 92. Lou was the matriarch of a large and grateful family. Lou Barrett was a poet, scholar, teacher and social activist. Her poetry appeared in Midstream, Connecticut River Review, Poetica magazine, Muse, Voices Israel, and the National English Journal. She was honored by the Connecticut Council of Teachers of English and the Connecticut Poetry Society for her work. Her publications include five collections of poetry that explore fearlessly and with intensity her Jewish heritage, her childhood in Brooklyn, and her maturing to adulthood and old age. Through all her writings, she found meaning in the connections between her own life and the symbols and images that have endured in myth, story, and literature throughout the centuries. Lou Barrett was a great teacher. She was a lifelong teacher in the classroom, transforming lives for decades of students. Beginning her teaching career in Greenwich Village in the 1940s, she later became a beloved teacher of English literature in the Westport Public Schools, where after retirement she continued as a writing coach. She shared her love of Jewish literature and scholarship with classes at Temple Israel in Westport, Connecticut and in Congregation Kol Ami in Jenkintown, Pennsylvania, where she and her husband for 73 years, the late Herbert Barrett, lived in their later years. Lou was a teacher, not only in the classroom, but in the way she raised her family. She had the instinct great teachers have: to reach and connect with every student, every child and grandchild according to his or her own personality and passions. She believed in her students, her children, and her friends, and strove to help them see in themselves the strength and beauty she saw in them. She treated every one with honesty and respect. Lucille Barrett is survived by five children, David, Joshua, Sarah, George, and Daniel, ten grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, October 6th, at 12:30pm at Temple Israel in Westport Connecticut, with private burial service to follow. The family will sit shiva after the burial at the home of Marvin and Joan Frimmer in Westport, CT. They will also be sitting shiva Wednesday, October 7th, from 5-8pm at the home of George Barrett and Debbie Neimeth, in Rydal, PA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Congregation Kol Ami, Elkins Park, Pennsylvania or Temple Israel, Westport, Connecticut. 1/3

STEINHAUSER--Shirley, on October 2, 2015. Her close friendships were central in her life, with love from her many friends. 1/3

ROTHSTEIN--William A. The Board of Trustees of The Altschul Foundation regrets the passing of William A. Rothstein, a devoted and longtime trustee and officer of the Foundation, and offers its condolences to his family and friends. Billy brought compassion, enthusiasm and dedication to his work on behalf of the Foundation and the various charitable causes he supported. His commitment to the Foundation will be greatly missed. The Trustees of The Altschul Foundation 1/3

KROHN--Barbara Ehrenwald of New York City, October 5, of ALS. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, artist, iconoclast and friend. Born in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia in 1935, she spent 7 years in England with mother Anny and father, author/psychiatrist, Jan Ehrenwald, before coming to the USA in 1946. She graduated from Smith College in 1956 and was married to ophthalmologist/professor David Krohn from 1957 until his 2002 death. Her career as an editor/literary agent started at Houghton Mifflin, then she became Publisher and Editor-in-Chief of Balsam Press. Her ceramic sculptures have appeared in many shows, most recently at Teatown Lake Reservation and the National Arts Club. She is survived by daughters, Deborah and Lisa, son-in-law Adam Wolfe, and grandchildren Livia, Martine, Sammy, Olive and Eero. Graveside service 1:00 pm Friday, October 9th at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. 1/3

SMITH--Doris H.,96, of Tamarac, FL, passed away on October 3, 2015. Devoted wife of Philip (deceased). Beloved mother of Jeffrey (Barrie) and Michael (Rita). Grandmother of eight grandchildren and twelve great-grandchildren. Loving sister of Gladys and the late Seymour and Howard. A wonderful lady - you will be sorely missed. Graveside service 10:45am, Wednesday, October 7, Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, LI. Shiva will be held at the Harmonie Club from 5-9pm on Wednesday. 1/3

LORILLARD--Alice W.,of Far Hills, N.J., died peacefully at home, September 29th. She was the daughter of the late Richard and Gertrude Sheldon Whitney She is survived by her children, Lisa Halsted and her husband, Scott of Mill Valley, CA and Peter Lorillard and his wife, Vicki of Bedminster and six grandchildren. A memorial mass will be held on Thursday, October 29th, 11:00 at St. Elizabeth's Church, Peapack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Essex Foxhounds, P.O. Box 295, Gladstone, NJ 07934. 1/3

CONSTABLE--Elise Jewett, of New York City passed away peacefully on Wednesday, September 9th, 2015. Elise was born on February, 17th, 1930, in Baltimore, MD. Her parents were Henry L. Constable, ESQ., and Gertrude J. Constable of Elkton, MD. After graduation from the Tatnall School in Wilmington, DE, where she was class valedictorian, she was presented at the Baltimore Cotillion in Maryland. She was employed by the DuPont Company in both Wilmington and NYC. In 1972, she joined Fiduciary Trust International where she was the Assistant to the Chairman of the Board. She retired as an Officer of the bank in 1997. Elise was a member of the Colony Club, the Junior League, the Holland Dames, and the Garden Club, all in NYC. Upon her retirement, Elise enjoyed traveling and spending time with her nieces and nephews. She is survived by her brother Richard Constable, her sister-in-law, Anne Constable, both of Madison, CT and six nieces and nephews - Ashley Constable Neary of NYC, Cody Constable of NYC, Diana du Pont of Ft. Wayne, IN, and Melinda Beard, Anthony du Pont, and Edmond du Pont, all of California. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering. Her memorial service is to be held on October 15th at St. James Church in NYC at 2:00pm. 1/3

WALLAU--Alex Lee II, died on his 98th birthday, October 2, 2015, at home in Palm Beach, FL. Born in Great Barrington, MA in 1917 to Grace and Alex Lee Wallau. Graduated from High School in Harrison, NY. Served in the US Army 1940-46. Paratrooper in the 82nd Airborne. Rose to rank of Major. Formerly of The Bronx and Riverside, CT, Mr. Wallau was the President of The Bonnie Doon Company, a manufacturer of high fashion women's hosiery. Predeceased by his beloved wife, Susan Huguley Wallau and daughters, Anne Ward Wallau and Susan Wallau de Rohm and son-in-law, Jose "Puchy" Rohm, he is survived by his brother Charles L. "Bill" Wallau and by his children Alex Wallau III (Martha), Elizabeth Wallau Howard (Edgar), Ward Wallau (Liz), Sheldon Wallau, Claire Wallau Musso (Carlos) and his grandchildren: Ali Rohm Young (Marcelo), Jose "JJ" (Lucilla) and Maximiliano Rohm, Grace and Keating Wallau, Ruby and Charles Wallau, Graham Faught, Christopher and Charles Howard and three great- grandchildren: Alexia and Martina Young and Alex Rohm. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated on Saturday, October 10th at St. Catherine's Church in Riverside, CT at 11am. Condolences may be offered at www.leopgallaghergreen wich.com. 1/3

KARLINSKY--Bette S. (nee Solomon), died peacefully in her sleep September 30, 2015, at age 88 in Boca Raton, Florida. Formerly of New York City, New York; Roslyn, Long Island; and Montreal, Canada, she is survived by son Martin (Christine Ruppert), and daughters Debi (Kathy Rocklen) and Joanna (Justine Berkeley). She was pre-deceased by her dear husband Raymond, and so many good friends and relatives. There was never a person or a dog she did not have all the time in the world to help. Her love stays with us. At her express wish, no memorial and no donations. 1/3

BARRETT--Lucille, died October 4, 2015, at age 92. Lou was the matriarch of a large and grateful family. Lou Barrett was a poet, scholar, teacher and social activist. Her poetry appeared in Midstream, Connecticut River Review, Poetica magazine, Muse, Voices Israel, and the National English Journal. She was honored by the Connecticut Council of Teachers of English and the Connecticut Poetry Society for her work. Her publications include five collections of poetry that explore fearlessly and with intensity her Jewish heritage, her childhood in Brooklyn, and her maturing to adulthood and old age. Through all her writings, she found meaning in the connections between her own life and the symbols and images that have endured in myth, story, and literature throughout the centuries. Lou Barrett was a great teacher. She was a lifelong teacher in the classroom, transforming lives for decades of students. Beginning her teaching career in Greenwich Village in the 1940s, she later became a beloved teacher of English literature in the Westport Public Schools, where after retirement she continued as a writing coach. She shared her love of Jewish literature and scholarship with classes at Temple Israel in Westport, Connecticut and in Congregation Kol Ami in Jenkintown, Pennsylvania, where she and her husband for 73 years, the late Herbert Barrett, lived in their later years. Lou was a teacher, not only in the classroom, but in the way she raised her family. She had the instinct great teachers have: to reach and connect with every student, every child and grandchild according to his or her own personality and passions. She believed in her students, her children, and her friends, and strove to help them see in themselves the strength and beauty she saw in them. She treated every one with honesty and respect. Lucille Barrett is survived by five children, David, Joshua, Sarah, George, and Daniel, ten grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Tuesday, October 6th, at 12:30pm at Temple Israel in Westport Connecticut, with private burial service to follow. The family will sit shiva after the burial at the home of Marvin and Joan Frimmer in Westport, CT. They will also be sitting shiva Wednesday, October 7th, from 5-8pm at the home of George Barrett and Debbie Neimeth, in Rydal, PA. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to Congregation Kol Ami, Elkins Park, Pennsylvania or Temple Israel, Westport, Connecticut. 1/3

BENARDO--Helene, devoted and determined mother of Sanford (Kathy) and Leonard (Jennifer), and loving wife for fifty-four years of Leo, passed away on October 5 after a short bout with cancer. She was 80. Helene leaves behind a legacy rich with writing, teaching and unconditional love for her family. For many years a literature teacher at the Bronx High School of Science, Helene edited the school's feminist magazine and taught a beloved course on women in literature. Her dear friends, Stella Economou and Marilyn Reinhardt, provided her comradeship for decades. 1/3

FALK--Stephen Harrison, on October 4, 2015. Beloved husband of Rita. Loving father of William, Eileen and Helen. Cherished grandfather of Leah, David, Evan and Alex. Devoted brother of Deen and Lynne. Services 12 Noon Wednesday, October 7, 2015 at Temple Emanuel of Great Neck, Great Neck, NY. For information contact Riverside Nassau North Chapels 516-487-9600. 1/3
RUBIN--Cynthia 055/50-10/07/2010 Beloved twin sister and aunt. Always remembered. Corinne and Family 1/3

SIDNAM--Gloria, longtime New York City and Bedford resident, died on October 5th at home in Manhattan. Born in New York on 23 January 1937, Gloria was married to Joseph Ercolano in 1956, to Burt Wells in 1969, and to Alan Sidnam, the love of her life, in 1975. Art was the centerpiece of Gloria's life. She spent more than thirty years on the creative side of the advertising business in its heyday, working at Warwick & Legler, Grey Advertising, and finally Ogilvy & Mather, where she was Associate Creative Director when she retired. Starting in 1989 Gloria devoted a great part of her boundless energy to becoming an art history scholar and docent at the Metropolitan Museum in New York City. Throughout her years at the Met, she studied constantly, continually expanding her knowledge base. She reveled in the details and loved inspiring her students. She was completely fluent on all aspects of the Met collection -- Greek, Roman, European, and American art, even Arms & Armor. Her free time was devoted to cultivating beauty in everything she touched, oil painting, visiting museums and art collections, but, perhaps most of all, to her many friends. She was surrounded by people whom she loved and who loved her dearly. In addition to those friends, Gloria is survived by her son Gregory Ercolano, her stepdaughter Caroline Sidnam, and her extended family. The time and place of a memorial gathering have not yet been determined. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Northern Westchester Hospital and the Metropolitan Museum. 1/3

FRACKMAN--Robert, age 89, passed away peacefully on October 5 from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. He is survived by his wife of 23 years, Risa; son, David; daughter-in-law, Kirsten Cole; and grandsons, Max and Zeke. He was a graduate of Riverside Military Academy, attended Syracuse University, and served in the US Air Corps. He was an energetic and successful entrepreneur, having distinguished himself as the owner of the Incentive Corporation of America and Treetops Realty & Development Co. In 1996, he and his wife created and developed The Inn at Robert's Grove, one of the leading resorts in Belize. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, October 8, at 1pm at Temple Beth- El, 350 Roxbury Rd., Stam- ford, CT. 1/3

Quotation of the Day for Thursday, October 8, 2015

ROTHSTEIN--William A. The Board of Trustees of The Altschul Foundation regrets the passing of William A. Rothstein, a devoted and longtime trustee and officer of the Foundation, and offers its condolences to his family and friends. Billy brought compassion, enthusiasm and dedication to his work on behalf of the Foundation and the various charitable causes he supported. His commitment to the Foundation will be greatly missed. The Trustees of The Altschul Foundation 1/3

DAUM--Rosalie, (nee Gullo), passed away on October 6, 2015. Survived by loving sister, Ann Macaluso and her spouse Peter. Also survived by one niece and three nephews, six great-nieces and nephews. Visiting Thursday, 4-8pm at Miraglia Funeral Chapels, 8519 New Utrecht Ave, Brooklyn. Funeral Mass Friday, 11am at St. Patrick's Church, 4th Ave & 95th St., Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations to St. Jude Children's Hospital would be appreciated. 1/3

KLIOT--Gregory, M.D.,52, beloved husband of Donna DiDonato, son of Harriet Kliot and predeceased father Dr. David Kliot will be greatly missed: He died October 6, 2015 after an extended illness. He is survived by siblings Nancy Kliot and Ben Kliot as well as nephews Alix and Jay Straus. Dr. Gregory Kliot was a Board Certified Obstetrician/Gynecologist with over 20 years of experience. He graduated from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in NYC, and was a Fellow of both the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (F.A.C.O.G.) and the American College of Surgeons (F.A.C.S.). His commitment to the field was exemplified by his dedication to Resident Education and the training of future physicians. Over the years, he was recognized in many ways, including as Clinical Assistant Professor at SUNY--Downstate Medical Center, awarded "Attending of the Year" and "Best Teacher" locally, and honored with the "National Faculty Award for Excellence in Resident Education" from the Council on Resident Education in Obstetrics and Gynecology. A fund to provide continued educational tools and support for the Residents at Maimonides Medical Center has been set up in his honor. Dr. Kliot was recognized in his profession as Chair of the Brooklyn and Staten Island Section of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and was President of the Brooklyn Gynecological Society. He also tirelessly worked to make the hospitals to which he admits patients the best in New York by serving on Hospital Committees. Established over 30 years ago by his father, Dr. David Kliot, the Kliot practice has always been at the forefront of advancing women's rights in the labor room, this work continued while he was with Boro Park Obstetrics and Gynecology. He was an amazing man and those closest to him understood how special he was. He can be best remembered by his kindness, generosity, and sense of humor. He loved sharing his home with friends and family and living with his wife in Prospect Park South, Brooklyn. A memorial service will be held at the family home in Brooklyn on Sunday, October 11th at 1pm. The family will also accept visitors on Saturday from 4pm-7pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Dr. Kliot Residents Fund At: drgregorykliotresidentsfund@mydagsite.com 1/3

BENARDO--Helene, devoted and determined mother of Sanford (Kathy) and Leonard (Jennifer), grandmother to Anya, Felix, Allegra and Daisy, and loving wife for fifty-four years of Leo, passed away on October 5. She was 80. Helene leaves behind a legacy rich with writing, teaching and unconditional love for her family. For many years a literature teacher at the Bronx High School of Science, Helene edited the school's feminist magazine and taught a beloved course on women in literature. Her dear friends, Stella Economou and Marilyn Reinhardt, provided her years of comradeship. 1/3

FRIEDMAN--Francine, on October 6, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Rabbi Herbert, devoted mother of David and Charles. Service Thursday, October 8, 1pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

HAGEN--Robert Peter, Jr.,"Peter," of Basking Ridge, NJ died on September 26, 2015 at Morristown Medical Center after a brief illness. Born June 22, 1945 in Ft. Benning, GA, Peter was a 1967 graduate of the United States Military Academy, and served with distinction in the Vietnam War. He is survived by his two beloved children, Robert and Taylor, his ex-wife, Kate of Bernardsville; his brother Charles, sister-in law Laura Newman and niece Anna of Brooklyn, NY. A funeral service will be held at St. Luke's Episcopal Church of Gladstone, NJ. on October 11, 2015 at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that any donations be made to the American Cancer Society. 1/3

KEATING--Thomas C. On behalf of the Rudin family and the employees of Rudin Management Company, we mourn the loss of our dear friend and colleague, Thomas C. Keating. Tom was a valued and dedicated partner in our company. We will greatly miss Tom and all of his wisdom, experience and leadership. We send our sincere condolences to his son, Tom, daughter, Amy, and the entire Keating family. Jack Rudin Chairman, Rudin Management Company Bill Rudin and Eric Rudin Co-Chairmen, Rudin Management Company 1/3

WALLAU--Alex Lee II, died on his 98th birthday, October 2, 2015, at home in Palm Beach, FL. Born in Great Barrington, MA in 1917 to Grace and Alex Lee Wallau. Graduated from High School in Harrison, NY. Served in the US Army 1940-46. Paratrooper in the 82nd Airborne. Rose to rank of Major. Formerly of The Bronx and Riverside, CT, Mr. Wallau was the President of The Bonnie Doon Company, a manufacturer of high fashion women's hosiery. Predeceased by his beloved wife, Susan Huguley Wallau and daughters, Anne Ward Wallau and Susan Wallau de Rohm and son-in-law, Jose "Puchy" Rohm, he is survived by his brother Charles L. "Bill" Wallau and by his children Alex Wallau III (Martha), Elizabeth Wallau Howard (Edgar), Ward Wallau (Liz), Sheldon Wallau, Claire Wallau Musso (Carlos) and his grandchildren: Ali Rohm Young (Marcelo), Jose "JJ" (Lucilla) and Maximiliano Rohm, Grace and Keating Wallau, Ruby and Charles Wallau, Graham Faught, Christopher and Charles Howard and three great- grandchildren: Alexia and Martina Young and Alex Rohm. A funeral Mass will be celebrated on Saturday, October 10th at St. Catherine's Church in Riverside, CT at 11am. Memorial donations may be made to the Inner-City Scholarship Fund of NYC. 1/3
KLINGHOFFER--Leon. It has been 30 years since you were brutally murdered and taken away from us. Your legacy and our love for you are eternal. Ilsa & Paul and Lisa & Jerry 1/3

LAITMAN--Lt. Col. Milton A.,died October 6, 2015 after a sudden heart attack. He will be buried at West Point alongside his wife of 75 years, Josephine Propp Laitman. Born April 15, 1916 in NYC, "Mickey" graduated USMA ('39), married his beloved "Josie" and served in WWII, attaining the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He founded Planned Financial Programs and leaves behind a remarkable legacy. Survivors include his three daughters and their spouses, seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Donations can be made to the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund, The American Heart Association or to a charity of your choice. 1/3

KROHN--Barbara Ehrenwald of New York City, October 5, of ALS. Beloved wife, mother, grandmother, artist, iconoclast and friend. Born in Bratislava, Czechoslovakia in 1935, she spent 7 years in England with mother Anny and father, author/psychiatrist, Jan Ehrenwald, before coming to the USA in 1946. She graduated from Smith College in 1956 and was married to ophthalmologist/professor David Krohn from 1957 until his 2002 death. Her career as an editor/literary agent started at Houghton Mifflin, then she became Publisher and Editor-in-Chief of Balsam Press. Her ceramic sculptures have appeared in many shows, most recently at Teatown Lake Reservation and the National Arts Club. She is survived by daughters, Deborah and Lisa, sons-in-law Adam Wolfe and Peter Miller, and grandchildren Livia, Martine, Sammy, Olive and Eero. Graveside service 1:00 pm Friday, October 9th at Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. 1/3

KLEIN--Charles (Chuck) died at home in Keego Harbor, MI on September 30, 2015. Chuck was a Temple U alumni, US Navy vet, pioneer of cable television, and entrepreneur. He loved his wife Shelley, his nieces and nephew, and his dogs. 1/3

KEATING--Thomas C. The Partners of Goldfarb & Fleece LLP mourn the passing of our good friend and colleague Thomas C. Keating. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Tom, Ann Marie, Amy, and the entire Keating family. 1/3

HENKIN--Eitam and Naama. The entire Yeshiva University community mourns the tragic death of Eitam and Naama Henkin, beloved children of Chanan and Hila Armony, and Rabbi Yehuda Henkin, esteemed Torah scholar, and his revered wife, Rabbanit Chana Henkin, founder and dean of the Jeanie Schottenstein Nishmat Institute for Advanced Jewish Studies for Women in Jerusalem. Chana Henkin is a graduate of Yeshiva University's Stern College for Women (1968) and its Bernard Revel Graduate School of Jewish Studies (1976) and received an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters Degree from the University in 2001. Our sympathies are extended to the entire bereaved families. May they be comforted among all who mourn for Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm, President Emeritus Rabbi Dovid Miller, Rosh Kollel, Yeshiva University in Israel 1/3

FRACKMAN--Robert, age 89, passed away peacefully on October 5 from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis. He is survived by his wife of 23 years, Risa; son, David; daughter-in-law, Kirsten Cole; and grandsons, Max and Zeke. He was a graduate of Riverside Military Academy, attended Syracuse University, and served in the US Air Corps. He was an energetic and successful entrepreneur, having distinguished himself as the owner of the Incentive Corporation of America and Treetops Realty & Development Co. In 1996, he and his wife created and developed The Inn at Robert's Grove, one of the leading resorts in Belize. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, October 8, at 1pm at Temple Beth- El, 350 Roxbury Rd., Stam- ford, CT. 1/3

BARSA--Albert Simon, 91, formerly of Rye, NY, passed away on October 4, 2015 in Charlotte, NC. Mr. Barsa was raised in New York City where he attended the Loyola School. He continued his education at MIT, receiving a degree in Aeronautical Engineering in 1947. Mr. Barsa served with the Corp of Engineers in Europe during WWII. He was president of Odette Barsa, Inc., a maker of fine lingerie. In 2010, after living in Rye, NY for 56 years, Mr. Barsa and his wife moved to Charlotte to be closer to their daughter. Mr. Barsa is survived by his wife of 66 years, Gloria; daughter, Barbara and son- in-law, Jim Jamison; daughter-in-law, Susan Barsa; grandchildren: Albert and Christina Barsa, Kyle and Blake Jamison; sister, Nadia Gerrity. He was predeceased by his son, Albert Barsa, Jr. and a brother, Gabriel Barsa. 1/3

WEISS--Irma Giustino. The Trustees and Staff of the Whitney Museum of American Art express with profound sadness the passing of Irma Giustino Weiss. A woman of great style, undaunted conviction and razor- sharp wit, Irma lived a life of generosity and audacity. A passionate supporter of the arts and education, her spirit will live on at the Whitney through her countless contributions including the Benjamin and Irma Weiss Director of Research Resources. Irma's warmth, humor and good friendship will be deeply missed. Our sincerest condolences go out to her family and many friends. Leonard A. Lauder, Chairman Emeritus; Flora Miller Biddle, Honorary Chairman; Neil G. Bluhm, Co-Chair; Laurie M. Tisch, Co-Chair; Rich DeMartini, President; Adam D. Weinberg, Alice Pratt Brown Director 1/3

GREENBERG--I. Melbourne, M.D.,a neurosurgeon and a neurosurgical instrument innovator, died on Tuesday, at the age of 94, near his home in Roslyn Estates, New York. Dr. Greenberg began his neurological and neurosurgical practice in 1952. In the early 1950s he founded the Neurological Surgery & Neurology practice, which is presently known as the Leslie Munzer Neurological Institute of Long Island. In 1975 he invented the Greenberg Universal Retractor System to reduce tremor, provide more controlled movements for surgeons while performing surgery. The Greenberg System is now used by hospitals worldwide. In 1987 he developed the "Finger Rotation of Instrumentation," commonly known worldwide as the '501 Patent. He created many videos demonstrating his concepts and techniques. In 1994 his video, "Surgical Ergonomics: Craniotomy," won a Freddie Award at the International Medical Film Festival. He won a second Freddie in 1996 for his video, "Integrated Surgical Support Systems in Endoscopic Cholecystectomy." In addition to his active neurosurgery practice and inventions, Dr. Greenberg had appointments for over 30 professorships throughout the world. This included North America, Europe, Russia, and China. In 1985 he received an academic appointment of full clinical professor in neurosurgery at Stony Brook University School of Medicine, New York. In 1960 he was the chairman of postgraduate medical education of the Nassau County Medical Society. In 1976 Dr. Greenberg was elected to the Board of Directors of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons. He is survived by his wife, Louise Greenberg, two children, Ann GreenbergMudrick and Dr. Jeffrey Greenberg, two grandchildren, Sophie Greenberg and Olivia Greenberg, a son-in- law, Paul Mudrick, and a daughter-in-law, Susan Amato Greenberg. 1/3

KLIOT--Gregory, M.D.,52, beloved husband of Donna DiDonato, son of Harriet Kliot and predeceased father Dr. David Kliot will be greatly missed: He died October 6, 2015 after an extended illness. He is survived by siblings Nancy Kliot and Ben Kliot as well as nephews Alix and Jay Straus. Dr. Gregory Kliot was a Board Certified Obstetrician/Gynecologist with over 20 years of experience. He graduated from the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in NYC, and was a Fellow of both the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (F.A.C.O.G.) and the American College of Surgeons (F.A.C.S.). His commitment to the field was exemplified by his dedication to Resident Education and the training of future physicians. Over the years, he was recognized in many ways, including as Clinical Assistant Professor at SUNY--Downstate Medical Center, awarded "Attending of the Year" and "Best Teacher" locally, and honored with the "National Faculty Award for Excellence in Resident Education" from the Council on Resident Education in Obstetrics and Gynecology. A fund to provide continued educational tools and support for the Residents at Maimonides Medical Center has been set up in his honor. Dr. Kliot was recognized in his profession as Chair of the Brooklyn and Staten Island Section of the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and was President of the Brooklyn Gynecological Society. He also tirelessly worked to make the hospitals to which he admits patients the best in New York by serving on Hospital Committees. Established over 30 years ago by his father, Dr. David Kliot, the Kliot practice has always been at the forefront of advancing women's rights in the labor room, this work continued while he was with Boro Park Obstetrics and Gynecology. He was an amazing man and those closest to him understood how special he was. He can be best remembered by his kindness, generosity, and sense of humor. He loved sharing his home with friends and family and living with his wife in Prospect Park South, Brooklyn. A memorial service will be held at the family home in Brooklyn on Sunday, October 11th at 1pm. The family will also accept visitors on Saturday from 4pm-7pm. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Dr. Kliot Residents Fund At: http://drgregorykliotresidentsfund.mydagsite.com 1/3

ROGERS--Gertrud, on October 8, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Erich. Loving mother of Gary and Elaine. Cherished aunt of Monica Rothstein. Services: 12 noon, Sunday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

LORILLARD--Alice W.,of Far Hills, N.J., died peacefully at home, September 29th. She was the daughter of the late Richard and Gertrude Sheldon Whitney She is survived by her children, Lisa Halsted and her husband, Scott of Mill Valley, CA and Peter Lorillard and his wife, Vicki of Bedminster and six grandchildren. A memorial mass will be held on Thursday, October 29th, 11:00 at St. Elizabeth's Church, Peapack, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Essex Foxhounds, P.O. Box 295, Gladstone, NJ 07934. 1/3

MILLAR--Caroline Sloane, of New Providence, NJ and Southampton, NY, passed away on October 7, 2015. Born on December 19, 1928 in the Bronx, Caroline was the great-granddaughter of James Sloane, brother of William and John Sloane of W. & J. Sloane, Interior Decorators and Home Furnishers. She met her husband Bill at a Womrath Book Shop in NYC at the time he was attending NYU School of Engineering. She was a gourmet cook, skilled bridge player, talented gardener and avid reader of The New York Times. She was a Mayflower descendant, and Thanksgiving was a special time for the family. Her passion was spending time by the ocean in Southampton, NY with family and friends. She is survived by her devoted husband, William M. Millar, her two loving children, William Sloane Millar, MD, FACR and Suzanne Millar Mount, and two beloved grandchildren, Bradley and Alyssa Mount. 1/3

NAY--Howard Riley, MD, known to his friends as "Skip," passed away peacefully on October 6, 2015, in Lynchburg, Virginia after suffering an acute stroke. He was 85. Dr. Nay received his MD from Columbia University, College of Physicians and Surgeons in New York City in 1956. After his internship at Bellevue Hospital, he completed his surgical residency at St. Luke's Hospital, NYC. From 1959-1961 he served in the United States Air Force Medical Corps in Ankara, Turkey. Dr. Nay was Senior Attending Surgeon and Chief of the Surgery "A" Service at St. Luke's Hospital in New York until his retirement in 2000. He was Instructor in Surgery and Associate Clinical Professor of Surgery at Columbia University, College of P&S, and had several articles published in medical publications throughout his career. A talented and innovative surgeon, Dr. Nay was known for his kind bedside manner. He had a private practice in Manhattan at 925 Park Avenue, and later worked at Isabella Nursing Home in New York until 2012. Dr. Nay was predeceased by his wife of 38 years, Geraldine "Gerry" Tullock Nay; his parents, Howard E. Nay and Agnes G. Nay of Wheeling, WVA, his brother, Robert E. Nay of Springfield, VA, and his sister Barbara Nay Raine of Charleston, WVA. He is survived by his sister Janet Nay Carenbauer of Wheeling, WVA; his daughters Kathryn Nay Clay of Lynchburg, VA, Betsy Nay Schwengel of Bristol, RI, Jenny Nay Masters of Hastings on Hudson, NY; his grandchildren Luke, Dina, Riley and Teddy; his sons in law, Lucius D. Clay of Lynchburg, VA and Robert H. Schwengel of Bristol, RI; brother and sister-in-law, John and Kathy Godwin of Alpharetta, GA, and many beloved nieces and nephews. A celebratory service will be held on Friday, October 9, 2015, at 11:30am in the chapel at Virginia Episcopal School in Lynchburg, VA. Interment of his remains and service in Onteora Cemetery, Tannersville, NY will take place in summer, 2016. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in his name to The Onteora Theater, PO Box 546, Tannersville, NY 12485. 1/3

STANFIELD MURRAY-- Sarah, a writer/editor from Jackson Heights, NY, passed away October 7, 2015, at the age of 38. She is survived by her loving husband James Murray, step-children Justin and Dubheasa Murray, parents Kirtley and Frances Stanfield, mother-in-law Mary Murray, aunt Gisele Yetz, several brothers- and sisters-in-law and friend Brian Geldin. A memorial service will be announced soon for Conway Funeral Home in Jackson Heights. Donations may be made in Sarah's name to Curly Tail Pug Rescue, http://www.curlytail pugrescue.org/. 1/3

PINCUS--Dr. Murray Benjamin, 92, a renowned surgeon of urology and a professor of medicine at Mt. Sinai Hospital for over 45 years, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Wednesday, October 7. He is survived by his devoted wife of 50 years Ann, his beloved daughters Beth (Andrew) and Lynn, and his adoring grandchildren Jake and Rachel. Dr. Pincus received both his BA and his MD from the University of Virginia, earning the highest honors of Phi Beta Kappa and Alpha Omega Alpha. Dr. Pincus was also affiliated with the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston and served as Chief of Urology at Elmhurst Hospital in New York. Dr. Pincus was published in numerous medical journals and served with distinction as a Captain in the US Air Force during the Korean War. Funeral services will be held in private. 1/3

STUBING--William Charles, 76, died October 4, receiving home hospice care after struggling with a brain prion disease. He was unafraid to face death, although he loved life and the people around him. He was a loving and devoted partner for 37 years and husband for two of those years. His friendship, counsel, and dinner invitations were eagerly sought by friends, family, and colleagues. His guidance shaped the current form of the New York Academy of Medicine and The Greenwall Foundation. The latter's work in bioethics supported many leaders in the area. He wanted to make end-of-life decisions easier for those in need of such decisions. He was pastoral and loved the good things in life: good food, glorious music, and particularly old friends. A private service will be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 1/3

LAITMAN--Lt. Col. Milton A.,died October 6, 2015 after a sudden heart attack. He will be buried at West Point alongside his wife of 75 years, Josephine Propp Laitman. Born April 15, 1916 in NYC, "Mickey" graduated USMA ('39), married his beloved "Josie" and served in WWII, attaining the rank of Lieutenant Colonel. He founded Planned Financial Programs and leaves behind a remarkable legacy. Survivors include his three daughters and their spouses, seven grandchildren and nine great-grandchildren. Donations can be made to the West Point Jewish Chapel Fund, The American Heart Association or to a charity of your choice. 1/3

GIANGRECO--Christine, on October 6, 2015. Oldest child of Agnes (nee McKinney) and Ernest. Loving sister of Paul (Lillie) of Basking Ridge, NJ and Clare of East Brunswick, NJ. Dear friend and roommate of 35 years to Carol Stone. Beloved aunt of Karen (her Goddaughter), Michael, Diane, Pamela and William. Duffy Funeral Home, 255 9th Street, Brooklyn. Entombment to follow at St. John's Cemetery, Middle Village, Queens, NY. 1/3

WU--Dr. Clyde Y.C. The President and Trustees of Columbia University express deep sorrow at the passing of Dr. Clyde Y.C. Wu, cherished friend and alumnus, compassionate physician, Trustee Emeritus, and Benefactor of the University. A graduate of Columbia's College of Physicians and Surgeons, Dr. Wu together with his late wife, Helen, gave back selflessly to Columbia in ways that will be felt for generations to come. Through his philanthropy and leadership, including his steadfast commitment to supporting faculty and collaborative research with China, Dr. Wu played an integral role in the University community. While serving as a University Trustee and Vice Chair of the Medical Center's Board of Advisors, Dr. Wu provided counsel marked by the same wisdom and benevolence that made him invaluable to his patients. Columbia University extends its profound sympathy to his children, grandchildren, extended family, and all who feel his loss. 1/3

WU--Clyde. Columbia University Medical Center celebrates the life and mourns the passing of Clyde Wu, M.D., our friend and benefactor. A member of the P&S Class of 1956 and a longtime faculty member at the Wayne State University School of Medicine, Dr. Wu was an accomplished cardiologist, a generous alumnus, a respected leader and a valued colleague. The extraordinary philanthropy of Dr. Wu and his late wife, Helen, established the Clyde and Helen Wu Center for Molecular Cardiology and five Clyde and Helen Wu Professorships; the Wus' generosity was crucial in the construction of our new Medical and Graduate Education Building. Their foresight allowed us to establish the Clyde and Helen Wu Fellows Program, which brings promising junior faculty from the Peking Union Medical College in Beijing to train on our campus; and the Wu China Center fosters collaborations between our institution and prominent medical schools throughout China. Dr. Wu served Columbia with the distinction, grace, modesty and insight that were characteristic of everything he did, as a member of the University's Board of Trustees and as Vice Chair of the Medical Center's Board of Advisors. We offer our condolences to his children, grandchildren and the extended Wu family. Roy Vagelos, M.D. Chair, Board of Advisors Columbia University Medical Center Lee Goldman, M. D. Executive Vice President and Dean of the Faculties of Health Sciences and Medicine Columbia University 1/3

WEINER--Herbert Zelick. Nov. 14, 1927-Oct. 8, 2014 Thinking of you every day, my beloved father. I will always miss your unconditional love and support, sage advice and joyful spirit. Ellen Jane Weiner 1/3
ZIPPER--Sheila. Friend in heart and mind, remembered with love. Ellie Bromberg & Family 1/3

ROSENBERG--Frank, 95, of New York, NY on October 9, 2015. Beloved husband of Natalie for 72 years. Dear father of Martin, Sara Abbott (Ken) and Hal (Nancy). Cherished grandfather of four and great-grandfather of four. Memorial service Sunday, October 11 at 2pm, Plaza Funeral Home, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NYC, NY 10024. 1/3

ZIPPER--Sheila, of New York City, NY passed away on Thursday, October 8, 2015. She was 79. She was born August 20, 1936 in Brooklyn, NY. She graduated from Hunter College in New York and Fordham Law School in New York. Teacher, Lawyer, devoted Mother and Grandmother. Beloved wife of Gerald Zipper, she is survived by sons Michael and Andrew, brother Alvin and four grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Amsterdam Avenue and 91rst street in New York City at 10:00am on Sunday October 11. In lieu of flowers contributions may be sent to Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 434 West 33rd Street, NY, NY 10001. 1/3

PINCUS--Dr. Murray Benjamin, 92, a renowned surgeon of urology and a professor of medicine at Mt. Sinai Hospital for over 45 years, died peacefully at his home in Manhattan on Wednesday, October 7. He is survived by his devoted wife of 50 years Ann, his beloved daughters Beth (Andrew) and Lynn, and his adoring grandchildren Jake and Rachel. Dr. Pincus received both his BA and his MD from the University of Virginia, earning the highest honors of Phi Beta Kappa and Alpha Omega Alpha. Dr. Pincus was also affiliated with the Peter Bent Brigham Hospital in Boston and served as Chief of Urology at Elmhurst Hospital in New York. Dr. Pincus was published in numerous medical journals and served with distinction as a Captain in the US Air Force during the Korean War. Funeral services will be held in private. 1/3
GREENBERG--Charles H. You will be cherished and adored forever. Love, Doree, Andy, Deanne, Emily, Charlie, Lynn, Hillary, Scott, Joely and Eric 1/3

GRABINO--Priscilla, on October 8, 2015 two days prior to her 85th birthday. Beloved wife of Harold. Loving mother of Eric and Amy (Robert Schecterson). Adoring grandmother of Emily and Jessica Landau and Calder and Jane Schecterson. Graduate of Syracuse University and Fordham University. Contributions may be made to The Museum of Jewish Heritage or Stephen Wise Free Synagogue. Services Sunday 11am at "The Riverside" 76 street and Amsterdam Avenue. 1/3

LINDSAY--Melvin Jay. Artist, master potter, sculptor, adventurer, specialized in large-scale ceramics. Born June 14, 1943 in Eugene, OR; died September 27, 2015 in Carmel, NY. Director, Garrison Art Center, 1980s. At Tallix Art Foundry in Beacon, NY, he worked on the 24-foot tall Leonardo Da Vinci horse statue, among others. Ceramics instructor, Art Student League, Sparkill, NY. Lindsay traveled extensively throughout the world, using the trips as inspiration for his works. 1/3

GOLUB--Gerald. The Members, staff, and his fellow Advisors to TIGER 21 mourn the passing of Gerry Golub, our dear friend. Gerry was a most unusual man of humility, rare intelligence and deep courage. The courageous and determined manner in which he spoke about his approach to fighting Lymphoma for many years was an inspiration. He was always upbeat, and when he wasn't, you couldn't tell. Gerry started from modest beginnings, having walked five miles uphill to and from school every day. He founded Goldstein Golub and Kessler, which would go on to become the largest single office accounting firm in America, and then years later figured out how to structure a sale that broke new ground in his profession. Gerry was first and foremost a family man. He spoke mostly about his wife Bonnie, his children and grandchildren, and he partook in every triumph and challenge as if they were his own. His colleagues at TIGER 21 often shared in the joys of each college acceptance (and nursery school acceptance) that he so proudly shared. As an advisor and confidant, Gerry was unique. He seemed to have time to listen and provide thoughtful advice whenever he was called upon to do so. As the "numbers man," Gerry was the one we all turned to for important perspective about whether we were seeing things correctly and understanding the importance of one trend or another. His power was rooted in his common sense; he understood people's motivations and how best to approach the endless challenges of growing a business. Gerry's professionalism, preparation and thoughtfulness really set the standard for all of us. Gerry was a disciplined man. In the 25 years in which he participated in monthly meetings with fellow Members, he was always the first to arrive and had the highest attendance record by far, something he was always proud of. Gerry was a role model. In his retirement he took on communal responsibilities for his local fire department, that he labored over, as if the challenges were his own. He cared that much. Mostly, he was a good man and a good friend, and his loss will be deep and long lasting. We extend our deepest sympathies to Gerry's wife, Bonnie, his children and grandchildren. We share your loss. We were honored to have counted Gerry as a good friend and a cherished advisor. Michael W. Sonnenfeldt TIGER 21 Founder and Chairman 1/3

SATIN--Gene. 1/1/27 - 10/13/06 Missed beyond words, but rememberings are precious and last forever . . . not a day goes by. Your Loving Family, Elly, Jon, Doreen & Joel, Mike and Matt 1/3

JOBE--Edward Blinn. November 24, 1929-October 4, 2015. Edward B. Jobe passed away unexpectedly but peacefully on Sunday, October 4, with Laura, his wife of 56 years, by his side. A man of honor and integrity, he was deeply loved by his family and friends and adored and respected by the many people whose paths he crossed over his long, successful business career. A native of Iowa, Ed spent over 50 years in the insurance industry. Following the highly successful management-led buyout from Aetna Life and Casualty in September 1992, he was named Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer of American Re Corporation and American Re-Insurance Company where he spent 33 years of his career until his retirement in December of 1995. During Ed's tenure as CEO, American Re more than doubled in size and was one of the most profitable reinsurers in the U.S., positioning the company for its ultimate sale to Munich Re at among the highest multiples of book value ever experienced in the U.S. insurance industry. While proud of the financial results, Ed measured success by the many talented people he helped during his career and the deep client relationships he encouraged and nurtured, many of which are still in place today. Born November 24, 1929 in Keokuk, Iowa, Ed received many awards in his lifetime, but his greatest achievement was meeting the love of his life, Laura (Halvorson) Jobe, while calling on her family's bank in St. Ansgar, Iowa. A five year courtship led to a long and loving marriage filled with laughter. They had a unique marriage contract which every year could either be renewed or dissolved, with no hard feelings. The last contract was renewed on February 21, 2015. Including his wife Laura, Ed is survived by his devoted daughter Trudy Queripel, her husband Jeffrey, Trudy's three children, Stephen, Laura and John Deckoff, his brother Wayne (Shirley), sisters Janis McBain (George) and Jerilyn Mason (Roger) and his beloved dog, Molly. To visit and sign his guestbook, please visit: yourtribute.com. 1/3

STUBING--William Charles, 76, died October 4, receiving home hospice care after struggling with a brain prion disease. He was unafraid to face death, although he loved life and the people around him. He was a loving and devoted partner for 37 years and husband for two of those years. His friendship, counsel, and dinner invitations were eagerly sought by friends, family, and colleagues. His guidance shaped the current form of the New York Academy of Medicine and The Greenwall Foundation. The latter's work in bioethics supported many leaders in the area. He wanted to make end-of-life decisions easier for those in need of such decisions. He was pastoral and loved the good things in life: good food, glorious music, and particularly old friends. A private service will be held at St. Thomas Episcopal Church. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 1/3

SHINBAUM--Leslie, died October 8. Beloved husband of 49 years to wife Myrna. Adored father of Karen (Nick) and Craig (Bari), cherished brother of Myrna. He leaves his family and friends a legacy of caring, inquisitiveness and a passion for life. He will be deeply missed. Services private. 1/3

ZIPPER--Sheila, of New York City, NY passed away on Thursday, October 8, 2015. She was 79. She was born August 20, 1936 in Brooklyn, NY. She graduated from Hunter College in New York and Fordham Law School in New York. Teacher, Lawyer, devoted Mother and Grandmother. HIRSCH--Herbert. Our family mourns the loss of beloved father, grandfather, and uncle Herbert Hirsch who died of natural causes at age 90 on October 9th. A born and bred New Yorker, Herb graduated from the Horace Mann School, Brown University and Columbia University Law School and served in the Navy during World War II. After law school, Herb joined the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver, and Jacobson where he specialized in corporate and art law and became a partner. His passion was art law and he served as Chair of the Art Law Committee of the New York City Bar Association. Herb and then-wife Felicia raised their three sons on the Upper West Side of Manhattan while spending summers in his beloved East Hampton. Herb was pre-deceased by his much-loved son Ted, his brother Bud and sister Edith. He is survived by sons Laurence and Dennis, daughters-in-law Alice, Suzanne, and Mary, beloved grandchildren Clara, Zander, Isaac, Harry and Olivia, nieces and nephews, his sister-in-law Peggy Hirsch and brother-in-law Jack Shore. His presence will always be felt and remembered and his passing leaves a big hole in our lives. We miss him and love him. Services Monday, October 12th, 11am, at the Independent Jewish Cemetery in Sag Harbor, NY. 1/3

ZELINSKY--Daniel, 92, died peacefully September 16. Survived by devoted wife Zelda; children Mara (Kevin), Paul (Deborah), David (Dorothy); grandchildren Anna, Rachel, Ben and Ellen. A brilliant mind, earned Ph.D. from University of Chicago at 22. Pioneering algebraist with 45-year Northwestern career. Fulbright scholar, Guggenheim fellow, twice fellow at the Institute for Advanced Study, avid chamber violinist and connoisseur of many things. He was an inspiration to all. 1/3

CODRINGTON--Kerstin Margareta, passed away peacefully on October 4, 2015 at her home in Chester, NJ. She was 76. Born in Sundsvall, Sweden to Nils Westman and Margit Lidgren, she attended Uppsala University in Sweden and Cornell University, before marrying Garrett Codrington in 1962. Kerstin belonged to SVEA, Swedish Women's Club, Creative Living Bible Study and avidly pursued the decorative arts personally and professionally. Her family and friends will remember her intelligence, sense of humor, beauty and radiant smile. GALVIN--William Aloysius Jr.,a 40 year resident of Alamo, California died on September 28, at the age of 76, at his home, from Acute Myeloid Leukemia. Born in New York City to William A. Galvin, Sr. and Marion Snyder Galvin, he was raised in Manhasset, NY, attended St. Mary's Elementary School and Manhasset High School. He graduated from the University of Notre Dame and was commissioned a 2nd Lt. in the U.S. Army in Air Defense Artillery and served during the Cuban missile crisis. He followed in his father's footsteps and became a lawyer. He earned his law degree from Armstrong College. He was a Public Defender early in his career and later went into private practice as a disability lawyer in Oakland and Walnut Creek, CA. He is survived by his wife of 51 years, the former Carol Armstrong, by his daughters Rachel (Rick Jones) and Mary Galvin (Kevin Hendren), and by his two grandchildren, Madeline and William Jones. His parents and brother John predeceased him. Burial will be at Holy Rood Cemetery, Old Westbury, NY. A celebration of his life is to be held in Alamo on October 24. For details please email: galvinmemorial@gmail.com Contributions may be made in his memory to: doctorswithoutborders.org. 1/3

BING--Alexander III "Sandy," 84, passed away at home after a sudden, brief fight with lung cancer on September 12, 2015. Sandy was born and lived in New York City; attended Dalton and Lincoln Schools, graduated Phi Beta Kappa from Middlebury College and received a Masters degree in American History from Columbia University; served in Europe after WWII in the United States Army. Sandy was a partner and Director of Research at L.F. Rothschild, and later worked at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette in fixed income research. He married Cynthia Eaton, and together they raised four children. Sandy's parents, Matilda S. and Alexander S. Bing; wife, Cynthia E. Bing; daughter, Abigail R. Bing; and former wife, Elisabeth G. Bing predeceased him. He is survived by son, Alexander M. Bing; daughters, Cynthia K. Bing and Virginia G. Bing; son-in-law, Michael Padial; and granddaughter, Eloise B. Padial. A memorial service will be held at The Church of the Heavenly Rest, 90th St. and 5th Ave. at 3pm, October 16, 2015 with reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Friends of the Upper Delaware River (FUDR.org) and/or EarlySteps.org. To view full obituary, visit: www.legacy.com. 1/3

LEEDS--Herbert Alan Died peacefully October 5, 2015, at age 98 in Bloomington, MN. Formerly of New York, NY, Milwaukee, WI, Richmond, VA, Pittsburgh,PA and Miami, FL. Herbert is survived by sons, Alan and Eric; grandson, Tristan; daughter-in-law, Gwendolyn Gwyn-Leeds; and cousins, nieces and nephews. He was predeceased by his beloved wife of 67 years, Dorothy (nee Samuelson). Born in New York City, April 1, 1917. As a youngster his leadership qualities led him to Camp Rising Sun, an invitation-only, International, full scholarship, leadership summer program. He attended Columbia University and, from 1942 to 1946, served in the U.S. Navy where he met and married Dorothy who was a member of the WAVES. His early retail career included tenures with Macy's and Lord & Taylor in New York, and Boston Store and Schuster's in Milwaukee. From 1959 to 1966 he was Vice President/General Manager of Thalheimer's, Richmond, VA where he was also at the forefront of racially integrating public facilities in Richmond. From 1966 to 1973 he was President/CEO of Gimbel's/Pittsburgh and was on the board of Gimbel Brothers Inc. In recognition of his international retail accomplishments he was officially designated Cavaliere by The Order of Merit of the Italian Republic. In 1973 he was named Retailer of the Year by the Pennsylvania Retailers Association. In 1975 he formed Leeds Business Counseling in Miami, an International retail and marketing consultancy firm whose many clients included Nike, Tourneau, Roberta di Camerino, Aventura Mall and Miami International Airport. He ran L.B.C. until his retirement in 2008. He was President of the Better Business Bureau of Richmond, President of the Pittsburgh Retail Merchants Association, Board member and Finance Vice President of the Pittsburgh Symphony, Board member of the Pittsburgh Opera and Board member of WPBT Public Television in Miami. Since 1968 he was Board Member Emeritus of the University of Pittsburgh, Graduate School of Business. He was an adjunct Professor at F.I.U. in Miami and taught economics at Miami-Dade Community College. From 1957 to 1959 he was President of Temple Sinai in Milwaukee. Active in retirement, he lectured about retail merchandising at the University of Minnesota College of Design and hosted political seminars at his residence. The time and place of a memorial gathering has yet to be determined. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to Camp Rising Sun, c/o the Louis August Jonas Foundation, 152 Madison Ave., N.Y., NY 10016. Hodroff-Epstein Memorial Chapel, 612-871-1234. 1/3

Raised in Czernovitz, then Romania and now Ukraine, Frieda was a Holocaust survivor who came to New York in 1949. A true matriarch, she loved her family, world travel, New York and bridge. She will be remembered for her strong will and independent spirit as well as her support of Israel and Jewish causes. 1/3

GREENBERG--I. Melbourne, M.D.,a neurosurgeon and a neurosurgical instrument innovator, died on Tuesday, at the age of 94, near his home in Roslyn Estates, New York. Dr. Greenberg began his neurological and neurosurgical practice in 1952. In the early 1950s he founded the Neurological Surgery & Neurology practice, which is presently known as the Leslie Munzer Neurological Institute of Long Island. In 1975 he invented the Greenberg Universal Retractor System to reduce tremor, provide more controlled movements for surgeons while performing surgery. The Greenberg System is now used by hospitals worldwide. In 1987 he developed the "Finger Rotation of Instrumentation," commonly known worldwide as the '501 Patent. He created many videos demonstrating his concepts and techniques. In 1994 his video, "Surgical Ergonomics: Craniotomy," won a Freddie Award at the International Medical Film Festival. He won a second Freddie in 1996 for his video, "Integrated Surgical Support Systems in Endoscopic Cholecystectomy." In addition to his active neurosurgery practice and inventions, Dr. Greenberg had appointments for over 30 professorships throughout the world. This included North America, Europe, Russia, and China. In 1985 he received an academic appointment of full clinical professor in neurosurgery at Stony Brook University School of Medicine, New York. In 1960 he was the chairman of postgraduate medical education of the Nassau County Medical Society. In 1976 Dr. Greenberg was elected to the Board of Directors of the American Association of Neurological Surgeons. He is survived by his wife, Louise Greenberg, two children, Ann GreenbergMudrick and Dr. Jeffrey Greenberg, two grandchildren, Sophie Greenberg and Olivia Greenberg, a son-in- law, Paul Mudrick, and a daughter-in-law, Susan Amato Greenberg. 1/3

KORNREICH--David R. David R. Kornreich, 80, died peacefully at his home in Katonah, NY, on October 6, 2015 after a brief illness. Born on January 9, 1935, in New York City to the late Herbert and Gertrude Kornreich, he graduated from the Fieldston School and Tufts University. He served in the US Army in Paris after World War II, coming home to join his father in the insurance business. David retired in 2012, after the brokerage had become Loveman, Kornreich, & Steers. David's great passion was music. He was very active in Friends of Music Concerts, Inc., serving as president and board member for decades. He was an active member of the Choral Arts Society (now the Hudson Chorale) and sang in countless concerts. He served for many years on the board of Copland House. David was married in 1961 to Camille Antoinette Budarz, who predeceased him. In 2014, he married Nancy Dana Gold. He is survived by his wife and his two sons, Geremy Kornreich of Boulder, CO, and Christopher Kornreich and his wife Lourdes Kornreich of Port Charlotte, FL. A memorial celebration will be held at the Ossining Public Library's Budarz Theater on November 1, at 6pm. Donations in David's memory may be made to Phelps Hospice, 701 North Broadway, Sleepy Hollow, NY 10591. 1/3
