STUBING--William C. The Directors of the Greenwall Foundation are grieved and saddened at the death of our beloved President Emeritus William C. Stubing, who served as President for 21 years. His warmth, generosity, interest in others, graciousness, understated humor, elegant writing, humility, intellectual curiosity, wide artistic interests, and skills as a raconteur and host will continue to inspire us and many others whose lives he touched. His intellectual and artistic interests were as broad as the good works and his impact on many people and institutions. He enthusiastically shared his deep knowledge of the history, religion, architecture, and the arts scene of New York City. A deeply religious person, he had one eye on heaven and one fixed solidly on earth and was often called upon when family and friends needed someone in whom they could confide and seek counsel. His vision enabled Greenwall to have extraordinary national impact for a relatively small foundation, becoming the main funder of bioethics research in the United States. Under his leadership, the Foundation was willing to be bold and take risks in supporting potentially controversial areas of inquiry. The Foundation also supported emerging arts in New York City, supporting creative accomplishments in the fine and the performing arts. He led the board to focus on supporting gifted young bioethics scholars through career development awards, establishing the Greenwall Faculty Scholars Program. Many awardees have become leaders in bioethics. His suggestions and encouragement contributed to the success of many grantees and enriching their lives. Born September 28, 1939, he was educated at Concordia Senior College and graduated from Concordia Seminary. He earned his Masters at the New York University School of Education. Before the Greenwall Foundation, he served as a priest and worked at the American Medical Association and then the New York Academy of Medicine, as Director of the Academy, the first and only non-physician to hold that position. He worked with board members to modernize the structure of the Academy. We extend our deepest condolences to his beloved partner of thirty-seven years and husband, Ronald Thomas, who survives him. Funeral services will be private. A memorial service is planned for November 2015 in New York. Tributes in his memory may be made to the Metropolitan Museum of Art. 1/3

ROTHSCHILD--Robert Friend, age 97, died peacefully on October 7, 2015 in his native New York City. The eldest child of Herbert and Nannette Rothschild, he is survived by his wife, Margaret, daughter, Katherine, son, Peter, and sister, Barbara Michaels. His first wife, Maurine, died in 2004. Born in 1918, he grew up on Sedgwick Avenue in the Bronx, attended the Fieldston school and Harvard College, from which he graduated in 1939 with a degree in biochemistry. During World War II, he worked on the development of radar at the Sperry Gyroscope Company. He served for many years as vice president and then president of the family furniture business, John Stuart, Inc. His lifelong passion for science led him to write "Two Brides for Apollo," a scholarly book on the 18th-century astronomer Samuel Williams, which he published at 90. He was a founding member of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture and the Maine Community Foundation. He served on numerous boards, including those of the Farnsworth Museum and Portland Art Museum in Maine, and on the visiting committee of the Fogg Museum at Harvard. Since 1967, he has made his second home in Dark Harbor, ME, on the island of Islesboro. He was an avid sailor, first on Long Island Sound and later along the coast of Maine, which he explored over five decades in his yawl, Amistad. In addition to his wife, sister, and children, his loss is mourned by his grandchildren, step-children, and many friends. A memorial gathering will take place in the coming weeks. In lieu of flowers, we ask that gifts be sent to those organizations to which he was so deeply devoted in life: the Farnsworth Museum of Art, 16 Museum Street, Rockland, ME, 04841; the Islesboro Island Trust, PO Box 182, Islesboro, ME 04842; and the Department of the History of Science, Attention Recording Secretary, Harvard College, Cambridge, Massachusetts 02138. 1/3

SNEIDER--Robert George, on October 3, 2015. Formerly of Kings Point, NY. Beloved husband of Judith Weiss Sneider. Adored father of Steven and Linda Sneider and Susan and Daniel Goldman. Dear brother of Michael and Barbara Sneider. Devoted grandfather of four. Our loving Bobby was the bravest of them all. 1/3

GOLUB--Gerald L. It is with profound sadness that the family of Gerald ("Gerry") L. Golub, 76, of Chappaqua, NY, announces his passing on October 9, 2015. A graduate of Yeshiva of Flatbush, Stuyvesant High School, Brooklyn College, and an MBA candidate at Baruch. For five decades, Gerry served as Managing Partner of Goldstein Golub Kessler & Co. and Chairman of American Express Tax and Business Services. He is survived by the love of his life and wife of 54 years, Bonnie, and their children, Kenny (Alyssa), Laurie, and Alli (Merv), and grandchildren Dani, Mackie, Murielle, Sam, Sascha and JJ, all jewels in his crown. He served on many Boards including Tiger 21, Nexia, Leukemia Lymphoma Society, Stuyvesant High School, the NYS Society of Accountants, the Chappaqua Library and Zoning Boards and as a Fire Commissioner. He drove a Harley for 15 years and was an avid car and sports enthusiast. He will be lovingly remembered for his sharp mind, quick wit, charisma, boundless energy, sense of humor and style -- as a man of infinite class and integrity. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 18 at Temple Bet Torah, 60 Smith Ave., Mt. Kisco, NY at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Leukemia Lymphoma Society. 1/3

GOLUB--Gerald. The Members, staff, and his fellow Advisors to TIGER 21 mourn the passing of Gerry Golub, our dear friend. Gerry was a most unusual man of humility, rare intelligence and deep courage. The courageous and determined manner in which he spoke about his approach to fighting Lymphoma for many years was an inspiration. He was always upbeat, and when he wasn't, you couldn't tell. Gerry started from modest beginnings, having walked five miles uphill to and from school every day. He founded Goldstein Golub and Kessler, which would go on to become the largest single office accounting firm in America, and then years later figured out how to structure a sale that broke new ground in his profession. Gerry was first and foremost a family man. He spoke mostly about his wife Bonnie, his children and grandchildren, and he partook in every triumph and challenge as if they were his own. His colleagues at TIGER 21 often shared in the joys of each college acceptance (and nursery school acceptance) that he so proudly shared. As an advisor and confidant, Gerry was unique. He seemed to have time to listen and provide thoughtful advice whenever he was called upon to do so. As the "numbers man," Gerry was the one we all turned to for important perspective about whether we were seeing things correctly and understanding the importance of one trend or another. His power was rooted in his common sense; he understood people's motivations and how best to approach the endless challenges of growing a business. Gerry's professionalism, preparation and thoughtfulness really set the standard for all of us. Gerry was a disciplined man. In the 25 years in which he participated in monthly meetings with fellow Members, he was always the first to arrive and had the highest attendance record by far, something he was always proud of. Gerry was a role model. In his retirement he took on communal responsibilities for his local fire department, that he labored over, as if the challenges were his own. He cared that much. Mostly, he was a good man and a good friend, and his loss will be deep and long lasting. We extend our deepest sympathies to Gerry's wife, Bonnie, his children and grandchildren. We share your loss. We were honored to have counted Gerry as a good friend and a cherished advisor. Michael W. Sonnenfeldt TIGER 21 Founder and Chairman 1/3

BACON--Katharine Weld, 95, died at Goodwin House Alexandria on October 1, 2015. She was one month away from her 96th birthday. The daughter of Philip Balch Weld and Katharine Saltonstall, Katharine was born with her twin sister, Adelaide (Whitney, Knott, Braden), on November 8, 1919 in Islip, New York. She was the last survivor of her family of six: Mary Elizabeth Weld Wolcott, Philip Saltonstall Weld, Rose Weld Baldwin and Frances Weld Gardiner. After her grandfather, Civil War General Stephen Minot Weld died in 1920, the family moved to the 52 acre Rockweld estate in Dedham, Massachusetts, designed by her grandfather with help from Frederick Law Olmsted (now owned and managed by MIT). The estate was famous for having one of the first and finest rock gardens. The family spent summers at General Weld's Wareham estate. When still a young girl, Katharine moved to New York City and attended the Brearley School and graduated from Milton Academy class of 1937. She married William Benjamin Bacon in 1940 and lived in Brookline, Hamilton, and Beverly, Massachusetts. She was active in the Massachusetts Republican Party, The Museum of Fine Arts, The Essex Institute, (now a part of the Peabody Essex Museum), and the Beverly Improvement Society. She enjoyed playing golf at the Myopia Hunt Club in Hamilton, Massachusetts. Her other interests were gardening, bridge and needlework. After the death of her husband in 1991 she lived in Beaufort, South Carolina before moving to Alexandria, Virginia. She is survived by three of her four children: Priscilla Bacon Woods (Mrs. Ward W.), Daniel Carpenter Bacon and Martha Bacon Martin (Mrs. David B. H.), nine grandchildren and 16 great grandchildren. She was predeceased by her oldest child William Benjamin Bacon, Jr. There will be a celebration of her life at the Goodwin House, 4800 Fillmore Ave, Alexandria, VA on Monday, October 12, 2015 at 4:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the Goodwin House Foundation. 1/3

ROGERS--Gertrud, on October 8, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Erich. Loving mother of Gary and Elaine. Cherished aunt of Monica Rothstein. Services: 12 noon, Sunday at Riverside-Nassau North Chapel, 55 N. Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

STARR--Alice Marcelle Paule, (nee Casanova). Passed away peacefully in her sleep on October 3, 2015. Alice paved her own way through the world - traveling, learning languages, and integrating herself into the life and culture of many countries. Born in Constantine, Algeria on August 3, 1921, during the French colonial era, Alice developed an appreciation for science, music, and, most of all, languages. Her favorite story was how she made herself indispensable to the American servicemen stationed in North Africa during World War II with her grasp of not only the English language, but also American slang, French and Arabic. It was there that she met her husband of 29 years, Warrant Officer Joseph Rankin Starr. Three sons were born in quick succession after the War, and the family followed her husband's career to Germany, the United States, Vietnam, Iraq, Iran, and Panama, ending up in New York in 1964 when her husband joined the United Nations civil service. Alice worked teaching French and translating for luminaries such as Josephine Baker and eminent institutions such as the United Nations. She maintained active involvement in city life, with memberships to the Metropolitan Museum of Art, The Explorer's Club, and The Alliance Francaise and played a key role in the operation and management of her Upper East Side co-op. Alice is survived by her three sons, Paul, Robert, and Gerald Starr, five grandchildren, and ten great-grandchildren. 1/3

LINDSAY--Melvin Jay. Artist, master potter, sculptor, adventurer, specialized in large-scale ceramics. Born June 14, 1943 in Eugene, OR; died September 27, 2015 in Carmel, NY. Director, Garrison Art Center, 1980s. At Tallix Art Foundry in Beacon, NY, he worked on the 24-foot tall Leonardo Da Vinci horse statue, among others. Ceramics instructor, Art Student League, Sparkill, NY. Lindsay traveled extensively throughout the world, using the trips as inspiration for his works. 1/3

CONSTABLE--Elise Jewett, of New York City passed away peacefully on Wednesday, September 9th, 2015. Elise was born on February, 17th, 1930, in Baltimore, MD. Her parents were Henry L. Constable, ESQ., and Gertrude J. Constable of Elkton, MD. After graduation from the Tatnall School in Wilmington, DE, where she was class valedictorian, she was presented at the Baltimore Cotillion in Maryland. She was employed by the DuPont Company in both Wilmington and NYC. In 1972, she joined Fiduciary Trust International where she was the Assistant to the Chairman of the Board. She retired as an Officer of the bank in 1997. Elise was a member of the Colony Club, the Junior League, the Holland Dames, and the Garden Club, all in NYC. Upon her retirement, Elise enjoyed traveling and spending time with her nieces and nephews. She is survived by her brother Richard Constable, her sister-in-law, Anne Constable, both of Madison, CT and six nieces and nephews - Ashley Constable Neary of NYC, Cody Constable of NYC, Diana du Pont of Ft. Wayne, IN, and Melinda Beard, Anthony du Pont, and Edmond du Pont, all of California. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Memorial Sloan Kettering. Her memorial service is to be held on October 15th at St. James Church in NYC at 2:00pm. 1/3

pepper & PoeWritten and illustrated by Frann Preston-­Gannon. 32 pp. ­Orchard/Scholastic. $16.99. (Picture book; ages 3 to 6)
 
Life’s pretty great for Pepper, a fluff-ball gray house cat who has eyes like lime-green saucers and firm personal boundaries. Then his owner gives him a young companion, and it all goes south. The kitten tumbles around, making a mess. Only when the two collude to blame it on a mellow-looking dog can the cats be friends. It’s a perfectly paced little tale, and Preston-Gannon composes each page with geometric precision, setting her charismatic pets against a sleek black background.

KELLER--Harold J.,age 92, died peacefully in his home on August 20th surrounded by family. He enjoyed a successful career growing Rose Brand Incorporated, a flavoring business started by his father and uncle in the early 1900's in the Lower East Side of Manhattan. Harold was predeceased by his wife of 55 years, Marilyn Keller and brother Morris. He is survived by his second wife, Phyllis Hoffman; a brother David, four daughters; four sons-in-law; and five granddaughters. Known to all for his two handed set shot and superior palate, this charismatic Culinary Psychiatrist had a remarkable following of loyal customers and friends and will be dearly missed by all. 1/3

GRUTERS--Michael Spencer. January 11, 1940-August 9, 2015 Michael Spencer Gruters of Manhattan, NY, passed on suddenly at home. Beloved husband, love of my life for 32 short years, Elizabeth Blakeslee Gruters, Father of his adored son Michael Spencer York Gruters and a daughter from a previous marriage Elizabeth Spencer Franklin. A brilliant renaissance man, whose accomplishments never outweighed his vision and creativity. His extraordinary complexity, mathematical and analytical genius is reflected in some of his projects: development of the first shared multitasking environment linking mainframe (IBM) and mini (DEC) computers; creation of pattern recognition film scanning and analysis programs for high energy physics research; wrote early (DEC) disassembler, assembler, editor and operating systems; all contributing to faculty status at Princeton University. Contributed to work on capturing first live pictures of the moon. Supervised military and civilian personnel at a top secret "strategic air command base" in Omaha, NE. Developed the first text editing/ composition publishing system to print newspapers, Pocono Record, Pa. Designed and wrote a system that would reconstruct the editorial and classified data base of the New York Daily News. Patent application for "color correction of NTSC video graphics systems" by Textronics Corporation. Created a new method of "Quantizing" whereas a video image would be significantly compressed with the least detectable visual difference; Designed inlaid rose and gray granite stone sidewalk at 1020 Madison Avenue NYC, completed an exhausted interaction of color study in oils of 12 canvas boards on color field negation. Extensive work in NYC in wood working, stone laying, interior and exterior design. 45 Patent or patent pending inventions and creations which include Digital Juke box (memory cards), LVD Video compression, NFL field goal analysis, Windows O/S replacement, Moving sidewalks, Concept boat (solar/wind/tidal/wave), NFL helmet shock, Submerged tunnels, Tubular arched bridges, Valve shaft (cam shaft replacement), Tidal Energy design, Urban wind farm, Waste conveyor, PETS: Pet Environmental Transfer System, East river tidal/solar power, Smokeless ashtrays, Super Duper Market, Paradoxice (casino dice game) Fairway patch, Book wings, #

MACDONALD--Marianne T. March 11, 1928, passed away October 10, 2015. Born in Ennetbaden, Switzerland. Beloved mother of Kristin MacDonald (Neal Walker) and grandmother of Charlotte and Isobel Walker. Also survived by her brother Roger Morgenthaler of Zurich. Funeral mass October 12, 10:30 am, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills, NY 1/3

TURETSKY--Elihu, 75, passed peacefully on October 8th after a gallant fight. His sister Carol, brother Howard and brother-in-law Mart were with him. Elihu was highly educated, extremely intelligent, religious and a gentle soul. "Aggie eggie boomp!" I love you. Your baby sister, Carol 1/3

NEUFELD--Meyer P.,formerly of Boro Park and Patchogue, he died at his home in Woodmere, NY on October 10, 2015 in his 95th year. He was predeceased by parents Rebecca (Meyer) and Harris Louis Neufeld, and siblings Abraham, Claire Kirschenbaum, and Shirley Antman. He leaves his beloved wife Judith (Ginsberg) and his dear daughters Sandra (Marc) Geller, Deborah (Paul) Schwartz, and Laura (Joel) Lieberman. Cherished grandchildren are: Jacqui, Madeline, Alex, Jenny, Jesse, Daniel, Avi, Ben, and Jonathan. For shiva details, call Parkside, 516-868-1616. 1/3

KONECKY--Murray Leon. May 14, 1922 - October 6, 2015. The living legacy of Murray Leon Konecky, who lived until October 6, 2015, resides in the people he most loved and who most loved him. He had "a good run" with his wife Adele Levin Gurman Konecky. He was the father of Joshua Konecky and Michael Konecky and Michael's wife Vicki, grandfather to their daughters Cassie and Heather and her husband Greg, and great-grandfather to Katy and Lindsay. For 48 years, he was also the father of Andrew and his wife Nancy, and grandfather to their children Karen and Amy; father to Dennie and her husband Roni, and grandfather to their daughters Lyrit and Shane and her husband Uri; and father to Robert and his wife Susan, and grandfather to their children Lily, Stuart and Julian. Murray's love of family goes beyond his immediate family and extends to his many cousins, especially Stuart and Kitty Konecky, and his many nieces and nephews and their children, all of whom are proud to call him uncle and friend. He is predeceased by those with whom he shared a lifetime of love and family celebrations, and who are recorded for posterity in the many photographs of the Fabulous Four--Murray and his brothers, Bill, Gerry and Ron. He is also survived by his sisters-in-law Mildred and Isobel Konecky. Murray's kindness to family, friends and neighbors, his love of music and books, his mastery of fine food and wine, and his ability to make everyone feel comfortable were hallmarks of his personality. His family will fondly remember him as the master of the barbecue and the ultimate host of fine dining. And they will treasure the memory of his wonderful sense of humor, his heart of gold, and his ability to unconditionally love his family. Zikhrono livrakha--may his memory be for a blessing. 1/3

GOLUB--Gerald. It is with profound sadness that we offer our condolences to the Golub family. Our hearts go out to you. Our 50 year relationship has always been the best and most satisfying and Gerry will be truly missed. The Stoppelmann Family 1/3

STERN--Charles 94, of New York, NY on October 10, 2015. Devoted husband of Sydell and the late Eve. Beloved father to Enid and June (Murray). Loving grandfather to Jeremy (Veronica), Michael, Amanda (Brad) and Emily. Great-grandfather to Connor, Sawyer and Ethan. Funeral services today 12:00 noon at Riverside Mt. Vernon, 21 W. Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. 1/3

RICE--Glenn B. We are greatly saddened by the untimely passing of our esteemed former partner, Glenn B. Rice. We extend our deepest sympathies to Glenn's mother Rhoda, Glenn's daughter Nikki, her husband Mark, and their children Noelle and Benjamin, to Glenn's sister Amy, her husband Fred, and their son Max, and to Glenn's extended family. We will remember Glenn for his devotion to his family, his charm and wit and his zealous advocacy on behalf of clients. OTTERBOURG P.C. 1/3

LEBOW--Stanley E.,On October 9, 2015 at his home. Born in the Bronx in 1926. He lived the American Dream. Lifelong painter, writer, entrepreneur who owned several advertising companies and produced eldercare websites during the infancy of the Internet. Spearheaded local political campaigns during the 1960s and 1970s. Served combat duty as a Captain in the United States Army in the European theater during WWII. Loving husband of 65 years to Margot Lebow, father to Andrew and Leslie Lebow, Richard and Sara Lebow, and Kenneth and Elizabeth Flatto. Blessed grandfather of Laura, Matthew, LJ, Melanie, Michael, Sarah, Diana, and Evan. Will be interred at a private ceremony with full Military honors. 1/3
GOLUB--Gerald. He built a fine enterprise, prestigious and permanent. That is a feat more significant than writing a Great Book because it yields thousands of beneficiaries. Stanley 1/3

EISENSTEIN--Alvin Gordon. 10/26/87. Remembering these past 28 years & always, by his loving family and friends. For his gracious thoughtfulness & his business prescience which made him an icon to many. Rebe Eisenstein & Family 1/3

HIRSCH--Herbert. Our family mourns the loss of beloved father, grandfather, and uncle Herbert Hirsch who died of natural causes at age 90 on October 9th. A born and bred New Yorker, Herb graduated from the Horace Mann School, Brown University and Columbia University Law School and served in the Navy during World War II. After law school, Herb joined the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver, and Jacobson where he specialized in corporate and art law and became a partner. His passion was art law and he served as Chair of the Art Law Committee of the New York City Bar Association. Herb and then-wife Felicia raised their three sons on the Upper West Side of Manhattan while spending summers in his beloved East Hampton. Herb was pre-deceased by his much-loved son Ted, his brother Bud and sister Edith. He is survived by sons Laurence and Dennis, daughters-in-law Alice, Suzanne, and Mary, beloved grandchildren Clara, Zander, Isaac, Harry and Olivia, nieces and nephews, his sister-in-law Peggy Hirsch and brother-in-law Jack Shore. His presence will always be felt and remembered and his passing leaves a big hole in our lives. We miss him and love him. Services Monday, October 12th, 11am, at the Independent Jewish Cemetery in Sag Harbor, NY. 1/3
KORNREICH--David. We mourn and will miss our veteran Trustee's commitment, intelligence, musical passion, and wit. Fred Pack, President Michael Boriskin, Artistic & Executive Director 1/3

LINDSAY--Melvin Jay. Artist, master potter, sculptor, adventurer, specialized in large-scale ceramics. Born June 14, 1943 in Eugene, OR; died September 27, 2015 in Carmel, NY. Director, Garrison Art Center, 1980s. At Tallix Art Foundry in Beacon, NY, he worked on the 24-foot tall Leonardo Da Vinci horse statue, among others. Ceramics instructor, Art Student League, Sparkill, NY. Lindsay traveled extensively throughout the world, using the trips as inspiration for his works. 1/3

EPPINGER--Theodore F.,on October 10, 2015, age 89. Beloved husband to the late Ella. Survived by son Barry, daughter-in-law Tina Marie, and son Ronald, and cherished grandchildren Melissa, Jennifer, Gregory and Nicole. He enlisted in the US Navy right out of high school, and upon his discharge, began his career working in the Office of the Bronx District Attorney as a hearing reporter. In September 1951, he was appointed secretary to Honorable Albert Cohn, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department. While working in the District Attorney's office, he attended pre-law classes at St. John's University and graduated from New York Law School in 1954. He was appointed as an Assistant District Attorney in 1956, and retired in 1968 as Senior Trial Assistant and Chief of the Indictment Bureau. He went out and practiced law in the private sector as founding partner of Eppinger, Reingold & Korder, in Larchmont and Westchester Square, New York. He practiced continuously in the Bronx County Courthouse, and for many years, served as counsel to Dollar Savings Bank. He served as Secretary of the Chippewa Democratic Club, and was a long-time member of the New York State and Bronx County Bar Associations. Visitation: Monday, 7-9pm. Services Tuesday 12:00 Noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Entombment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery. 1/3

RICE--Glenn B. Beloved father of Nikki , and devoted, loving grandfather of Noelle and Benjamin, passed away on October 7. Glenn will also be dearly missed by his son-in-law, Mark Chemtob, his sister Amy and nephew Max, his extended family of friends, and colleagues at law firm, OSH&R. A lover of life whose stories and reminiscences will be cherished and retold, Glenn will be remembered at 10am, Tuesday, October 13, Riverside Chapel, 76 and Amsterdam, NYC. 1/3

Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, October 13, 2015.

GORDON--Elliot M.,90 passed away on October 11 after a long illness. He is survived by his loving partner of 36 years, Lynda Gould, his son, Miles, daughter-in-law, Vera (Bittner), sister, Lois Schneider, of Haverford, PA, brother-in-law Frank Gould, and sister-in-law, Janet Weinstein, of Philadelphia, and nieces Ellen Rothstein, Leah Garnett, Ruth Rothstein, Mollie Weinstein-Gould, Jordan Gould and nephew Jesse Gould. Elliot grew up in Philadelphia and received a B.A. and M.A. in Romance Languages from the University of Pennsylvania, class of '45. He served in the Navy and then studied at the Sorbonne from '47 to '49, where he perfected his French and his French accent. Elliot settled in New York City where he owned Stereo Lab in Greenwich Village, selling components and high end stereo equipment. He then went to work at CBS Television where he was an audio engineer for 35 years. He earned an Emmy in 1987 for technical work at NFL Today. Elliot was a bridge aficionado and Life Master. He was an early adapter of home computers, and initiated a course at Lenox Hill Neighborhood House to instruct seniors in their use which he taught as a volunteer. He collected rare and out-of-print books on the fine arts and enjoyed incorporating his book searches into his world travels. Funeral services Thursday, October 15th, 4:30pm at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 W. 76th St, NYC. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Wright Center on Aging/NY Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68 Street, NYC, 10065. 1/3

GOLUB--Gerald L. It is with profound sadness that the family of Gerald ("Gerry") L. Golub, 76, of Chappaqua, NY, announces his passing on October 9, 2015. A graduate of Yeshiva of Flatbush, Stuyvesant High School, Brooklyn College, and an MBA candidate at Baruch. For five decades, Gerry served as Managing Partner of Goldstein Golub Kessler & Co. and Chairman of American Express Tax and Business Services. He is survived by the love of his life and wife of 54 years, Bonnie, and their children, Kenny (Alyssa), Laurie, and Alli (Merv), and grandchildren Dani, Mackie, Murielle, Sam, Sascha and JJ, all jewels in his crown. He served on many Boards including Tiger 21, Nexia, Leukemia Lymphoma Society, Stuyvesant High School, the NYS Society of Accountants, the Chappaqua Library and Zoning Boards and as a Fire Commissioner. He drove a Harley for 15 years and was an avid car and sports enthusiast. He will be lovingly remembered for his sharp mind, quick wit, charisma, boundless energy, sense of humor and style -- as a man of infinite class and integrity. The funeral will be private. A memorial service will be held on Sunday, October 18 at Temple Bet Torah, 60 Smith Ave., Mt. Kisco, NY at 2pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Leukemia Lymphoma Society. 1/3

KRASSNER--Beatrice, of Long Beach, NY passed on October 11, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Marvin Robert Krassner. Devoted mother of Merrill and Larry. Cherished sister of Mark Arroll. She was a good friend to many and will be missed by all. 1/3

MACDONALD--Marianne T. March 11, 1928, passed away October 10, 2015. Born in Ennetbaden, Switzerland. Beloved mother of Kristin MacDonald (Neal Walker) and grandmother of Charlotte and Isobel Walker. Also survived by her brother Roger Morgenthaler of Zurich. Funeral mass October 12, 10:30 am, Our Lady Queen of Martyrs, Forest Hills, NY 1/3

FELD--Andrea. The family mourns the passing of Andrea, 61, on October 11, 2015, following a prolonged illness. She was predeceased by her beloved parents Fred and Mona, and is survived by her loving husband Seth Marvin, daughter Monica, brother Steven, sister-in-law Donna, niece Rebecca, brother-in-law Mark, nephews Robert and Chad, niece Jaime, step-mother Lena, and devoted dog Morgan. Graduate of Smith College and Medill School of Journalism at Northwestern and distinguished journalist, she began her career as Feature Writer for the Beachcomber on LBI, advanced to McGraw Hill as Associate Editor for Today's Secretary magazine in NYC, then to Bride's magazine as Copy and Features Editor and became Managing Editor, also served as Vice President of Public Relations of New York chapter of Women in Communications. A lover of The Beatles, Shakespeare and everything Elizabethan, Andrea will be sorely missed! 1/3

COHEN--Baukje P.,87, of Manhattan, NY, and Ashley Falls, MA, succumbed to Alzheimer Disease on Saturday, October 10. Devoted wife of Noel and mother of Mark; mother-in-law to Sheila; grandmother to Kaitlyn and Christopher; and aunt to Kathy, Mitch, and Sabrina, Lauren, Savannah, and Allison. A wonderful woman, talented artist, former head of the hematology laboratory at the university hospital of Utrecht, the Netherlands, until her marriage to Dr. Noel L Cohen in 1957, as well as teacher to generations of interns and medical students at Bellevue Hospital in New York. She will be deeply missed by her family and friends in both Sheffield and New York City. Donations may be made to Hospice Care in the Berkshires through Finnerty & Stevens Funeral Home, 426 Main St., Great Barrington, MA 01230. To send remembrances to her family go to www.finner tyandstevens.com 1/3

KLIOT--Gregory, MD. The Medical Staff of Maimonides Medical Center is deeply saddened by the sudden passing of Dr. Gregory Kliot. Dr. Kliot was associated with the Department of OB/GYN for 17 years. He was very dedicated to his patients and his profession. He will be sorely missed by all who knew him. Sincere condolences are extended to his family. G. Neiderman, MD, President E. Chapnick, MD, Pres.-Elect H. Adler, MD, Secretary A.Taub, MD, Treasurer E. Fitzpatrick, MD, Past-Pres. 1/3

MIYOSHI--Lindsley Cameron, born October 23, 1948, died suddenly, of natural causes, September 30, 2015, at her home in New York's Chinatown. A writer and lover of the arts and of all things Japanese, Lindsley was the adoptive daughter of George Albert Cameron Jr. and Christine Patten Reed, both deceased. She worked at The New Yorker from 1985 to 1996 and published two books: "The Prospect of Detachment" (fiction) and "The Music of Light: The Extraordinary Story of Hikari and Kenzaburo Oe." She earned an M.F.A. from Bennington College in 2005. In 2006, she married Masao Miyoshi, who predeceased her. Her wish was to be interred in the Miyoshi family tomb in Tokyo, Japan. Lindsley gave unstintingly of her gifts in her capacity as a juror on the panel of the Japan-U.S. Friendship Commission Prize for the Translation of Japanese Literature, administered by the Donald Keene Center of Japanese Culture, Columbia University. Survivors include her birth mother, Elizabeth Ritchie; her half sister, Kate Gordon; her half brother, Stephen Carlyle; her stepbrother, John Ritchie; cousins, nieces, in-laws, and a host of friends, colleagues, and admirers. Sayonara, dearie. 1/3

KATOVITZ--George, passed away at his home in Glen Cove, NY on October 12th, a day short of his 86th birthday, after a summer-long illness. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Jean; his four sons Michael (J.); Tom (Debbie); Ken (Michelle); and Ron (Lisa); and seven grandchildren: Emma, Sarah, Jack, Luke, Caroline, Kate and Max. He will be missed by all. A wake will be held at McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home in Glen Cove on Thursday, October 15th from 3pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Church, also in Glen Cove at 10am on Friday, October 16th. 1/3

EPPINGER--Theodore F.,on October 10, 2015, age 89. Beloved husband to the late Ella. Survived by son Barry, daughter-in-law Tina Marie, and son Ronald, and cherished grandchildren Melissa, Jennifer, Gregory and Nicole. He enlisted in the US Navy right out of high school, and upon his discharge, began his career working in the Office of the Bronx District Attorney as a hearing reporter. In September 1951, he was appointed secretary to Honorable Albert Cohn, Presiding Justice of the Appellate Division, First Department. While working in the District Attorney's office, he attended pre-law classes at St. John's University and graduated from New York Law School in 1954. He was appointed as an Assistant District Attorney in 1956, and retired in 1968 as Senior Trial Assistant and Chief of the Indictment Bureau. He went out and practiced law in the private sector as founding partner of Eppinger, Reingold & Korder, in Larchmont and Westchester Square, New York. He practiced continuously in the Bronx County Courthouse, and for many years, served as counsel to Dollar Savings Bank. He served as Secretary of the Chippewa Democratic Club, and was a long-time member of the New York State and Bronx County Bar Associations. Visitation: Monday, 7-9pm. Services Tuesday 12:00 Noon at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 West Broad Street, Mt. Vernon, NY. Entombment to follow at Woodlawn Cemetery. 1/3

KORN--Richard, of Boynton Beach, Kauneonga Lake, and Brooklyn passed away peacefully on October 11, surrounded by his family. Loving husband of Claire, devoted father of Matt (Zina) and Lauren (Eric) Popkoff, devoted grandfather to Alex, Jesse and Nicole, dear brother of Jon (Sue), adored uncle of Josh, Brian and Hayley. Richard was an outstanding teacher at school (Brooklyn Tech) and in life. He derived true joy in helping others. His greatest passions were tools, cars, boating but most of all family and friends. Funeral services are Tuesday, 1:00pm at Parkside Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd. 1/3

KONECKY--Murray Leon. May 14, 1922 - October 6, 2015. The living legacy of Murray Leon Konecky, who lived until October 6, 2015, resides in the people he most loved and who most loved him. He had "a good run" with his wife Adele Levin Gurman Konecky. He was the father of Joshua Konecky and Michael Konecky and Michael's wife Vicki, grandfather to their daughters Cassie and Heather and her husband Greg, and great-grandfather to Katy and Lindsay. For 48 years, he was also the father of Andrew and his wife Nancy, and grandfather to their children Karen and Amy; father to Dennie and her husband Roni, and grandfather to their daughters Lyrit and Shane and her husband Uri; and father to Robert and his wife Susan, and grandfather to their children Lily, Stuart and Julian. Murray's love of family goes beyond his immediate family and extends to his many cousins, especially Stuart and Kitty Konecky, and his many nieces and nephews and their children, all of whom are proud to call him uncle and friend. He is predeceased by those with whom he shared a lifetime of love and family celebrations, and who are recorded for posterity in the many photographs of the Fabulous Four--Murray and his brothers, Bill, Gerry and Ron. He is also survived by his sisters-in-law Mildred and Isobel Konecky. Murray's kindness to family, friends and neighbors, his love of music and books, his mastery of fine food and wine, and his ability to make everyone feel comfortable were hallmarks of his personality. His family will fondly remember him as the master of the barbecue and the ultimate host of fine dining. And they will treasure the memory of his wonderful sense of humor, his heart of gold, and his ability to unconditionally love his family. Zikhrono livrakha--may his memory be for a blessing. 1/3

LYONS--James E.,March 10, 1951-October 10, 2015. The partners, attorneys and staff of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom LLP mourn the passing of our retired partner and friend, Jim Lyons. The former co-head of our West Coast Litigation practice, Jim played a key role in the development of Skadden's reputation for bet- the-company litigation. An exceptionally talented lawyer, Jim handled headline- making securities and corporate issues, directors' and officers' liability, international arbitration and other complex commercial disputes during his 34 years of practice. We remember Jim not only for his legal acumen, but also for his warmth, his Mark Twain-like wit and his great love for the firm. We extend our condolences to Jim's family, including his wife, Mary Jane, and his children, Sean and Caitlyn. 1/3
TANNER--Robert Edward. 1/31/1952-10/13/2014 Wish you were here. We miss you. Barbara, Max, Gwen, Claire and Truan 1/3

GREENE--George, 90, died peacefully Sunday evening at home in Great Neck, NY. Born in Bronx, NY in 1925 to Rae and Alexander David Greene; graduated from The Bronx High School of Science; attended Hunter College; and served in the United States Air Force, after which he was a professional model, cartoon writer, night club owner, big band singer, ham radio operator and stockbroker--he led a most interesting life. Survived by his devoted wife of more than 58 years, Ellen; loving father of son Alex (Lori) and daughter Claudia Wolfson (Steven); and adoring grandfather of Steven, Dana, Matty and Jake. A man of fierce integrity and concern for family, friends and the world. An autodidact, he taught us so much and never missed an opportunity to make us laugh. He loved us and we loved him dearly. Funeral service will be held at 11:00am, Tuesday, October 13th at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue at 91st Street, New York City. 1/3

BERMINGHAM-FOX--Carol. Loving mother of Sarah Bermingham and beloved wife of Colin Fox, died peacefully at home on the evening of October 8th following a long arduous partnership with a rare and deadly cancer. Born in Hamilton, Ontario, a graduate of the University of Toronto, Carol moved to New York to pursue a career in mental health. It was there that she married John Bermingham, father of Sarah, enrolled at New York University and graduated Summa Cum Laude with a Bachelor of Science. She earned her MSc from Columbia University and gained experience in the field of mental health at the Psychiatric Institute. As a psychiatric nurse clinician she joined the team at Mount Sinai Hospital, during which time her marriage ended. Carol reunited with Colin (having met him many years before) and they were married in New York in 1986. They eventually returned to Canada in 1989, but within a year she was diagnosed with a rare cancer. Surviving surgery she went on to teach at Ryerson University in Toronto and to act as an administrator at The Homewood Health Centre in Guelph, Ontario. Aside from her career in medicine, she was a great lover of the arts, particularly opera, which she learned at her grandfather's knee. That love of the arts was enhanced by a stay in Rome, during which Colin was involved in a film, and the eternal city became her spiritual home. Mementos of her Italian sojourn fill the house that she has so beautifully decorated. Carol always downplayed her accomplishments. Rather, she championed the struggles of those whose lives were circumscribed by mental illness and poverty. When she worked in New York she was held in high esteem by her colleagues at Mount Sinai, some of whom have become lifelong friends. Her cancer seemed to be in remission but after 21 years it recurred and it was found to have spread. As with the many setbacks she encountered in her life, Carol faced this one with remarkable resilience and courage. In 2011, when she was given only six months to live, Carol refused to succumb to fear, pursuing her love of travel, art, and music and spent two winters in Rome, beating the odds by four and a half years. Facing the end, she decided that she wanted to die at home. Her wish was fulfilled all too soon. Greatly loved by Colin and Sarah, her family and friends, Carol has left an indelible mark and an empty place in our lives. Visitation will be held at the family home, located at 37 Henderson Street in Elora, Ontario, on Friday, October 16th, 2015 between the hours of 3pm and 7pm. Funeral Service for Carol will be conducted at St. John the Evangelist Anglican Church, at the corner of Henderson and Smith Streets in Elora, Ontario, on Saturday, October 17th, 2015 at 3:30pm. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to the St. Francis Table Capuchin Outreach to the Poor (www.capuchinoutreach.org) or the St. John's Elora Choir Fund (stjohns@sentex.net). 1/3

Hirsch Michael Starr, President 1/3

HADDEN--James R.W. "Jamie," 35, died peacefully on October 11, 2015 at home in Middletown, CT in the loving company of his mother, father and Oak Hill family. Jamie tackled his physical and intellectual challenges with courage, determination and humor well beyond his years. He was a warrior of the heart who witnessed and stimulated a generation of improvement in the lives of persons with intellectual disabilities. Without words, he powerfully advocated by gentle presence. Without sight, he stimulated the vision of policymakers. Without being able to stand or walk, he motivated others to stand firm for the dignity, safety and inclusion of his disabled peers with all citizens in the fundamental amenities and protections of community life. He surprised countless skeptics touched by his vulnerability into an awareness that true beneficiaries of inclusion are not those allowed inside, but those who let go of the need to keep others out. He taught us to see the real person in each human regardless of how clothed in wealth, race, ethnicity, personal preference or ability. He reminded us that love always trumps accomplishment. Jamie is survived by his admiring and adoring immediate family, Sara, David and Liza, grandparents Jack and Jeanne Blum, a platoon of supportive aunts and uncles, and their children who always found room for cousin Jamie among their ranks. Jamie enters freedom from pain and the company of his predeceased mischievous brother, Sam, and his grandparents, Hamilton Hadden, Sally Hadden and Susanne Blum. Visiting hours will be held from 4pm to 7pm at Taylor & Modeen, 136 South Main Street, West Hartford, CT on Thursday, October 15, 2015. A Service of Celebration will be held in Jamie's honor on Saturday, October 31, 2015 at 2pm at St. James Episcopal Church, 1018 Farmington Avenue, West Hartford, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Oak Hill, 120 Holcomb Street, Hartford, CT 06112 or to HARC, 900 Asylum Avenue, Hartford, CT 06105 in support of these exemplary organizations. For online condolences and directions please visit: www.taylorandmodeen.com 1/3

SONNENBLICK--Dani. (Augusta Dann), daughter of Pearl and Herbert Dann, died October 11, 2015 at the age of 87, after a long courageous battle with cancer. Born in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY, she attended Shore Road Academy. Her family moved to Mt Vernon, NY, where she graduated from AB Davis High School. She cut short her attendance at University of Delaware to marry her husband, Jack E. Sonnenblick. She and Jack were married 69 years, before his death this past April. They lived in Ft. Belvoir, VA, while Jack was in the service, eventually moving to Westchester, NY. Dani was a graduate of the New York School,l of Interior Design. After working for several years, she opened an art gallery, Art Latitude, on Madison Avenue in New York City in the 1970's. When she and Jack retired to Florida, they became legacy members of the Boca Raton Museum of Art, to which they left a substantial part of their glass collection. She was a long serving Trustee at the museum from 1987 until her death. They were members of the Old Oaks Country Club in Westchester, NY, Westchester Country Club in Rye, NY, and members of the Boca Rio Golf Club in Boca Raton, Florida. Dani enjoyed gold, bridge, and had a life long passion for the arts and music. She lived her life to the fullest. She leave behind her cherished children, Jon Sonnenlick, Micki Hirsch (Steven Hirsch), Robert Sonnenblick (Pamela Sonnenblick). She was adored by her grandchildren Karen, Lisa, Jesse, Adam, Leah, Alexandra, Cary and Savannah, great- grandchildren, Daniel, Jonah, Nicholas, Julie, Henry and Jack. She also leaves her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Rosemary Dann, brother-in- law and wife Arthur and Sybil Sonnenblick, sisters-in-law Jean Saklad, Muriel Perry, and several nieces and nephews. She also leaves her devoted dog Poochan. Donations in her memory may be made to: American Cancer Society for Ovarian Cancer Research: PO Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK73123-1718, Boca Raton Museum of Art, 501 Plaza Real, Boca Raton, FL 33432, Hospice Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Funeral services are with Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton, FL. Phone: 1-800-992-9262. 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien J.,88, a prominent real estate broker and advisor, passed away at his home on October 13, 2015, survived by his cherished and devoted wife of 28 years, Jane Studley. When the Nazis invaded Belgium in 1940, Julien's family fled first to Cuba, finally arriving in the United States in 1944, when Julien was 16. After serving in the US Army from 1950-1953 during the Korean War, Julien returned to New York City, where he established a real estate brokerage firm, Julien J. Studley, Inc., in 1954. This firm became the foremost tenant-oriented commercial real estate firm in New York and later in major cities throughout the United States. Julien became widely-known as a thoughtful and valued advisor to commercial tenants on all real estate matters and was highly respected by his colleagues and clients. However, his passion for life extended well beyond his professional duties. Julien was also a leader in the philanthropic community in New York, serving as Chairman of the New School for Social Research, from which he received the Distinguished Service Award in 1997. He was also the Chairman of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, and served as a significant member of the Boards of Lincoln Center and The Graduate School of CUNY. All those who were privileged to know him will miss his friendship, compassion, wisdom, and readiness to help others. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his son Jacob, his sister-in-law Helen Studley, his stepson Ni jun and Ni jun's wife LuLu, and his beloved step-grandchildren Adam and Benjamin. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City on October 16, at 10:00am. Burial will follow at The Kensico Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, New York. Donations in Julien's memory may be made to the New School or to any charity of your choice. 1/3

EHRLICH--Jerome A.,M.D., Formerly of Scarsdale, passed away on October 12, 2015 at the age of 93. He was the son of Anna and Benjamin Ehrlich and brother of the late Marcia Ehrlich Pavloff. He is survived by his devoted wife of 67 years, Francine, his wonderful children Richard Ehrlich, Dr. Amy Ehrlich Charney (Lewis Wise), Dr. James B. Ehrlich (Janet Cagen), and Wendy Ehrlich (Dr. Todd Jick); his grandchildren Erica Charney (Dr. Robert Rix), Dr. Julie Ehrlich, Rachel Ehrlich, Drew Ehrlich, Jeffrey Ehrlich and Margot Ehrlich, and Aron Charney of blessed memory; and one great-grandchild, Ryan Charney Rix, the first of the next generation. Dr. Ehrlich was a graduate of Lafayette College and the University of Health Sciences at Chicago Medical School. He was Board Certified and a Diplomate of the American Board of Family Medicine, with a sub-specialty in ENT. He served as a Captain in the Army as a physician in Germany during the Korean War in an AAA Battalion, and later in the Fifth General Hospital, from 1953-1955. He was on the medical staff of Lawrence Hospital, in Bronxville, for over 40 years as an attending physician, holding multiple positions on various hospital boards, and was a member of the American Legion Post 52 of Scarsdale. Dr. Ehrlich put his heart into his family and into his work, and was an avid tennis player, equestrian, scuba diver and musician. He will be remembered with great love for his zest for life, travel and adventure by all who knew him: his family, friends, colleagues and patients. Services will be held at Temple Israel in White Plains on Wednesday, October 14th at 11:30am. Interment will be at Kensico Cemetery, Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. 1/3

LIEBERFELD--Lawrence, 95. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, musician, raconteur, gourmet, and encyclopedia of New York City history and architecture, among other subjects. Graduated from Columbia Grammar School, from Yale in 1939 and Yale School of Architecture in 1942. Larry sang with the Dessoff Choirs, the Canby Singers, the New Amsterdam Singers, and the Amato Opera and worked as a consultant to universities, independent schools, and foundations. He is survived by his wife, Ruth Turner, children Ann Masur of Oak Park, IL, and Daniel Lieberfeld of Pittsburgh, grandchildren Kate and Ben Masur and Jesse Lieberfeld, and three great-grandchildren. 1/3

MAY--Joan of New York, died on October 12th, aged 87. Beloved wife of city planner Richard May, she was Assistant Dean at Weill Cornell Medical College. Her loving family will soon announce a memorial service. 1/3

JORDI--Peter U.,of Nutley, NJ, passed on October 11, 2015. Peter was a Freight Forwarder and the owner of Transcontainer Transport, Inc. in Clifton, NJ. He is survived by his beloved wife, Edith Coka Jordi; two daughters, Kirsten and Jessica Jordi, five grandchildren and several other family members. Visitors will be received at the S.W. Brown & Son Funeral Home, (www.swbrownandson.com), 267 Centre St., Nutley on Thursday from 4-8pm. There will be a private graveside service. 1/3
TANNER--Stefen J. In remembrance of a fine man; with appreciation, respect and sincerity. William 1/3

STERN--Charles. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Charles Stern, and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

GARCIA-MANSILLA--Lucio. Lucio Garcia-Mansilla, Founder of Decameron Resorts, is dead at 71. Lucio Garcia-Mansilla of Mill Neck, NY and Cartagena, Colombia died on October 11, 2015 in New York from complications following heart surgery. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Jane Riggs Garcia-Mansilla; his children, Dr. Alexandra Riggs Garcia- Mansilla and Lucio Riggs Garcia-Mansilla, his two grandchildren, Lily and Rafael, his brother, Eduardo Garcia-Mansilla, his sister-in law Veronica Pueyrredon, and his adored son-in-law and nieces and nephews. Mr. Garcia-Mansilla was born in Argentina and raised in Uruguay. He came to the United States to attend the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania where he met his wife, Pinkie. In 1987, he founded the Decameron Group of Hotels & Resorts in Cartagena, Colombia. During his time as the President of this international hotel chain, the company grew to include 44 resorts in 11 countries throughout Latin America, the Caribbean, and Africa. While an exceptional entrepreneur, he also cared deeply about others, especially about Decameron's 12,000 employees. He helped to improve the quality of life of employees and others through a foundation that will now be re-named in his honor. 1/3

RAS--John C. SFO, passed away on October 11. He is survived by his wife Marichu L. Ras, son Louie John Ras, grandson Billy John Ras, granddaughter Taisha Monique Ras, sister Hilda Ras Philip, and brother Ruben Ras. Visitation will be held on Sunday, October 18th and Monday, October 19th 2-4pm and 7-9pm at "The Riverside Memorial Chapel". 1/3

FREIDUS--Jeffrey, of Manhattan, NY, beloved husband of Rosalind, father of Gregory (Karen) and Amanda, has passed away at the age of 73. The father of a loving family, he was esteemed for his aptitude, respected for his spirit and cherished for his warmth. In addition to being an innovator in real estate, he was equally passionate about and excelled in a variety of sports and had many personal hobbies that he treasured dearly. His tranquil natural disposition was epitomized by his enduring affinity for the beach. He was a mentor to all who wanted to learn from him, a benefactor to all who appealed to him and, most importantly, he was loved by all who knew him. Funeral services will be held on Thursday, October 15th 2015 at 11:00am at Temple Israel of the City of New York, located at 112 East 75th Street, New York, NY 10021. In lieu of flowers, mourners are asked to make a donation to Calvary Hospital Hospice and Home Care, 1740 Eastchester Road, Bronx, NY 10461, in memory of Jeffrey Freidus. 1/3
SIEGEL--Marc. Beloved husband of the late Anne F. Siegel. Loving father of Peter K. Siegel. Cherished grandfather of Rachel Carlson Siegel. Service at Riverside Chapel, October 15 at 11:30 AM. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Aimee Robin Jacobs. Our family mourns the loss of beloved wife, mother, and daughter. Her professional career was spent as a Principal at her public accounting firm, servicing clients for over forty years. Her dedication and concern for her residents in the properties she represented was beyond reproach. Protective of all who she loved, everyone felt safer knowing they had Aimee on their side. She is survived by her loving husband Marvin, children Melissa and Gregory, mother Lucille Jacobs, and Aunt Irma Alper. Her presence will always be felt and her passing leaves a big hole in our hearts. Services will be held Thursday, October 15th, 10am, at Gutterman's, Woodbury New York. 1/3

BRADLEY--Marilyn. Born on October 11, 1937, died October 10, 2015 after a sudden, brief fight with lung cancer. She is survived by her sister Judith Shafran and brother-in-law Irving Shafran; as well as her niece, Pamela Schein Murphy and her husband Marc Murphy, her great-niece Campbell and her great-nephew Callen. She will be missed for her sharp mind, unique personality and fantastic sense of style. 1/3

FREIDUS--Jeffrey. The Officers and Clergy of Temple Israel of the City of New York mourn the passing of long-time member Jeffrey Freidus. We extend our heartfelt sympathy to his bereaved family. Andrew Hoffman, President David J. Gelfand, Rabbi 1/3

KATOVITZ--George, passed away at his home in Glen Cove, NY on October 12th, a day short of his 86th birthday, after a summer-long illness. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Jean; his four sons Michael (J.); Tom (Debbie); Ken (Michelle); and Ron (Lisa); and seven grandchildren: Emma, Sarah, Jack, Luke, Caroline, Kate and Max. He will be missed by all. A wake will be held at McLaughlin Kramer Megiel Funeral Home in Glen Cove on Thursday, October 15th from 3pm-5pm and 7pm-9pm. A funeral Mass will be celebrated at St. Patrick's Church, also in Glen Cove at 10am on Friday, October 16th. 1/3

MITCHELL--Thomas M.,73. A lifelong resident of New York, "Tommy" died peacefully at home on October 11, 2015, following a brief illness. He is survived by Linda Lachman Mitchell, his wife of 25 years, their son John C. Mitchell, his daughter and son Sandra and Ben Mitchell and his sisters, Maria Bullaro and Roseanne Bullaro, all of New York City. Condolences can be paid to the family at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Thursday, October 15th at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A mass will be held in his honor at St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street on Friday, October 16th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to the Doe Fund, 232 East 84th Street New York, NY 10028. 1/3

Terry Collins said Harvey, who struggled through five innings in winning Game 3 of the teams’ National League division series, had indicated he would be available to pitch in relief if needed.
Lamar Odom, a former N.B.A. star and reality television personality, was on life support Wednesday at a Las Vegas hospital, with his estranged wife, Khloe Kardashian, by his side.
Novak Djokovic extended his winning streak to 13 matches with a 6-2, 6-1 win over Martin Klizan in the second round of the Shanghai Masters.
CBS Sports filled a big void on its golf broadcasting team by hiring Dottie Pepper, giving the network, which covers the most PGA Tour events, its first female voice.
The Florida freshman defensive back Deiondre Porter was suspended indefinitely after being arrested on suspicion of firing a gun in the direction of his pregnant girlfriend.
Bobby Ryan, Mika Zibanejad and Kyle Turris each had a goal and an assist, Erik Karlsson added a career-high four assists, and the Ottawa Senators beat the Blue Jackets, 7-3, in Columbus, Ohio.
Toronto F.C. beat the Red Bulls, 2-1, on Tuesday night to clinch its first playoff appearance, with Sebastian Giovinco scoring his 22nd goal of the season.
In front of a crowd at a Washington Heights gym, Mayor Bill de Blasio took a bit of a victory lap on Wednesday after a one-year freeze that he pushed for was placed on stabilized leases.
Television highlights.

MITCHELL--Thomas M.,73. A lifelong resident of New York, "Tommy" died peacefully at home on October 11, 2015, following a brief illness. He is survived by Linda Lachman Mitchell, his wife of 25 years, their son John C. Mitchell, his daughter and son Sandra and Ben Mitchell and his sisters, Maria Bullaro and Roseanne Bullaro, all of New York City. Condolences can be paid to the family at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue on Thursday, October 15th at 2-5pm and 7-9pm. A mass will be held in his honor at St. Thomas More, 65 East 89th Street on Friday, October 16th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations in his memory can be made to the Doe Fund, 232 East 84th Street New York, NY 10028. 1/3

McGRATH--Paula Grace, age 46, died on October 4, 2015 after a long battle with breast cancer. She is survived by her sons, Dylan and Leopold Diouf, her brother, John McGrath, her parents, Diane McKecknie and John W. McGrath, and her former husband, Pape Diouf. Born in New York City, she attended The Nightingale Bamford School and The Loyola School. She was a graduate of American University and received her JD from Fordham Law School. She spent much of her adult life in London where she was an adjunct professor at both Fordham and Syracuse Universities. She and her sons returned to East Hampton each summer. Contributions may be made in her name to Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. 1/3

WINTER--Lewis Vince, 87, died October 12th at home. Known for his critical eye and passion for art, design, and craftsmanship. Lewis enjoyed life amidst change. "I was lucky to have participated in the '60s cultural scene. I loved the future that it gave me," he said. He frequented Dick Bellamy's Green Gallery at the time and was influenced by Henry Geldzahler. Early to Chelsea, Lewis renovated a townhouse and filled it with art deco furnishings from flea markets. An entrepreneur, he started up Yesterday's News, selling vintage clothing to Andy Warhol, Patti Smith, and others. Lewis then launched the clothing design career of his wife, Harriet. Lewis is survived by their children Alexander Winter, Andrea Shlasko, and Joanna Barsh, and sister, Judith Burger. Luigi, we miss your style, sense of adventure, and joy of the hunt. It was a good life. Services will be on October 16 at 11:15am, Riverside Memorial, 180 West 76th Street. We welcome all who loved Lewis as we do. 1/3

SONNENBLICK--Dani. (Augusta Dann), daughter of Pearl and Herbert Dann, died October 11, 2015 at the age of 87, after a long courageous battle with cancer. Born in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, NY, she attended Shore Road Academy. Her family moved to Mt Vernon, NY, where she graduated from AB Davis High School. She cut short her attendance at University of Delaware to marry her husband, Jack E. Sonnenblick. She and Jack were married 69 years, before his death this past April. They lived in Ft. Belvoir, VA, while Jack was in the service, eventually moving to Westchester, NY. Dani was a graduate of the New York School,l of Interior Design. After working for several years, she opened an art gallery, Art Latitude, on Madison Avenue in New York City in the 1970's. When she and Jack retired to Florida, they became legacy members of the Boca Raton Museum of Art, to which they left a substantial part of their glass collection. She was a long serving Trustee at the museum from 1987 until her death. They were members of the Old Oaks Country Club in Westchester, NY, Westchester Country Club in Rye, NY, and members of the Boca Rio Golf Club in Boca Raton, Florida. Dani enjoyed gold, bridge, and had a life long passion for the arts and music. She lived her life to the fullest. She leave behind her cherished children, Jon Sonnenlick, Micki Hirsch (Steven Hirsch), Robert Sonnenblick (Pamela Sonnenblick). She was adored by her grandchildren Karen, Lisa, Jesse, Adam, Leah, Alexandra, Cary and Savannah, great- grandchildren, Daniel, Jonah, Nicholas, Julie, Henry and Jack. She also leaves her brother and sister-in-law Richard and Rosemary Dann, brother-in- law and wife Arthur and Sybil Sonnenblick, sisters-in-law Jean Saklad, Muriel Perry, and several nieces and nephews. She also leaves her devoted dog Poochan. Donations in her memory may be made to: American Cancer Society for Ovarian Cancer Research: PO Box 22718, Oklahoma City, OK73123-1718, Boca Raton Museum of Art, 501 Plaza Real, Boca Raton, FL 33432, Hospice Palm Beach County, 5300 East Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL 33407. Funeral services are with Gutterman Warheit Memorial Chapel in Boca Raton, FL. Phone: 1-800-992-9262. 1/3

HADDEN--James R.W. "Jamie," 35, died peacefully on October 11, 2015 at home in Middletown, CT in the loving company of his mother, father and Oak Hill family. Jamie tackled his physical and intellectual challenges with courage, determination and humor well beyond his years. He was a warrior of the heart who witnessed and stimulated a generation of improvement in the lives of persons with intellectual disabilities. Without words, he powerfully advocated by gentle presence. Without sight, he stimulated the vision of policymakers. Without being able to stand or walk, he motivated others to stand firm for the dignity, safety and inclusion of his disabled peers with all citizens in the fundamental amenities and protections of community life. He surprised countless skeptics touched by his vulnerability into an awareness that true beneficiaries of inclusion are not those allowed inside, but those who let go of the need to keep others out. He taught us to see the real person in each human regardless of how clothed in wealth, race, ethnicity, personal preference or ability. He reminded us that love always trumps accomplishment. Jamie is survived by his admiring and adoring immediate family, Sara, David and Liza, grandparents Jack and Jeanne Blum, a platoon of supportive aunts and uncles, and their children who always found room for cousin Jamie among their ranks. Jamie enters freedom from pain and the company of his predeceased mischievous brother, Sam, and his grandparents, Hamilton Hadden, Sally Hadden and Susanne Blum. Visiting hours will be held from 4pm to 7pm at Taylor & Modeen, 136 South Main Street, West Hartford, CT on Thursday, October 15, 2015. A Service of Celebration will be held in Jamie's honor on Saturday, October 31, 2015 at 2pm at St. James Episcopal Church, 1018 Farmington Avenue, West Hartford, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Oak Hill, 120 Holcomb Street, Hartford, CT 06112 or to HARC, 900 Asylum Avenue, Hartford, CT 06105 in support of these exemplary organizations. For online condolences and directions please visit: www.taylorandmodeen.com 1/3

McMANUS--John J.,91, at Goodwin House Retirement Community, Falls Church, VA, September 20, 2015. Born April 4, 1924 in Glen Cove, L.I., New York. Nassau County Commissioner of Public Welfare, 1959. CEO and Executive Director United Fund of Long Island, 1965-1971. Private burial. 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien J. The New School mourns the passing of Chair Emeritus and long-serving Trustee Julien Studley, a New York City real estate legend and philanthropist who came to New York as a teenage war refugee and built a business that would transform Manhattan's skyline. STUDLEY--Julien. An army buddy, business partner and dear friend, will not only be missed but always remembered for his success, wit and philanthropy. Norman P. Rappaport 1/3

ASTROVE--Edgar, 89, of Hamden, CT, passed away on Tuesday, October 13, 2015. He was a widower from his wife of 42 years, Katherine Adler Astrove, survived by his companion of many years, Sue Cohen, son, Jim Astrove and his wife, Ann B. Astrove, daughter, Jane Graver, his grandchildren, Melissa, Bennett and Grace, as well as scores of loving relatives and dear friends. Edgar received an undergraduate degree from City College of New York and graduate degrees from the University of Michigan. He also served in the U.S. Army during WWII. Edgar was a dedicated philanthropist, inventor, artist, harmonica player, and caring member of each community in which he lived. The family would like to offer a special thanks to the staff of Right at Home of New Haven and The Whitney Center. Edgar will be greatly missed by all who knew and loved him. There will be a graveside service at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla, NY on Friday, October 16, at 11:00am. There will be a celebration of Ed's life later that day at 2:00pm at the Lawn Club in New Haven, CT. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation (http://www.pdf.org/). 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien J. The Board and Staff of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts are deeply saddened by the passing of our Director Emeritus, Julien J. Studley, whom we honored with our Distinguished Service Award in November, 2008 for his decades-long service to Lincoln Center. He served Lincoln Center as representative of the Film Society in 1993, where he later became Chair. He was a member of our Audit Committee, Employee Benefits Committee, and was the long-time Chair of the General Services Committee. Julien was deeply involved in Lincoln Center's redevelopment as a member of the Redevelopment Committee and its precursor, the Committee for the 21st Century. In recent years he has been a member of the PR and Branding, Outreach, and the Community Engagement committees. We will miss him and we extend our condolences to his beloved wife, Jane, and to his family and friends. Katherine Farley, Chair Jed Bernstein, President Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts 1/3

HIRSCH--Herbert. IFAR (The International Foundation for Art Research) mourns the loss of Herbert Hirsch, a longtime member of our Law Advisory Council. We will miss his wise advice and friendship. Sharon Flescher, Exec. Dir. Anthony Williams, Chairman 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien J. The governors, members and staff of The Real Estate Board of New York mourn the passing of Julien J. Studley, distinguished real estate broker, philanthropic leader and active REBNY member for 50 years. Julien served on REBNY's Board of Governors from 1996-1998. In 1997, his colleagues awarded him the prestigious Louis Smadbeck Broker Recognition Award, which honors brokers whose career merits include personal and professional integrity, long-term leadership, prominence in the brokerage community and participation on REBNY's committees. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his wife, Jane, his children Jacob and Ni jun, and the entire Studley family. Rob Speyer, Chairman John Banks, President 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien J. The Graduate Center, CUNY, and its Foundation Board deeply mourn the loss of Julien Studley, a wise and valued Board member for over two decades and Board Chair from 1994 to 1997. In 1992 he was awarded an honorary degree of Doctor of Humane Letters from the Graduate Center, and was the honoree at the Graduate Center's Fiftieth Anniversary Gala in 2000. A staunch advocate of this institution's mission and programs, Julien supported student fellowships, public programming, and faculty scholarships. His leadership and intellectual curiosity will continue to inspire and guide us. We send deep condolences to the members of his family. Chase F. Robinson, President, The Graduate Center William P. Kelly, President Emeritus Frances D. Horowitz, President Emerita Craig Kaplan, Esq., Chair, The Graduate Center Foundation 1/3

NEWHOUSE--Susan Marley. Today an extended community celebrates the life of Susan Marley Newhouse, who died August 13, 2015, in New York City. Wellesley College joins this community in mourning the loss and honoring the life of a distinguished alumna and philanthropist. She will long be remembered for her devotion to the College, her passion for the arts and humanities, her unwavering service, and her extraordinary generosity. Sue earned an English degree from Wellesley in 1955 at age 19, the same year she met her future husband, Donald Newhouse. Sue's love for her alma mater was infectious, and the impact of the Newhouse family's enduring generosity to Wellesley cannot be overstated. The Newhouses have supported Wellesley's financial aid programs, Wellesley Centers for Women, and many other initiatives. In 2004, a major gift established The Susan and Donald Newhouse Center for the Humanities at Wellesley, which promotes innovative, imaginative, and influential research in the humanities and creates opportunities for intellectual risk-taking and the lively exchange of ideas. This vibrant hub unites the College across disciplines and hosts visiting and resident scholars, artists, and performers. The first director of the Susan and Donald Newhouse Center for the Humanities, 1949 Professor of Ethics and Professor of English Tim Peltason, sums up the community's sentiments: "I remember best about Susan her exceptional kindness and good cheer, [and] the sense that it gave her genuine and disinterested delight to see the good effects of her generosity. She was always... eagerly curious about the intellectual life of the College." Susan Newhouse supported Wellesley in many ways, including as a trustee of the College and as co-chair of the capital campaign in 2005 that set new records for fundraising by a liberal arts college. Wellesley was one of many recipients of Susan Newhouse's time and talents. Memories of her warmth and positivity will be cherished by those who knew her personally and by countless more whose lives have been transformed by her vision and action. Our hearts go out to husband Don, children Kathy, Michael, and Steven, and all Sue's grandchildren and extended family. The struggle with illness at the end of her life does not dim the bright light she shone on us all. Chair of the Wellesley College Board of Trustees Laura Daignault Gates, President H. Kim Bottomly, and Provost Andrew Shennan. 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien J.,88, a prominent real estate broker and advisor, passed away at his home on October 13, 2015, survived by his cherished and devoted wife of 28 years, Jane Studley. When the Nazis invaded Belgium in 1940, Julien's family fled first to Cuba, finally arriving in the United States in 1944, when Julien was 16. After serving in the US Army from 1950-1953 during the Korean War, Julien returned to New York City, where he established a real estate brokerage firm, Julien J. Studley, Inc., in 1954. This firm became the foremost tenant-oriented commercial real estate firm in New York and later in major cities throughout the United States. Julien became widely-known as a thoughtful and valued advisor to commercial tenants on all real estate matters and was highly respected by his colleagues and clients. However, his passion for life extended well beyond his professional duties. Julien was also a leader in the philanthropic community in New York, serving as Chairman of the New School for Social Research, from which he received the Distinguished Service Award in 1997. He was also the Chairman of the Film Society of Lincoln Center, and served as a significant member of the Boards of Lincoln Center and The Graduate School of CUNY. All those who were privileged to know him will miss his friendship, compassion, wisdom, and readiness to help others. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his son Jacob, his sister-in-law Helen Studley, his stepson Ni jun and Ni jun's wife LuLu, and his beloved step-grandchildren Adam and Benjamin. Funeral services will be held at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City on October 16, at 10:00am. Burial will follow at The Kensico Cemetery, 273 Lakeview Avenue, Valhalla, New York. Donations in Julien's memory may be made to the New School or to any charity of your choice. 1/3
SIEGEL--Marc. Beloved husband of the late Anne F. Siegel. Loving father of Peter K. Siegel. Cherished grandfather of Rachel Carlson Siegel. Service at Riverside Chapel, October 15 at 11:30 AM. 1/3
HOCHMAN--Rubin. October 15, 1917 . On your birthday looking down at me with mom. Love/ miss you forever. Your loving daughter, Nettie 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien. We, the Board of Directors of Savills Studley, profoundly mourn the recent death of our former colleague and friend, Julien Studley. As founder of Julien J. Studley, Inc. in 1954, his innovative and visionary approach of representing tenants rather than owners was groundbreaking, changing the commercial real estate industry forever. As a broker, Julien advocated tenaciously for his clients--a trait that remains in the DNA of our firm's culture today. As a leader, he supported creativity, collaboration and, yes, a little healthy competition, inspiring people from all walks of life to be the best they could be. Those of us who were brought into the business by Julien are personally grateful to him for his encouragement and support. We, and indeed the entire industry, would not be where we are today if it were not for him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Jane and his children and grandchildren. Julien's contributions to the industry and to New York City will not be forgotten. 1/3

JOHNSON--Phyllis LaFarge. Writer and editor, died at home on September 19, 2015, age 82. She had immeasurable zest for life and was compassionate, practical and tenderly diplomatic in a way that was invaluable to her family and many friends. Talking with her was wonderful and she was always there to help. Unfailingly game, over 80, and ready to get up and start the next project, she traveled to the Zacatecas mountains in Mexico this February to prepare an exhibition on the Huichol Native Mexicans for the Natural History Museum of New York. Her favorite place was diminutive Tuckernuck Island where she swam, read and made beach plum jelly. She leaves a sister, Sheila La Farge, a daughter, Clare, a son and daughter-in-law, Tom and Sandra, and two granddaughters, Flavia and Alice. Her family and friends miss her deeply. A memorial service is planned for early 2016. 1/3

ROSEN--Doris, aka Doris Rosen Margett, nee Leavy, 97 years old, died on October 10, 2015. Predeceased by her husbands, Michael Rosen and The Honorable Charles Margett; and her beloved son, Sanford Rosen. Also survived by nephews, Roger and Dr. Jeffrey Leavy, countless friends and relatives. A unique woman, one of a kind. Services 11:30am, Friday, October 16, 2015, at Riverside- Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. 1/3

LEVY--Allen Richard. July 26th, 1938, died October 8th, 2015. He was the beloved father to Amanda, Michael and Randy, brother to Peter, father-in-law, ex-husband, uncle, cousin and friend. Crossword aficionado and classic car lover. He will be missed by all. 1/3
