STUDLEY--Julien J. NewYork-Presbyterian mo-urns the loss of our dear friend and benefactor Julien Studley. A public member of our Real Estate and Major Facilities Committee since 2011, Mr. Studley was instrumental in planning and developing numerous facilities that have advanced patient care and research for countless New Yorkers. His philanthropic efforts extended far beyond our walls, as he generously donated his time and resources to numerous causes supporting human rights, education and the arts. We will deeply miss his warmth, wisdom and gracious character. On behalf of NewYork-Presbyterian, we offer our deepest condolences to his wife, Jane, his son Jacob and all of his family and loved ones. Steven J. Corwin, MD, President and CEO Frank A. Bennack, Jr., Chairman of the Board of Trustees Peter S. Kalikow, Chair of the Real Estate and Major Facilities Committee NewYork-Presbyterian 1/3

HAROVAS--Antoine C. The leadership of Mount Sinai Roosevelt is deeply saddened by the loss of our friend and colleague Antoine C. Harovas, MD, who served the department of medicine and division of cardiology at Roosevelt Hospital with great distinction for almost 50 years. Respected by his colleagues and beloved by his many patients, Dr. Harovas was a mainstay in the department of medicine, and a mentor to the many young physicians who have passed through Roosevelt Hospital for their residency and medical careers. The Mount Sinai Roosevelt community extends heartfelt condolences to the Harovas family. Evan L. Flatow, MD, President, Mount Sinai Roosevelt A. Lawrence Attia, MD, President, Medical Board 1/3

GOODMAN--Mary Ellen (Weiss), March 24, 1924 - October 8, 2015. Survived by three children, Stephen, Nancy and Gerry, and four grandchildren, Joshua and Rachel Goodman, Leah Preston and Rebecca Gutstadt, and five great-grandchildren, Isaac, Dina, and Samuel Goodman, Sylvia Reifman and Caleb Preston. She lived fully until she died. Memorial service 4pm November 14 New York Society for Ethical Culture. 1/3

GOLDSCHMIDT--Charles, 94, of Mamaroneck, New York, passed away peacefully at home on October 15, 2015, survived by his cherished and devoted wife of 64 years, Patricia, his beloved children and their spouses, Richard and Karen, Jane and Robert, Peter and Caitlin, and adoring grandchildren Chelsea, Evan, Sara, Molly, Claire and Remy. A lifelong New Yorker with a second home in Phoenix, Arizona, "Charlie" was a pioneer and leader in the advertising industry, founder and Chairman of agency Daniel & Charles and its successor firms that followed. A graduate of NYU, he proudly served in the U.S. Navy throughout WWII as Executive Officer of the U.S.S. Bellatrix. A kind and caring man, he would do anything to help others in need, and was devoted to his entire family. Our navigator through life, he will be deeply missed by all of us, as well as scores of other relatives and dear friends. Funeral services will be held at Zion Memorial Chapel, 767 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY on Sunday, October 18 at 10:00am. Burial will follow at Mount Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY. Our family will receive guests at 710 The Crescent, Mamaroneck, NY on Sunday, October 18, 5:00-7:00pm. 1/3

GODMAN--Joseph. We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member, Joseph Godman, and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Angela W. Buchdahl, President Abigail Pogrebin, Central Synagogue of New York City 1/3

INJEIAN--William H. Born May 1, 1951 in New York City to Gerald and Anne Injeian. A true New Yorker, William Injeian attended PS 75 in Manhattan, Brooklyn Technical High School and the City College of New York, before joining the Air Force. After serving his country with the Air Force in Thailand during the Vietnam War, Mr. lnjeian spent the next twenty-two years serving the city he loved as an Investigator with the New York City Department Of Investigation. He married Barbara Kaye, a pediatric Nurse at Sloan Kettering, and lived in Manhattan and their beloved Callicoon. Nicknamed ""Big Bill," a moniker that referred more to his great heart than his imposing frame, William Injeian was a walking contradiction. A follower of Carlos Castaneda and William F Buckley; a hardcore biker who favored Hondas over Harleys; a possessor of profound religious faith and an equally dark sense of humor, William Injeian challenged and bedeviled us all. His integrity was unquestionable, his intellect was rigorous, his generosity was boundless in the end he was well-loved and respected by all who knew him. Though he'd lost his beloved wife, Barbara, in 2005, and his siblings, Geraldine and Gregory, Big Bill remained intensely connected to, and survived by, his nieces Anna, Talene, Arianna and Emily; and to his brother, Phillip, who he deeply adored and respected. William Injeian passed away on October 10th. Funeral services will be held this Saturday, at 3pm at the Frank Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue in New York City. Donations in care of Armenian - AGBU, 630 - 2nd Avenue, New York, NY 10016. 1/3

GALE--Katherine Jean, (nee Wallice). lifelong resident of Huntington, NY on October 13, 2015. Born February 9, 1922. Married 70 years to the love of her life, D. Kent Gale, (July 27, 1943), who predeceased her on March 5, 2014. Jean and Kent worked side by side for many decades at the Daniel Gale Agency, founded in 1922 by Kent's father, Daniel. Jean first worked as a secretary at the Daniel Gale Agency and became the first female real estate agent in 1939. She graduated from Central High School in Huntington, NY and was a longtime member of the Huntington Country Club. Loved ones left to cherish her memory are her children, Daniel K. Gale Jr., Stanley C. Gale and Mary Stokkers and their children and grandchild. Jean will be remembered as a devoted grandmother to Kelly J. Stokkers, Alyson Stokkers McKee, Kyle T. Stokkers, Stanley C. Gale Jr., Katherine J. Gale and Jaclyn L. Gale; and beloved great-grandmother to Brinley McKee. Private burial Saturday, October 17, followed by a celebration of Jean's life at 3:00pm for family and friends. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Visiting Nurse Hospice. Checks payable to: Visiting Nurse Hospice of Suffolk, Inc., 505 Main Street, Northport, NY 11768, or online: visitingnurseservice.org/ hos piceathome.html 1/3

Dougherty (deceased) and Dorothy Patt Dougherty; brother of Paul and Margaret. The Wake is Friday, October 16, 3-5pm and 7-9pm at Edwards Dowdle Funeral Home, 64 Ashford Ave., Dobbs Ferry. Funeral Mass is Saturday, October 17, 10am at St. Matthews Roman Catholic Church, 616 Warburton Ave., Hastings-on-Hudson. We are all bereaved. Please omit flowers. 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien. The Board and the Staff of the Film Society of Lincoln Center is deeply saddened by the loss of Julien Studley, a founder of our organization who served as an active and vital member of our Board for over four decades - as Chairman from 1991 - 1993, then for many years as Chair of our Exec Committee and our representative to the Board of Lincoln Center. Julien was a major supporter of our New Directors/New Films and he and his wife Jane, an incomparable cook, hosted many dinners for burgeoning film directors at their home. Julien was also instrumental in developing plans for the Elinor Bunin Munroe Film Center. It is difficult to imagine the Film Society without Julien Studley - he will be missed by everyone who knew him. Ann Tenenbaum, Chairman Daniel H. Stern, President Lesli Klainberg, Exe. Director 1/3

WILLIAMS--Jasmin H.,(nee Samuels). Born January 11, 1959 in Brooklyn, NY. Passed away August 28 at NYU Tisch Hospital. Beloved wife of Shawn Williams (married July 26, 1986). Mother of David Jeffrey and Jennifer Lynn, sister of Simonetti Samuels and Paul Zervos (deceased), daughter of June Tilton and Oscar Samuels (deceased). GREENBERG--Rosalie. The staff and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn the loss of Life Trustee Rosalie "Mickey" Greenberg. With her late husband Herbert, Mickey was a long-time benefactor of LIJ Medical Center and the health system. Her dedicated service and support enabled the hospital to provide outstanding healthcare to local residents and become a leading medical institution in the region. In addition, the Greenbergs' generosity supported facilities, programs and services at Cohen Children's Medical Center, North Shore University Hospital, and the Zucker Hillside Hospital. Mickey's leadership, enthusiasm, commitment and generosity has helped North Shore-LIJ remain steadfast in its mission to put patients first and make a difference in their lives by providing the highest quality healthcare available. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her family. Mark L. Claster, Chairman, Board of Trustees, North Shore-LIJ Health System Michael J. Dowling, President and CEO, North Shore-LIJ Health System 1/3

STUDLEY--Julien. All of us at Savills Studley profoundly mourn the recent death of our former colleague and friend, Julien Studley. As founder of Julien J. Studley, Inc. in 1954, his innovative and visionary approach of representing tenants rather than owners was groundbreaking, changing the commercial real estate industry forever. As a broker, Julien advocated tenaciously for his clients--a trait that remains in the DNA of our firm's culture today. As a leader, he supported creativity, collaboration and, yes, a little healthy competition, inspiring people from all walks of life to be the best they could be. Those of us who were brought into the business by Julien are personally grateful to him for his encouragement and support. We, and indeed the entire industry, would not be where we are today if it were not for him. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Jane and his children and grandchildren. Julien's contributions to the industry and to New York City will not be forgotten. Mitchell Steir, Chairman & CEO, Savills Studley Michael Colacino, President, Savills Studley Savills Studley Board of Directors The entire Savills Studley family 1/3

ROSEN--Doris, aka Doris Rosen Margett, nee Leavy, 97 years old, died on October 10, 2015. Predeceased by her husbands, Michael Rosen and The Honorable Charles Margett; and her beloved son, Sanford Rosen. Also survived by nephews, Roger and Dr. Jeffrey Leavy, countless friends and relatives. A unique woman, one of a kind. Services 11:30am, Friday, October 16, 2015, at Riverside- Nassau North Chapels, 55 North Station Plaza, (Opposite LIRR), Great Neck, NY. Interment to follow at Beth David Cemetery, Elmont, NY. 1/3

ORLAN--George, 87, of Ridgefield, CT passed away on October 14. He was a beloved husband to Adrienne Orlan for 60 years and father to Amy Gilroy, Beth Uzcategui and Fred Orlan. He is also survived by seven grandchildren. He was an avid conservationist who served on the Town of Ridgefield's Conservation Commission for 23 years, 12 of those in a leadership capacity, acting as a champion of the town's open spaces. He was a Korean War veteran, an attorney, a home and commercial builder, and a devoted father, husband and grandfather. Funeral services will be held at Temple Shearith Israel in Ridgefield, CT at 1pm on Sunday, October 18. 1/3

WINTER--Lewis Vince, 87, died October 12th at home. Known for his critical eye and passion for art, design, and craftsmanship. Lewis enjoyed life amidst change. "I was lucky to have participated in the '60s cultural scene. I loved the future that it gave me," he said. He frequented Dick Bellamy's Green Gallery at the time and was influenced by Henry Geldzahler. Early to Chelsea, Lewis renovated a townhouse and filled it with art deco furnishings from flea markets. An entrepreneur, he started up Yesterday's News, selling vintage clothing to Andy Warhol, Patti Smith, and others. Lewis then launched the clothing design career of his wife, Harriet. Lewis is survived by their children Alexander Winter, Andrea Shlasko, and Joanna Barsh, and sister, Judith Burger. Luigi, we miss your style, sense of adventure, and joy of the hunt. It was a good life. Services will be on October 16 at 11:15am, Riverside Memorial, 180 West 76th Street. We welcome all who loved Lewis as we do. 1/3

GALE--Katherine Jean. 1922-2015. A woman of quiet power, strength, and beauty who made a difference in the lives of so many people. Thank you, Jean. Patricia J. Petersen President and CEO Daniel Gale Sotheby's International Realty 1/3

WEISS--Irma Giustino. Died peacefully on October 6, 2015 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. This extraordinary woman was 96 years old. She was born on March 30, 1919 in New York City where she lived all of her long, productive life. She was a 1945 graduate of the School of Art at The Cooper Union, to which she was a devoted and generous alumna, establishing the Irma Giustino Weiss Scholarships for meritorious students in art and architecture and the IGW Cultural Enrichment Fellowship Program. The latter was particularly close to Irma's heart, as it provided students with the financial means to experience the unique artistic, theatrical and cultural treasures of New York City. The other favorite object of her substantial philanthropy was the Whitney Museum, to which she was a major donor, contributing at the highest levels, primarily towards the new building. She had a successful career and marriage. Irma was the first female hired in the Art Department of Triangle Publications, later received two Art Director Awards for her work at Ziff Davis Publishing, and ultimately became a Creative Director at Conde Nast Publications. She married Benjamin Weiss in 1969, and he predeceased her on October 23, 1992. It was a magical marriage, whose romance never ended. A building at Rockefeller University is named for them. She was a woman of style, an exceptional cook, highly intelligent, witty and a "liberal" in the best sense of the word. She deeply cared about human rights. Right up to her death, she was a yeasayer to life, going at it full blast, benefitting always from her most treasured virtue, her curiosity. In due course, a memorial service will be held in her honor. 1/3

ASTROVE--Edgar, 89, of Hamden, CT, passed away on Tuesday, October 13, 2015. He was a widower from his wife of 42 years, Katherine Adler Astrove, survived by his companion of many years, Sue Cohen, son, Jim Astrove and his wife, Ann B. Astrove, daughter, Jane Graver, his grandchildren, Melissa, Bennett and Grace, as well as scores of loving relatives and dear friends. Edgar received an undergraduate degree from City College of New York and graduate degrees from the University of Michigan. He also served in the U.S. Army during WWII. WEISS--Irma Giustino. Died peacefully on October 6, 2015 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. This extraordinary woman was 96 years old. She was born on March 30, 1919 in New York City where she lived all of her long, productive life. She was a 1945 graduate of the School of Art at The Cooper Union, to which she was a devoted and generous alumna, establishing the Irma Giustino Weiss Scholarships for meritorious students in art and architecture and the IGW Cultural Enrichment Fellowship Program. The latter was particularly close to Irma's heart, as it provided students with the financial means to experience the unique artistic, theatrical and cultural treasures of New York City. The other favorite object of her substantial philanthropy was the Whitney Museum, to which she was a major donor, contributing at the highest levels, primarily towards the new building. She had a successful career and marriage. Irma was the first female hired in the Art Department of Triangle Publications, later received two Art Director Awards for her work at Ziff Davis Publishing, and ultimately became a Creative Director at Conde Nast Publications. She married Benjamin Weiss in 1969, and he predeceased her on October 23, 1992. It was a magical marriage, whose romance never ended. A building at Rockefeller University is named for them. She was a woman of style, an exceptional cook, highly intelligent, witty and a "liberal" in the best sense of the word. She deeply cared about human rights. Right up to her death, she was a yeasayer to life, going at it full blast, benefitting always from her most treasured virtue, her curiosity. In due course, a memorial service will be held in her honor. 1/3

CASSIDY--Msgr. James P. Passed away October 14, 2015 at Calvary Hospital, Msgr. Cassidy was born on May 10, 1925 in New Rochelle, NY. He is the son of the late Patrick and Ellen Cassidy. He is pre deceased by his brothers, Thomas, Joseph A. and John G. He is survived by his brother Raymond G. and his wife Marie. Beloved uncle of 19 nieces and nephews as well as 53 grandnieces and nephews. Msgr received his B.A. Degree from St. Joseph's Seminary in 1950. Ordained a priest of the Archdiocese of New York in 1951. Received a M.S., Degree and a Ph.D. from Fordham in Educational Psychology. Did Post-Doctoral work in Clinical Psychology at Fordham and St. Vincent's Hospital. Msgr served as parish priest, first Holy Eucharist in Yonkers from 1951-1954 and Also St. Barnabas in Woodlawn 1954-1964. Msgr served as Director, Family Consultation Service, and Associate Professor at St., John's University. From 1972 to 1989 Director of Dept of Health and Hospitals for Arch of New York. He served as Chancellor of the New York Medical College from 1987 - 1992. From 1992 until 1995, he served as Director of International Association of Catholic Health Institution in Rome; from 1995-2000 he served as the Administrator of Holy Spirit Church in Cortland Manor, 2000-2003 he served as Director of Counseling at North American College in Vatican City. Msgr served as Conventual Chaplain at the Order of Malta and was awarded the Grand Cross Pro Piis Meritis on his 90th birthday. Msgr. Cassidy will be waked at Lloyd Maxcy & Sons, 16 Shea Place, New Rochelle, NY on Sunday, October 18, 2015 from 4pm to 8pm. Mass will be held Monday, October 19, 2015 at 10am at St. Patrick's Cathedral. Donations can be made to TCC Healthcare Center and Calvary Hospital in lieu of flowers. 1/3

TAYLOR--Kenneth D. The Trustees, alumni, residents and staff of International House note with great sorrow the passing of Ambassador Ken Taylor, an esteemed member of our Board since October, 1985, and a devoted supporter of our mission. Ken and his wife, Dr. Patricia Taylor, distinguished chair of our Women's International Leadership Program's Advisory Council, have inspired and touched the lives of hundreds of I-House residents around the world over the years through their example of leadership, courage and grace. Our deepest sympathy is extended to Pat and the family. Frank G. Wisner, Chairman Calvin Sims, President 1/3

GREENBERG--Rosalie "Mickey" Brown, November 27, 1917 - October 14, 2015. Mickey Greenberg lived a long and exemplary life, where family and community service were paramount. A founding member and third President of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center Service Guild and Trustee and a Vice Chair of LIJ and trustee of its successor North Shore- LIJ Health System where she spent 38 years focusing on community health development, medical affairs, women's health and physicians' relations as chairman of various committees. As LIJ's representative on the Board of the United Hospital Fund, serving as Chair of its Women's Board, and later as Vice Chair of its full Board of Directors she received the 1980 Distinguished Service Award. A Trustee of Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, she chaired its Board of Education during the mid-50's to the early 60's and served as Vice President of the Board of Trustees. Throughout her life, she led by example, with an optimistic attitude, sincere commitment to making a difference, and deep abiding love of family and friends. Loving wife of the late Herbert Greenberg of Great Neck, NY, for 58 years, she was the devoted mother of Edward A. "Woody" Greenberg (Jane Bowling), Betsy G. Feinberg (Robert), Amy G. Poster (Robert), and Susan G. Piper (Gordon); adored grandmother of Cara Feinberg, Guy Greenberg, Joanna Piper Cuevas Ingram (Carlos), Tracy Piper Sutherland (Ben) and Michael Piper and loving aunt and friend to a large extended family. Funeral service will be held at Temple Beth-El, Old Mill Road in Great Neck, on Sunday, October 18th at noon. 1/3

GOLDSCHMIDT--Charles, 94, of Mamaroneck, New York, passed away peacefully at home on October 15, 2015, survived by his cherished and devoted wife of 64 years, Patricia, his beloved children and their spouses, Richard and Karen, Jane and Robert, Peter and Caitlin, and adoring grandchildren Chelsea, Evan, Sara, Molly, Claire and Remy. A lifelong New Yorker with a second home in Phoenix, Arizona, "Charlie" was a pioneer and leader in the advertising industry, founder and Chairman of agency Daniel & Charles and its successor firms that followed. A graduate of NYU, he proudly served in the U.S. Navy throughout WWII as Executive Officer of the U.S.S. Bellatrix. A kind and caring man, he would do anything to help others in need, and was devoted to his entire family. Our navigator through life, he will be deeply missed by all of us, as well as scores of other relatives and dear friends. Funeral services will be held at Zion Memorial Chapel, 767 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY on Sunday, October 18 at 10:00am. Burial will follow at Mount Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY. Our family will receive guests at 710 The Crescent, Mamaroneck, NY on Sunday, October 18, 5:00-7:00pm. 1/3

MULLIGAN--William. William "Bill" Anthony Mulligan, 72, died Saturday, August 22, 2015 in Lloyd Neck, NY. Born November 23, 1943 in Huntington, NY to Louise and Frank Mulligan he was a long time very well-known mining professional, based in New York. After receiving a Bachelor of Science degree from Clarkson University, an MS in Geological Engineering from the University of Connecticut, and an MBA from NYU Bernard Baruch School of Business Administration, he served with distinction in the US Marine Corps, worked for various mining companies such as Amax and Latin American Gold, numerous investment and commercial banks including Lehman Brothers, Chase Manhattan, Prudential Bache and finally as Managing Director for Global Projects and Political Risk at AIG Global Trade and Political Risk Insurance Company. He was also a director of Arcon International PLC, and most enjoyably in his latter years, of Griffin Mining Ltd from October 1997 until December 2013. He also enjoyed fishing, hunting, and spending time with loved ones. Surviving are three children, Katherine Ryan, Amy Mulligan and William E. Mulligan; two grandchildren, Briton Ryan and Brody Ryan and his sisters Bernadette Haagenson and Rita Dragonette. A Memorial Service will be held on Saturday, October 24, 2015 at St. John's Episcopal Church in Huntington at 11am. 1/3

PARMER--William B.,M.D., 69, died on October 2, 2015. A 1968 Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Columbia University, he received his medical degree at Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons and completed his internship and residency at Montefiore Medical Center in New York. He was affiliated with California Pacific Medical Center (CPMC) in San Francisco and practiced medicine for more than 35 years. An outstanding internist loved by his patients, Dr. Parmer was also an avid reader and had deep knowledge in many areas, including classical music, literature, politics and sports. He was an accomplished tennis player, gardener and landscape painter. Above all, he cherished his family. Survivors include his wife Joan of San Mateo, CA; his daughters, Julia and Ilana of San Francisco; his mother Miriam Parmer of Great Neck, NY; and his sister, Laura Skodol of Phoenix, AZ. He is predeceased by his father, Dr. Leo G. Parmer. The Dr. William Parmer Memorial Fund in Support of Medical Resident Education has been established at CPMC in his honor. Donations can be made to the Dr. William Parmer Memorial Fund, CPMC Foundation, 2015 Steiner St., San Francisco, CA 94115. (www.CPMC.org/giving) 415-600-2415. 1/3
STAROBIN--Carol Fijan, Puppeteer, 97, of Saugerties, died October 8, 2015. Full obit: www.seamonwilseyfuneral home.com 1/3

RUSSELL--A. David. The Board of Directors of Youth Foundation, Inc. notes with profound sorrow the passing of its beloved and distinguished President Emeritus, A. David Russell on October 11, 2015. His contributions to the Foundation and its mission were significant. The Foundation will miss him greatly and extends its heartfelt condolences to his family. Pamela Fulweiler, President 1

SELVIN--Albert M.,of Pawling, NY, October 11, suddenly, riding his bike home one lovely fall day. Cyclist, musician, thinker, problem-solver, writer, traveler, loving family man. Al was warm, kind and genuinely good. Donations: Elephant Sanctuary, Hohenwald, TN; Guiding Eyes for Blind, Patterson, NY. 1/3

SHULL--Hugh Henderson "Buzzy" Jr.,80 of NYC, died on July 4 of heart failure. He was born at home and raised in Winston-Salem, N.C. by Zula "Lulu" Mae and Hugh H. Shull. Mr. Shull graduated at the top of his class from R.J. Reynolds High School in Winston-Salem, and, at age 16, entered the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, majoring in History and Latin. He was a member of the DKE fraternity. After graduating in 1955, he attended Columbia University School of Law, graduating with a J.D degree in 1959. He began his law career as a maritime attorney with Sea Land Services in Newark. He worked as a corporate lawyer for Kidde Inc. for 20 years, eventually serving as Senior Vice President and General Counsel. After leaving Manhattan in 1961, he lived in Montclair, NJ for 30 years before moving back to Manhattan in 1991. In Montclair he was an active member of saint Luke's Episcopal church and in New York was a member of Saint James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan, where he served as an usher and volunteered for community projects, including landscaping and gardening at St. James' and at St. Ann's in the Bronx. He is survived by his wife of 58 years, the former Elizabeth Watkins "Wattie" May; son Hugh H. Shull III and his wife Julija; daughters, Amy Finnerty Varadarajan, and Annabel Shull Levy and their husbands, Tunku Varadarajan and David Levy, eight grandchildren, and his sister Patty Webb. Mr. Shull was predeceased by his eldest child, Elizabeth Henderson Shull. A Memorial service was held on July 13 at Saint James' Episcopal Church in Manhattan. 1/3

She was 87. 1/3

TAYLOR--Kenneth D. The Trustees, alumni, residents and staff of International House note with great sorrow the passing of Ambassador Ken Taylor, an esteemed member of our Board since October, 1985, and a devoted supporter of our mission. SOHN--Lydia, 73, peacefully at home on October 15, 2015. Longtime dedicated reading specialist in New York City Public Schools. Beloved mother of Stefanie, mother-in-law of David Jackson, dear grandmother of Hunter, cherished sister of the late Irene, brother-in-law of Charles, sweet aunt to Scott. Service Sunday, October 18, 12:45pm at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Donations in her memory may be made to: Reading is Fundamental, www.rif.org 1/3
GOLDSCHMIDT--Charles. To a loving friend whose wit and humor will be sorely missed. Charlie's Bridge Game 1/3

GORDON--Elliot M.,90 passed away on October 11 after a long illness. He is survived by his loving partner of 36 years, Lynda Gould, his son, Miles, daughter-in-law, Vera (Bittner), sister, Lois Schneider, of Haverford, PA, brother-in-law Frank Gould, and sister-in-law, Janet Weinstein, of Philadelphia, and nieces Ellen Rothstein, Leah Garnett, Ruth Rothstein, Mollie Weinstein-Gould, Jordan Gould and nephew Jesse Gould. Elliot grew up in Philadelphia and received a B.A. and M.A. in Romance Languages from the University of Pennsylvania, class of '45. He served in the Navy and then studied at the Sorbonne from '47 to '49, where he perfected his French and his French accent. Elliot settled in New York City where he owned Stereo Lab in Greenwich Village, selling components and high end stereo equipment. He then went to work at CBS Television where he was an audio engineer for 35 years. He earned an Emmy in 1987 for technical work at NFL Today. Elliot was a bridge aficionado and Life Master. He was an early adapter of home computers, and initiated a course at Lenox Hill Neighborhood House to instruct seniors in their use which he taught as a volunteer. He collected rare and out-of-print books on the fine arts and enjoyed incorporating his book searches into his world travels. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Wright Center on Aging/NY Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center, 525 East 68 Street, NYC, 10065. 1/3

Mass Tuesday 11:00am at St. Augustine Church in Larchmont. Interment Private. For full obit. At JJFFH.com 1/3

GREENBERG--Rosalie. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the loss of our honorary director and former vice chairman, a woman of great energy, purpose and caring. Over 40 years, she guided our development and grantmaking programs and worked tirelessly to support hospitals and improve health care. We extend our sincere condolences to her children. J. Barclay Collins, II, Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr., President 1/3
ANDERSON--Lennart. The American Academy of Arts and Letters notes with sorrow the death of our esteemed colleague, a modern master whose paintings reflect the tenderness and elegance of the man. 1/3

WEISS--Irma Giustino. Died peacefully on October 6, 2015 at New York Presbyterian Hospital. This extraordinary woman was 96 years old. She was born on March 30, 1919 in New York City where she lived all of her long, productive life. She was a 1945 graduate of the School of Art at The Cooper Union, to which she was a devoted and generous alumna, establishing the Irma Giustino Weiss Scholarships for meritorious students in art and architecture and the IGW Cultural Enrichment Fellowship Program. The latter was particularly close to Irma's heart, as it provided students with the financial means to experience the unique artistic, theatrical and cultural treasures of New York City. The other favorite object of her substantial philanthropy was the Whitney Museum, to which she was a major donor, contributing at the highest levels, primarily towards the new building. She had a successful career and marriage. Irma was the first female hired in the Art Department of Triangle Publications, later received two Art Director Awards for her work at Ziff Davis Publishing, and ultimately became a Creative Director at Conde Nast Publications. She married Benjamin Weiss in 1969, and he predeceased her on October 23, 1992. It was a magical marriage, whose romance never ended. A building at Rockefeller University is named for them. She was a woman of style, an exceptional cook, highly intelligent, witty and a "liberal" in the best sense of the word. She deeply cared about human rights. Right up to her death, she was a yeasayer to life, going at it full blast, benefitting always from her most treasured virtue, her curiosity. In due course, a memorial service will be held in her honor. 1/3

LERNER--Harold, retired cantor, died peacefully at home on October 12 in New York City. He was 92. Descendant of a long line of distinguished European cantors, he began singing in synagogue choirs at age eight. After serving in WWII, he studied at Juilliard School of Music as well as with Cantor Adolph Katchko, the country's most prominent cantorial teacher. Following studies at the Jewish Theological Seminary, he became cantor of Temple Beth Hillel (Boston) and then cantor of Temple Adath Yeshurun (Syracuse), where he served for many decades. He moved generations of all faiths with his beautiful voice and inspired renditions of the Liturgy. His series of annual Cantors Concerts set examples of excellence, and his "Haggadah, A Search For Freedom," was nationally televised on PBS. He received an honorary doctorate from the Jewish Theological Seminary in recognition of his many achievements. Since 2006, he enjoyed the cultural delights of his home at Lincoln Center with his wife, Ginger. His Jewish musical, "Kimber Road," had staged readings at the 92nd Street Y and the JCC in Manhattan. Lerner is survived by Ginger, his two daughters and son-in-law, three grandchildren, and his stepfamily. A memorial service will be held at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue at 30 W. 68th St. at 2:15 on October 18. Contributions may be made to the Metropolitan Opera or the Langone Cancer Center. 1/3

OGILVIE--Donna Brace, of Riverside, CT and Sarasota, FL passed away peacefully of natural causes surrounded by family at Stamford Hospital on October 4 at the age of 105. Mrs. Ogilvie was born in New York City on January 21, 1910, to Ida and Donald Brace. Mr. Brace was cofounder of the publishing company, Harcourt Brace, in New York. Mrs. Ogilvie was a Director of Harcourt Brace & Co. and was honored for her service in 1960. Mrs. Ogilvie was a very generous and much admired philanthropist, supporting many causes, most notably the Stamford Hospital, Girls Inc., and Phillips Andover Academy in Andover, Mass, from which she graduated in 1930. For many years, starting in the late 1940's, she volunteered her time at Stamford Hospital, accumulating over 9,000 volunteer hours in her lifetime. She has served as Trustee of the Hospital, Director of the Hospital Foundation and President of the Auxiliary. She made many important financial gifts to the hospital, donating the Brace Auditorium in the hospital in honor of her father, the Donna Brace Ogilvie Auditorium at the Tully Health Center and the establishment of the upcoming Donna Brace Ogilvie Volunteer Resource Center in the expanded hospital. She was honored at a special dinner in May of 2015 for her generosity to the hospital over the years, where it was stated that other than the founding benefactor of the hospital, "no single individual has played a more important role in the history of Stamford Hospital." She served on the board of the Stamford Girls Club during the 50's and 60's. She also served as Chair of the national board of Girls, Inc., based in New York City, for many years and at her death was still active as Distinguished Board Chair as well as serving on the board of the local Girls Inc. chapter in Sarasota, FL. The Sarasota center was recently renamed in her honor. Her gifts to Andover Academy were many, including the Brace Center for Gender Studies in 1996. According to the school, "Ogilvie is known as the most prominent female benefactor in the history of the school." In 1997, Andover bestowed on her its highest honor, the Claude Moore Fuess Award. Her active philanthropic life earned her many other awards, honors and friendships that sustained her until her death. She was predeceased by her parents and her sister, Katharine Brace Cummings and three husbands, John Ralph Latham, Louis Francis Kroeck and Dr. John Black Ogilvie, a well- known surgeon practicing in Stamford. She had three children: John Brace Latham, who predeceased her. Surviving are her daughters Katharine Latham Butler and Karen Kroeck Scheid (Dean), and a nephew, Donald Brace Cummings, as well as four stepsons. She is also survived by her grandchildren, Luke Butler of San Francisco, Winston Stubbart of Bluffton, SC, Evan Stubbart of Gilbert, AZ, and their families. Donna enjoyed her life to the fullest. Her joy was in giving. In her memory, gifts may be made to Girls Inc., 120 Wall St., #

GAFFNEY--Loti Falk, 94, died at home on October 13, peacefully and comfortably, surrounded by loving family and her devoted caregivers, Ana Kruppenbacher and Michelle Wilson. Loti grew up in fortunate circumstances. Born in Istanbul, she spent her childhood and teenage years in Milan and St. Moritz, where she compounded her native fluency in Italian and French with working knowledge of the other major European languages. Despite the strictness and formality of her upbringing, she was permitted to go to Paris to study philosophy at the Sorbonne, acquiring a body of knowledge that would prove significant in her social and political views later in life. Loti and her family came to New York in the late 1930s and Loti plunged into the life of the city, learning English, taking courses at Columbia and, when the war finally came to America, performing volunteer service. Along the way, she fell in love with Michael A. Gerard, a US Army lieutenant, who was to command a tank battalion in the European Theatre. Loti and Mike had two sons, Robert and Peter, who survive her today. After her marriage to Mike ended in divorce in the 1950s, Loti was determined to give her sons the advantages she enjoyed as a child. To supplement her income, she took two jobs. She was an instructor in Italian and French at Berlitz School of Languages (a remarkable feat since Berlitz limited its faculty to native speakers). In addition, she became quite proficient and prominent in providing scripts for dubbing Italian films into English: the challenge of matching up lip movements to words in another language. Among her many credits were Fellini's 8-1/2, Divorce Italian Style, The Seven Capital Sins, L'Aventura and Rocco and his Brothers. In 1963, Loti married Leon Falk, Jr., of Pittsburgh, a leading philanthropist and industrialist, taking on, among other things, eight new stepchildren and a number of step-grandchildren, a daunting, but rewarding, task for a woman barely in her 40s. Almost immediately, she became a powerful force in the Pittsburgh cultural community, taking positions on the boards of all the major cultural organizations, reviving the nearly moribund Pittsburgh Playhouse and, her most cherished accomplishment, turning the Pittsburgh Ballet from a small local company to a recognized national and international force in ballet, a position it continues to hold today. Loti's contributions were far more than financial. She had a deep sense of and appreciation for beauty in many forms of artistic expression-music, dance, painting, sculpture-enhanced by outstanding organizational and leadership skills, all implemented by a powerful commitment to getting things done right. Leon was also a prominent cattle breeder, operating Falklands Farm in the Allegheny Mountains east of Pittsburgh, producing prizewinning Polled Hereford cattle. Loti was a city girl, but she plunged into country life with the same intensity she devoted to everything else. She developed and nurtured a large, year round, organic garden at a time when organic was a term associated with chemistry or music, but certainly not food. The farm and its products were to be a central part of Loti's life for a long time: a place to appreciate nature and a place to share with her grandchildren. After Leon's passing in 1988, Loti, while maintaining her commitments in Pittsburgh, began to spend more of her time at her pied a terre in New York and traveling in Europe. In 1993, she married Frank Gaffney, a prominent Pittsburgh attorney and a fellow board member of the Pittsburgh Symphony. Her marriage to Frank added three more stepchildren to her ranks. Soon thereafter, Loti acquired a home in the Tuscan countryside, south of Florence and she and Frank began an idyllic life in the land of her youth, speaking her native language, cultivating an olive grove and making (and selling) their own brand of olive oil, making many new Italian friends, and, above all, sharing with her frequently visiting family the joys she loved as a child. With Frank's untimely passing in November 2001, shortly after the tragedy of 9/11, Loti knew the time had come to return home, and settled back in New York. As she moved into her mid-80s, her commitment to culture and her family remained robust: she joined the Board of the Martha Graham Dance Company, she volunteered at the Little Red Schoolhouse-Elisabeth Irwin High School and the Rubin Museum of Art. In recent years, as age has slowed her, she has stayed closer to home, spending time with her sons Robert and Peter and their wives Pippa and Melinda, as well as her grandchildren, Celia Gerard and her partner Mark McGrath of New York, Robert Gerard and his wife Cara of Sonoma, CA, William Gerard and his wife Libby of Oakland, CA, Jennifer Gerard of Los Angeles and Wylie and Ben Johnston of New York, and four great grandchildren: Chloe and Kellen (Robert) and Lucy and Emmy (William). She also remained devoted to her 11 stepsons and daughters (and their children and grandchildren) from her marriages to Leon and Frank and to her cousins, nieces and nephews throughout the world. Loti's final act of generosity was the donation of her body to medical research and, at her express wish, there will be no funeral or memorial service. Those wishing to commemorate her life may make gifts in her name to a charity of their choice or perform a simple act of kindness. 1/3

GODMAN--Joseph M.,91, passed away on October 15, 2015. Joe graduated first in his class at NYU School of Law, where he was the Editor-in-Chief of the Law Review. He was a renowned corporate attorney who practiced for over 40 years, and had a passion for swing and jazz music. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother, he will be remembered for his devotion to his family, his kindness and generosity. Joe will be missed by all who knew him. 1/3

HOLMES--Elisabeth. Elisabeth Nicholson Holmes, known as Robin, and Mummy, Baas or AuntieBaas to the younger generations, died on Monday evening October 12th. She had been bravely fighting ALS which was diagnosed on her 79th birthday on January 26th of this year. Robin was born Elisabeth Blair Nicholson in 1936 in Roslyn, New York. She attended the Green Vale School in Locust Valley, NY,; St. Michael's in Newport, RI and graduated from Miss Porter's School in Farmington, CT to which she remained devoted throughout her life. Robin met her husband, Col. Frederick S. Holmes Jr. (Freddy) who survives her, at a clambake at Second Beach in Middletown, RI when they were both teenagers. When she made her debut in Newport in 1954, Freddy made sure to secure an invitation to the party after which they began dating. They were married there at ages 20 and 21 in 1956 in the chapel of Freddy's alma mater, St. George's School, shortly after Freddy's graduation from West Point. Son Freddy 3rd arrived in 1957 when they were stationed in Stuttgart Germany and later, daughter Susan in 1960 in Massachusetts where Freddy was getting his first of two degrees from MIT. As a military family, they moved many times in the first 17 years of marriage before settling in Annandale, VA in 1973 when Freddy worked at the Pentagon. Robin had many varied interests, notably gardening, both in Virginia and at their summer home in Eagles Mere, PA; needlepoint, knitting, reading, world affairs and perhaps most famously, the British Royal Family about which she could tell you everything. She was knowledgeable about all European history and the history of art. She was an excellent public speaker. She worked extensively as a volunteer for the American Red Cross for many years in Blood Services, counseling, and disaster services, attaining the rank of Deputy National Director of Volunteers at National Headquarters in Washington. She was a Daughter of the American Revolution. When she was in her 50s she got her first- ever paying job with the NFCU. She made many friends there from many different countries and all walks of life. Everyone there who got married got a plant from one of Robin's cuttings as a gift and every baby born got something hand-knitted. She volunteered with after-school programs for years, tutoring grade-school children. This was a calling she loved before she had to give it up as her speech became impaired. She made friends wherever she went, always showing an interest in other people. She never met a cab driver who's life story she hadn't learned before it was time to pay her fare. She is survived by her husband Freddy, children Freddy 3 and Susan, their spouses, Kathy Holmes and Matt Heller, three grandchildren, Helen and Caroline Holmes and Nathaniel Heller, and Brian Aguirre, Helen's husband. She leaves behind many friends of all ages who will miss her always sunny, upbeat disposition, warmth and kindness. Donations may be made in Robin's memory to the ALS Association 7507 Standish Place Rockville, MD or at alsinfo.org 1/3

GREENBERG--Rosalie "Mickey" Brown, November 27, 1917 - October 14, 2015. Mickey Greenberg lived a long and exemplary life, where family and community service were paramount. A founding member and third President of the Long Island Jewish Medical Center Service Guild and Trustee and a Vice Chair of LIJ and trustee of its successor North Shore- LIJ Health System where she spent 38 years focusing on community health development, medical affairs, women's health and physicians' relations as chairman of various committees. As LIJ's representative on the Board of the United Hospital Fund, serving as Chair of its Women's Board, and later as Vice Chair of its full Board of Directors she received the 1980 Distinguished Service Award. A Trustee of Temple Beth-El of Great Neck, she chaired its Board of Education during the mid-50's to the early 60's and served as Vice President of the Board of Trustees. Throughout her life, she led by example, with an optimistic attitude, sincere commitment to making a difference, and deep abiding love of family and friends. Loving wife of the late Herbert Greenberg of Great Neck, NY, for 58 years, she was the devoted mother of Edward A. "Woody" Greenberg (Jane Bowling), Betsy G. Feinberg (Robert), Amy G. Poster (Robert), and Susan G. Piper (Gordon); adored grandmother of Cara Feinberg, Guy Greenberg, Joanna Piper Cuevas Ingram (Carlos), Tracy Piper Sutherland (Ben) and Michael Piper and loving aunt and friend to a large extended family. Funeral service will be held at Temple Beth-El, Old Mill Road in Great Neck, on Sunday, October 18th at noon. 1/3

CONWAY--Margaret "Peggy", of Rutherford, New Jersey died peacefully on October 16, 2015 after a brief illness. She was predeceased in death by her loving husband, Dr. Patrick Conway in 1978. Margaret was born in New York City in 1926, and graduated from Cathedral High School, Hunter College, and New York University, where she received her Doctoral Degree in applied mathematics, ABD. Margaret was an Adjunct Professor at Fairleigh Dickinson University, Rutherford and Teaneck, New Jersey campuses. She also taught high school at Essex Catholic High School in Newark, New Jersey, beginning in 1968, where she was the first female teacher at an all-boys high school. Margaret moved from New York City to Rutherford in the early nineteen fifties, when her husband was appointed Professor at the founding campus of Fairleigh Dickinson University in Rutherford, and remained a lifelong resident. She is survived by her sons, Kevin, of Rutherford and Cornwall, Connecticut, and Dennis, of Rutherford and Valdosta, Georgia. An avid traveler, only a year ago found her walking hills in Ireland at the property of her husband's relatives. Viewing will be at Calhoun Mania Funeral Home, Rutherford, New Jersey on Monday and Tuesday, October 19 and 20, from 2 to 4pm and 7 to 9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will be at St. Mary's Church, Rutherford, at 9:30am on October 21 and Interment will follow at George Washington Memorial Cemetery in Paramus, New Jersey. Margaret loved flowers, and they are appreciated. 1/3

GARCIA-MANSILLA--Lucio. Lucio Garcia-Mansilla, Founder of Decameron Resorts, is dead at 71. Lucio Garcia-Mansilla of Mill Neck, NY and Cartagena, Colombia died on October 11, 2015 in New York from complications following heart surgery. He is survived by his wife of 45 years, Jane Riggs Garcia-Mansilla; his children, Dr. Alexandra Riggs Garcia- Mansilla and Lucio Riggs Garcia-Mansilla, his two grandchildren, Lily and Rafael, his brother, Eduardo Garcia-Mansilla, his sister-in law Veronica Pueyrredon, and his adored son-in-law and nieces and nephews. Mr. Garcia-Mansilla was born in Argentina and raised in Uruguay. He came to the United States to attend the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania where he met his wife, Pinkie. In 1987, he founded the Decameron Group of Hotels & Resorts in Cartagena, Colombia. During his time as the President of this international hotel chain, the company grew to include 44 resorts in 11 countries throughout Latin America, the Caribbean, and Africa. While an exceptional entrepreneur, he also cared deeply about others, especially about Decameron's 12,000 employees. He helped to improve the quality of life of employees and others through a foundation that will now be re-named in his honor. 1/3

Beloved uncle of 19 nieces and nephews as well as 53 grandnieces and nephews. Msgr received his B.A. Degree from St. Joseph's Seminary in 1950. Ordained a priest of the Archdiocese of New York in 1951. Received a M.S., Degree and a Ph.D. from Fordham in Educational Psychology. Did Post-Doctoral work in Clinical Psychology at Fordham and St. Vincent's Hospital. Msgr served as parish priest, first Holy Eucharist in Yonkers from 1951-1954 and Also St. Barnabas in Woodlawn 1954-1964. Msgr served as Director, Family Consultation Service, and Associate Professor at St., John's University. From 1972 to 1989 Director of Dept of Health and Hospitals for Arch of New York. He served as Chancellor of the New York Medical College from 1987 - 1992. From 1992 until 1995, he served as Director of International Association of Catholic Health Institution in Rome; from 1995-2000 he served as the Administrator of Holy Spirit Church in Cortland Manor, 2000-2003 he served as Director of Counseling at North American College in Vatican City. Msgr served as Conventual Chaplain at the Order of Malta and was awarded the Grand Cross Pro Piis Meritis on his 90th birthday. Msgr. MIYOSHI--Lindsley Cameron, born October 23, 1948, died suddenly, of natural causes, September 30, 2015, at her home in New York's Chinatown. A writer and lover of the arts and of all things Japanese, Lindsley was the adoptive daughter of George Albert Cameron Jr. and Christine Patten Reed, both deceased. She worked at The New Yorker from 1985 to 1996 and published two books: "The Prospect of Detachment" (fiction) and "The Music of Light: The Extraordinary Story of Hikari and Kenzaburo Oe." She earned an M.F.A. from Bennington College in 2005. In 2006, she married Masao Miyoshi, who predeceased her. Her wish was to be interred in the Miyoshi family tomb in Tokyo, Japan. Lindsley gave unstintingly of her gifts in her capacity as a juror on the panel of the Japan-U.S. Friendship Commission Prize for the Translation of Japanese Literature, administered by the Donald Keene Center of Japanese Culture, Columbia University. Survivors include her birth mother, Elizabeth Ritchie; her half sister, Kate Gordon; her half brother, Stephen Carlyle; her stepbrother, John Ritchie; cousins, nieces, in-laws, and a host of friends, colleagues, and admirers. Sayonara, dearie. 1/3

REMPE--Harriette Eileen, nee Peterson, loving wife and mother, passed away peacefully to God on October 15, 2015. Harriette was born on May 19, 1930 and raised in Hollis, Queens. Cheerleader and Senior Class Secretary, Harriette was very popular with her classmates at Andrew Jackson High School, and a recognized local beauty. A prom date with Senior Class President Charles Rempe grew into a lifetime friendship and loving marriage of sixty years. After graduating from Hofstra University and Katherine Gibbs, Harriette worked as an executive secretary for Bulova Watch Company, marrying Charles on December 11, 1954. From a modestly furnished apartment in Queens, to a starter home in Melville, and then finally their dream home in Dix Hills, they built a life together centered on their family, work, friendships and Lutheran faith. Harriette was a long-time member of Gloria Dei Lutheran Church in Huntington, and house member of the Huntington Country Club, where for many years she was active with the club's social committee. Harriette took great pride in her homemaking, beautifully decorating and furnishing her house and garden, and preparing delicious meals for family and friends. She and Charles enjoyed dancing, traveling together and each other's company. Although she had tenderness for animals of any kind, Harriette was an unabashed dog-lover. Ginger, Pepper, Sandy, Daisy, Cookie, Gigi, Little Bit, Sammy Jo, Tom, Trixie, Gretel, Sable and Crystal all received her unconditional love and affection. She is survived by her adoring and devoted husband Charles; her loving children, Denise, Janine and Glenn; her three grandchildren, Ryan, Brooke and Victoria; and her dear brother George Peterson. Her beloved son Charles predeceased her in his infancy. Visitation: Sunday 4-7pm and Monday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, 1380 New York Ave., Huntington Station, NY 11746. Church Service: Tuesday 11am at Gloria Dei Lutheran Church, 22 East 18th St., Huntington Station. www.jacobsenfuneral.com. 1/3

EHRLICH--Jerome A.,M.D., Formerly of Scarsdale, passed away on October 12, 2015 at the age of 93. He was the son of Anna and Benjamin Ehrlich and brother of the late Marcia Ehrlich Pavloff. He is survived by his devoted wife of 67 years, Francine, his wonderful children Richard Ehrlich, Dr. Amy Ehrlich Charney (Lewis Wise), Dr. James B. Ehrlich (Janet Cagen), and Wendy Ehrlich (Dr. Todd Jick); his grandchildren Erica Charney (Dr. Robert Rix), Dr. Julie Ehrlich, Rachel Ehrlich, Drew Ehrlich, Jeffrey Ehrlich and Margot Ehrlich, and Aron Charney of blessed memory; and one great-grandchild, Ryan Charney Rix, the first of the next generation. Dr. Ehrlich was a graduate of Lafayette College and the University of Health Sciences at Chicago Medical School. He was Board Certified and a Diplomate of the American Board of Family Medicine, with a sub-specialty in ENT. He served as a Captain in the Army as a physician in Germany during the Korean War in an AAA Battalion, and later in the Fifth General Hospital, from 1953-1955. He was on the medical staff of Lawrence Hospital, in Bronxville, for over 40 years as an attending physician, holding multiple positions on various hospital boards, and was a member of the American Legion Post 52 of Scarsdale. Dr. Ehrlich put his heart into his family and into his work, and was an avid tennis player, equestrian, scuba diver and musician. He will be remembered with great love for his zest for life, travel and adventure by all who knew him: his family, friends, colleagues and patients. Interment will be at Kensico Cemetery, Sharon Gardens, Valhalla, NY. 1/3

HANLON--Robert M.,Jr., of Point Lookout, NY, in his 83rd year on October 7, 2015. Beloved son of the late Robert M. and Marian Meaney Hanlon. Predeceased by his loving first cousin, Claire P. McCrudden and survived by his much loved Iggy. Funeral and burial were private. 1/3

GOLDSCHMIDT--Charles, 94, of Mamaroneck, New York, passed away peacefully at home on October 15, 2015, survived by his cherished and devoted wife of 64 years, Patricia, his beloved children and their spouses, Richard and Karen, Jane and Robert, Peter and Caitlin, and adoring grandchildren Chelsea, Evan, Sara, Molly, Claire and Remy. A lifelong New Yorker with a second home in Phoenix, Arizona, "Charlie" was a pioneer and leader in the advertising industry, founder and Chairman of agency Daniel & Charles and its successor firms that followed. A graduate of NYU, he proudly served in the U.S. Navy throughout WWII as Executive Officer of the U.S.S. Bellatrix. A kind and caring man, he would do anything to help others in need, and was devoted to his entire family. Our navigator through life, he will be deeply missed by all of us, as well as scores of other relatives and dear friends. Funeral services will be held at Zion Memorial Chapel, 767 E. Boston Post Road, Mamaroneck, NY on Sunday, October 18 at 10:00am. Burial will follow at Mount Hebron Cemetery, 130-04 Horace Harding Expressway, Flushing, NY. Our family will receive guests at 710 The Crescent, Mamaroneck, NY on Sunday, October 18, 5:00-7:00pm. 1/3

CORBIN--Frank G M, 90, of Pelham, NY passed away peacefully on October 17, 2015. He is survived by his two children, Catherine and Peter, his daughter-in-law, Annette, and his two grandchildren Kaitlyn and Caroline. A graduate of Cardinal Hayes High School, class of 1943, and Fordham University, class of 1950, he proudly served in the U.S. army during WWII as a Lieutenant in Europe. He had a successful career in Public Relations, but his true passion was sharing his love of the communications industry with his students at Fordham, where he taught for 59 years. His strength was unwavering, his intellect was rigorous, and his selfless nature was to be admired. He was well loved, respected, and will be missed. Donations requested to Frank G M Corbin Scholarship Fund details and service information can be found at www.pelhamfuneral.com. 1/3

KELLY--Patricia M.,on October 16, 2015. Devoted wife of the late Matthew. Loving sister of Jo Hoey, Molly Twohig (Phillip) and Kate McCrossan. Treasured Aunt to many Nieces and Nephews. Respected member of the Dept. of Social Work at Lenox Hill Hospital. Beloved Council Member at St. Jean Baptiste Church and Board Member and longtime Volunteer at the New York Common Pantry. A great and much loved friend who will be missed by many. Visitation Tuesday 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 81st and Madison Avenue. Mass will be at St. Jean Baptiste Church 76th and Lexington Avenue on Wednesday 10:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Jean Baptiste Church and the New York Common Pantry. 1/3

FOGELSON--Daniel Industry leader, Strategist, Respected marketing mind, husband, father. Daniel Reid Fogelson. 1959-2015. For full obituary and memorial service information please see Sugarman Sinai Funeral Home website. 1/3

LORING--Leo, on October 16 just short of his 105th birthday. Beloved father of Anne, dear husband of the late Lily. Uncle to many, and a second father to his nephew Jim. He lived an extraordinarily long life with many passions, especially his love of skiing and recent love of painting. We thought he would live forever, he will always remain in our hearts. Service today, 4pm at "The Riverside" 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

BALLEN--Natalie. Our dear Aunt Nat, you were ever the rock of the family. We will miss your warmth, humor, family stories and kind spirit. We will remember you always with love. Your Winter/Miller nephews and nieces 1/3

MAYNARD--Bernice, on October 17, 2015 in Ann Arbor, MI, at age 101. Survived by son Frank (Lisa Barry), daughter Micheline, formerly of the Times, grandsons Benjamin and Parker Maynard, and devoted friend Maxine Clapper. Memorial donations may be made to the Ann Arbor City Club or the public radio station of your choice. 1/3

GODMAN--Joseph M.,91, passed away on October 15, 2015. Joe graduated first in his class at NYU School of Law, where he was the Editor-in-Chief of the Law Review. He was a renowned corporate attorney who practiced for over 40 years, and had a passion for swing and jazz music. A beloved husband, father, grandfather and brother, he will be remembered for his devotion to his family, his kindness and generosity. Joe will be missed by all who knew him. 1/3

DOBROF--Rose. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of RiverSpring Health and the Hebrew Home at Riverdale mourn the passing of our dear friend, Rose Dobrof. Rose was a leader, visionary and champion in the field of geriatric social work and was integral to the early success of the Hebrew Home. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Rose's immediate and extended families. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. Daniel Reingold President and CEO RiverSpring Health 1/3
SALISBURY--Philippa Ryan. Died October 12 after a long illness. Born April 26,1963. Daughter of Nancy and the (late) John, sister of Adrienne, Anne and Gay. 1/3

BALLEN--Natalie, died October 17th, five weeks short of her 97th birthday. She was surrounded by her much beloved and loving family. Natalie was born in Manhattan to Benjamin and Dora Winter. She was a graduate of Hunter College where she developed a life long love of learning. As a voracious reader, NPR and classical music listener, museum and theater goer, she took advantage of all that New York City had to offer. A generous woman from the start, she showed by example; not just with items of measurable value but with her time and energy. Natalie was predeceased by Irving, her loving husband of 39 years and was a devoted and much cherished mother to Steven Stern (Janet) and Barbara Heffer (John) and stepmother to Roger (Lynda), Kate and Sian and stepgrandmother to Amanda, Paul, Isobel, Alex, Olivia and William. Her greatest joys were her grandchildren, Michael (Lauren), Marcy, Alison and Douglas (Jenny) and her eight great-grandchildren. Natalie made an indelible impression on all who knew her and will be remembered for her generosity of spirit and incredible love of family. Services will be private. The family will receive relatives and friends at the Heffer residence on Monday, October 19 between 5:30pm and 9pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to the charity of their choice. 1/3

BALLEN--Natalie. Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our devoted member, Natalie Ballen. The beautiful qualities of her life shall endure forever in our hearts and her memory will bring us comfort. To all who loved her we express profound sympathy. 1/3

CARRICK--Ann Ewing, of Somers, New York, died on October 2, 2015, at Northern Westchester Hospital, after a short illness. She was 78 years old. Known to many by the nickname "Roonie," she was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, on March 23, 1937. She was the daughter of Meredyth H. and Betty T. Ewing. She attended The Ellis School in Pittsburgh, then Chatham Hall boarding school in Chatham, Virginia. She graduated from Garland Junior College in Boston, Massachusetts, in 1957 with an associates' degree in early childhood education. After graduation, she moved to New York City, where she taught kindergarten at Brooklyn Friends School. In 1961, she married Bruce R. Carrick. They lived in New York City for several years, and moved to Westchester County after their first child was born in 1964. Ann was a dedicated wife and mother, and a wonderful cook and hostess. She spent nearly every summer of her life at Rocky Reef, an extended lakeside property in Ontario, Canada, associated with her family since the 1890s. She is survived by her husband and their three children: a daughter Meredyth Carrick Sanderson and two sons, Charles L. and James B. She is also survived by three grandchildren: Virginia Sanderson and Findlay and Tobias Carrick. A private memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, New York. Memorial donations may be made to the Magnetawan Public Library, P.O. Box 130, Magnetawan, Ontario, P0A 1P0, Canada. Attention: Bonnie Davidson. 1/3
GODMAN--Joseph. A good man has passed away! Our beloved brother (in-law). Annie Jacobson, Marvin & Sandy Stollman 1/3
