DLUZNIEWSKI--John Boleslaw, also known as John Dee, 91, of NYC passed away peacefully on October 19, 2015 at home. He is survived by his wife, Sophie, and his daughter, Diane. A student of Rhodes School NYC and a graduate of NYU in Finance. Held various executive positions in corporations such as Int'l Playtex in Delaware and Scotland, Revlon and IOS in Geneva, Switzerland. He proudly served in the US Army in New Guinea in WWII. He continued to dedicate his service as a volunteer at the New York VA Hospital and as a Lieutenant with the Auxiliary Police with the 17th Precinct, NYC. A lifetime member of American Legion and Toastmasters Club. He was well loved, respected and will be missed. A viewing will be held at John Krtil Funeral Home on Wednesday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, the family requests donations be made to your charity of choice. 1/3

SCHWARTZ--Betty, 85, of Larchmont, NY, died on September 22, 2015 surrounded by her family. Betty was the daughter of Alice and Herbert Pels, the sister of Alan and Donald Pels, and the wife of Marvin Schwartz. She is survived by her children, Steven, Ellen, Phillip and Nancy, and her grandchildren Emma, Eric, Sophie, Lauren and Leo. Betty was a devoted mother and grandmother, and surrogate mother to many. She was a tireless champion of Planned Parenthood, and a committed volunteer to other causes as well. A memorial will be held November 1, 2015 at 11:30am at the Larchmont Shore Club. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to Planned Parenthood of Hudson Peconic. 1/3

DOBROF--Rose. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Brookdale Foundation extend our deepest sympathy to the family of Rose Dobrof. We had the privilege of collaborating with Rose for more than 40 years and are grateful for her wisdom and guidance as a Senior Fellow and in helping develop programs for older people across the country, especially the Respite Program. It is rare for a person to touch so many lives...Rose did. Her lifelong energy and passion for improving the lives of elders will guide the field in the future. Stephen L. Schwartz, President The Brookdale Foundation 1/3

WIENER--Gertrude "Trudy", passed away peacefully on October 19th, 2015 surrounded by her loved ones. She was the beloved wife of the late Stanley B. Wiener, a loving mother and cherished grandmother. She is survived by her two children, Gwen Eide and Stacey Cohen, her son- in-law, Robert J. Eide and her three grandchildren Maxwell S. Cohen, Genny S. Eide and Isabel H. Eide. We love you and miss you Boopie! Services will be held at "The Riverside Memorial Chapel" located at 180 W76th Street at 11:15am on Wednesday October 21,2015. Burial to follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. 1/3

ZERILLI-MARIMO-- Mariuccia. The NYU community grieves the loss of our good friend and Life Trustee, Baroness Mariuccia Zerilli- Marimo. An energetic and passionate advocate of Italian culture, she was the generous and committed force behind the creation of NYU's Casa Italiana Zerilli-Marimo, which, thanks to the Baroness, serves not only as a home to NYU's Department of Italian Studies, but as one of the most prominent centers for Italian thought, culture and scholarship in the U.S. She conceived of the creation of Casa Italiana as an homage to her late husband, and added to its success by providing support for a literary award, programming, and faculty in Italian Studies. A bridge-builder, a person of great warmth and charm, a generous and discerning philanthropist, a proponent of all that is great in Italian culture, a New Yorker in her heart if not her origins, a lover of the arts and literature, a believer in NYU's global efforts, and a recipient of NYU's Gallatin Medal and President's Medal, her absence will be keenly felt at NYU. Her memory will be cherished throughout our campus--and especially among the members of the Casa Italiana community-- for all the wonderful works she helped build, foster, and support. Her family, friends, and loved ones are in our hearts on this sad day. William Berkley, Chair, NYU Board of Trustees John Sexton, President 1/3
DILL--Richard C. Beloved Brother. Always Remembered. Peter L. Dill 1/3

KELLY--Patricia M. The Board and Staff of New York Common Pantry mourn the loss of our dear Pat. She taught us how to treat those who come for help with compassion and respect and they and we responded with love for her. Pat volunteered each Thursday for many years helping guests in our Pantry program, and was an important member of our Board of Directors for over 20 years. She will continue to represent the spirit of our Pantry. 1/3

WARREN--Kellyanne McCaul, of Manhattan passed away after an accident Sunday, October 18, 2015. A longtime resident of Gramercy Park, she is survived by her husband, Jeff; beloved children Samuel and William; daughter of Michael (deceased) and Catherine McCaul; sisters Rose- anne, Allison, Karen and Erin Mary and their families. She grew up in Baldwin, NY, attended Adelphi and Fordham Universities, and worked at Goldman Sachs and Lehman Brothers for 13 years. Kelly was an active and loved member of Grace Church School and the Gramercy Park communities. Her dedication to serving others was tireless. She adored her volunteer time at Memorial Sloan Kettering Pediatric Oncology Unit and various other charities, however, her love and devotion for her sons was her true purpose. Kelly's light, energy, optimism and kindness will never be forgotten and her joyful spirit will be missed. Visitation, Thursday, 6-9pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home. Funeral Service, Friday at Grace Church at 4pm. Reception to follow. 1/3

SHAPIRO--Joseph S.,formerly of Chestnut Hill, MA, died of cancer in NYC on October 18, 2015. He was surrounded by his loving family. Joseph was predeceased by Lilian, his wife of 50 years. He will be greatly missed by his two children, Kimberly Konigsberg of NYC and Kenneth Shapiro of Westport, CT; his daughter-in-law Patricia; and his four grandchildren James, Samantha, Alex and Andre. He was also survived by his sister and brother-in-law, Lotti and Philip Rubin. Born and raised in Sharon, MA, Joseph loved to recount how his friends chanted "Joe's no shmoe, Shapiro's our hero" whenever he led Sharon to one of its many victories on the fields and basketball court. He graduated from Brown University in 1953, loving "Bruno" until the day he died, and went on to play basketball for the U.S. Navy. In 1962 he started at Lundermac, a Whirlpool distributor, that created laundry rooms for multi-family housing throughout New England. He retired in 2007 as President, shortly before moving to NYC. Joseph was not only the most dotting husband, father and grandfather, but also a caretaker and cheerleader, becoming "Pa" to many. Seldom did he miss any of his grandchildren's games or performances, delighting in their achievements. He was truly one of a kind: the most giving man with unparalleled empathy, kindness and an unbridled love for his family. He will be forever loved. A reception will be held on Thursday, October 22 from 5-8pm at The Konigsberg's: 7 Gracie Square, 9A, New York, NY. There will be a graveside service for family and close friends on October 24th at 11:00am at Newton Cemetery: 791 Walnut Street, Newton, MA. Donations may be made to The Joseph T. Ruggiero Cancer Research Fund, Weill Cornell Medicine, 1305 York Ave 12th Floor, New York, NY 10021. 1/3

SACHS--Norma Gantz. Long time resident of New Rochelle, NY died on October 18, 2015 at age 90. Married to Monroe (dec.) and loving mother of David and Robert. Survivors include daughters-in-law Linda Shackelford and Caroline Taggart, nieces Ann Adenbaum, Julie Turjoman, Diane Iselin, Jennifer Iselin, and Terry Newman, and nephew Sam Adenbaum. Funeral services will be held at Westchester Reform Temple, 255 Mamaroneck Road, Scarsdale, NY at 10am on Tuesday, October 20. Interment following the service. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made in her name to Hospice of Westchester, 1025 Westchester Avenue, Suite 200, White Plains, NY 10605. 1/3

MILLEN--Robert W.,peacefully passed away on October 6, 2015 at 1:56am. Woody was born on November 12, 1939, in New York, NY, to Robert S. and Barbara Babcock Millen. He graduated from the Green Vale School, The Brooks School, and the University of Virginia. At the time of his death, he was Chairman of the Whitney Trustees and a long term Board Member of Palmetto Golf Club, where he held numerous committee/board positions, including President. He is survived by his sister Martha Brosnahan (husband Tim), brother J. Michael Millen (wife Mary Jane), and nephew John Daniel Chauncey Millen (wife Ashley). Memorial Service, 11am, October 30th at St. Thaddeus Episcopal Church, Aiken, SC, followed by wake at Palmetto Golf Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Virginia Athletics Foundation in support of the men's golf program (VAF, P.O. Box 400833, Charlottesville, VA 22904) or the Hitchcock Woods Foundation (Hitchcock Woods Foundation, P. O. Box 1702, Aiken, SC 29802). 1/3

HEILBORN--George H. A long-time resident of Ridgewood, NJ, passed away suddenly on October 17, 2015. Beloved husband of Phyllis, father to Stephanie and Allison, father-in-law to Martin Quirno and Jaseung Coue, and grandfather to Jorge Quirno. Born in Cologne, Germany, he came to the U.S. at the age of five, settling in Peoria, Illinois with his family. George was a Phi Beta Kappa graduate of Northwestern University with a BA in Physics and a brother of Theta Chi fraternity. He held an MA in Physics from Harvard University's Graduate School of Arts & Sciences. He founded IPS Computer Marketing Corporation, a dealer and broker of used computer systems and components for commercial use, in 1963. IPS was a pioneer in the development of the computer leasing industry and went public in June 1972. George sold IPS to USF&G Financial Services Corporation in December 1988. George acted as President of the Computer Dealers and Lessors Association, served on the Board of Visitors at Northwestern University and endowed the Heilborn Lectures at Northwestern's Department of Physics and Astronomy in the memory of his parents, Walter and Christine Heilborn. George was a member of and served a term as President of Harvard University's Graduate School of Arts & Sciences Alumni Council. He also served on the Children's Aid and Family Services Finance Committee. He was a passionate amateur pilot and driver of sports cars, participating in many Ferrari Club events over the years. He was a member of The Ridgewood Country Club, Shelter Island Yacht Club, Harvard Club of NYC and the Metropolitan Club. Visiting will be at the Vander Plaat Funeral Home, (vpfh.com), 257 Godwin Avenue, Wyckoff, NJ, 07481 on Thursday, October 22 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. A funeral mass will be held at Our Lady of Mt. Carmel Church, 1 Passaic St, Ridgewood, NJ 07450 on Friday, October 23 at 10:30am. Interment will be private. 1/3

SEIDMAN--Bernard. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Bernard Seidman, who leaves behind a loving family that will carry on a tradition of exceptional Jewish philanthropy. We extend our heartfelt condolences to Bernard's beloved wife, Edith; his children, Arlene, Dorothy, Robert, and Laurel; his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; Eric S. Goldstein, CEO 1/3
GRAINGER--Edmund C. Jr.,of Rye, NY in his 92nd year on October 18, 2015. Survived by his beloved wife Virginia, four children, 12 grandchildren and one great-grandchild. 1/3

BENAY--Marcus "Mike," 99, died on Saturday, October 17th after a brief illness. Mike established several successful businesses and was a member of the New York Mandolin Orchestra. He led trips with Margaret Morse Tours, traveling to Israel, Europe, and Scandinavia. He leaves his wife of 75 years, Florence, and his two sons, Elliott and Jeffrey, along with his beloved grandchildren, Erin, Megan, and Adam, and his great-grandson Benjamin. 1/3

GOLDBERG--Norma Indyck. In Memoriam Jan. 21, 1938 - Oct. 20, 2012 Three years later, after being taken by ovarian cancer, the wounds have not healed. 53 years of a wonderful marriage, 2 children, Jamie, David and four terrific grandchildren, Katie, Charlotte, Leyla and Alex. Norma leaves a legacy she could be proud of as reflected by her brother Arnold and sister Pearl, and as a NYC Public School teacher, as Director of Educational Services at Cablevision and among all those friends and relatives who loved her. She admired the doctors and staffs at Sloan Kettering Memorial Hospital and St. Francis Hospital In Roslyn, New York. With Deep Love, Norman Goldberg 1/3

GRUSHKIN--Esther. Esther Grushkin, PhD, who committed her life to teaching Hebrew language, literature, Bible and Judaic studies, died on October, 17, 2015. Born in Tel-Aviv, Israel in 1945, she came to the US at age 12. She received her doctorate in Ancient Near Eastern Studies at NYU, and taught at institutions across New York. She is survived by husband Jerome, mother Yael Mandel, sister Shoshana Steinberg, sons, Orren, Ailon and Daniel, daughters-in-law, Patricia and Jennifer, and granddaughters, Alexandra and Charlotte. 1/3
SEIDEN--Howard. Your always in our hearts. Our love for you will not die, never to be forgotten. Love, The Seiden Family 1/3

MARIMO--Mariuccia Zerilli. International Patrons of Duomo di Milano, together with its board members, remember with deep esteem Mariuccia Zerilli Marimo, enlightened Milanese citizen and generous supporter of the mission of spirituality and art of the Duomo di Milano in the world. 1/3

MURPHY--Dr. Franklin Lee. Asphalt Green mourns the sudden death on September 25th of our long time board member, friend and benefactor. A renowned cardiologist, Dr. Murphy was a nephew of our founders Dr. George E. and Annette Cross Murphy, and he continued their vision to create opportunities for sports and fitness for all New Yorkers. 1/3

DOBROF--Rose Harriet Wiesman, 90, November 11, 1924 - October 17, 2015. Loved by her family and friends who miss her tremendously. Rose was instrumental in the development of gerontological social work. Founding Director, Brookdale Center on Aging and Co-Director of Hunter/Mt. Sinai School of Medicine Geriatric Education Center. Served on many Boards of Directors such as Carter Burden Center for the Aging and New York Foundation. Selected by Mayor Dinkins to serve as Chair of Commission on Aging Services. Appointed by Governor Cuomo to New York State Public Health Council and by President Clinton to 1995 White House Conference on Aging and Federal Council on Aging. Served as inspiration and mentor to many in social work and gerontology. Graduated from University of Colorado, Phi Beta Kappa. MSW from the University of Pittsburgh. Doctorate from Columbia University School of Social Work. Married 53 years to Alfred Dobrof, who had his own distinguished social work career until his death in 2001. Proud mother of Marilyn Katz (Daniel), Joan Penrod, (Steven), Susan Dobrof and Judith Dobrof (Frank Young). Cherished grandchildren, Julie Katz, Rachel Penrod-Martin (Ben), Lauren Katz and Henry Young. Memorial service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Manhattan, 2pm, October 25. Donations to The Carter Burden Center for the Aging (carterburdencenter.org/giving) or The U. of Pittsburgh School of Social Work (socialwork.pitt.edu/alumni/ ways-give.) 1/3

GROSSBERG--Jonathan, May 8, 1973--October 19, 2015, Beloved son of David and Judy. He is also survived by his brother Adam (Erica), sister Rachel Nash, his nephews and nieces Max and Samantha Grossberg and Taylor, Ethan and Hunter Nash. Services will be today at 12:30pm at Sinai Chapels, 162-05 Horace Harding Expy, Fresh Meadows NY. 1/3

McVERNON--John Joseph. On October 19, 2015. Beloved husband of Sharon (nee Babajko). Devoted cousin of Raymond Sierk, Ronald Holmes, and Dorothy Ray. Served as a Priest in the Diocese of Brooklyn for 43 years. Reposing at Martin A. Gleason Funeral Home, 10-25 150th St., Whitestone, NY. Mass of Christian Burial, Holy Trinity RC Church, Thursday, 9:45am. Interment Mt. St. Mary's Cemetery. Visiting Tuesday, 7-10pm and Wednesday, 2-5pm and 7-10pm. 1/3
FROLICH--Harry H.,died October 18, 2015 at age 97. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. We will all miss you. Funeral at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, New York, NY on October 21 at 11:00am. 1/3

RUSSELL--Allan David. Allan David Russell (David), 91, of Southbury, CT and Queensbury, NY died unexpectedly on October 11th. Husband of Patricia Abernethy Russell and widower of Lois Anne Robinson, who predeceased him in 1997, he was born in Cleveland, Ohio, the son of Allan MacGillivray Russell and Marvel Codling Russell. He attended University School, Phillips Exeter Academy, Yale University, and Yale Law School. Enlisting in the AAF during WWII, he set the world's nonpressurized altitude record of 52,000' at Wright Field on April 4, 1944, and then served with the 7th Air Force on Saipan in the Asiatic-Pacific Theatre from 1942-1946. David spent his professional career as Secretary, Senior Counsel for Sylvania Electronics, Inc., and later as Vice President & Associate General Counsel for its parent GTE Corporation. Challenging what he felt was an anti- competitive and discriminatory piece of anti- trust law, he initiated and tried the Continental Television suit, overturning Schwinn in the United States Supreme Court in 1977. He was a member of the Connecticut, Massachusetts, New York State, and Supreme Court Bars, served on or chaired a number of electronics industry, corporate counsel and corporate secretary associations and was an instructor at Yale Law School in the 1970's. David was a member of the St. Nicholas Society, the Society of Colonial Wars, the Sons of the Revolution, Phi Delta Phi, the Collie Club of America, and Youth Foundation where he was director, secretary, president, and at the time of his death President Emeritus. With his first wife Lois he bred, trained and competed collies in obedience and field trials, and co-founded and was president of the Collie Club of America Foundation. Active in civic affairs, he was a director of the Redding, CT Planning Commission, president of its Ethics Board, and warden of Christ Church, Redding. Sharing the wry wit and keen observations of Redding's most famous humorist, he was president of the Mark Twain Library from 1987-1994. He was president of the Danbury Yale Club for many years, and at the time of his death, president of his Yale Class of 45W. He is survived by his wife, his three children, Lisa Stockman, Robinson Russell, Martha Davis, their spouses, and ten grandchildren. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, October 28th at 1pm at the Church of the Epiphany, 262 Main Street North, Southbury, CT 06488. Contributions in his memory may be made to the Mark Twain Library, 439 Redding Road, West Redding, CT 06896 or to the Yale Class of 1945W Scholarship Fund, Yale University, P.O. Box 2038, New Haven, CT 06521. 1/3
TERRY--John David. 11/5/43 - 10/20/2013 Love and miss you everyday- you were everything to me. Rest In Peace - Your Jackie 1/3

COELHO--Rita Bel Emanuel, passed away peacefully on October 18, 2015, at age 101. Beloved wife of the late David for 74 years. Loving mother of Gary (Jane) and Wendi Levitt (Steven). Cherished grandmother of Cynthia (Marc), Caryn (Paul), Andrew (Amanda), Adam (Cheryl), Daniel (Victoria) and Kenneth (Rachel) and loving "GG" of nine. Services, Wednesday, October 21, 2015 at 12 noon, Riverside Nassau North, 55 North Station Plaza, Great Neck, NY. 1/3

SCHERER--A. George III, died on October 17, 2015 at Albany Medical Center hospital in Albany, NY. Great-great- grandson of famed nineteenth-century painter Francis Bicknell Carpenter, best known for his painting The First Reading of the Emancipation Proclamation of President Lincoln, George had a passion for history and literature. Born in New York City on August 13, 1933, George grew up in Rumson, NJ. The family moved back to New York City and George attended St. Bernard's School. In 1952, he graduated cum laude from St. Paul's School in Concord, NH. At St. Paul's he was co-captain and goaltender of the ice hockey team. George graduated from Yale University in 1956 with a degree in English. At Yale, he joined the ice hockey team as goaltender and broke the record for the highest number of saves in a single game. He still stands atop the Yale career rankings in save percentage (.899). After college, he went on to play with the New York St. Nicks Hockey Club. George worked for many years in the paper and pulp industry, starting in the woods of Maine and later working for Diamond International Corporation. George is survived by his wife, Carlin Whitney Scherer, his son John Carpenter Scherer, and his stepchildren Richard R. Stewart Jr. and Whitney Stewart. Memorial services will be held Saturday, October 24, 2015 at 11am at Brewster & Shea Funeral Service, 34 Park Place, Manchester Center, VT. Interment will follow in the family lot in Dellwood Cemetery. To send the family personal email condolences please visit: www. sheafuneralhomes.com. 1

DOBROF--Rose. Hunter College mourns the loss of Dr. Rose Dobrof, Hunter Professor and founder of the Brookdale Center on Healthy Aging. A nationally- renowned expert in the field of gerontology, Rose made the Brookdale Center a leader in the field. In addition to her invaluable work at Brookdale, Rose served as the Co- Director of the Hunter College/Mount Sinai School of Medicine Geriatric Education Center and as a longtime member of the Brookdale Center Council of Advisors. Rose's tireless efforts on behalf of older adults serves as an inspiration to us all. Our sincerest condolences to her daughters Marilyn, Joan, Susan and Judy, and her entire family. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College; Suzanne Santry, Chair, Brookdale Center Council of Advisors 1/3

ZERILLI-MARIMO-- Mariuccia. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the death of Baroness Mariuccia Zerilli-Marimo. A member of the Director's Roundtable since 1999, she became a Trustee in 2003 and Life Trustee in 2008. Passionate about culture, music, and the arts, the Baroness was a generous and supportive Trustee. Warm, enthusiastic, and overflowing with good cheer, she added much to meetings and social events here. She will be greatly missed. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. Colin B. Bailey, Dir. 1/3

USDAN--Nathaniel "Duke", passed away peacefully at age 88 on October 20, after a brief illness. Predeceased by his wife, Suzanne Usdan, of 49 years, he is survived by his loving wife, Tara, his children Esme Usdan and James Snyder, Adam Usdan and Andrea Pollack and John Usdan and Eva Colin Usdan. He is also survived by six grandchildren, Andrew Snyder, Hanna and Matthew Usdan, and Sam, Simon and Joshua Usdan. The first thing you noticed upon meeting Duke was the twinkle in his eye. A popular guy with a great sense of humor who loved to tell stories and laugh at his own jokes, he had many devoted friends, from his employees at Heller and Usdan Paper, to his bridge buddies, to his golf partners. An ardent golfer, he was club champion at Quaker Ridge Golf Club four times. He was also devoted to Park Avenue Synagogue, where he served as chairman of the board, and to UJA, where he was a past member of the distribution committee. He loved to travel, read American history and eat good food. His kind demeanor, singular sense of humor and his joyful presence will be sorely missed. Funeral services are private. Shiva will be held on Thursday, October 22 from 5-9 and on Friday, October, 23 from 2-5 at Duke and Tara's home - 770 Park Avenue Apt. 14B. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Park Avenue Synagogue. 1/3
DOBROF--Rose. Beloved mentor, colleague and friend. You will never be forgotten. Nora O'Brien-Suric, Margaret H Reiff, Eliza Winans Rossman, Danylle Rudin, Renee Solomon 1/3

WIENER--Gertrude "Trudy", passed away peacefully on October 19th, 2015 surrounded by her loved ones. She was the beloved wife of the late Stanley B. Wiener, a loving mother and cherished grandmother. She is survived by her two children, Gwen Eide and Stacey Cohen, her son- in-law, Robert J. Eide and her three grandchildren Maxwell S. Cohen, Genny S. Eide and Isabel H. Eide. We love you and miss you Boopie! Services will be held at "The Riverside Memorial Chapel" located at 180 W76th Street at 11:15am on Wednesday October 21,2015. Burial to follow at Beth David Cemetery in Elmont, NY. 1/3

FRIEDLAND--Stuart Murray, of Hewlett, New York, died on October 17, 2015, after a short illness and a long life. He passed away two weeks short of his 86th birthday. He is survived by his wife of 61 years, Rhoda Friedland. His children, Edward and Lisa Friedland and Michael and Lauri Friedland, his grandchildren, Adam, Peter, Andy, Matthew and Will, and his brother and sister-in-law, Richard and Joyce Friedland, mourn his passing. Stu was born in the Bronx, and lived nearly his entire life in the Five Towns. He was a fixture in several communities, including his spiritual home at Congregation Sons of Israel in Woodmere, NY and St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, NY, where he was a committed employee and volunteer for many years. Stu's friends and colleagues remember him as a nice guy. A beloved husband, father, grandfather, brother, uncle and friend, he will be remembered for his devotion to his family, his kindness and his sense of community. He will be sorely missed. 1/3

BARLACH--Ruth, died peacefully at the age of 97 on October 19, 2015 in Bayonne, NJ. Wife of the late Bernard. An avid tennis and Scrabble player into her late 80s. Mother of Sue and Marilyn Dershowitz. Grandmother of four and great grandmother of six. She will be missed. 1/3

DOBROF--Rose Harriet Wiesman, 90, November 11, 1924 - October 17, 2015. Loved by her family and friends who miss her tremendously. Rose was instrumental in the development of gerontological social work. Founding Director, Brookdale Center on Aging and Co-Director of Hunter/Mt. Sinai School of Medicine Geriatric Education Center. Served on many Boards of Directors such as Carter Burden Center for the Aging and New York Foundation. Selected by Mayor Dinkins to serve as Chair of Commission on Aging Services. Appointed by Governor Cuomo to New York State Public Health Council and by President Clinton to 1995 White House Conference on Aging and Federal Council on Aging. Served as inspiration and mentor to many in social work and gerontology. Graduated from University of Colorado, Phi Beta Kappa. MSW from the University of Pittsburgh. Doctorate from Columbia University School of Social Work. Married 53 years to Alfred Dobrof, who had his own distinguished social work career until his death in 2001. Proud mother of Marilyn Katz (Daniel), Joan Penrod, (Steven), Susan Dobrof and Judith Dobrof (Frank Young). Cherished grandchildren, Julie Katz, Rachel Penrod-Martin (Ben), Lauren Katz and Henry Young. Memorial service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, Manhattan, 2pm, October 25. Donations to The Carter Burden Center for the Aging (carterburdencenter.org/giving) or The U. of Pittsburgh School of Social Work (socialwork.pitt.edu/alumni/ ways-give.) 1/3

STUBING--William C. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of The New York Academy of Medicine mourn the passing of our friend, Bill Stubing. His work improved thousands of lives over his many decades of committed support to advance the field of biomedical ethics and his leadership roles in the philanthropy sector. A wonderful colleague, he served with distinction as the Academy's first professional director, laying a strong foundation for the Academy's modern growth and development. We send our deepest condolences to his family and colleagues. 1/3

ZERILLI-MARIMO-Mariuccia The Board of Directors and Advisory Trustees of Friends of FAI mourn the passing of our great friend and patron, Mariuccia Zerilli-Marimo, who leaves a lasting, beautiful and unique legacy through her profound commitment to advancing the appreciation of Italian culture in New York. 1

BANDES--Seymour, died peacefully on October 19th at the age of 98. Seymour was the beloved husband of Lucille. He and Lucille were married in 1949, and she was the love of his life until the day he died. He was the beloved father of Susan, Ron and Ken, and the adored grandfather of Michael, Ian, Daniel, Steven, Ella and Andrew. Seymour was born in the Bronx, attended DeWitt Clinton High School, NYU, and Columbia (where he received an MS) and served as a Captain in the United States Army Air Corps in World War II. He was a founder of the Stevens-Bandes Printing Co. His greatest passions were his family, tennis, gardening, archeology, and travel - including four trips to China. He was a founder of the Long Island Society of the Archeological Institute of America, and its president from 1981 to 1985. In lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to the Society (to donate call Larry Merson at 516-487-2583) or to Amnesty International. Services will be held Thursday at noon at Sunset Chapel, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, New York. 1/3

McCLAIN--Beverly Jean, died September 23, 2015 at age 60. Bev lived large, loved passionately and endured her daunting fate with grace and dignity. She will be forever missed, but her spirit will reside in the hearts of all she touched. Service: Middle Collegiate Church, 112 2nd Ave., NYC, October 24, 3pm. Donations: www.metavivor.com. 1/3

OFFER--Shoshana. Condolences upon the passing of Shoshana Offer in Israel, mother of Koby, Dan and Nadav Offer. May the family be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. The Wilf Family 1/3

VAN HORNE GREENBERG-- Janice, of New York City, died peacefully on October 14 after a long struggle with COPD, in the Central Park West apartment she had shared with her husband, the art critic Clement Greenberg, since 1960. Janice, known widely as Jenny, was born in New York City and raised in the suburb of Rye. After graduating from Bennington College in 1955, she moved to Manhattan, where she soon met and married Clem. After giving birth to their daughter, Sarah Dora, Jenny pursued a career in the theater, acting in a multitude of Off Off Broadway plays and studying at the Actors Studio. In 1974, Jenny co-founded Madison Avenue magazine, for which she also served as editor-in-chief. In the 1980s, Jenny began writing plays. Her work, which included the highly lauded one-act Fine Line, has been seen in many productions in Los Angeles and New York. After Clem's death in 1994, Jenny edited two volumes of his work: "Homemade Esthetics" (a New York Times 1999 Notable Book of the Year); and "The Harold Letters (1928-1943): The making of a young intellectual," based on letters from Clem to his best friend from college. Three years ago, Jenny shared her own life story, publishing a memoir, "A Complicated Marriage: My life with Clement Greenberg". Jenny is survived by her brother, Norden van Horne, beloved daughter, Sarah Greenberg Morse, devoted son-in-law Matthew Morse, and adored granddaughters, Clementine and Roxanna. 1/3

GOLUB--Ina. World Renowned Judaic Artist, passed away on October 20, 2015. Beloved wife of the late Herbert. Dear sister of Myrna Wertheimer. Funeral services will be conducted on Wednesday October 21, 2015 at 1pm at Temple Emanu-El, 756 E. Broad St., Westfield, NJ. Interment at Beth Israel Cemetery, Woodbridge, NJ. Services by Menorah Chapels at Millburn, 2950 Vauxhall Rd., Union, NJ. 1/3
FROLICH--Harry H.,died October 18, 2015 at age 97. Beloved husband, father and grandfather. We will all miss you. Funeral at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, New York, NY on October 21 at 11:00am. 1/3
CORBIN--Frank G.M. The Society of the Silurians notes with sadness the passing of long-time member Frank G.M. Corbin. 1/3

SWICK--Zina. We are very saddened by the news that the mother of our esteemed and dear partner, Dan Swick, passed away yesterday. Only because of the love and devotion that Dan showered upon his Mom 24/7 these past many months was his Mom able to live and enjoy her family for as long as she did. We express our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Dan and his wife, Esther, and to their children, Anlee and Yonina and their husbands, and to all of the other members of Dan's family. Herrick, Feinstein LLP 1/3

WEIS--Robert Freeman, of Sunbury, PA. Born on June 10, 1919, he died on October 19th, 2015 in NYC. Beloved husband, dearest friend and love of Patricia Ross Weis for 57 happy years; dearly loved father of Jennifer Ross Weis Monsky, Colleen Ross Weis, and Jonathan Harry Goldman Ross Weis; proud fatherin-law of John R. Monsky, Martin Laiks, and Analisa Barreto Weis; adoring and lucky grandfather of Harrison Weis Monsky, Annabel Weis Monsky, Gillian Stella Weis Monsky, Caitlin May Weis Monsky, Jacob Ross Barreto Weis, Dayssi Francesca Barreto Weis, and Felix Emanuel Barreto Weis, Allison Weis Laiks and Lara Frances Weis Laiks. He leaves a sister, Ellen Wasserman of Baltimore. Robert's family meant everything to him, and he meant everything to them. There was no one more adored for his enduring support of their endeavors and their own choices. It is hard to express how much he will be missed. Mr. Weis attended Mercersburg Academy and Yale University, class of 1941, following which, he was drafted into the U.S. Army. He was subsequently assigned to the U.S. Army Air Force officer training program, ultimately attaining the rank of captain. A leader in the supermarket industry, Robert started young --packing groceries and delivering them in a little red cart. He learned from his father, Harry Weis, who had founded the chain that he would run. He always remained loyal to his hometown, Sunbury, where Weis Markets is located, and it was his dedication to the company and leadership that preserved more than 18,300 jobs in 165 stores across Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, West Virginia and Maryland. He went to work every day until he was 95 with enthusiasm and high regard for all his associates. Mr. Weis was an active philanthropist. He and his wife have supported a number of major philanthropic projects and causes, including: Bard College, where Mrs. Weis is on the board of trustees; Franklin and Marshall College where they established the Robert F. and Patricia G. Ross Weis Professorship in Judaic Studies and the Weis College House; Susquehanna University, where they helped establish the Blough-Weis Library and the Stella Freeman Weis Cultural Endowment; the Lown Cardiovascular Research Foundation of Boston; the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation; and Sunbury Community Hospital during its non- profit years. Mr. and Mrs. Weis also helped establish the Department of Judaic Studies at Yale University, endowing a professorship for this department. Additionally, they supported the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies at Yale. Mr. Weis was a Sterling Fellow at Yale. After the Chernobyl disaster in 1986, Mr. Weis sponsored a flight of Jewish survivors who emigrated to Israel. Mr. Weis was also a longtime supporter of the United Jewish Appeal (UJA) and was treasurer of UJA's Sunbury chapter for 55 years. Throughout his life, Mr. Weis was a strong supporter of Israel and once accompanied former Israeli Prime Minister, Golda Meir, on a helicopter flight over the Sinai Desert. Mr. Weis was a longtime member of Congregation Beth-El in Sunbury and was the major donor to the construction of the new synagogue. Mr. Weis was generous to many causes and to friends in need. He will always be cherished. Funeral Services, 1:30pm, Wednesday, October 21, at Congregation Beth-El, 249 Arch St. in Sunbury, PA. Shiva, 7pm on Wednesday and 12-9pm on Thursday at the Weis home in Sunbury, PA. Shiva will be held in NYC at the Weis home, 7-9pm Saturday, 12-9pm Sunday and 12-9pm Monday. 1/3

POPPER--Florine, aged 81, of Stamford, CT, passed away at home on Sunday, October 18, 2015 after a six month battle with a rare brain disease. She is survived by her cherished and devoted husband of 57 years, James, her beloved children and their spouses, Jeffrey and Lisa, William and Linda and their adoring grandchildren Jennifer, Daniel, Gregory, Douglas, Michael and Jesse. Florine was a graduate of Hunter College, a former teacher and antique dealer. She was an avid reader and crossword puzzle enthusiast. She will be sorely missed by those who loved her. The family has requested a private funeral service. Donations may be made to the CJD Foundation, New York, NY at www.cjdfoundation.org. 1/3

USDAN--Nathaniel "Duke", passed away peacefully at age 88 on October 20, after a brief illness. Predeceased by his wife, Suzanne Usdan, of 49 years, he is survived by his loving wife, Tara, his children Esme Usdan and James Snyder, Adam Usdan and Andrea Pollack and John Usdan and Eva Colin Usdan. He is also survived by six grandchildren, Andrew Snyder, Hanna and Matthew Usdan, and Sam, Simon and Joshua Usdan. The first thing you noticed upon meeting Duke was the twinkle in his eye. A popular guy with a great sense of humor who loved to tell stories and laugh at his own jokes, he had many devoted friends, from his employees at Heller and Usdan Paper, to his bridge buddies, to his golf partners. An ardent golfer, he was club champion at Quaker Ridge Golf Club four times. He was also devoted to Park Avenue Synagogue, where he served as chairman of the board, and to UJA, where he was a past member of the distribution committee. He loved to travel, read American history and eat good food. His kind demeanor, singular sense of humor and his joyful presence will be sorely missed. Funeral services are private. Shiva will be held on Thursday, October 22 from 5-9 and on Friday, October, 23 from 2-5 at Duke and Tara's home - 770 Park Avenue Apt. 14B. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Park Avenue Synagogue. 1/3

WEIS--Robert Freeman, of Sunbury, PA. Born on June 10, 1919, he died on October 19th, 2015 in NYC. Beloved husband, dearest friend and love of Patricia Ross Weis for 57 happy years; dearly loved father of Jennifer Ross Weis Monsky, Colleen Ross Weis, and Jonathan Harry Goldman Ross Weis; proud fatherin-law of John R. Monsky, Martin Laiks, and Analisa Barreto Weis; adoring and lucky grandfather of Harrison Weis Monsky, Annabel Weis Monsky, Gillian Stella Weis Monsky, Caitlin May Weis Monsky, Jacob Ross Barreto Weis, Dayssi Francesca Barreto Weis, and Felix Emanuel Barreto Weis, Allison Weis Laiks and Lara Frances Weis Laiks. He leaves a sister, Ellen Wasserman of Baltimore. Robert's family meant everything to him, and he meant everything to them. There was no one more adored for his enduring support of their endeavors and their own choices. It is hard to express how much he will be missed. Mr. Weis attended Mercersburg Academy and Yale University, class of 1941, following which, he was drafted into the U.S. Army. He was subsequently assigned to the U.S. Army Air Force officer training program, ultimately attaining the rank of captain. A leader in the supermarket industry, Robert started young --packing groceries and delivering them in a little red cart. He learned from his father, Harry Weis, who had founded the chain that he would run. He always remained loyal to his hometown, Sunbury, where Weis Markets is located, and it was his dedication to the company and leadership that preserved more than 18,300 jobs in 165 stores across Pennsylvania, New Jersey, New York, West Virginia and Maryland. He went to work every day until he was 95 with enthusiasm and high regard for all his associates. Mr. Weis was an active philanthropist. He and his wife have supported a number of major philanthropic projects and causes, including: Bard College, where Mrs. Weis is on the board of trustees; Franklin and Marshall College where they established the Robert F. and Patricia G. Ross Weis Professorship in Judaic Studies and the Weis College House; Susquehanna University, where they helped establish the Blough-Weis Library and the Stella Freeman Weis Cultural Endowment; the Lown Cardiovascular Research Foundation of Boston; the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation; and Sunbury Community Hospital during its non- profit years. Mr. and Mrs. Weis also helped establish the Department of Judaic Studies at Yale University, endowing a professorship for this department. Additionally, they supported the Fortunoff Video Archive for Holocaust Testimonies at Yale. Mr. Weis was a Sterling Fellow at Yale. After the Chernobyl disaster in 1986, Mr. Weis sponsored a flight of Jewish survivors who emigrated to Israel. Mr. Weis was also a longtime supporter of the United Jewish Appeal (UJA) and was treasurer of UJA's Sunbury chapter for 55 years. Throughout his life, Mr. Weis was a strong supporter of Israel and once accompanied former Israeli Prime Minister, Golda Meir, on a helicopter flight over the Sinai Desert. Mr. Weis was a longtime member of Congregation Beth-El in Sunbury and was the major donor to the construction of the new synagogue. Mr. Weis was generous to many causes and to friends in need. He will always be cherished. Funeral Services, 1:30pm, Wednesday, October 21, at Congregation Beth-El, 249 Arch St. in Sunbury, PA. Shiva, 7pm on Wednesday and 12-9pm on Thursday at the Weis home in Sunbury, PA. Shiva will be held in NYC at the Weis home, 7-9pm Saturday, 12-9pm Sunday and 12-9pm Monday. 1/3

ROCHE--Dr. Jeffrey C. Born in Manhattan in 1950, Dr. Roche passed peacefully at home in Maryland on October 19th. A lifelong learner, he attended Regis High School, Boston College (Physics, BS (Phi Beta Kappa), MS) and Johns Hopkins (MD, MPH). As a board-certified pathologist for 35 years, he managed laboratories, worked in public health and led research on genetic testing efficacy for Medicare. A devoted father, son and brother, he is survived by family members Ellen, Anne, Mary Ellen and Maureen Roche and Bernard and Andrew Bouchard. 1/3
TICHNER--Alan. 3/2/1927-10/22/2003 Forever your Gloria. 1/3

PRAGER--Buddy. My dearest Bud, 3 years without you is an eternity. Sorry you were wrong, you don't get used to everything. We all miss you and love you. Your Loving Family, Ron, Renee, Hara & Honey 1/3

POPPER--Florine, aged 81, of Stamford, CT, passed away at home on Sunday, October 18, 2015 after a six month battle with a rare brain disease. She is survived by her cherished and devoted husband of 57 years, James, her beloved children and their spouses, Jeffrey and Lisa, William and Linda and their adoring grandchildren Jennifer, Daniel, Gregory, Douglas, Michael and Jesse. Florine was a graduate of Hunter College, a former teacher and antique dealer. She was an avid reader and crossword puzzle enthusiast. She will be sorely missed by those who loved her. The family has requested a private funeral service. Donations may be made to the CJD Foundation, New York, NY at www.cjdfoundation.org. 1/3

ZERILLI-MARIMO-- Baronessa Mariuccia. The Trustees, Administration, Faculty, Students and Family of La Scuola d'Italia mourn the loss of our long time Trustee, benefactor and friend, Mariuccia Zerilli-Marimo. As the "first lady" of Italian culture and education in New York, as the patron of so many cultural events and institutions and as a great friend to so many over so many years, she will be sorely missed. Her guiding presence factored most meaningfully in the development of La Scuola d'Italia as the singular Italian prep school of its type outside Italy--a dream shared and realized by the Baronessa and her fellow Trustees. Her memory will long endure at La Scuola among its large family and community. May she rest in Heavenly Peace. 1/3

ZERILLI-MARIMO-- Mariuccia. The Trustees, Fellows, and staff of the Morgan Library & Museum mourn the death of Baroness Mariuccia Zerilli-Marimo. A member of the Director's Roundtable since 1999, she became a Trustee in 2003 and Life Trustee in 2008. Passionate about culture, music, and the arts, the Baroness was a generous and supportive Trustee. Warm, enthusiastic, and overflowing with good cheer, she added much to meetings and social events here. She will be greatly missed. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, Pres. Colin B. Bailey, Dir. 1/3
ANTHONY--Telly. Beloved and adored, always. Sari, David, and Jessie 1/3
GORDON--Larry. Gone 55 years. A life too sweet and too short. Mommy 1/3

WEIS--Robert F. The Bard College community mourns the passing of Robert F. Weis, husband of long-time trustee and devoted alumna Patricia Ross Weis. Their generosity has helped strengthen the Bard education in the liberal arts. We extend our condolences to Mrs. Weis, their children and grandchildren. Charles P. Stevenson Jr., Chair David E. Schwab II '52, Chair Emeritus Leon Botstein, President 1/3

WEISS--Irma Giustino. The Cooper Union community is deeply saddened by the loss of Irma Giustino Weiss, friend, benefactor and alumna of the School of Art at The Cooper Union, class of 1945. A highly determined, passionate and aware individual, Mrs. Weiss broke the glass ceiling for women in media by becoming the first female to be appointed to an all-male creative team at Triangle Publications, where she later helped launch Seventeen magazine, inspiring and empowering teenage girls across America to be independent and self-confident. Lover of fine art, advocate for the underprivileged, traveler, exceptional cook, voracious reader and principled citizen, Mrs. Weiss captivated all with her unmatched sense of style and her encyclopedic mind. Students, faculty, staff, alumni and trustees are grateful for her many contributions to The Cooper Union and for her love and thirst for knowledge. Richard Lincer, Chairman Bill Mea, Acting President Saskia Bos, Dean of Art 1/3

BANDES--Seymour, died peacefully on October 19th at the age of 98. Seymour was the beloved husband of Lucille. He and Lucille were married in 1949, and she was the love of his life until the day he died. He was the beloved father of Susan, Ron and Ken, and the adored grandfather of Michael, Ian, Daniel, Steven, Ella and Andrew. Seymour was born in the Bronx, attended DeWitt Clinton High School, NYU, and Columbia (where he received an MS) and served as a Captain in the United States Army Air Corps in World War II. He was a founder of the Stevens-Bandes Printing Co. His greatest passions were his family, tennis, gardening, archeology, and travel - including four trips to China. He was a founder of the Long Island Society of the Archeological Institute of America, and its president from 1981 to 1985. In lieu of flowers, the family welcomes donations to the Society (to donate call Larry Merson at 516-487-2583) or to Amnesty International. Services will be held Thursday at noon at Sunset Chapel, 1285 Northern Blvd, Manhasset, New York. 1/3

MACKAY--Nancy Webb, died on October 11, at her home in South Portland, Maine. She is survived by her partner of 27 years, Ardis Cameron. A gifted soprano, she studied and traveled throughout Europe in the 1960s. In the 1970s, she worked in New York City as a case worker in family court, then in the 1980s, moved back to Maine. A memorial service will be held on Saturday, November 14 at 11am at the First Congregational Church United Church of Christ, 301 Cottage Rd., South Portland. In the future, Nancy can be found if you take "the second star to the right and then straight on 'til morning." 1/3

SCHNITZER--Hedy We mourn the passing of our dear aunt, Hedy Schnitzer, on October 15 at the age of 92. She was laid to rest next to her beloved late husband Bernard on October 18 at Mt Hope Cemetery. She will be deeply missed and forever in our hearts. Lloyd, Alex and Evan Lowy, Susan Elbe, David, Andrew and Jacob Lowy 1

WEINSHEL--Marcia L.,of Danbury, CT, formerly of Yonkers NY, passed away on October 17, 2015, at the age of 86. She suffered a traumatic brain injury seven years ago, which left her diminished, but her spirit remained intact. Marcia was born in Brooklyn, NY on August 21, 1929, to the late Saul and Rose Stambler. She married Noah Weinshel, at the young age of 18, and raised three children while continuing her education. She graduated from Hunter College, and then pursued a Master's degree in Education from NYU. She had a varied career starting out as an artist, designing neck ties, then as a special education teacher and, eventually, with Noah, in his accounting office. She was brilliant and insightful, a lover of opera, travel, crossword puzzles, and cats. Marcia relished her role as a mother and a grandmother. She and Noah made charitable contributions to several causes through the Stiefel Foundation, which was donated to them by loyal clients. The Weinshel children continue to donate through the foundation, to carry on their traditions. Marcia is survived by her younger brother Stephen Stambler (Mimi), of Bradenton FL; her three children - Elizabeth (Joel) of Riverdale NY, David of Danbury CT, Sarah (Preston) and grandchildren Adam and Nina Lurie of Scarsdale NY, and several nieces, nephews and friends. She was predeceased by her beloved husband Noah and her "third daughter," daughter-in-law, Gloria Weinshel. A graveside ceremony open to friends and family will be held at Sharon Gardens in Valhalla on Sunday, October 25, 2015 at 9:30am. A reception will follow at Sarah and Preston's home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Metropolitan Opera House, the Dr. Joseph B. and Lillian Stiefel Foundation, or a charity of one's choice. 1/3

LIPSKAR--Carol Margolis formerly of New Rochelle, NY, died peacefully on October 20, 2015 at age 71. She was a light in every life she touched and will be missed by the friends and family she leaves behind. Beloved wife of the late Chaim Lipskar, devoted mother to her two sons, Simon and Aaron. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National MS Society. 1/3
FRIEDLAND--Stuart M. Stuart was a good man and a mensch. Frank & Lillian Hollander 1/3

KORNFELD--Evelyn, age 82. Survived by her loving sons Adam (Margo) and Neil (Jillian). Proud grandmother of Zachary, Stephanie, Melissa and Andrew. Your love and beautiful smile will be in our hearts forever. Memorial service at "The Riverside" at Amsterdam and 76th St., Thursday, October 22nd, 5pm. 1/3
PERRY--Edward. June 27, 1908-October 22, 1993 Dear Edward, your spirit is always with me. Your presence is greatly missed. Much Love, Fito 1/3

TIZZIO--Thomas R.,77, of Middletown, NJ, lost his courageous battle to cancer at his home, surrounded by his family and loved ones on October 20, 2015. Thomas is survived by his loving MaryAnn of 53 wonderful years; sons, Anthony, Vincent, Thomas and daughter- in-law Victoria; and his loving seven grandchildren, Christopher, Abigail, Isabella, Julia, Noah, Liana and Olivia. Thomas was a loving father, husband, grandfather and friend. Thomas was a gentleman and had a loving personality that inspired hope, love, and friendship. Thomas enjoyed a long and successful career at AIG. His passions included his love of reading, walking and most of all, being a grandfather. Thomas will be tremendously missed by all who knew him. Thomas will be reposing at the Evergreen Memorial Funeral Home 1735 Route 35, Middletown, NJ 07748 on Thursday, October 22, 2015 from 7-9pm and Friday, October 23, 2015 from 2- 4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will take place Saturday morning, October 24, 2015 at 9:15am at St. Mary's Chapel, 26 Leonardville Road, Middletown, NJ 07748. Interment to follow at Fairview cemetery. 1/3
WEISS--Fred, died October 20, 2015, at age 86. Beloved husband of Carol, adored father of Sydney (Susan) and Emily, loving grandfather to Hunter and Stephanie Wasserman. He will be missed. 1/3

FESINSTINE--Stanley B.,71, of Port Richey, FL, died October 17, 2015. Survivors: wife, Edith; children, Lori, Vincent, Jack, Robin, and Michael; 15 grandchildren; nine great- grandchildren; five siblings. Dobies Funeral Home New Port Richey, FL 727-841-7555. 1/3

FERGUSON--William C. Retired Chairman and CEO of NYNEX (now Verizon), died October 14, 2015, in Jupiter, Florida. He was 84. From 1989 until his retirement in 1995, Mr. Ferguson led the transformation of the company for the newly competitive communications era, expanding its wireless footprint, diversifying into international markets and advocating for reform of the nation's telecommunications policies. Over a Bell System career spanning more than four decades, he also held leadership positions at Michigan Bell and served as president of New York Telephone from 1983 to 1987. In addition, he was active on several corporate and charitable boards. Born in Detroit, Michigan, Mr. Ferguson attended Albion College, where he earned a B.A. in Liberal Arts in 1952. Bill tirelessly gave back to Albion throughout his lifetime as a parent, donor, professor, board chair and acting president. Mr. Ferguson is survived by his wife of 63 years, Joyce Ferguson; his three daughters, Laura Ferguson, Ellen Keleman (Robert), and Joanne Gerrish (Shep); seven grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Albion College in his name at www.albion.edu/giving. 1/3

POLIO--John, MD, 62, of West Simsbury, CT, died Wednesday, October 21, 2015. Dr. Polio was a gastroenterologist; Connecticut Gastroenterology Association, Hartford, CT; a Transplant Hepatologist - Yale University Liver Transplant Unit; Clinical Professor of Medicine - University of Connecticut. Graduated College of the Holy Cross; Boston University School of Medicine; resident at Strong Memorial Hospital, fellow at Yale University School of Medicine; Senior Attending Staff within the Department of Medicine at Saint Francis Hospital; authored over 50 medical publications and abstracts; won numerous awards including the American Liver Foundation's "Distinguished Achievement Award," Saint Francis Hospital's "Distinguished Physician Award," "Thomas R. Preston Award of Excellence in Teaching," and UCONN Gastroenterology-Hepatology Fellows' "Outstanding Teacher Award." Visit www. vincentfuneralhome.com for service information. 1/3

SCHNITZER--Hedy We mourn the passing of our dear aunt, Hedy Schnitzer, on October 15 at the age of 92. She was laid to rest next to her beloved late husband Bernard on October 18 at Mt Hope Cemetery. She will be deeply missed and forever in our hearts. Lloyd, Alex and Evan Lowy, Susan Elbe, David, Andrew and Jacob Lowy 1
ROSENBERG--George S. Always in my heart and mind. My greatest sorrow is that you didn't experience the joy of Will, Grayson, Georgia, and Danny. Yours Forever, Nettie 1/3

RUBIN--Cynthia B.,53, Attorney, activist and friend died October 20 of breast cancer. Beloved wife of Peter Finder. Cherished daughter of Lanny and Elizabeth Rubin. Devoted sister of Bradley Rubin and Keith Bogart. Dear niece of Ralph Rubin and Linda Feldman, David and Andrew Bogart. Ms. Rubin was a prominent family law attorney who was well respected by judges and adversaries, and admired by her grateful clients. She was active on many New York State Bar Association committees and was an international monitor for The Truth and Reconciliation Commission amnesty hearings in South Africa in 1998. She was a tireless supporter of many charitable organizations. Past President and board member of the Young Survival Coalition. Board member and past Co-President of the Judges and Lawyers Breast Cancer Alert. Board member of Sanctuary for Families from whose Legal Center she received the 2007 Abely Award for pro bono achievement. In 2015 In honor of her contributions Sanctuary for Families created the Cynthia B. Rubin Matrimonial Fellowship. Cynthia will be remembered for her energy, intelligence, passion, humor, integrity, compassion, optimism, generosity and happiness. If a situation was difficult, she made it better and when things were going great, she made you appreciate it. She was a great friend. Her smile lit up every room. She was the light of the lives of the many who loved her. For her, every occasion, including her own mortality, was one for laughter. It can be said of Cynthia that if more people were like her, our world would be so much happier it would be unrecognizable. Services will be held at 2:00pm Monday, October 26 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. Donations in Cynthia's honor may be made to Sanctuary for Families, PO Box 1406 Wall Street Station, New York, NY 10268, sanctuaryforfamilies.org 1/3

She is survived by her devoted daughters Andrea O'Neill (Tim) and Christina Webers (Frank), by her cherished grandchildren Caroline O'Neill, Frank and Caitlin Webers, April Saxe (Duff), May Burke (Peter), June Hatch (Michael), and nine great-grandchildren; as well as her nieces and nephew. Visiting: Sunday, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at the John J. Fox Funeral Home, 2080 Boston Post Road, Larchmont, NY. Mass: Monday, 10am at Saints John & Paul Church in Larchmont. Interment at Greenwood Union Cemetery in Rye. For full Obit go to: www.JJFFH.com 1/3

SUSSMAN--Martin S.,passed away on October 21. He was 78. Since 1961, Mr. Sussman was a practicing attorney in the State of New York, and a founding member of the law firm Seltzer, Sussman, Haberman & Heitner, LLP. Mr. Sussman was a director of Griffon Corporation (NYSE:GFF) since 1989. With over fifty years experience as a practicing attorney, Mr. Sussman brought a broad insight into various aspects of business law applicable to Griffon. For the past five years, Mr. Sussman served as Griffon's lead independent director. "Marty was not only an esteemed director, he was a great friend, and will be missed by all who knew him," said Griffon Chairman of the Board, Harvey R. Blau. Mr. Sussman graduated from City College with a Bachelor of Business Administration degree with a major in accounting. He obtained his law degree, as well as his Masters Degree (LLM) in taxation for New York University School of Law. Mr. Sussman was a member of the New York State Bar Association as well as a member of the Real Property Trust & Estates Section of the American Bar Association. Mr. Sussman is survived by his loving wife, Sheila; daughters, Lynne and Caryn; and four grandchildren, Zachary, Nicole, Stephanie and Danielle. Services will be held Friday at 10:00am at Gutterman's Chapel, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, New York. 1/3

SUSSMAN--Martin S. It is with profound sorrow that we mourn the loss of our esteemed Founding Partner and extend heartfelt condolences to his loving wife of 56 years, Sheila, and his entire family. Seltzer Sussman Heitner LLP 1/3

DOBROF--Rose Harriet. The Board of Directors, staff and volunteers of the Carter Burden Center for the Aging note with profound sadness the loss of Dr. Rose Dobrof, our distinguished Board Member. Her commitment to helping others and her dedication to the mission of the agency profoundly affected our programs and our growth. Dr. Dobrof helped us see possibilities and develop initiatives that addressed the needs of an ever growing constituency of older adults. We mourn the passing of our colleague, and our dear friend who so compassionately taught us by example that we could make a difference. Our sincerest condolences are extended to her family. Jeffrey A. Weber, Chairman; William J. Dionne, Executive Director 1/3
MOLOF-- Dr. Alan Hartley Died October 22nd 2015 at 86 years old. We will greatly miss you. 1/3

HASSOLD--Rev. William J.,Jr., age 90, died October 16, 2015 in Oviedo, FL of complications from hip surgery. Only son of William J. Hassold Sr. and Johanna Doering, he was born on December 5, 1924 in Chicago, Il. He was a professor at Concordia Lutheran College in Ann Arbor, MI 1963-1975, and earned his Doctorate in Theology from Concordia Seminary, St. Louis in 1971. He married Sarah Ansoph Schalow on June 14, 1982 and served as pastor of various Lutheran Church - Missouri Synod congregations until his retirement from the ministry in 1989. He is survived by Sarah's children John M., Paul G., and Philip R. Schalow, and Louise M. Del Vecchio, and six grandchildren. A memorial service for Will and his wife Sarah Hassold, who died September 28, will be held at Prince of Peace Lutheran Church, Orlando, FL, on Sunday, October 25 at 1pm, followed by a reception. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be made to Lutheran Haven, Oviedo, FL 32765. 1/3

SHERMAN--Randolph S. Kaye Scholer LLP mourns the October 20 passing of our great partner, friend and mentor at the age of 70 after a several year battle with Lymphoma. Randy was a former chair of our Litigation Department and Antitrust Practice Group and ably served clients and the pro bono community for almost 50 years. He worked on a variety of high-profile, precedent-setting cases throughout his career across a variety of industries. Clients and colleagues at the bench and bar all recognized Randy for the highly strategic, brilliant brief writer and tireless perfectionist he was. Continuing the tradition of great lawyers who view the law as a profession, not a job, Randy was a talented and creative litigator and problem solver who contributed to the development of several important areas of the law and provided the underserved with access to justice. In the last year alone, pro bono causes he helped champion include his work in securing a nationwide settlement in one of the largest series of labor trafficking cases in United States history, and still ongoing efforts in conjunction with the Brennan Center for Justice to preserve an independent judiciary in the state of Kansas. As devoted as he was to clients - ever ready to leap to their aid when they needed it - Randy was also a dedicated family man. We express our deep condolences to his wife Joan; his daughters Elissa Brachfeld and Stephanie Sherman Cronan (Chris); grandchildren Maddie and Daryn Brachfeld and Emma, Sophie and Tyler Cronan; sister Caroline Simon (Jeff); and mother Selma. A life richly blessed with family, friends and grounded in the ethos of loyalty, commitment and calling, Randy contributed invaluable leadership and wisdom to everyone in his orbit. He will continue to inspire all who knew him for generations. 1/3

MINTZ--David T.,93, of Scarsdale, NY, died peacefully at home on Monday. Dr. Mintz was a respected physician and a passionate musician. He is survived by his children and grandchildren. Donations in his memory can be made to White Plains Hospital. 1/3

GINSBERG-FELLNER--Dr. Fredda Vita. On October 22, 2015, Dr. Fredda Vita Ginsberg-Fellner, 78, passed away at the Lenox Hill Hospital after suffering from a long, protracted illness. Fredda was a wonderful and brilliant wife and mother, a caring physician and teacher, and a loving grandmother, sister and aunt. Fredda was revered by colleagues and loved by her patients; her overarching goal in her work was to help children with diabetes. She was a trailblazing pioneer for her work on juvenile diabetes and childhood obesity. During her long career, she was twice voted to "The Best Doctors in the United States." (1994 and 1997). She also won the prestigious Alexander Richman award (1995) as well as the Ellenberg Service Award (1992). Retired Professor of Pediatrics and Director, Division of Pediatric Endocrinology, Mount Sinai School of Medicine. Past President, New York Diabetes Association, New York Pediatric Society. Past Chair, Council on Diabetes in Youth, American Diabetes Association, Camp NYDA for children with diabetes. Graduate Bronx High School of Science, 1953, Cornell University, 1957, New York University School of Medicine, 1961, where she was elected to the Honor Society Alpha Omega Alpha. Devoted daughter of the late Nathaniel Ginsberg and Bertha Jagendorf. Beloved wife of Dr. Michael J. Fellner. Loving mother of Jonathan R. Fellner, Esq., of Chevy Chase, MD and Melinda Fellner Bramwit, Esq. (Mark) of Bedminster, New Jersey. Adored and adoring grandmother of Nathaniel H. and Nicholas C Fellner and Harry E., Miles B., and Simon F. Bramwit. Caring sister of Anne G. Mazelis (Jack). Dear aunt of Lorraine M. Flaherty (Brian) and Joan M. Mazelis (Steve Eauclaire). Great-aunt of Shaina, Carissa and Benen Flaherty and Amelia and Sam, Mazelis-EauClaire. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Juvenile Diabetes Research Foundation International, New York City Chapter, 432 Park Avenue South, New York City, 10016, would be appreciated. Services Sunday, 11:30am, at "The Riverside", 76 Street and Amsterdam Ave. 1/3

WEBB--Susan. The Metropolitan Opera mourns the death of Susan Webb, a longtime assistant conductor with the company until her retirement in 2003. We extend our sincerest condolences to her family and friends. Peter Gelb, General Manager James Levine, Music Director 1/3

DAVIES--Debora Ann. Our beloved Debora died on October 22, 2015 at age 60. She is survived by her husband, Howard Weinstein, parents, Gordon and Roberta Davies, sister, Robyn McIntosh, Beverly Schmid, extended family, and wonderful friends. She embraced all of us with her intelligence, creativity, beauty, grace and love. 1/3

RUBIN--Cynthia B.,53, Attorney, activist and friend died October 20 of breast cancer. Beloved wife of Peter Finder. Cherished daughter of Lanny and Elizabeth Rubin. Devoted sister of Bradley Rubin and Keith Bogart. Dear niece of Ralph Rubin and Linda Feldman, David and Andrew Bogart. Ms. Rubin was a prominent family law attorney who was well respected by judges and adversaries, and admired by her grateful clients. She was active on many New York State Bar Association committees and was an international monitor for The Truth and Reconciliation Commission amnesty hearings in South Africa in 1998. She was a tireless supporter of many charitable organizations. Past President and board member of the Young Survival Coalition. Board member and past Co-President of the Judges and Lawyers Breast Cancer Alert. Board member of Sanctuary for Families from whose Legal Center she received the 2007 Abely Award for pro bono achievement. In 2015 In honor of her contributions Sanctuary for Families created the Cynthia B. Rubin Matrimonial Fellowship. Cynthia will be remembered for her energy, intelligence, passion, humor, integrity, compassion, optimism, generosity and happiness. If a situation was difficult, she made it better and when things were going great, she made you appreciate it. She was a great friend. Her smile lit up every room. She was the light of the lives of the many who loved her. For her, every occasion, including her own mortality, was one for laughter. It can be said of Cynthia that if more people were like her, our world would be so much happier it would be unrecognizable. Services will be held at 2:00pm Monday, October 26 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. Donations in Cynthia's honor may be made to Sanctuary for Families, PO Box 1406 Wall Street Station, New York, NY 10268, sanctuaryforfamilies.org 1/3

EMERY--David. Surfer, psychologist, raconteur, father of five, grandfather of 10. My passionate Dad who devoured life and adventure goes to his last big home. He dreamed of peace in the world. I know he has found it. From Kansas to Kilimanjaro he left his print. Richard David Emery 1/3

BERNSTEIN--Marilyn. We mourn the passing on October 22, 2015, at age 88, of our beloved mother, Marilyn (Berman) Bernstein, loving wife of the late Fred Bernstein and mother of Richard, Steven, and the late Linda Ann Bernstein. Her memory will always be a blessing to everyone whose life she touched, and will give us strength and guidance all our lives. Service at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY, 2pm, on Sunday, October 25. The Chapel (718-445-0300) will provide details for graveside service and shivah days and hours. 1/3

WEISSER--Arthur, December 2, 1932, died October 22, 2015. He was the beloved husband of Linda, father to Eric and Stephen, grandfather to six. Services, 10am, October 25, Parkside- Brooklyn. Interment, 1130am, New Montefiore. 1/3

LIPSKAR--Carol Margolis formerly of New Rochelle, NY, died peacefully on October 20, 2015 at age 71. She was a light in every life she touched and will be missed by the friends and family she leaves behind. Beloved wife of the late Chaim Lipskar, devoted mother to her two sons, Simon and Aaron. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the National MS Society. 1/3

COLE--Morrill J.,87, who built Cole, Schotz into one of the most preeminent law firms in New Jersey, died on Friday. Born in Paterson, NJ, Cole graduated from Harvard University and Harvard Law School. He practiced law for 63 years and was a mentor and inspiration to scores of lawyers. Morrill, the husband of Doli Cole and brother of Tom Cole, who both predeceased him, is survived by sister Elizabeth, children Amy and Robert, two grandchildren, Danielle and Adam, and his partner of 13 years, Marlene Kleiner of Grandview, NY. Funeral services Sunday, 1pm at Barnert Temple, 747 Rt. 208 South, Franklin Lakes, NJ. Donations may be made to River-keeper, Inc. 1/3
MOLOF-- Dr. Alan Hartley Died October 22nd 2015 at 86 years old. We will greatly miss you. 1/3

COLE--Morrill. It is with profound sadness that the attorneys and staff of Cole Schotz, P.C. offer our condolences to the family of Morrill J. Cole, who was a founding member and incredibly important person to all of us, a wonderful friend and an extraordinary legal mind. Morrill was a native of Paterson, NJ and attended both Harvard College and Harvard University Law School. Following his graduation from law school, Morrill spent two years on the Harvard Law School faculty teaching programs focused on litigation skills. In 1955, Morrill returned to New Jersey and joined a small five person law firm in Paterson, NJ. He associated with wonderful attorneys and colleagues and was truly one of the founders of what today has become a firm of over 130 attorneys, of which he was so very proud. Morrill was very highly respected by the judiciary and colleagues alike. His professionalism and high ethical standards and the respect he gave to people at all levels was widely admired. He will always be remembered as a man of tremendous moral compass and an exceptional and insightful teacher to so many. Over the years, Morrill worked in a broad variety of civic matters. While in Paterson, NJ, he served as Chairman of the Community Relations Committee of the Paterson Jewish Community Council. He was a founder of the Paterson Task Force for Community Affairs, the local arm of President Johnson's Anti-Poverty Program. He served as Chairman of Paterson's Redevelopment Agency initiating much of the Urban Renewal infrastructure and office and housing construction developed in Paterson in the 1970s. Morrill combined the specialties of corporate and commercial litigation with transactional work and counselling in the conception and formation of businesses. He served as President of the firm for many years. Morrill was honored consistently with peer recognition as an outstanding litigator and attorney. In 1992, Morrill received the prestigious Trial Bar Award for distinguished service to Mr. Cole has been honored consistently with peer recognition as an outstanding litigator. In 1992 he received the Trial Bar Award for Distinguished Service in the Cause of Justice from the Trial Attorneys of New Jersey. In 1995 he was inducted as a Fellow in the American College of Trial Lawyers. In 1998, Mr. Cole was honored by the New Jersey State Bar Association with its Professional Lawyer of the Year Award, on recommendation of the Bergen County Bar Association to the New Jersey Commission on Professionalism in the Law. He was the recipient of the Professional Lawyer of the Year Award 1999 - Bergen County Bar Association, and the Bergen County Bar Foundation Attorney Achievement Award in 2000. More than anything, Morrill was a good man and a good friend. His loss will be felt by us and by so many others whose lives he touched. Morrill Cole's funeral will be held on Sunday, October 25th at 1pm at Barnert Temple, 747 Route 208, Franklin Lakes New Jersey. 1/3

MARKS--Elizabeth A.,wife of Burton for 61 years, mother of David and Rosanne, mother-in-law of Roberta, and, most importantly, nana to Sonia. The bride, a wealth management adviser, and the groom, the head of research for a bond rating agency, were married in a Roman Catholic ceremony.

MEAGHER--Henry Coupe, of Hyde Park, NY and Vero Beach, FL, passed away on Saturday, October 17th. He was 89 years old. Henry was born on December 17, 1925 in Saranac Lake, NY to Florence and Raymond Meagher. He was a husband of 59 years to his loving wife Janice Crimmins Meagher and father to Debbie Stanley, Janice Trojan and Jennifer Convery. Henry served in the Navy during World War II in the South Pacific. He graduated from Williston Academy and then Williams College where he was a member of Chi Psi fraternity and made many life-long friends. Following Williams, he returned to Poughkeepsie, NY where he founded the Mechanical Construction Corporation while attending NYU Business School. Henry married Janice Crimmins in 1956 and they raised their three children in Hyde Park, NY. Henry was an intelligent and hardworking businessman. He had a successful life-long career, diligently building a mechanical contracting company, Mechanical Construction Corporation, with his brother Raymond Meagher. The company played a role in the construction of facilities at Stewart Newburgh Airport, the Culinary Institute of America, Vassar College, and various IBM facilities including their World Headquarters in Armonk, NY. In 1995, the business was sold to Tougher Industries of Albany, NY. He was a member of the Board of Directors of The Poughkeepsie Savings Bank, Standard Gage, and Schatz Federal Bearing. Henry was an accomplished athlete particularly in tennis, squash, golf and skiing After retiring, Henry and Janice spent more time at their John's Island home in Vero Beach, FL. Henry is survived and will be deeply missed by his wife Janice Crimmins Meagher; his brother and sister-in-law Raymond and Bonnie Meagher of Millbrook, NY; children and sons-in-law Debbie and Jon Stanley of Mt. Kisco, NY, Janice and Greg Trojan of LaCanada, CA, and Jennifer and Kevin Convery of Western Springs IL; grandchildren Nicholas and Chris Stanley, Emily and Andrew Trojan, Alex, Tyler and Charlie Convery. His sister and brother-in-law Paul and Jeanne Kane of Cobleskill, NY predeceased him. A Mass of Christian Burial in honor of Henry will be held at 10am on Saturday, October 31, 2015 at Holy Cross Catholic Church in Vero Beach followed by a reception at The John's Island Golf Club. In lieu of flowers, contributions as a memorial may be made to The Alzheimer's and Parkinson Association of Indian River County, 2300 5th Avenue, Suite 150, Vero Beach, Florida 32960 or Williams College. 1/3

MORAN--Miriam K.,of Greenwich, CT, (formerly Darien, CT), died on Thursday, October 22, 2015, at Greenwich Hospital. She was born on December 11, 1932, in Boston, MA, to William and Hilda Kirkwood. She graduated from Trinity College in Washington, D.C. in 1954, and also attended Harvard University. Miriam was a teacher for many years at both the elementary and high school levels and enjoyed working with children of special needs; a true advocate of education. She served on the Board of Directors of India House and New York Medical College and as a trustee of the HealthCare Chaplaincy Network of New York. Miriam was a member of the Weeburn Country Club and Woodway Country Club of Darien; the Blind Brook Country Club of Rye Brook; the New York Yacht Club; the Indian Harbor Yacht Club and Belle Haven Club of Greenwich; India House of New York; The Bath and Tennis Club; Club Colette and The Everglades Club, all of Palm Beach. Miriam enjoyed bridge, golf, boating and travel. She led a highly active social life, continually entertaining friends and relatives and enjoyed being feted by them in turn. Miriam was a devoted mother, wife, and friend. She will be sorely missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. Miriam was predeceased by her husband Thomas Moran and son-in-law, James Livziey. She is survived by her children Suzanne (James) Rodenbush of Cheshire, CT, Walter (Danielle) Schwind of Fairfield, CT, Georgia Livziey of Jefferson, MA, and Scott (Ashley) Schwind of Darien, CT. and seven grandchildren. Her family would like to extend a special note of thanks to her loving and compass-ionate caregivers, especially Yvonne Jones. Funeral services will be privately held. Memorial donations may be made in Miriam Moran's name to the Parkinson's Disease Foundation at: www. pdf.org/en/fund--memdon. 1/3

FERGUSON--William C. Retired Chairman and CEO of NYNEX (now Verizon), died October 14, 2015, in Jupiter, Florida. He was 84. From 1989 until his retirement in 1995, Mr. Ferguson led the transformation of the company for the newly competitive communications era, expanding its wireless footprint, diversifying into international markets and advocating for reform of the nation's telecommunications policies. Over a Bell System career spanning more than four decades, he also held leadership positions at Michigan Bell and served as president of New York Telephone from 1983 to 1987. In addition, he was active on several corporate and charitable boards. Born in Detroit, Michigan, Mr. Ferguson attended Albion College, where he earned a B.A. in Liberal Arts in 1952. Bill tirelessly gave back to Albion throughout his lifetime as a parent, donor, professor, board chair and acting president. Mr. Ferguson is survived by his wife of 63 years, Joyce Ferguson; his three daughters, Laura Ferguson, Ellen Keleman (Robert), and Joanne Gerrish (Shep); seven grandchildren and two great- grandchildren. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Albion College in his name at www.albion.edu/giving. 1/3
